title: A Masterful Exploration of Family, Power, and Corruption
description: The film stands out not only for its meticulous storytelling but also for its artistic craftsmanship. The direction sets a high bar, enveloping viewers in a world that feels simultaneously real and heightened. Notable is a role that adds unexpected layers to a character who might otherwise have been reduced to genre clichés. Beyond being an engaging crime drama, the film probes deeper, exploring unsettling themes such as the corrupting impact of power and the moral compromises often made in the pursuit of success. Its multi-layered narrative and compelling characters make it more than just another mob story; it's a study in human complexities that has earned its place as a pivotal work in the annals of film.

title: The Godfather Part I
description:
Even though I gave this film a three star rating (pretty high for me), I consider it one of the more overrated ever. Reviewers from some newspapers and magazines gave it strong advanced notices, and that got the ball rolling before other media and the public saw it. Plus it had almost an all-star cast headed by Brando, often considered the king of American actors of his generation. Granted Pacino and some of the others were young but most of the cast had some reputation going in.

I know Coppola had not directed much if any but was known as a good writer, especially from "Patton." My gripe with the movie is it is basically an overblown melodrama with a lot of hype and gloss. The cinematography is good but not great. The acting: while a few minor people are good, Brando is terrible, mumbling more than ever with those cotton balls or whatever in his cheeks. Why did he think he had to play it this way? James Caan gives the best performance. And the flick is hackneyed, an old-time gangster one, full of violence and anger and crudeness. It is not film noir. They took the crime genre and Hollywooded it up, trying to make something grandiose. Two gangs pitted against each other, using gages and fifty caliber submachine guns. So what else is new? "Little Caesar" was better.

title: The Godfather
description: Best movies ever in history, I am from Germany and I loved it, My name is Henning Weigand and I have watch this movie 100 time.

title: Its fame outstrips its strength...
description:
This is a very good film, with well drawn and engaging characters. It is also impeccably acted which coupled with Coppola's eye for detail really helps the world feel authentic. The script's biting criticism of American capitalism is well done and subtle. It is perhaps too subtle because people tend to miss it upon first viewing.

Nonetheless, the notion that is the best that Hollywood has to offer is nonsense. While the film is is structured as a punitive plot Michael only get his just dessert is Part 3 of the saga. Morally, this film is incomplete until Michael dies along. I would not go so far as to say this film makes evil look good. But both does it straddle the line between making characters you can relate too and character you like. Vito, especially, is a bit too charismatic.

The film is is actually rather rough in places. The hospital scene has a slapped dash quality to it; the wedding sequence has multiple warts in terms of night for day shooting, continuity, deep focus framing etc. Likewise some of the action (i.e. Sonny's beatdown) is stagy and false. On the whole it is exceedingly well directed but Coppola's inexperience (or studio pressure) shows up in places.

This is a very good film. It is not the transcendent experience I was expecting.

title: A MUST WATCH
description: If you haven't seen this movie and you love Filmmaking... something is wrong.

title: Brando's Portrayal of The Godfather A Masterpiece
description: Marlon Brando, certainly one of the greatest actors of our time was magnificent as The Godfather. No one including Damian Chapa, who I produced "Brando Unauthorized," for could quite portray this actor. This is why I rate "The Godfather a 10. The filming in New York was located in parts of Little Italy, of which had to be approved by the bosses. Paramount at that time reluctantly went along with this project, and in the end results was a box office hit.

title: The Godfather
description:
The Godfather for one thing looks stunning. I strongly disagree with the previous reviewer who said the cinematography was horrid, for me the cinematography was one of the best assets of the film. In some scenes you have cinematography and lighting that is quite dark and mysterious, and then in scenes such as the wedding it is evergreen, autumnal and very picturesque. It is not just the cinematography that makes The Godfather look stunning, the costumes are beautifully tailored, the houses are gorgeous and majestic to look at and even the cars were immaculate.

Superb movie in their time. This movie is good.

title: The world inside the underworld!
description:
The godfather trilogy is an exclusive set of movies that will continue to live with humanity, every generation will see them to say, "Oh that was 10 out of 10." If you watch them you will know that the world that lives inside the underworld is same as the one we live in except that people in underworld are so smart, in fact smartness is the only thing that can keep them there. Don Vito Caroleone's early life shown in part-II is very well done to show the Don in making, how a kid who couldn't even tell his name went on becoming a underworld don who keep most senators, judges and lawyers in his pocket. Meeting of don with the so call five families are among most impressive scenes.

A saga that goes on for 9 continuous hours takes you around various walks in life of Mike (Don's younger son who become Don later), his school days, love life, personal life, family life, business life, political life and religious life. How all of these different roles Mike plays in his life and how intertwined these are.

I enjoyed watching these movies so much, I wish I had seen them much before then I did. Its amazing to see how the Part-III was made 18 years later the part-I was made and everything looks so continuous if watch them together.

I need not say much! The Godfather father trilogy been around for a while and everyone knows that they are great set of movies, its just the matter of when you actually get to see them.

Watch them! Kudos to Francis Ford Coppola! -Vishy

title: Probably one of the Worst movies I've seen
description:
This entire series being a classic, I had to watch it. I regret all of it. It was 12-13 hours of my life that I won't get back.

This movie is horrible. The plot moves slowly, drearily, and almost nothing happens. Audio is shabby, and understanding what is going on, and most crucially: WHY? is incredibly difficult. Keeping track of who is what guy is also difficult, as the names are rarely said; the lighting is poor, making this even worse. I didn't know who was who until the third movie, which I had to force myself to watch.

As a classic, watch it. Doesn't mean you have to like it, but now you can say why you hated it, which is the best part for me.

title: The best film of all time
description: This definitely deserves to be the top film in the IMDb.com 250 best films. It has so many memorable scenes which will live in the memory of those who see this film for ever. Scenes such as the wedding at the beginning, the shooting of the Don, the death of Sonny, Michael outside the hospital and when he's in the restaurant when he kills Sollozzo, the death of Vito in the garden and perhaps the best of all, the eventual hand over when Clamenza kisses Michael's hand and says "Don Corleone".Marlon Brando puts in a career defining performance in his portrayal of Don Vito Corleone. The rest of the cast is equally brilliant with Al Pacino showing that his casting for the role of Michael Corleone was inspired. Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen and James Caan as Sonny Corleone also deserve mention. The Cinematography is sensational as is the direction by Francis Ford Coppola. The film is even followed up by a sequel that all but matches this film in its brilliance. Quite simply the greatest film ever made!

title: It's good...but nowhere near the greatest
description:
I first saw The Godfather around 25 years ago, long before I became a film buff. I thought it was good, not great. When registering on IMDB a decade ago I rated it a 7/10 from memory. Incidentally part II I rated a little higher, an 8/10 due to the engaging flashbacks.

Ten years of being a film buff...I've seen some incredible works in that time (including two Coppolas, namely his Apocalypse Now & Dracula). Curious if The Godfathers are as good as their 9.2/9.0 ratings on here, I purchased the Bluray-Restoration Trilogy and just now watched the 3-hour first movie...only my second watch, and the first time since 25 years or so.

....and my opinion is unchanged! The Godfather is a good film. It's very well made, with tons of neat intelligent scenes and dialogue. Well acted. Fitting music. Decent camera work. But it's also tricky to follow, a few times I wondered who characters were referencing...this isn't a problem I've had with Goodfellas or Sopranos. Michael's relationship drama with his two wives isn't really that compelling, and neither is the paranoid mob war. The motives of the antagonist mobsters don't feel convincing.

A couple of action scenes have dated badly. One scene has Sonny punching clear air but the sound effects are claiming contact. Tho' the death scenes were generally done well and still look good today.

Curiously, there's often no offered subtitles when the characters talk in Italian. Specifically an important restaurant scene is missing this. I later watched an online clip with the translation, and I disagree with Copolla: the subs should've stayed in. Also, the image-quality isn't that impressive for a claimed 4k-mastering restoration. Very deep blacks for indoor scenes, meaning you struggle to differentiate among all those black suits. I guess they were going for a chiaroscuro-style (like Caravaggio famously employed in his paintings), so this gets a pass.

7/10 feels absolutely fair. Yet poll after poll still puts this movie right at the top (or very close) in the all-time rankings.

Citizen Kane is one of those I feel deserves such a reputation. The Godfather...not so much.

Part II next. Let's see if it holds its 8/10 (hopefully improves on it!).

title: I Hated this Movie
description:
I read a while back that "The Godfather" was a favorite book of an author I enjoy. I hence picked up a copy, and was enthralled. I had heard how great the movie was so I watched it, and I was appalled.

I grant you, the movie follows the book closely, but it doesn't understand what makes the book work. Most of the actors know what to do, and Al Pacino is perfect, but Marlon Brando is clueless. Vito Corleone is NOT a thinly veiled thug. He is a caring man, who is forced to do some horrible things. But in the end he accomplishes far more good than evil. This only makes Micheal's transformation in the book more horrible, because the deaths he commits serve no such higher purpose.

Also, scenes of great importance are removed, Johnny Fontane is barely in it, Santino's girlfriend has a cameo, and the Doctor is nowhere to be found. I know these character's don't directly effect the plot, but they give it an emotional foundation to build upon. I cared about them more than any of the other characters. I know Coppola had to cut the book down for time to do a movie, but he would have been better off doing a mini-series instead.

title: PIECE OF ART
description:
Review of "The Godfather"

Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather," released in 1972, is a cinematic masterpiece that has secured its place as one of the greatest films ever made. Based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, this epic crime drama captivates audiences with its powerful storytelling, memorable characters, and profound exploration of power, family, and morality within the Mafia underworld of 1940s and 50s America.

At the heart of "The Godfather" is the Corleone crime family, led by the iconic Don Vito Corleone, played flawlessly by Marlon Brando. Brando's portrayal of the aging patriarch is nothing short of legendary, capturing both the ruthless determination and tender familial love that define the character. His raspy voice and imposing presence command every scene he is in, making Don Vito a figure of both fear and admiration.

Al Pacino delivers a career-defining performance as Michael Corleone, the youngest son who initially wants nothing to do with his family's criminal enterprises. Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader is portrayed with subtle intensity, showcasing his character's moral descent as he becomes increasingly embroiled in the world of organized crime.

The supporting cast is equally exceptional, with James Caan as the hotheaded Sonny Corleone, Robert Duvall as the pragmatic Tom Hagen, and Diane Keaton as Michael's innocent wife, Kay Adams. Each actor brings depth and complexity to their roles, adding layers to the intricate web of relationships and betrayals that drive the narrative forward.

Coppola's direction is masterful, employing a deliberate pace that allows the characters and their motivations to unfold naturally. The film's cinematography, by Gordon Willis, is striking, using shadow and light to heighten the drama and emphasize the moral ambiguity of the characters' actions. The score, composed by Nino Rota, is hauntingly beautiful, underscoring the film's emotional weight and dramatic tension.

title: 8.1/10 - A Tragedy, Soaked with Shadows
description:
I'm super close to finishing the IMDb top 100 poster now, and I'm so, so hyped for that. It's been three and a half years since I've started, and getting so close to the top is unreal. Now, in my journey throughout this poster, I've came across all sorts of movies, expectations-wise: movies that I've heard little to nothing about beforehand, movies that have already been on my watchlist when I got the poster, movies I've seen but many years back, movies that are only there because people from a specific country love them (I'm looking at you, India). The thing I'm getting at is this: my expectations from movies are varied and very individual to each movie, and they are influenced by a lot of things. The Godfather is one of the movies I've been hearing about for years now, knowing how immensely impactful it is on cinema. Friends, fellow film lovers, one of my sisters - everyone just kept telling me I HAVE to watch it, a feeling that has only gotten stronger after watching Apocalypse Now - a great war movie by the same director - but me going from bottom to top on this poster meant not getting to watch this one for years, and I knew that when I started this whole journey. Now I'm here, though, after my rewatch to this film. Let's get into it.

The Godfather is a 1972 film by Francis Ford Coppola, based on Mario Puzo's book by the same name. The movie follows the Corleone family, an Italian mafia family in 1940's New York. The movie tells their story throughout a decade or so, with special focus on Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), the least involved in the family business of all the men of the family, and the way he gets pulled into the conflict - and the family business - when things go awry, and a bloody war starts with another big mafia family.

The first thing to catch my attention here is the cinematography. Many a film nerd have talked about how each shot here is soaked with shadows, and how the inner mafia world contrasts with the innocent, well-lit exterior in scenes like the famous wedding in the first act. They have crowned the cinematographer, Gordon Willis, as "prince of darkness", and analyzed each scene down to the last frame. Honestly, though? This is just, simply put, one the best-looking movie I've watched in quite a while, easily. It's not just the lighting - it's the composition, the attention to the background, the color grading. I think about a beautifully shot scene at a funeral, with flowers in the background, I recall another in a little garden where oranges grow, and so many more pop to mind. Even supposedly simple shots, with just one or two characters and very simplistic background, can become hellish, desperate, soaked in grief of sorts. The movie really does a great job on that front.

The dialogue is very iconic, too, with many lines popping up when looking back at the movie. It's not just about being quotable, referenced endlessly and everywhere - it's about the film's ability to make dramatic impact. When looking at today's mainstream cinema (and cinema in general, throughout history, though I do feel like in recent years it's been more of a phenomenon), so many movies are trying to pull off badass moments of dialogue, to be cool, to ingrain a moment into our brains, but when they have nothing up their sleeve it just makes everything cringy, tryhard, stiff (side note: you're more than welcome to read my latest film review, for The Dark Knight Rises, an example to such a movie). The Godfather manages to pull off so many great lines of dialogue with a lot of dramatic impact, and almost effortlessly at that - much of that thanks to actors such as Al Pacino and Marlon Brando, who deliver very good, natural performances here. Showing these underworld interactions in a movie and making it believable, well-written enough to not break the immersion - well, that takes some skill, and the people who were working on this movie definitely had it, and it shows.

In movies, and generally media, of this sort - you know, crime-centered stories that depict characters who get sucked into the underworld - the world of crime often seems alluring, luxurious, brimming with wealth. Even safer than the "ordinary" world, at times. But sooner or later it is revealed, in many of these stories, that the characters have been dancing on thin, thin ice for this whole time, and their bloody dance can make them fall right into cold, hellish depths just like that, swallowed by their greed and the violence of the underworld. The way that even in their happiest days they need to look over their shoulder, the tension between this deep, familial, loving bonds, that mix in the so-called "business" so much that it's hard to understand if the family is the goal and the crime is the means, or if it's vice versa - there's something very tragic about it all. I think that the movie captures this very well. We care for the characters, and when they fall into the dark pits of the underworld it has an impact, especially when we know that things could've been so much simpler had they chosen another path. And besides, just the tragedy of being born into it, being connected to evil acts by blood, knowing you could never escape your name, creates this dark feeling of determinism, dark fate. Works well.

Pretty much every male character here behaves like douchebags at least in some instances - violence, self-importance, misogyny, you know the drill. It's easy to notice that these characters act in ways that are not only illegal, but are also often immoral, or at least morally problematic. Despite that, we also get to see their more caring side, the bonds they have with each other, the love and respect they have for Vito. I feel like we're shown different facets in ways that really make the main characters feel more human, even though they're knee-deep in the crime world. And kudos to the actors, again, for delivering characters with complexities in a convincing, immersive way, especially Brando as Vito, who steals the focus of the plot even when he's off-screen. My point being: the characters here are written in a way that reveals both their humanity and their darker sides, which makes us relate to them just enough to be emotionally invested, and emphasizes the tension between those two sides. I like the movie's approach to that.

The pacing is also solid, which is not to be taken for granted - pacing can be a challenging thing to manage with movies of this sort, that let their plot unfold throughout a decade or so, and a pretty long runtime, too. With The Godfather there's almost always something interesting going on, some tension, this pulling sensation that makes me want to discover more. I wouldn't say that this movie has kept me at the edge of my seat constantly, but I would say that the pacing here is indeed solid, especially in the final act. This movie is a bit of a slow burn, in some ways, but it's always in escalation, always raising the stakes and making the characters change. I will also say here that the soundtrack is very solid as well - it just works well when it comes to creating an atmosphere, and it's used pretty well. It's not my favorite soundtrack ever by any means, but it's recognizable, echoing the tragic themes this movie is focusing on, and it usually hits the spot.

The Godfather is a tragic portrayal of a crime family who's getting sucked into a bloody war, where no one can stay uninvolved, no family member can step aside and let everything drift away. It's the best-looking film I've seen in quite a while, and it shows characters from every angle, the loving and caring one as well as the harsh, violent, ruthless one. A rise and a fall, a fall and a rise - no stability can be expected when living on the thin ice. The tension between business and family here, and the alluring luxury of the underworld, made me think of Breaking Bad, which, though maybe anachronistic, is a big compliment when it comes from me. I'm feeling an 8.1/10 on this one. A very good movie indeed.

title: Best movie
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is more than just a film-it is a cinematic masterpiece that has stood the test of time. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the movie explores themes of power, loyalty, and family in the world of organized crime.

At the heart of the story is the Corleone family, led by the aging patriarch Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando in an iconic performance). His reluctant son, Michael (Al Pacino), undergoes a compelling transformation from a war hero uninterested in the family business to a ruthless mafia leader. This character arc is one of the most fascinating in film history, brilliantly portrayed by Pacino.

The film is a masterclass in storytelling, cinematography, and character development. Coppola's direction, combined with Nino Rota's haunting score and Gordon Willis' moody cinematography, creates an immersive experience. Every scene is meticulously crafted, from the chilling opening sequence to the gripping finale.

What makes The Godfather exceptional is its balance between crime drama and a deeply personal family saga. The film humanizes its characters while never glorifying their violent world. With standout performances, memorable dialogue, and a powerful narrative, The Godfather remains one of the greatest films ever made.

title: A True Classic
description: Hands down, The Godfather is the best picture ever made, in my opinion. The Godfather II is also a great film, and so is Citizen Kane. Hollywood, in its heyday, made some incredibly classic films, which makes it rather difficult to choose which ones are best. I have chosen The Godfather. Have watched it many times, and it never fails to keep me interested and entertained.

title: The story of Corleone family
description: I'm not going to waste my time and my words on the plot or the summary of the film, but I'll write about the feelings that I proved watching "the Godfather". This film is a perfect movie and the cast is one of the best ever seen: Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire... The majority of the actors are still appreciated and sought-after. The cinematography is wonderful; the soundtrack is very good (when I hear the trumpet at the real beginning I have the creep). I was really surprised when I read that "the Godfather" won only three Academy Awards: it should have won at least 10 of them. "The Godfather" is one of of the films that will be remembered even many years by now, and it's without doubts one of my favourite movies (with "the Godfather - part II and part III" and "Braveheart"). Don't miss it!

title: An Epic!
description:
There are some movies which cannot be reviewed. We can all have our opinions, but we cannot rate them. These are the movies which go beyond the ratings and awards. The Godfather (1 and 2) is one such movie(s). To give a rating to these two movies would be an insult to its creators and I am not making any attempt to do so. These are two legendary movies, each an epic, a magnum opus for all other 'Don' movies.

Thus, I present here some of my views and scenes from the two movies that touched my heart.

Right movie from the beginning of the movie, the music is haunting. It pulls you towards itself, like the fatal attraction of parvana to the shama. Marlon Brando is characteristic. There has never been another Don in history so charming, honorable and one who is also a true family man. A Don who respects his friends and never forgets a favor.

The transformation of Al Pacino from the distant lad who says "That's my father, Kate, not me" to the emotional son beside his father in the hospital ensuring him "I am with you now" to ultimately the unprecedented words pronounced by him "I am working for my father now" underlines the storyline.

Some of my favorite dialogues by the movie are: "A man who doesn't spend time with his family, can never be a real man." "I never ask for a second favor when I have been refused the first." "Don't tell me you're innocent, because it exhausts my intelligence." "Don't ever take sides with anyone against your family." "Women and children can be careless but not men." The distress look on Brandon's face when he finds out his war hero son is invariably pulled into the underworld business, the silent tears of acknowledgement when he hears the news of his other son's murder and simply says "I want no acts of vengeance" shows that some actors don't need big dialogues to act.

The final stages between father and son are beautifully portrayed. A concerned father advising his son, the last person he thought would be his successor. And the dutiful son consoling his dad that "We'll get there".

The music is not just background score but also underlines the essence of the movie. Attentions to details like the steady flow of water, chirping of the birds, are hard to ignore.

The climax of the movie where he lies with so much conviction to his beloved wife completes the transformation of Al from a civilian to the head of the Corleone family.

title: The Godfather is an insightful sociological study
description: The Godfather is an insightful sociological study of violence, power, honor and obligation, corruption, justice and crime in America. Part I of The Godfather Trilogy centers on the Corleone crime "family" in the boroughs of New York City in the mid 1940s, dominated at first by aging godfather/patriarch "Don" Vito Corleone.

title: GOAT
description: There are many more things that I should talk about this movie but I'll cut short. Cinematography, realism, script, emotions, actings, musics and so many other things make this movie Greatest. And there's an important point. All of these was made in 1972. Can you believe it? It's like invent a flying car. For those years circumstances, this movie is beyond masterpiece.

title: Al Pacino and Marlon Brando
description:
Al Pacino and Marlon Brando Two great artists who played a work that is unique throughout history.

The scenes of mafia gang management in Tous Brando's film, as well as the precise performance of Al Pacino as the young son of the family, who is a military man, are truly unique. Francis Ford Coppola founded a family in the 70s that ruled Hollywood and world cinema for many years. The second part of The Godfather has a more mature content and story than the first part. In my opinion, the exhibited plans from the olden days and Al Pacino's childhood in the village of Corleone are unique. It has been about 50 years (half a century) since the release of this magnificent work of art, and it is still one of the leaders of world cinema.

title: A truly excellent drama about a life of a mafia family
description: Today a very well known movie and for me the best ever. The story is based on the novel -The Godfather- from which the movie obviously got its name and it follows the most part of the story in the novel. The cast is also excellent the stars who play each character fit their role in the movie perfectly. Some parts of the story may become confusing to some audience if they don't pay much attention to the movie, i found the movie more interesting when i watched it the 3rd time because I had missed some tiny details which make this movie so good. The story won't become boring, it keeps you watching the movie all the time because you really want to know what will happen next which is quite rare in many movies. The effects are also done well for the 70's period, they look very realistic. The movie really gives you a good description of that dark period in history in a non boring way.Those who enjoy watching drama will love this movie.

title: Great movie ever
description: Not too much, for me this is the best movie ever seen. It offers business lessons that no one else can teach. I and the ISO Logistics brand have applied and implemented in business extremely effectively.

title: A Story about Family and Murder

This movie is also unmatched in its acting, still being one of the greatest casts ever. On top of all of this there is a great story of someone becoming a family man even though that goes against what he previously thought moral. Micheal Corleone has one of the biggest character arcs of any character ever, he is a totally different man by the end of this movie. The Godfather is a timeless movie and inspired a generation of film.

title: GREAT AND A CLASSIC. BUT PERHAPS OVER-RATED?
description: The Godfather is a great movie and, in a series of three, the quality didn't diminish. The second installment won the Oscar for best picture, and it deserved it. However for those who read the book first, it is all familiar territory. Marlon Brando has only been better in "On the Waterfront" and Al Pacino has never been better, that is saying something. The film is perfect, almost. The book is better than the film and rarely get's mentioned. Emotion is there, but an age old stereotype get's enforced along the way. Everything else is perfect and earns the honour of being a true classic. The problem with the first installment, the second one was somehow better.

title: honestly i didn't like it

As Peter Griffin said i didn't like the movie.... 😂😂😂 totally agree "It insists upon itself" brilliant!!!! I love family guy and also don't get the Godfather.

For me it was a bloated mess of a film, with the storyline often not possible to follow, and other times not worth following at all. I also completely despised Marlon Brandos performance - I know many people will shout loudly for me for saying that, but I honestly thought it was a borderline pantomine performance.

There are some great, iconic moments in the film (the restaurant, toll booth etc...) but for a film this long, they are few and far between.

title: The best movie to be ever done.
description: Grown up watching this, and its a classic that everybody should watch at least once.

title: The Godfather: A Masterpiece of Crime and Family Drama
description:
The Godfather is a classic crime drama film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on the novel by Mario Puzo. It tells the story of the Corleone family, a powerful mafia clan in New York, and their struggle to maintain their power and legacy in the face of changing times and enemies. The film focuses on Michael Corleone (played by Al Pacino), the youngest son of the aging patriarch Don Vito Corleone (played by Marlon Brando), who reluctantly joins the family business after his father is nearly killed by a rival drug lord. Michael's transformation from a war hero to a ruthless mob boss is one of the most compelling and tragic character arcs in cinema history.

The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time, and a masterpiece of storytelling, cinematography, acting, music, and editing. It won three Oscars, including Best Picture, Best Actor for Brando, and Best Adapted Screenplay for Coppola and Puzo12. It was also the highest-grossing film of 1972, and for a time, the highest-grossing film ever made2. It has influenced countless filmmakers and genres, and has spawned two sequels, The Godfather Part II (1974) and The Godfather Part III (1990).

The Godfather is a film that transcends its genre and explores universal themes of family, loyalty, power, corruption, violence, and morality. It is a film that deserves to be watched and rewatched by every movie lover.

title: The film that reaffirmed my love for cinema.
description:
Undoubtedly one of the best movies of all time.

Francis Ford Coppola is not only responsible for this masterpiece, but also for its sophomore release, which is also in my top 10 list of films, along with another classic, Apocalypse Now.

title: Art - a masterpiece of Filmmaking
description:
This Movie was filmed in 1971/2 but set in the 50's. Pulling off a period film with zero technology in such incredible detail is a testament to the director & the production crew.

This is not a fast paced movie, it's genuinely a pice of art that doesn't try impress, but it may well capture you!!

Every aspect of the film is exceptional, there isn't a single poor performance, I can't think of a movie that comes close in terms of 'across the board' acting.

The soundtrack is iconic but fits the film perfectly.

The story line is simply gripping from start to finish.

No Spoilers - but there is an Al Pacino scene that still makes my heart beat faster than any other!!

title: Great Movie
description:
The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola, who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo, based on Puzo's best-selling 1969 novel of the same title. The film stars Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Richard Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte, and Diane Keaton. It is the first installment in The Godfather trilogy, chronicling the Corleone family under patriarch Vito Corleone (Brando) from 1945 to 1955. It focuses on the transformation of his youngest son, Michael Corleone (Pacino), from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss.

Paramount Pictures obtained the rights to the novel for $80,000, before it gained popularity. Studio executives had trouble finding a director; the first few candidates turned down the position before Coppola signed on to direct the film but disagreement followed over casting several characters, in particular, Vito and Michael. Filming took place primarily on location around New York City and in Sicily, and was completed ahead of schedule. The musical score was composed principally by Nino Rota, with additional pieces by Carmine Coppola.

title: One of the five or best films of all time.
description:
I'm unusual in that I

1) read the Mario Puzo novel in it's entirety prior to seeing the original film in the early 1970s

2) I saw the film in first run theatrical release when I was 12 or 13.

3) my initial reaction was comparing the film to the book.

But time went on, and I rewatched this film many times, and I began to see this film, and indeed, the book, in a very different light, the light of the struggle of ethnic immigrants from Southern Europe to make it in an America that was ostensibly equal to all, but in reality discriminated against Jews, Italians, Greeks, Armenians, et al.

Family, Clan, blood feud, take care of your family first, these were themes that resonated with me quite strongly as I rewatched this film.

"A man, to be a man, must have family," says Don Corleone in the powerful opening scene. The ritual of being godparents is powerful in the Catholic & Eastern Christian churches in a way not understood well by American Protestants.

Ostensibly a movie about the Mafia, but really a show about Family, and loyalty to family.

One of my very favorite films.

title: Superior

title: The Godfather I: A Timeless Classic of Power, Family, and Betrayal
description: The Godfather I is a cinematic masterpiece that intricately weaves themes of family, power, and betrayal into a compelling and unforgettable narrative. Marlon Brando's iconic performance as Vito Corleone, coupled with Al Pacino's transformation as Michael Corleone, drives the film's emotional depth and intensity. Francis Ford Coppola's masterful direction, combined with a stellar cast and Nino Rota's haunting score, creates an atmospheric and immersive experience. The film's meticulous attention to detail and exploration of complex moral dilemmas make it a timeless classic and a cornerstone of American cinema.

title: Timeless masterpiece

title: God Father
description:
We know from Gay Talese's book Honor Thy Father that being a professional mobster isn't all sunshine and roses. More often, it's the boredom of stuffy rooms and a bad diet of carry-out food, punctuated by brief, terrible bursts of violence. This is exactly the feel of "The Godfather," which brushes aside the flashy glamour of the traditional gangster picture and gives us what's left: fierce tribal loyalties, deadly little neighborhood quarrels in Brooklyn, and a form of vengeance to match every affront.The movie (based on a script labored over for some time by Puzo and then finally given form, I suspect, by director Francis Ford Coppola) gets the same feel. We tend to identify with Don Corleone's family not because we dig gang wars, but because we have been with them from the beginning, watching them wait for battle while sitting at the kitchen table and eating chow mein out of paper cartons.

"The Godfather" himself is not even the central character in the drama. That position goes to the youngest, brightest son, Michael, who understands the nature of his father's position while revising his old- fashioned ways. The Godfather's role in the family enterprise is described by his name; he stands outside the next generation which will carry on and, hopefully, angle the family into legitimate enterprises.

Those who have read the novel may be surprised to find Michael at the center of the movie, instead of Don Corleone. In fact, this is simply an economical way for Coppola to get at the heart of the Puzo story, which dealt with the transfer of power within the family. Marlon Brando, who plays the Godfather as a shrewd, unbreakable old man, actually has the character lead in the movie; Al Pacino, with a brilliantly developed performance as Michael, is the lead.

But Brando's performance is a skillful throwaway, even though it earned him an Academy Award for best actor. His voice is wheezy and whispery, and his physical movements deliberately lack precision; the effect is of a man so accustomed to power that he no longer needs to remind others. Brando does look the part of old Don Corleone, mostly because of acting and partly because of the makeup, although he seems to have stuffed a little too much cotton into his jowls, making his lower face immobile.

The rest of the actors supply one example after another of inspired casting. Although "The Godfather" is a long, minutely detailed movie of some three hours, there naturally isn't time to go into the backgrounds and identities of such characters as Clemenza, the family lieutenant; Jack Woltz, the movie czar; Luca Brasi, the loyal professional killer; McCluskey, the crooked cop; and the rest. Coppola and producer Al Ruddy skirt this problem with understated typecasting. As the Irish cop, for example, they simply slide in Sterling Hayden and let the character go about his business. Richard Castellano is an unshakable Clemenza. John Marley makes a perfectly hateful Hollywood mogul (and, yes, he still wakes up to find he'll have to cancel his day at the races).

The success of "The Godfather" as a novel was largely due to a series of unforgettable scenes. Puzo is a good storyteller, but no great shakes as a writer. The movie gives almost everything in the novel except the gynecological repair job. It doesn't miss a single killing; it opens with the wedding of Don Corleone's daughter (and attendant upstairs activity); and there are the right number of auto bombs, double crosses, and garrotings.

Coppola has found a style and a visual look for all this material so "The Godfather" becomes something of a rarity: a really good movie squeezed from a bestseller. The decision to shoot everything in period decor (the middle and late 1940s) was crucial; if they'd tried to save money as they originally planned, by bringing everything up-to-date, the movie simply wouldn't have worked. But it's uncannily successful as a period piece, filled with sleek, bulging limousines and postwar fedoras. Coppola and his cinematographer, Gordon Willis, also do some interesting things with the color photography. The earlier scenes have a reddish-brown tint, slightly overexposed and feeling like nothing so much as a 1946 newspaper rotogravure supplement.

Although the movie is three hours long, it absorbs us so effectively it never has to hurry. There is something in the measured passage of time as Don Corleone hands over his reins of power that would have made a shorter, faster moving film unseemly. Even at this length, there are characters in relationships you can't quite understand unless you've read the novel. Or perhaps you can, just by the way the characters look at each other.

title: EPIC MOVIE
description: Still one of the best movies to date, one of my favorite. At this point I can't count how many times I watched this. I'm going to watch this over and over forever lol. Just does not get old. I consider this a time piece.

title: elegantly made mafia masterpiece
description:
I cannot tell you how damn LONG I've been waiting to finally see this movie! It's taken multiple excuse-less years of avoidance for me to finally muster up the time and energy to consume this delight and, now that I've finally seen it, I'm happy to say that it IS indeed a brilliant, powerful, and borderline perfect masterpiece!

I viewed this film in its restored edition on a crisp, beautiful blu-ray disc and, honestly, that's probably the best way to watch this movie. Try and find the most visually pleasing copy of the film you can find and just sit back, relax, and watch! The cinematography is truly gorgeous, and probably some fraction of what makes this film so memorable and beloved to this very day. Every shot is a painting within itself...mundane actions now take on this otherworldly elegance only seen in the finest novels and most stunning works of art. Just staring at this film makes it well worth the three hour length.

The performances are also all spectacular, largely because of how fantastic the cast is. We all know about Marlon Brando's Oscar- winning performance, and how breathtaking that beautiful monologue of his towards the end is, as well as the fine acting efforts done by Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton, and (in a much smaller role) the great Sterling Hayden, not to mention wonderful supporting performances from Abe Vigoda, John Cazale, Richard S. Castellano, and Talia Shire, among plenty others.

Nearly every scene is engaging and gripping, and the three hours are quite quick and the overall film flows like a steady stream of neverending goodness...there isn't much else to say about this one. While I may not think it is "the greatest movie of all time" as some others like to label, it is still a damn good (scratch that, I mean GREAT) one, and must be seen by all!

title: The Godfather
description: The Godfather's discussion of religion looms large, with the boundaries of good and evil blurred by grace, warmth, kindness and family. The godfather upends the conventional wisdom about the gangster. Instead of being a bully, the gangster can be gentle and gentle. The director orchestrates mass assassinations and deftly USES a cross-montage of revenge. When Marlon Brando spoke in the calmest of voices that he would make an offer he could not refuse, the violence of the underworld was maximized and great aesthetic tension was generated.

If you think the public is sophisticated enough to see through this and grasp the real message of the film: mafia = evil, Don Corleone is less evil than the others but is still evil, than guess again.
Beautifully crafted film, definitely a lesson in filmmaking and an inspiration to generations of actors, directors, screenwriters and producers.

title: Just wow

title: Perfect
description:
Yes--this is the great American film. It is a work of art from the vision of a brilliant director who synthesized his amazing knowledge of world cinema with a

completely American persona--mob story, love story, suspense story--and got

together the greatest actors of the time to create a work of such power and

brilliance that it has deservedly taken its place among the great artistic

achievements of all time. Everything came together so perfectly in this film. Seeing it in its opening week in 1972 (at a midnight showing since all of the other times were sold out--unusual at the time), we simply could not believe how the 3 hours flew by so fast. It was a breath-taking experience. It was so

intriguing, so riveting. From the opening wedding scene straight through to that door closing in Diane Keaton's face--we sat there in amazement. And in the

numerous times I've seen the film since--it has retained its punch and its

marvelous power to entertain and engage.

title: being a gang

"The Godfather" is undoubtedly one of the greatest films ever made, and for good reason. Francis Ford Coppola's epic crime drama is a masterclass in storytelling, boasting an impeccable cast, stunning cinematography, and a riveting plot that has captivated audiences for decades.

The film's exploration of the Corleone crime family is both fascinating and gripping, with complex characters who are both ruthless and sympathetic. Coppola's direction is masterful, creating a world that feels both authentic and larger-than-life. The film's score, composed by Nino Rota, is unforgettable, perfectly complementing the action on screen.

title: The Godfather" is a cinematic triumph that continues to be celebrated for its masterful storytelling
description:
"The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that has established itself as one of the greatest films in history. Released in 1972 and directed by Francis Ford Coppola, the movie captivates audiences with its gripping narrative, unforgettable characters, and remarkable performances.

Set in the world of organized crime, "The Godfather" follows the Corleone family, led by patriarch Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) and his sons Michael (Al Pacino), Sonny (James Caan), and Fredo (John Cazale). The film delves into the intricate workings of the mafia, exploring themes of power, family, loyalty, and the consequences of a life surrounded by violence.

What makes "The Godfather" truly exceptional is its ability to create a rich and immersive atmosphere, transporting viewers into the dark underbelly of the mafia. The film beautifully captures the essence of the 1940s and 1950s, with meticulous attention to detail in terms of set design, costumes, and cinematography. The haunting score composed by Nino Rota adds another layer of depth to the storytelling, perfectly complementing the on-screen events.

The performances in "The Godfather" are nothing short of extraordinary. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic portrayal of Vito Corleone, for which he won an Academy Award. Al Pacino, in his breakout role as Michael Corleone, showcases his incredible range as an actor, transforming from an innocent young man to a calculating and ruthless leader. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, all contribute immensely to the film's brilliance.

Beyond its gripping narrative and impeccable performances, "The Godfather" presents a thought-provoking exploration of morality and the corrupting nature of power. It raises profound questions about the choices individuals make and the consequences they face in a world where honor and loyalty hold immense significance.

title: A family tragedy
description: Most filmgoers who rhapsodize over this wonderful film probably place an inordinate stress on the violence and the politics which connect not only one family, but several, in this sprawling tale of post World War II America. With apologies to those of Italian heritage, I think the tragedy of the Corleones is less a matter of ethnicity than their ruination by blood which is set in motion by two evils: greed and a lust for power. The film is one which sets off the family or clan, [the neighborhood as victim] against the larger, unforgiving American society. The characters are wonderfully realized and splendidly acted. They appear as if drawn to life for the first time. The sinister atmosphere of the film, from its great opening sequence to its frightening close, is a nearly three-hours-long treatise on the disintegration of a family. The Corleones are revealed as equal parts melting kindness and merciless vengeance. The Godfather's turning point is Captain McCloskey's unnecessary assault upon Michael. The meanness of the violent act unhinged the human ideal in the Don's young son. From Michael's understandable love and need to protect his helpless father in an unguarded, creepy hospital emerged his irrevocable decision to cast away any desire to become successful in the eyes of legitimate society. The slow, sure gestation of the plan to assassinate both Captain McCloskey and Virgil Solozzo is one of the major rewards for anyone who loves this film. The seamless transition of Michael Corleone from a patriotic, dutiful, obedient son into a cruelly vengeful and malignant weapon is terrifying portrait. The title of the movie applies to both Don Vito and to Don Michael, with the son slowly eroding the warm and loving family, painstaking built by the father, into a loveless, cheerless collection of individuals adrift on a sea of loneliness and treachery.

title: The Godfather" (1972): A Timeless Masterpiece and Its Impact on Life
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is not merely a film; it is an enduring phenomenon in cinematic history. Released in 1972, this epic crime drama offers more than just a glimpse into the life of the mafia; it provides profound insights into the complexities of family, power, and morality that continue to resonate with audiences worldwide.

Profound Narrative and Emotional Depth At its core, "The Godfather" is a poignant exploration of the Corleone family, led by the patriarch Vito Corleone, portrayed by Marlon Brando in a role that stands as one of the greatest in film history. The movie delves deep into the dynamics of loyalty and duty that bind the family. Each character is meticulously crafted, allowing the audience to experience their personal dilemmas and moral conflicts. This portrayal enriches the viewer's understanding of their own familial bonds and the responsibilities that come with them.

title: Great film
description:
They don't make these epic films anymore.

I thought it was a tad too violent. Not my taste.

Perhaps the best thing about The Godfather is that, even though the characters are involved in some questionable activities, they aren't really made out to be bad guys; you keep cheering for the Corleones almost no matter what they do. Some people might use this as criticism but I think it is rather refreshing.

Finally, the film is so well crafted in almost every aspect; the sound (particularly in the scene where Michael Corleone kills Sollozzo and McCluskey but also Nino Rota's score, of course), the cinematography (there are some stunning shots) and the aforementioned acting is all top notch. And yet, I think it falls a bit short of a masterpiece even though I have very few complaints.

title: Overrated

I think this is one of those movies which are "immune" to any kind of critic but maybe that is why it's considered to be one of the greatest movies. No one can say otherwise. But I've seen better. It's not even the fact that it's old and there are some scenes that seem ridiculous since I watched it first time in 2023. Partly it was a good and beautiful movie but not even in the top 10 I've seen.

It was far too long and I know there are people who say "you just can't concentrate" but I beg to differ. There were lots of scenes that were unnecessary long for no reason at all.

Also one of disturbing things was that the characters were just so uninteresting that I was waiting for them to die. Acting was mediocre, mostly just overdramatic yelling which has nothing to do with being a passionate Italian.

Now I have watched it once and that's enough. The other parts of this series can go in the category "I'd rather stare at a wall for three hours".

title: best movie
description:
It is now past 1 PM and I just finished watching Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather". I should probably go to bed. It's late and tomorrow I have to wake up a bit early. But not early enough to postpone writing these lines. Now that I have seen it three times, the opportunity of sharing my thoughts and refreshed insights are too much of a good offer to sit on. So, bear with me.

This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.

But it goes even deeper than that. It all revolves around the Corleone family led by Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He is the most honest of these men, sitting right on the edge. But for people like him, who do not fully embrace this world, it's not easy. He avoids conflict until it is absolutely necessary. He is a man defined by moral principles. There is a scene at the beginning, in which, during his daughter's wedding day, one of his associates, Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana) practices his speech that he is going to give to the Don when he meets him. The scene with these two is funny and almost adorable. I could not help but sympathize both of them only to realize that I am feeling warmth for two mobsters. Not to even mention that Lenny Montana was an actual mob hit-man and that he was actually nervous as he said that line.

The more I watched the more I realized just how incredibly com.

title: Sorry guys, no part 4....ever!

I am sorry t say that the commentary made by francis coppola at the end of part 3 on the DVD editon clearly states that for the last ten years of Mario Puzo's life they discussed a possible part 4 of the godfather, hoping that they could evolve upon the rise the corleone family business, as a whole. I.e.: how they gained political influence among society, how michael grew distant and how the rest of them drew close, and then skip 40-50 years ahead to vincent corleone losing the bussiness that was worked upon so hard to gain, through drugs and loss of all political influence and respect, whilst haunted by the loss of his cousin love, and ironically have one final scene with Michael and vincent before michael died. i.e.: this would be a part 2 narrative.

This was majorly discussed, but time was not on puzo's side to write it, and francis refuses this to be done without puzo.

One might say "How about Scorsese?" but lets face it, this was a coppola/puzo thing. Scorsese would take it off track like any other director, even someone like Speilburg couldn't do it!

It's a crying shame as this seemed like an all time classic to erase the existence of part 3's disaster!

title: Loyalty, Legacy, and the Loss of Soul: Why The Godfather Still Reigns
description:
The Godfather" is not merely a film-it is the cinematic equivalent of scripture. Directed with near-religious precision by Francis Ford Coppola, this 1972 magnum opus transcends its gangster genre trappings to become a sweeping meditation on power, loyalty, identity, and the corruptive gravity of legacy. It is, quite simply, a masterclass in narrative architecture, tonal control, and myth-making.

From a technical standpoint, the film is a symphony of visual and auditory restraint. Gordon Willis' chiaroscuro lighting-earning him the nickname "The Prince of Darkness"-imbues every frame with tension, secrecy, and moral ambiguity. Nino Rota's score doesn't just accompany the film; it mourns it. The editing, the production design, and the blocking are all executed with the discipline of a military operation, serving not spectacle, but mood and meaning.

But beneath the aesthetic lies the soul of the story: The Godfather is a Shakespearean tragedy wearing a tailored suit. Michael Corleone's arc-from reluctant outsider to cold-blooded patriarch-is one of the most chilling transformations in cinema, not because it's forced, but because it feels inevitable. The film dissects the myth of the self-made man, revealing the rot beneath the empire he inherits.

What's prophetic about The Godfather is its portrayal of systemic power as familial, hereditary, and inescapably violent. In a world now run by corporate dynasties, political bloodlines, and algorithmic empires, the Corleone family's quiet handshakes and whispered betrayals feel hauntingly contemporary. The boardrooms have changed, but the rules haven't: loyalty is a currency, weakness is a liability, and the system always wins-unless you become it.

More than 50 years later, The Godfather is still the film that every serious director bows to and every institution secretly fears. It is art that not only entertains, but indicts. It asks: At what point does power stop being protection and become pathology? And how much of your soul must you forfeit to preserve your name?

This is not just cinema-it is legacy, fate, and consequence, distilled into 175 minutes of perfection.

title: Artan Avdiu
description:
Rather than concentrating on everything that is great about The Godfather, a much easier way for me to judge its quality is on what is bad about it. Almost every film has something that I don't like about it, but I can honestly say that I wouldn't change anything about The Godfather. There is nothing weak about it and nothing that stands out as bad. That's why it gets ten out of ten.

This is one of those films that made me wonder why I hadn't seen it earlier. The acting from everyone involved is great, Marlon Brando comes across perfectly as the head of the family, and James Caan and Al Pacino are excellent as his sons. The soundtrack by Nino Rota is also very memorable, bringing back memories of the film every time I hear it. The plot has to be excellent for it to get ten out of ten, and it is, it's far from predictable and the film is the definition of a great epic.

The film is pretty shocking in the way every death occurs almost instantaneously, and as it spans ten years so many different things happen and every minute of it is great entertainment. It's a well- made and entertaining film that is only the first part of a trilogy, but it stands on its own as a wonderful film in its own right. If you haven't seen it, what are you waiting for? This was one acclaimed film that didn't disappoint.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is both intimidating and deeply human, crafting a character whose quiet, composed demeanor belies an undercurrent of ferocity and sagacity.

title: The Family of the 20th Century
description:
From Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola, The Godfather, to me, was the movie of the 20th century. It had the perfect cast, screenplay, story, characters, set design, ect. It deserved every single Oscar that it was nominated for.

The Godfather tells the story of the Corleone family and their life of living in the Mafia territory. It tells how Don Vito (Marlon Brando) struggles to keep up with his business and how he will pass it on to his youngest son Michael (Al Pacino). The movie also tells about the life of Vito's oldest son Sonny (James Caan), the famous Fredo (John Cazele), and Vito's daughter Connie (Talia Shire).

Produced by Mario Puzo (Superman) and directed by Francis Ford Coppola (The Outsiders, Dracula). The Godfather is the greatest movie ever.

Cast includes: Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, John Cazele, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire, Abe Vigoda, Robert Duvall, and Sterling Hayden.

title: One of the Greatest Gangster Movies!
description:
This is one of the best mafia crime movies ever made!

The story is very clearly presented and easy to follow. The soundtrack of the film is Killer and adds immensely to the atmosphere that surrounds the story. The acting is top notch especially by Marlon Brando. He has created a character that is hard to forget and certainly one of the most iconic characters of 20th century cinema. Unique and unforgettable!

My rating isn't a 9 or 10 for the reason that I don't particularly like Al Pacino's character, which to be honest - annoys me. And not a nice annoyance, if you understand me, but more - I feel the character is boring and a bit redundant. In 1-2 places the storyline didn't draw me in as I would have liked.

But overall the film is a masterpiece and I highly recommend it to fans of cinema, the crime genre, the power of the Italian mafia in America at the time, etc.

Final score: 8/10.

description:
The performances are nothing short of extraordinary. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, the patriarch of the Corleone family. Al Pacino shines as Michael Corleone, the reluctant son who is drawn into the family business. His transformation from an innocent outsider to a ruthless leader is both chilling and captivating.

The film's narrative is rich and complex, exploring themes of family loyalty, corruption, and the American Dream. The storytelling is enhanced by the stunning cinematography and the memorable score by Nino Rota. The film's pacing is deliberate and allows the audience to fully immerse themselves in the world of the Corleones.

title: Still at the top of my list
description:
The Godfather was an epic novel, an excellent story, and the movie could have easily been botched on numerous levels; instead, Francis Ford Coppola managed to create an enduring masterpiece of modern cinema. This excellence he achieved in spite of the constant harassment and general incompetence of Paramount Pictures. Coppola was almost fired by the studio several times during the filming of this classic, yet he managed to persevere and realize his vision through to the end. The casting, direction, acting, cinematography, and story are all top notch. Add to it a beautiful score by Nino Rota and you have the #1 IMDb movie of all time. This is a movie I have watched many times and found few weaknesses.

If Paramount had its way, The Godfather would have been much different. In this alternate reality, Coppola would have been fired and replaced with some studio sycophant director. There would be no Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone, since Paramount felt Brando was a troublemaker. Michael would have been played by Ryan O'Neal or Robert Redford since Paramount wanted a "prettier" leading man. Al Pacino, despite superior acting ability, would have probably remained undiscovered. The story would not have taken place in the 40's and 50's, but instead would have been contemporary in order to minimize production costs. To be sure, the ultimate result of Paramount's expediency would have been unmitigated disaster. Thankfully, Coppola fought Paramount throughout the entire production, and much like the Godfather himself, refused to dance on the strings of those Paramount pezzonovante.

If you are a girl like myself you will for certain fall deeply in love with the human, but dangerous young Al Pacino (and he is drop dead gorgeous too!)

A classic!

title: Absolute masterpiece
description:
The Godfather, directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is an absolute masterpiece that continues to stand the test of time as one of the greatest films ever made. Released in 1972, this iconic crime drama offers a compelling narrative, impeccable performances, and a mesmerizing portrayal of power, loyalty, and family dynamics.

The film revolves around the Corleone family, led by the powerful Don Vito Corleone, played flawlessly by Marlon Brando. Brando's portrayal of the patriarch is nothing short of legendary, capturing the essence of a complex character torn between tradition and the evolving world around him. His commanding presence and nuanced performance earned him an Academy Award, and rightfully so.

The Godfather boasts a stellar ensemble cast, with remarkable performances by Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, James Caan as Sonny Corleone, and Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen. Each actor brings their A-game, immersing the audience in a world of crime, power struggles, and the intricate workings of organized crime families.

Coppola's direction is masterful, showcasing his keen eye for detail and his ability to create an immersive cinematic experience. The film's pacing is deliberate, allowing the audience to become fully absorbed in the narrative and the richly developed characters. The script, co-written by Coppola and Mario Puzo, is a work of art, filled with memorable dialogue and profound insights into the human condition.

One cannot discuss The Godfather without mentioning its iconic score, composed by Nino Rota. The haunting melodies perfectly complement the film's atmosphere, adding depth and emotion to pivotal scenes. The combination of visuals, performances, and music creates an unforgettable cinematic experience that lingers long after the credits roll.

The Godfather is not just a gangster film; it is a powerful exploration of family, loyalty, and the corrupting influence of power. It delves into the moral complexities of its characters, forcing viewers to question their own sense of right and wrong. The film's themes and narrative continue to resonate with audiences, cementing its status as a timeless classic.

title: Best movie ever!
description: WOW! As I am yet to see any of the other Godfather movies, this is the best mafia drama I have ever seen and is definitely a top 10 film! The acting in this is outstanding, Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, and James Caan specific. The plot in this movie is the best plot I have ever seen and it is paced so well! title: Just another violent movie...
description: Just another violent gang movie, whats the big deal? I hate these sort of movies about mafia guys going around with guns thinking they are all tough, put them in a ring one on one with Tyson and see how tough they are. I Don't understand why this movie is so praised, Whats the big deal? There is enough violent gang movies around, what makes this one special? There are so many movies better than this one out there, don't waste your time with this. I suppose there must be lots of fans of this movie like there is for lots of other violent pointless ****house movies such as Sin City and the likes, I guess this just highlights that there must be fairly big problems in our society today, why would anyone find this sort of negative and pointless junk enjoyable? The way that this sort of thing is portrayed in movies as being "cool" is really quite sickening, I wonder how many people who have had personal experience with murder and violence would find this sort of thing enjoyable, not many I would say. If you think you are going to get anything worthwhile out of this movie think again, your life will not be enriched in any way by watching this, spend the three hours out enjoying the sunshine or talking to your friends and family or something instead...

title: no. 1 it is not, brilliant it is
description: OH MY GOD!!! I have never watched a film this long before then decided to sit down and watch it again. I've seen plenty this long and although I enjoyed them and watched parts of them again, I have never watched one like this all the way through. Let's take your standard gangster film, either you have the new guy just arrived in town looking for trouble, Joe from 'A fistfull of dollars', or you have the guy looking for revenge, Porter in Payback, or the cop trying to stop them, countless films. THIS IS DIFFERENT!! Sure you might say gangsters have been the guys your rooting for before but no not like this. You start with an established family, and you watch them fall into the ruin and gradually get saved. Brando and Pacino both deserve every award there is for making characters who although are often bad you can still see the old fashioned hero in. Not one bad actor, not one bad character. Not one bad moment. Yet why isn't it no. 1? Well I don't know but it isn't really no. 1 material. Perhaps its the fact you have so much story to take in and so much happens that you aren't sure whats just happened or it could be simple. I could have just expected a no. 1, a film that had me crying, cheering, yelling. I didn't get that but I cant think of one better gangster film, or one other film that deserves to be a classic like this. So perhaps it is a no. 1, for now until a true no. 1 comes along. For those of you who say 'the book was good, not sure if I want to see this', then I'll tell you this. This film is a book. not only is it a book, it's a great book. You cant put it down but when you do you can start anywhere. You can flick back to clarify what has happened, the story is well structured the characters well developed. It's well cut as if it's been edited by a publisher. I don't want to call this no. 1 because when you see it you'll constantly be judging it as a no. 1 film, like I was, and you will feel let down. However if you see it not expecting a no. 1, you will finish it having seen a no. 1.

title: excellent if..
description: An awesome movie if you like italian mafia kind movies.

title: SUCH A GREAT MOVIE
description:
Overall, The Godfather is one of Hollywood's greatest critical and commercial successes that gets everything right; a gangster flick that is overflowing with life, rich with emotion and subtle acting, and further blessed with amazing direction from Francis Ford Coppola.,

Life Lesson: It's your duty to be there for your family, regardless of the circumstances. This will help protect them while you're alive, and leave a meaningful legacy after you're gone.

The film is a good reminder never to make decisions or act out rashly. A good example is when Sonny Corleone (the eldest son of the Godfather, Don Vito Corleone), flies into a rage at hearing his sister having been again subject to domestic abuse.

title: The whole

Ganster films are not my cup of tea but if you have to watch one it should be this one.

That being said, if you don't watch to the end then you don't get the full story/film.

title: As good as its gets
description: This is what movies are all about, a great cast, wonderful performances, intresting characters, stand out scenes,lovely score and a great story all into one. The film may be 3 hours long but the film is always watchable and never boring, and it does not feel like 3 hours long. This is the only film out of the three that the whole family is together, which makes it easily the best.The scenes that stand out are the horses head(of course), sonnys shooting, vitos last breaths,and the five killings at the end. I dont know what it is but the film and the other two are never the same when sonny dies, apart from vito ,sonny is by far the most interesting character of the all the films even more than michael, i only wish he lived a little longer. title: The Gangster epic that nobody can refuse
description: Gangster films have been one the pillars of Hollywood. Since their debut in the 30s of the Golden Age. Classics such as The Public Enemy and White Heat spotlighted the criminal life. Viewed as a true grit crime drama that not only entertained audiences but made one dream of that lifestyle with all the pros and cons. Eventually, mobsters began to faze out in favor of other genres primarily Westerns. In 1972 Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Francis Puzo forever changed how gangsters were depicted with The Godfather. It took organized crime and brought it into a realistic depiction not ever seen before. Based on the Novel by Puzo, The Film follows the lives of the Corleone family led by Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). The Godfather most feared, respected, and powerful Criminal in New York. We follow over the years as Vito gets older and begins to lose power, all while through reluctance his youngest Son Michael (Al Pacino) slowly comes to power as head of the Family. The reason why The Godfather has the status that it does is because of its tone it gave gangsters more of a romanticized sort of Glorifying the Mob. Here you have this family that has all this power and respect. Its cultural impact depicted them as real people as opposed to just cutting out stereotypes. Even though it is a gangster film it is more so about the family than one of the major themes. The way families act. The use of its beautiful soundtrack and the dialogue add more Authentic appeal to Italian culture. The film shook waves with its more realistic dedication Death and the Violence felt more real from being shot to being ridden with bullets. Gives a taste of what life in a family like this was like or could be like. The acting is top-notch from everybody in the from James Caan as Sonny, his attitude very traditional wise guy quicker to anger and aggression. Diane Keaton is sort of the naive love interest. Though the two who make the film the most are Brando & Pacino. Overwhelming development Brando's Godfather is iconic everybody has been inspired by this character. This character has been spoofed and parodied in so many things. Like Carmine the Roman Falcone from Batman. He comes off as a man of honor, while in the context of this film, you don't know anything about him just more so how he's built up. However, the way Brando speaks and how he carries himself you get the idea that this is a powerful man. He honors his family he understands the plights of those who come to him on the wedding day he's not a pushover, but he is fair in a way. The progress that Al Pacino handles well from the beginning he's more innocent out of the family business., but as the movie goes on and the events that occur can kind of see how to ends up where he does it doesn't feel like you question why he goes down this path. How his mannerism changes it's a different person by the end. It's classy, and thematic it's. Groundbreaking if not for The Godfather there wouldn't be gangster media like there is today.

title: good
description:
The Godfather is an unparalleled cinematic masterpiece that stands as a testament to the art of filmmaking. Directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, the film not only redefined the gangster genre but also left an indelible mark on the history of cinema.

At its core, "The Godfather" is a compelling exploration of power, family, and the American Dream. The narrative weaves a complex and intricate tapestry of the Corleone crime family, led by the iconic patriarch, Vito Corleone, portrayed with unparalleled brilliance by Marlon Brando. Brando's performance is a tour de force, bringing gravitas and humanity to a character that transcends the typical portrayal of a mob boss.

The film's pacing is deliberate and masterful, allowing the story to unfold with a sense of inevitability. The cinematography, marked by Gordon Willis's iconic dark and moody visuals, adds a layer of sophistication, creating an atmosphere that is both elegant and foreboding. The use of light and shadow becomes a visual language, conveying the moral complexities and inner conflicts of the characters.

One of the film's greatest strengths lies in its meticulous character development. Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, undergoes a profound transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless and calculating heir to the family empire. The dynamic between Michael and his brothers, played by James Caan and John Cazale, adds depth to the narrative, exploring themes of loyalty and betrayal.

Nino Rota's haunting score further enhances the emotional impact of the film, underscoring key moments with a sense of tragedy and nostalgia. The famous soundtrack has become synonymous with the film itself, contributing to its enduring legacy.

"The Godfather" is a cinematic triumph that transcends its genre. It combines stellar performances, a richly layered narrative, and technical prowess to create a film that not only entertains but also provokes thought. Its influence can be seen in countless works that followed, solidifying its place as a timeless classic. In the realm of cinema, "The Godfather" remains an offer that audiences simply cannot refuse.
