title: The Godfather (1972): A Cinematic Masterpiece with Minor Flaws
description:
"The Godfather" is an unparalleled cinematic masterpiece. I thoroughly enjoyed it and was deeply moved by its intricate storyline and compelling characters. The film boasts outstanding performances from the entire cast, particularly Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, who delivered exceptional performances.

One of the film's strengths is its meticulous storytelling and the personal growth of the character of Michael Corleone. We witness his transformation from a quiet and peace-loving individual to a powerful and ruthless leader. This transformation is portrayed with great precision and complexity, and the story allows ample time to witness the character's development and motivations.

However, there is one criticism I would like to address. Although the story is engaging and filled with intricate details, I sometimes felt that the film was overly long. Certain scenes and subplots were unnecessarily prolonged, affecting the film's pacing and making it feel somewhat lengthy.

Nevertheless, "The Godfather" remains an exceptional film that is unquestionably worth watching. The intricate storyline, memorable characters, and outstanding performances make it a cinematic masterpiece. While there may be some minor flaws, they do not detract from the overall quality of the film.

title: Cagney at his peak would have been proud to be in this one.
description:
The gangster film was pretty much the property of Warner Bros during the 1930's. And rightfully so. With their star line-up of Bogart, Edward G., Muni, Raft, O'Brien and the magisterial Cagney , how could they fail?. Public Enemy, the original Scarface, the Roaring 20's, Little Caesar. Even today these films still have a great raw power no matter how certain elements may be dated. And with White Heat Warner proved they could still come up with a truly great gangster film in the late 40's .

But when The Godfather came along in 1972 it blew away all the opposition.

The hype had really gone into overdrive by the time it reached Ireland in the Summer of 1973. Although it was the film you had to see at the time, for boys of my generation, Marlon Brando was yesterday's man.

Clint Eastwood was our idol, with the spaghetti Westerns and Dirty Harry.

And, to be honest, the wedding scene, the scene with Brando's pottering around in the garden with his grandson, and the scenes of family banter did seem to me, then, to get in the way of the undoubtedly brilliant set-pieces of violence and pad out the film unnecessarily. Seeing the sequel two years later largely helped me to confirm my original view that the original was more a star vehicle to revive Brando's career and I went along with the perceived opinion that the later film was the masterpiece of the series.

Almost 30 years later, having greatly expanded my vocabulary of World Cinema, The Godfather still ranks in my Top 10 of all time,(and I can't see that ranking will ever change) whereas the sequel, while I admire it as a great film, would be some way short.

What marks the film out as particularly special include many of the features that I found boring as a teenager: the family relationships; the jostling for positions in the family and mafia hierarchy, but especially the carefully plotted change in Michael's character. Has Pacino ever been better? Like Jack Nicholson, he was at his best in his early films, before the fame thing went to his head. And Coppola undoubtedly kept his performance and character on a tight rein in contrast to Part 2, where there may just have been a touch of caricature.

The great scenes were masterfully directed: the toll-booth assassination; the various violent deaths, Michael's cafe killings; the shocking church murders, but, overall, its the pacing and development of the film, and Coppola's masterly handling of the actors which will make this one run and run. And I haven't even mentioned Nino Rota's spellbinding music.

Of course Coppola has mostly disappointed since then, (although I will always maintain that Rumble Fish is a minor gem, )one acknowledged masterpiece is more than most directors could even dream about.

Cagney at his peak would have been proud to be in this one. What higher praise can I give it.

title: Well worth the time
description: I find it extremely disheartening that people would complain about the length of "The Godfather." Unlike most movies of the three hour duration, I find that when I view "Godfather," not once do I look at my watch or think about how long it is. And that is simply because it is the closest thing to perfection on film that we have yet to see. Never once do I question it when I see this ranked as the #1 film on various lists. Coppola, despite a shaky career of hits and misses, created a structural story so memorable and unmatched that it must have the three hour length to fully develop into a nuanced story, setting the stage for its successors. And I challenge anyone to find a more memorable screen performance than Marlon Brando. So for those of you who don't like three hour movies, you'd better stick to the 90 minute masterpieces like "Cruel Intentions" and "Gone in 60 Seconds." You'll probably understand them better.

title: A precise and flowing work
description:
Mario Puzo's The Godfather is a landmark of cinema. The three-hour film is the result of an incredibly precise brand of filmmaking. Despite the fact that the story spans a number of years and thousands of miles, there is a clear, very natural progression throughout the film (with the exception of a subplot or two). The characters are complex and varied, each playing a specific role that contributes to the story. The film does admirably well in keeping the story relatively coherent, despite its complexity.

In the film, Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) is the head of a powerful crime family in New York. He arranges killings and is involved in illegal gambling rings, among other things. Yet to those who love him, he is known as a man of reason and justice. He is the Godfather - a title of respect and endearment. Many seek him out for his blessing, his advice  or a favor. Despite the fact that he is, essentially, a murderer, the movie does an excellent job of making the audience respect him; the deaths he arranges are always justified in some manner to the audience. They men killed are either other criminals - usually involved in narcotics and other crimes somewhat worse than the Corleones' - or are corrupt in some way, a danger to "the family" and probably murderers themselves.

Vito's family has a hierarchical power structure. At the top is the first-born, Santino "Sonny" Corleone (James Caan), hot-headed and vengeful, with a lust for power - he is inverse of the collected and methodical Vito. Then there is Fredo (John Cazale), the ambitious but ultimately incompetent son who is more interested in women and booze than the family business. Finally there is Michael (Al Pacino) - the youngest son who is clearly the central character throughout the film.

Michael is a young World War II veteran who wants no part in his father's business. His signature line is "That's my family, Kay it's not me." He respects his father more than any other man, but he wants to live a different line. He is a dynamic, fully-realized character that is absolutely convincing. He is also a very different character at the end of the film - but in a way that is completely consistent with his personality.

The film has an excellent pace. There is an ebb and flow - the film begins rather slowly, then picks up the pace, and rises to the climax of the first act - and then the pace slows once more, only to build up suspense again to a final climax, in which all loose ends are neatly tied. Never is the audience bored - the story keeps a tight grip on the viewer, ensuring that they wonder as to the fates of the characters even in the slowest parts - a remarkable accomplishment in of itself.

The Godfather is a excellent film in every sense of the word - technically, aesthetically, in terms of story and characters, themes and music. It immerses the audience in a completely different - yet perhaps altogether to familiar - world. It is a classic that is - and will be - rooted in film history.

title: Masterful Craftsmanship
description:
As both a director and a screenplay writer, reviewing "The Godfather" from 1972 is an opportunity to delve into one of the most masterfully executed films in cinematic history. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, the film is a sprawling tale of family, power, and the transformations wrought by ambition and loyalty.

From a directorial standpoint, Coppola's vision for "The Godfather" is nothing short of visionary. The meticulous attention to period detail, the use of lighting to convey mood and emotion, and the masterful staging of scenes combine to create a palpable sense of time and place. The opening wedding scene alone is a masterclass in storytelling, introducing a multitude of characters and relationships through seamless interactions that feel both authentic and significant. Coppola's use of close-ups and long takes draws viewers deeper into the world of the Corleone family, creating an intimacy that is both compelling and unsettling.

As a screenplay writer, the narrative structure and character development in "The Godfather" serve as exemplary models. The screenplay, co-written by Coppola and Puzo, is a testament to the power of adaptation, transforming the novel's rich narrative into a tight, focused exploration of Michael Corleone's evolution from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mob boss. The dialogue is iconic, imbued with a weight and realism that resonate long after the film ends. Phrases like "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse" have entered the cultural lexicon, demonstrating the screenplay's impact.

The performances, particularly those of Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone and Al Pacino as Michael, are monumental. Brando's portrayal of the patriarch is nuanced and layered, communicating power and vulnerability in equal measure. Pacino's transformation over the course of the film is riveting, a testament to both the actor's skill and the screenplay's depth.

Moreover, the film's exploration of themes such as the corruption of the American Dream, the complexities of family loyalty, and the moral compromises inherent in the pursuit of power, is handled with nuance and sophistication. It's a narrative that invites reflection and debate, demonstrating the screenplay's depth and the directorial vision's capacity to provoke thought.

In conclusion, as a director and screenplay writer, I view "The Godfather" as a cornerstone of cinematic achievement. Its influence on film narrative, character development, and the craft of movie-making is indelible. It stands not only as a compelling family saga but as a profound commentary on power, morality, and the American psyche. "The Godfather" is a film that endures, its legacy a testament to the genius of its creators.

title: The Godfather
description:
Short and Simple Review by WubsTheFadger

It should be noted that The Godfather was the first gangster/mobster movie I had ever seen. I was 17 years old when I first saw it and it blew me away. Francis Ford Coppola transports you into the world of the Corleone family. He masterfully introduces use the memorable characters and settings that become classics in cinema history. The story is full of twists that you stunned and the flow of the film is elegant and graceful.

The acting is masterful. Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, John Cazale, Diane Keaton, Robert Duvall, and many others all perform perfectly. They all add to story and are all unique. They are some of the best characters in cinema.

The pacing is perfect. Coppola takes his time creating his characters and settings. The runtime is very long but I found it to go by rather quickly because of the interesting and intense story.

Pros: Masterful storytelling, memorable characters, amazing acting, perfect pacing, and a good runtime

Cons: None

Overall Rating: 10

title: Cinematic perfection, why not 10/10?
description:
The Godfather is one of maybe 3 or 4 of those 'perfect movies'. The ones where no matter how many times you watch it, you can't nit-pick anything wrong, unnecessary, even if your life depended on it. It has an amazing story, incredible (and subtle) acting, great cast overall, and it is consistently gripping for the 3-hour run time. There is no trace of any laziness or mistake.

So why shouldn't I give this a perfect rating while we're at it? Well, two reasons mainly.

The first is universal: Despite it's Cinematic perfection, the way I see a perfect movie is if no one hated it. If ANY human being watched this movie from start to finish, they would be on the edge of their seat for 178 minutes (and I mean ANYONE who watched this, not one person left behind). It seems a little like splitting hairs if one person would lean back for a second and no longer calling this movie 'perfect', but when I hear that word, I expect people to mean what they say. And judging from the few hateful reviews I've seen on this one, it just doesn't quite make the cut.

Second, I would be one of those people who happened to sit back for a portion of the movie, mostly after Don Vito came back from the gunshot scene. I was thrilled and angry at the same time, but seeing as how he went on with business as before, I figured it was a break in the movie for everyone to re-cap so far. Bottom line, I got lost a little after that.

Again, if the Godfather were perfect, then it would have a prefect 10/10 overall rating as well, and not the 9.2 it currently has. Still, I recommend anyone who likes movies to watch this one. It will most likely be worth your while.

title: Movie Review: The Godfather.
description:
*Roughly Translated From Brazilian Portuguese.

Movie Review: The Godfather.

I'm starting to catalog the movies and series I've seen from scratch, and pay attention Connie, this is the only time I'm going to give you any explanations about my business. This is a layman's critique. I usually won't have great criteria when doing an analysis. Here I write as a spectator, who likes movies and that's all, giving only my opinion, based on absolutely nothing.

I thought a lot about which movie I would choose to be the first. It would have to be an odd movie to say the least, and I found it.

A film considered by many to be the best work ever made in the seventh art, The Godfather is a work of many layers, but I don't intend to go on too long.

The work has several aspects, which work very well, and several movie moments that are interspersed and talk to each other, causing the viewer different emotions throughout the film.

A very long film, with its story embedded in the film from start to finish. In short, this density of history requires the viewer to pay close attention, so as not to miss any details. Of all aspects such as the strong figure of Don Corleone, the family history that is tied up during the film, I believe that the most relevant aspect to deal with here is what is really at stake: The construction of the Godfather, who is Michael .

In my view, this film portrays this character construction as being the godfather, and I suppose and hope that part II and III are respectively the middle and end of his story. If not, anyway, that was the clear impression the film gave me.

For all the zeal and care I've seen in this film, and also for the fact that it's very old and so well built in every way, I allow myself to give this film full marks, hoping I don't get used to pushing that button too often.

It's not business, it's personal.

Rating: 5/5 - This film is a Masterpiece.

title: Never take sides against the family.
description:
One of the greatest films of all time, a true masterpiece. The Godfather is arguably the best gangster drama, as well as the film that established the standard.

In the story, the Mafia is seen from within. That is its secret, allure, and spell; it has shaped how the general public perceives the Mafia ever since. In place of the real world, there is an authoritarian patriarchy ruled by the Godfather, with betrayers as the only bad guys. Michael (Al Pacino) gave the following advice: "Never take sides against the family." The Godfather traces the arc of this doomed idealism with a beauty that is still fresh.

title: en iyi film
description: The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest masterpieces in cinema history. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, the film masterfully explores themes of family, power, and betrayal. Marlon Brando and Al Pacino deliver iconic performances, portraying the grandeur and darkness of the mafia world. With its gripping narrative, unforgettable lines, and haunting score, the movie takes viewers on a profound journey. Michael Corleone's character arc, in particular, unfolds like a tragic epic. Every scene is meticulously crafted, making it a pinnacle of both technical and storytelling excellence, earning its place as "the greatest film of all time" in the eyes of many.

title: An unparalleled masterpiece
description:
Many reviews talk about the genius evidenced in this masterpiece of "gangster" movies. Of course, it really is a family movie, with a story set in the gangster world. What can I add that has not been said already? The simple fact that this classic captures the family dynamic that is practically gone from movies of the last 20 years.

The movie does not drown in schmaltz or sappy emotion. The love of the sons for the Godfather is natural and understandable. We can all identify with loving someone so much that we would be willing to die for them, or worse. The togetherness as well as the personal prejudices of the Corleone family (esp. Sonny) make the dynamic totally believable.

I loved this movie, and I can watch it over and over. In fact, I think I will!

title: The Best Film of All Times
description:
The Godfather I-II is far the best film ever. It's the per excellence for cinema in terms of narrative, acting, technique, and visibility. Some might argue that it is nor revolutionary, for example, such as The Citizen Cane. I totally agree with that argument that the GodFather I-II is not revolutionary in terms of narrative and form. Yet, but what it perfectly does is to combine all the virtues and improvements of cinematography, and raise them to an advanced level. At its time, it seems it's the end of cinema in terms of perfection. Moreover, it paved the way for the emergence of a new breed of actors such as Robert DE Niro, Al Pacino, James Caan, John Cazale, Taila Shire, Diane Keaton. It made Robert Duvall a power player in Hollywood Cinema, and gave a legend, Marlon Brando a chance to make an honorable leave that he unfortunately did fail to use. Regarding direction, Coppola set the standards for perfect directing.

I was born in 1975, that is to mean, I did not remember 70s but as I started to watch films and became an aficionado for films, I realized that only the Godfather I-II is enough to call '70s' as the best decade of modern cinema.

title: Great great Godfather
description:
The godfather trilogy is an exclusive set of movies that will continue to live with humanity, every generation will see them to say, "Oh that was 10 out of 10." If you watch them you will know that the world that lives inside the underworld is same as the one we live in except that people in underworld are so smart, in fact smartness is the only thing that can keep them there. Don Vito Caroleone's early life shown in part-II is very well done to show the Don in making, how a kid who couldn't even tell his name went on becoming a underworld don who keep most senators, judges and lawyers in his pocket. Meeting of don with the so call five families are among most impressive scenes.

A saga that goes on for 9 continuous hours takes you around various walks in life of Mike (Don's younger son who become Don later), his school days, love life, personal life, family life, business life, political life and religious life. How all of these different roles Mike plays in his life and how intertwined these are.

I enjoyed watching these movies so much, I wish I had seen them much before then I did. Its amazing to see how the Part-III was made 18 years later the part-I was made and everything looks so continuous if watch them together.

I need not say much! The Godfather father trilogy been around for a while and everyone knows that they are great set of movies, its just the matter of when you actually get to see them.

Watch them! Kudos to Francis Ford Coppola!

title: The Godfather
description: The film is a must see, anyone who has not yet seen it is missing out on the true beauty of film making. This film has deserved all of the awards it received. Marlon Brando plays an excellent role as Don Vito Corleone, and along with Al Pacino as Michael Corleone. They both fit their parts perfectly! The first time I saw it I was blown away by the acting. Marlon Brando especially, his character's voice really makes him unique and fun to watch. Al Pacino is a war hero and the youngest son of three, he comes home for his sister Connie's wedding. And the godfather's daughter's wedding day is the most important to him. Like said, this movie is a must see and I highly encourage everyone who has not seen it to see it as soon as possible, classic movies like these never get old.

title: This movie is one you can't refuse
description: I absolutely loved this movie. I watched it for the first time about a week ago and have not been able to stop thinking about it since. The acting of both Marlon Brando and Al Pacino is simply phenomenal. Pacino's never-changing serious demeanor perfectly conveys the life of a mobster. One can almost feel bad for Brando's 'Vito Corleone'. He is displayed as an old man who loves his family and will do anything to make sure they thrive rather than a ruthless killing machine. There is violence, but it's not over-the-top gore. It's all done in good taste. I found this movie to be very interesting because I know next-to-nothing about the Mafia. True, this movie is long at almost 3 hours but it's worth it. Now, to mention the music. I thought the music was truly beautiful and timeless. It perfectly captures the essence of the movie. . I've had the theme song stuck in my head for days now. At times my heart was beating fast for the characters out of suspense. I cried when they cried. I really felt some of the deaths. Overall, I feel as though this movie rightly deserves the title of 'Greatest Movie Ever Made'. I could watch this movie over and over again without getting tired of it. It's a timeless classic and, currently, my favorite movie.

title: Breathtaking although not the greatest mob film
description: This movie had me speechless by the end. In this movies there are no errors,no mistakes, everything is perfection. It is perfect in every aspect of the movie. It boosted Pacino to stardom along with a Dog Day Afternoon. It is Francis Ford Copollas greatest classic alongside Apocalypse now. This movie has a great story line and shows what its really like to be in a mob family down to the very last detail. No part of this movie is wrong and the views of the mob are correctly viewed. This movie is an all-time classic. I would not consider it the greatest mobster movie as i feel Good Fellas is but it is perfect and could not have been done better by a perfect director. I give this movie an amazing 10 out of 10.

title: very good movie
description:
good was a very good movie i enjoyed it a lot

good story line will still watch the sequels. Rather than concentrating on everything that is great about The Godfather, a much easier way for me to judge its quality is on what is bad about it. Almost every film has something that I don't like about it, but I can honestly say that I wouldn't change anything about The Godfather. There is nothing weak about it and nothing that stands out as bad. That's why it gets ten out of ten.

This is one of those films that made me wonder why I hadn't seen it earlier. The acting from everyone involved is great, Marlon Brando comes across perfectly as the head of the family, and James Caan and Al Pacino are excellent as his sons. The soundtrack by Nino Rota is also very memorable, bringing back memories of the film every time I hear it. The plot has to be excellent for it to get ten out of ten, and it is, it's far from predictable and the film is the definition of a great epic.

title: The Best Film Ever Made

I have seen The Godfather now about ten times or so and the movie grows on me more each time I watch it. I pick up little things that I didn't notice every time and to me the movie gets better and better each time as well. The storyline changes so much and I hardly notice that it is three hours long. I would have to say that I don't think there will ever be a film that could ever come close to The Godfather. They just don't make them like they used to.

title: GOOD 1900 MOVIE ALL THE TIME!!!
description:
Visually, The Godfather is stunning. The film's cinematography, by Gordon Willis, is famous for its use of shadows and muted colors, creating a sense of foreboding that permeates every scene. The film's score, composed by Nino Rota, is equally iconic, with its haunting theme music perfectly capturing the tragic grandeur of the Corleone family's story.

However, The Godfather is not without its challenges. The film's deliberate pacing and complex plot can be daunting for some viewers, particularly those accustomed to more fast-paced, action-oriented films. At nearly three hours long, it demands a level of commitment and attention that not everyone may be willing to give. Additionally, the film's portrayal of violence and its glorification of the Mafia lifestyle have been criticized, though it's clear that Coppola is more interested in exploring the moral complexities of his characters than in glamorizing their actions.

In conclusion, The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves its place in the pantheon of great films. It's a richly layered, meticulously crafted story about power, family, and the corrupting influence of ambition. While its slow pace and lengthy runtime may not appeal to everyone, those who invest the time will be rewarded with a film that is as thought-provoking as it is visually and emotionally impactful. The Godfather is more than just a crime drama; it's a profound exploration of the human condition, and its influence on cinema is undeniable.

title: God Father
description:
The Godfather is an undeniable cinematic masterpiece that continues to captivate audiences more than 50 years after its release. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, this epic tale of family, power, loyalty, and betrayal sets the standard for what a crime drama should be.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is legendary. His commanding presence, coupled with his nuanced performance, defines the character as one of the most iconic figures in film history. Al Pacino, as Michael Corleone, undergoes a fascinating transformation, evolving from an outsider to the ruthless head of the Corleone family. The chemistry between the actors, especially in pivotal scenes like the wedding and Michael's eventual rise, is nothing short of extraordinary.

The film's screenplay, written by Puzo and Coppola, is brilliant, filled with sharp dialogue and deep moral complexity. It explores the theme of power and its corrupting influence on individuals and families. The cinematography by Gordon Willis is stunning, with its dark and atmospheric lighting complementing the film's somber tone.

The pacing is impeccable, building tension at just the right moments while allowing the audience to appreciate the intricate family dynamics. The film's score, composed by Nino Rota, is haunting and unforgettable, becoming as synonymous with the story as the characters themselves.

The Godfather is not just a film about organized crime, but about family loyalty, sacrifice, and the American Dream. It is a timeless work of art that has influenced countless filmmakers and remains one of the greatest films ever made. If you haven't yet experienced it, prepare to witness the brilliance that has shaped the landscape of cinema.

title: The Hollywood Family: Part 1
description: Francis Ford Coppola's movie about the Corleone family is the story of the ultimate Hollywood family. Although "The Godfather" has lost some of it's original steam. In 1972 the causal treatment of violence was beyond shocking. With films like "Natural Born Killers," "Goodfellas" & "Pulp Fiction" (any Tarantino film for that matter) savage violence done in an "every day life" manner is no longer as shocking. Although there are a few scenes that stand out, even today. When Michael Corleone paid back those gentlemen for the attempted murder of his father. That is one of the greatest scenes in the history of film. And of course the scene were one of Mr. Ed's comrades makes a cameo. The most amazing thing to myself is how much of a family this really is. The Corleone's love each other, and that shines through above everything else in this film. But even with all it's greatness it lasted too long. So this great film just doesn't make the 10 cut for me. 9 (would be 9.8) out of 10.

title: Overrated action movie, nothing more...
description:
OK so The Godfather is an entertaining movie. OK, so it has some nice music, decent acting, and a gripping plot. All in all, I'm secure enough to state that it is an OK movie.

However, the fact that it is rated 9.2 out of 10, and on #2 spot in the top IMDb movie list requires some analysis. Deep analysis on this simple question: is this movie really better than the 100,000 or so other movies in IMDb? Better yet, is there something wrong with humanity if a movie about sick, violent, greedy, vengeful, hateful people gets a #2 spot?

My answer to this last question is, sadly, yes. Well, at least for the bulk of humanity: individually, there is no problem to rate this movie 10/10 (in fact, there is but hey, I'm putting it into perspective here), because it is fairly entertaining. But the fact that statistically it has been rated so high shows you about the sad and devious nature of people.

I, for one, have rated at least 200 movies higher than The Godfather, and I am proud of it, because I cannot convince myself that a film which tells you the story of people with the lowest possible moral can be one of the best I've seen. Main characters have to have at least a very small ray of humanity and decency in them for the movie to be really good (character depth), or else, it is just an average action movie, nothing more...

8/10

title: The Godfather is not just a movie
description:
The Godfather is not just a movie; it's a cinematic experience that redefined the gangster genre and established itself as a timeless classic. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, this film blends intricate storytelling, deep character development, and intense drama in a way that few others have achieved. Set against the backdrop of a mafia family, it's more than a tale of crime-it's a meditation on power, loyalty, and family dynamics.

At its core is Marlon Brando's unforgettable portrayal of Vito Corleone, the aging patriarch of the Corleone family. His performance is both powerful and understated, bringing a quiet dignity to a character who's capable of ruthless decisions. Brando's ability to convey so much with just a glance or a whispered word elevates the role to iconic status. Al Pacino, playing Michael Corleone, is equally mesmerizing as the reluctant son who gradually descends into the family's world of organized crime. Watching Michael's transformation from a war hero into the new Godfather is one of the most compelling character arcs in cinema.

The film's pace is deliberately slow, giving each scene time to breathe and each character a chance to shine. Coppola masterfully uses this pace to build tension, especially in moments like the wedding sequence, where seemingly mundane events hint at deeper undercurrents of power struggles and family ties. This patience pays off in climactic scenes like the baptism juxtaposed with a series of brutal assassinations-a haunting depiction of Michael's full embrace of his new role.

The supporting cast, including James Caan as Sonny, Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, and Diane Keaton as Kay Adams, add even more depth to the film. Each character is well fleshed out, adding layers to the story and reinforcing the sense that this is not just about crime, but about the personal cost of power.

Visually, The Godfather is stunning. Gordon Willis' cinematography, often called "The Prince of Darkness," uses shadows and warm hues to create an atmosphere of both intimacy and menace. The haunting score by Nino Rota adds an extra layer of emotion, amplifying the tension, heartbreak, and inevitable downfall that permeates the film.

While The Godfather is filled with violent moments, it never feels gratuitous. Each act of violence has weight and consequence, serving the larger narrative and deepening our understanding of the characters' moral dilemmas.

Ultimately, The Godfather is a film about the American Dream and its darker side. It explores the lengths to which individuals will go to protect their family and legacy, often at the cost of their humanity. Even more than 50 years after its release, it remains relevant and continues to influence filmmakers and storytellers across genres.

It's not just a movie-it's an experience, a masterclass in filmmaking, acting, and storytelling. For anyone interested in the power of cinema to explore complex themes, The Godfather is essential viewing.

title: like watchin willlie's catch

Baseball and Film are among my passions. The soul craves seeing something done well. Even people who know nothing about baseball can look at Willie Mays catch in the 53 (not sure of the year) World Series and see that it is executed with perfection.

Every sence in this Movie has a kind of Mauysian Catch quality. In the first sence, we see a man sitting at a dek with a most grandfatherly deamonor petting a pussy cat. I first thought this was a deliberate attempt to make a statement he is so gentle yet a cold blooderd mobster. Legend has it however, that the cat came onto the set by accident and Brando (with the reflex of a Willie Mays) knew just what to do.

When Tom is kidnapped he is told "If I wanted to kill you'd be dead alreardy" we are reminded that murder is a natural as breathing.

From the time the undertaker begs for justice until the time Kay sees Micheal for a ruthless killer we see acting as good as the Sey Hey Kid could catch. To maintain this quality for a few sences is an achievement. To maintain it in every sence for well over two hours is an offer no one should refuse.

title: The Godfather is a true cinematic
description:
The Godfather is a true cinematic gem that will forever remain in the history of cinema. A score of 9, in my opinion, cannot reflect the depth and skill of this film, but it is as an attempt to express my admiration and respect for it.

The film tells the story of the Corleone mafia family and their godfather, Vito Corleone, played by the unrivalled Marlon Brando. The superb screenplay, based on Mario Piuso's novel, allows the viewer to delve deeply into the world of crime, power and family values.

Director Francis Ford Coppola created an incredibly atmospheric film, combining drama, thriller and crime plot. Excellent acting, beautiful music by Nino Rota, skilful work with the camera and scenery - all this is perfectly combined in "The Godfather".

The film not only tells the story of a mafia family, but also touches on deep themes of morality, justice and family bonds. It's a story about human relationships, ambition and how power changes people.

I really enjoyed "The Godfather" and even though a score of 9 may seem insufficient, it is one of those films that leaves an unforgettable impression and that you think about for a long time after watching it. It is a classic film that is worth watching for all film lovers.

title: The greatest movie ever made.
description: Francis Ford Coppola achieved perfection on film with this great work. He directs so subtly that he makes it seem simple. But watch the subtleness of the scene outside the hospital when Michael (Al Pacino, at his best) lights the cigarette of Enzo the baker. One quick shot of Michael's hands, and they aren't shaking, and we know that he was born for the family business. The great Marlon Brando ad-libbed the films most important scene, that in the garden with his grandson, as the Don dies in peace, ironic for a man that lived such a violent life. The moody cinematography of Gordon Willis is the best ever caught on film. And the score by Nino Rota (I know the Academy didn't believe it belonged entirely to Rota, but who cares what the Academy thinks?) is a classic. The rest of the cast, which includes Robert Duvall, James Caan, John Cazale, Talia Shire, Diane Keaton, Abe Vigoda, Richard Castellano, Richard Bright, Alex Rocco, Richard Conte, John Marley and Sterling Hayden is in top form. Every film and television show about the mafia since this one has borrowed or outright stolen from this film. It is a story of profound depth, an American tragedy, told in three acts, and this, the first act, is the best. And yet at its root, it is a very simple story, as Don Corleone prepares his children for the lives they will have to live and the world they will have to live in. It can be summed up as family values, mafia style.

title: Greatest Movie of all time?
description:
In my opinion, easily one of the top five movies of all time. I believe every person should sit down and watch not only this film, but the second and third ones as well.

Coppola and Puzo collaborated to create a beautiful artistic picture. Although an organized crime family is depicted, the real story is about family, and love. Michael's struggle is well documented, and as he attempts to stay away from the family business, his love for his father causes him to become a criminal as he attends to his father in the Don's greatest time of need.

As it turns out, Michael proved to be the ideal choice for the next Don, and now the story begins to unfold. The whole Godfather Saga chronicles one man's struggle to maintain his business but at the same time maintain his family.

A touching yet tragic saga about a likeable man.

title: summer time
description: The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy from a screenplay by Mario Puzo and Coppola. Based on Puzo's 1969 novel of the same name, the film stars Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story, spanning the years 1945 to 1955, centers on the transformation of Michael Corleone from reluctant family outsider to ruthless Mafia boss while also chronicling the family under the patriarch Vito Corleone. The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in world cinema[4]—and as one of the most influential, especially in the gangster genre.[5] Now ranked as the second greatest film in American cinema (behind Citizen Kane) by the American Film Institute,[6] it was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 1990.[7] The film was for a time the highest grossing picture ever made, and remains the box office leader for 1972. It won three Oscars that year: for Best Picture, for Best Actor (Brando) and in the category Best Adapted Screenplay for Puzo and Coppola. Its nominations in seven other categories included Pacino, James Caan and Robert Duvall for Best Supporting Actor and Coppola for Best Director. The success spawned two sequels: The Godfather Part II in 1974, and The Godfather Part III in 1990.

Today I watched it to see if it really was the best movie ever made...and no, it's not.

It's not the best...it's not the worst.

In reality 0 this is maybe a 4 or 5 or maybe a 6.

But to bring the score down from over a 9.5 to reality, I voted it a 1.

Not fantastic actors, not a fantastic script. Nothing mind blowing about this.

Lots of stuff didn't even make sense.

It drags on and on and the story barely comes to a close.

This movie is so far over-rated, it's sad really.

Highly over-rated.

title: Great Film (Even if a Tab Bit Overrated)

The narrative is rich and complex, the characters are very memorable, and the performances by so many actors (from Al Pacino to Robert De Niro to James Caan) are iconic. The film's cinematography and attention to detail create an immersive atmosphere that pulls you into the world of the Corleone family. The score is haunting and perfectly complements the film's tone, enhancing the emotional weight of key scenes. Additionally, the exploration of power, family loyalty, and moral conflict adds layers that make it worth rewatching and thinking about. Can't take stars off just because others have put this movie on a pedestal. Re-watch and discuss it every few years with my wife.

title: Masterclass of a film
description:
Review of "The Godfather"

Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather," released in 1972, is a cinematic masterpiece that has secured its place as one of the greatest films ever made. Based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, this epic crime drama captivates audiences with its powerful storytelling, memorable characters, and profound exploration of power, family, and morality within the Mafia underworld of 1940s and 50s America.

At the heart of "The Godfather" is the Corleone crime family, led by the iconic Don Vito Corleone, played flawlessly by Marlon Brando. Brando's portrayal of the aging patriarch is nothing short of legendary, capturing both the ruthless determination and tender familial love that define the character. His raspy voice and imposing presence command every scene he is in, making Don Vito a figure of both fear and admiration.

Al Pacino delivers a career-defining performance as Michael Corleone, the youngest son who initially wants nothing to do with his family's criminal enterprises. Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader is portrayed with subtle intensity, showcasing his character's moral descent as he becomes increasingly embroiled in the world of organized crime.

The supporting cast is equally exceptional, with James Caan as the hotheaded Sonny Corleone, Robert Duvall as the pragmatic Tom Hagen, and Diane Keaton as Michael's innocent wife, Kay Adams. Each actor brings depth and complexity to their roles, adding layers to the intricate web of relationships and betrayals that drive the narrative forward.

Coppola's direction is masterful, employing a deliberate pace that allows the characters and their motivations to unfold naturally. The film's cinematography, by Gordon Willis, is striking, using shadow and light to heighten the drama and emphasize the moral ambiguity of the characters' actions. The score, composed by Nino Rota, is hauntingly beautiful, underscoring the film's emotional weight and dramatic tension.

title: Godfather 1972 are separated with 2020 dark-side world.
description:
Without undue emphasis, it shows the closeness, the warmth of family ties. The scenes are filled with wives and squalling babies, festive weddings and equally festive funerals, spaghetti prepared in the kitchen. There is the flavor of Italian home life that few gangster films have attempted. At the same time, there is also a specificity in the persona that few films have dared.

Which crooner was separated from whose orchestra on a friendly suggestion from the Godfather? And which movie producer was induced to hire him for a war movie by finding the head of his favorite horse in bed with him one morning? (Here, literary hyperbole may have embellished the facts, but it makes an effective, blood-curdling scene.)

title: This classic inferior to GoodFellas.
description:
The Godfather Part I deserves to be seen for what it is, not what its reputation is or what Part II added to it. With that in mind, my review: The first 2 hours are rather aimless, shabbily edited to look like a discordant bunch of too-thoughtfully-crafted "moments" without a common center. The actors' portrayals, while very strong throughout the cast, frequently overshadow what they are talking about. I tend to think that the story is usually the most important and interesting part of films, but here it is put on the backburner by, dare I say, too rich character-development. Actually, is that what it was? I come away from it without any true understanding of Michael's motivations or concept of morals, or why he chose to totally ignore them in the pursuit of power. I often felt that Don Corleone himself, who is not in the film as much as one might expect, is also hidden behind his own famous mannerisms and the reputation that goes along with being the Godfather. Having said that, the last hour, with Michael as the new head of the family, finally gains a focus and becomes interesting. The cross-cutting of the christening and the murders was perfectly masterful and thrilling. However, how the film morphed into Michael's story (and how he himself morphed into the cold blooded killer) is rather abrupt and unconvincing, though I am grateful for the change in tone.

Most importantly, it is inferior to GoodFellas, and thus can't even stake a claim as the best film of its genre.

title: I am amezed to see the explanation of this movie
description: Mainly I have understood this by reading the imdb of the movie Francis Ford Coppola's *The Godfather* (1972) is a cinematic masterpiece that redefined the gangster genre and remains one of the greatest films of all time. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the film follows the powerful Corleone crime family, led by Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), as they navigate the treacherous world of organized crime. At its core, the film is about power, loyalty, and the moral decay of those who seek control. The story revolves around Vito's reluctant son, Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), who transforms from an innocent outsider to a ruthless mafia boss. Brando delivers a legendary performance as the aging patriarch, his mannerisms and gravitas making Vito Corleone an iconic character. Pacino's portrayal of Michael's gradual descent into the mafia underworld is equally remarkable, capturing the nuances of his internal conflict. The supporting cast, including James Caan as Sonny, Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, and Diane Keaton as Kay Adams, adds depth to the narrative, making the Corleone family feel authentic and complex. Coppola's direction is masterful, with each scene meticulously crafted to build tension and emotion. Gordon Willis's cinematography uses shadow and lighting to enhance the film's dark, brooding atmosphere, while Nino Rota's haunting score adds to its emotional weight. The film's pacing allows the audience to absorb its themes without feeling rushed, making every moment impactful. One of the film's greatest strengths is its exploration of family and power, showing how personal choices can lead to inevitable consequences. Michael's journey is both tragic and compelling, as he sacrifices his morality for the sake of the family. The film also delves into themes of loyalty and betrayal, with characters making difficult decisions that test their allegiances. The dialogue is sharp and memorable, with lines like "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse" becoming part of pop culture. Violence is used sparingly but effectively, making each act of brutality feel consequential rather than gratuitous. The famous baptism scene, where Michael consolidates his power while renouncing sin in a church, is a brilliant juxtaposition that highlights the duality of his character. The Godfather is more than just a gangster film; it is a deeply human story about ambition, family, and the corrupting influence of power. Its influence on cinema is immeasurable, inspiring countless films and directors. Even decades after its release, it remains a gold standard for storytelling, acting, and filmmaking.

Popularly viewed as one of the best American films ever made, the multi-generational crime saga The Godfather is a touchstone of cinema: one of the most widely imitated, quoted, and lampooned movies of all time.Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando, whose iconic performance has overshadowed an even better turn by Al Pacino as his son Michael) is a man for whom family is all. "A man who doesn't spend time with his family can never be a real man," he says, and he lives by that. He's devoted to his wife, dotes on his children and grandchildren, throws a lavish wedding for his daughter, and kills or threatens anyone who gets in his way or that of his family and friends. His sons are all in the family business, which includes union racketeering and gambling.

title: Who's being naive Kay?
description:
The Godfather is an iconic film that has captivated audiences for decades, and it's hard to overstate its influence on cinema. The performances are one of the film's most remarkable aspects. The casting feels flawless, with each actor embodying their character so deeply that it's difficult to imagine anyone else in those roles. Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone, for example, gives a performance so compelling and layered that it becomes the very soul of the movie. The same can be said for Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, whose transformation from an innocent bystander in the family business to a calculating and ruthless leader is one of the most powerful character arcs in film history.

The soundtrack also plays a significant role in shaping the atmosphere of the movie. Nino Rota's score is timeless, evoking the grandiosity and melancholic weight of the Corleone family's legacy. From the very first notes, the music immerses the audience into the world of crime, power, and betrayal, making the story feel even more monumental. It's hard to think of a film where the soundtrack so perfectly complements the emotions and tensions playing out on screen.

One of the central figures in the film is Michael Corleone, whose character arc serves as the backbone of the story. Michael's transition from an innocent, war-hero son who is initially detached from the family's criminal activities to the cold, methodical Don is brilliantly portrayed. His calm and calculated demeanor, even in moments of high tension, signals that he always had the qualities to lead the family, even if he resisted it at first. His decisions, especially the lie he tells at the end, highlight a central theme in the movie: that objectivity and strategic thinking often outweigh moral considerations. It's a chilling reflection of how power operates in the shadows, with Michael's final decisions drawing a line between personal ethics and the brutal efficiency required to run an empire.

The film is undeniably dense, filled with many characters and intricate subplots. For someone who struggles to keep track of names and faces, this can feel overwhelming. It's a complex narrative that requires close attention, with new characters constantly emerging, each playing a pivotal role in the grand scheme. This complexity, while sometimes confusing, also mirrors the chaotic and interconnected nature of mafia life, where loyalty, betrayal, and shifting alliances are part of the daily routine. The fact that even minor characters end up having a significant impact later in the story shows how intricately woven the screenplay is.

Dialogues are undoubtedly the heart of The Godfather. The film is filled with memorable exchanges that capture the themes of power, family, and corruption. Scenes like Michael's conversation with Kay where he insists she is being naive, or the moment when a character mentions how he would steal a purse if it were another wedding-only to later betray the family-demonstrate how every line is charged with meaning. These dialogues don't just drive the plot forward, they build the world of the Corleones, exposing how deeply corruption is embedded in the institutions that are supposed to uphold justice, like the police. The line between morality and immorality becomes increasingly blurred as we witness how personal and political conflicts are resolved through ruthless actions, and words that carry heavy consequences.

In terms of pacing and direction, there are moments where the film feels somewhat disjointed. The transitions between certain scenes occasionally feel abrupt, as though some sequences weren't given the full time to play out. This isn't to say that the direction is bad-far from it. Francis Ford Coppola masterfully builds tension, especially in scenes like the famous revolver scene, where the stakes feel incredibly high and every second drips with suspense. However, at times, the pacing slows, creating atmospheres that might feel drawn out or unnecessarily tense. While this deliberate pace works to establish the weight of certain decisions or events, it occasionally hinders the overall flow of the narrative.

Even with these minor issues, The Godfather remains a film driven by powerful performances and sharp dialogue. Its exploration of power, loyalty, and the darker aspects of human nature is timeless, and while the film may not be perfect in terms of pacing or complexity, its ability to create such a vivid world of moral ambiguity and raw emotion is what cements its place as a masterpiece. It's clear why no remake could ever do justice to the original-it's a unique blend of impeccable casting, memorable writing, and thematic depth that would be nearly impossible to replicate.

While the film's complexity might feel overwhelming at times, especially with the large ensemble cast, its strengths far outweigh these issues. It's not just a movie about the mafia; it's about family, sacrifice, and the human condition. The fact that it continues to spark conversation and interpretation speaks volumes about its impact. Despite the occasional pacing issues and the challenge of keeping track of all the characters, The Godfather excels in creating an immersive, emotionally charged experience that is still unrivaled in its genre.

title: Best Movie
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is an enduring masterpiece that transcends the crime genre, offering a profound exploration of power, family, and morality. Adapted from Mario Puzo's best-selling novel, the film's intricate narrative and impeccable craftsmanship have solidified its status as one of the greatest films in cinematic history.

Et in the 1940s, "The Godfather" chronicles the Corleone family under patriarch Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). The story unfolds with the juxtaposition of familial loyalty and the brutal world of organized crime. As Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), Vito's youngest son, evolves from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless mafia boss, the film delves into themes of power, corruption, and the American Dream.

The narrative is meticulously structured, balancing intimate character development with broader socio-political commentary. Coppola's direction ensures that each scene contributes to the overarching themes, making the film's substantial runtime feel purposeful and engaging.

Performances:

title: yes

title: "I Believe In America."
description:
"America has made my fortune." This is the opening quote to The Godfather and in my opinion, the best movie in American history. And what would America be without it's greatest cinema-piece? It would be a nation lost of entertainment, a nation without a character as undeniable as Marlon Brando's Godfather. Without him, there would be a missing link to every actor in the history of cinema minus the few previous such as Humphrey Bogart's Rick Blaine from Casablanca. The performance of he convinces anyone that Don Vito Corleone is truly alive. Not only alive in the film, but alive as an actual person who speaks to us in volumes, a man who's moral guidelines and love for his family make him a respectable role model, even though he is the head of a mafia family. Don Corleone reaches out to all that see this movie and he is instantly respected as a person of honor, one who we know is of high power, yet is more a democrat rather than a fascist like other corrupt crime lords. Sonny, his son is in fact, fascist in a manner of speech and it shows when he must take over the business. Tragically, Michael the youngest son of the Corleone family is molded into the form of "zero tolerance" throughout the picture. The film really isn't about the Mafia; it's about family. The most important thing in The Godfather isn't the rise of power or the loss of it, only how much the other people in your life mean to you.

Many movies inevitably become boring and have scenes that are meant to be remembered but are easily forgettable. The Godfather never becomes boring. It hooks you the minute it begins and keeps you attached. Impressive for nearly a three-hour movie. An undertaker gives a speech to convince Don Corleone to avenge his daughter against the decadent hoods that attempted to rape her. From there on, the movie continues as a sweeping epic. Death strikes many times in this movie; all the moments of this are breathtaking and at many times, heart-wrenching. I sympathize for the many characters in The Godfather that meet with tragedy because they are so lovable. The 1972 classic takes you inside of the crime syndicate; a place I am oddly enough, happy to be. I feel like a member of the Corleone family every time I watch. Prior to viewing, I must admit that this world wasn't my most desired destination. Many parts and lines are memorable in this movie. What's so amazing is that most of them are back to back, which is a trademark of director Francis Ford Coppola. Most of his films achieve continuous scenes, ones that are embedded in our minds forever. For further proof, see Apocalypse Now or The Godfather Part II.

The Godfather is however, better than it's sequel. Even though the second film may have a more powerful and haunting conclusion and may also have more of a meaning, it still doesn't dig as deep into your soul like the original. Why is the first movie better you ask? Because The Godfather is in this one. Not Robert De Niro's version, but Marlon Brando's. To attempt to replace Brando is a ridiculous waste of time. Brando is The Godfather. No one else can compete with that.

title: One of the best movie evere made
description:
What can I say?

The godfather is a movie taken care of from head to toe. The movie does not miss anything, it's just perfect, the plot, the actors, the well-written scripts, everything is perfect. If someone has not seen it yet, I recommend that you see it.

title: What to say that hasn't been said?
description:
Great story of a mafia family. Although this story does not reflect real mafia workings (a fairy tale in comparison) it's great entertainment with a lot of class and a lot of style. The sets are spectacular, acting flawless and characters intriguing.

There is a lot of subtle material ocuuring in the continuous power struggle the mafia family is undergoing, especially with Michael. His gradual change, from war hero to Godfather is brought on by the violent events around him. He can't help but be sucked in. His icy cold demeanor is a reflection of the violent world around him and how the human character adapts to it, the transformation from doting husband to ruthless killer. Various events; the assassination attempt on his father, his brother and wife's murder, the betrayal by associates, the beating of his sister, gives him insight into the workings of the human mind. As the cold, clear thinker (as opposed to his animal-like brother, Sonny) he survives and becomes king.

Brando is great as the older Don who is starting to lose his edge with oncoming age and the love of his family. His old school mentality does not adapt to the more businesslike, colder generation of mafia hoods where honor and respect are becoming a thing of the past.

This movie is marvelous character study comparison between father and son in a violent world. Intelligently done and should hold up for generations to come.

title: Incredible in every way
description: This film was incredible. Unlike Goodfellas which was a juvenile and silly glorification of mobsters, Godfather was written to perfection and a masterpiece cinematically.

title: Brilliance.
description:
The greatest American movie of all time, the Godfather marked a new era of film making much closer to the old studio system style. It was also an early example of a new appraoach to film-making ushered in by new wave of directing talent. Known as the Movie Brats, an including The Godfather director Francis Ford Coppola and the likes of Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese, they were directors emerging through the study of the film medium in the 1960's and here it definitely shows. Coopla brings in a new innovative, stately style and substance to the production.

Coppola takes the classic gangster genre and, complete with an all star cast and a brilliant, perfectly judged and written screenplay, turns the film into an epic work of beauty. Every scene is beautifully and perfectly composed, with the composition owing much to the classic Italian Reniassance era, in particular the of Caravaggio. The dark, warm colours make the film look a painting; a work of art to be more precise. Coppola direction is masterful, evoking classic Hollywood film-making elements, such as the close-up up and shot-reverse-shot, as well as new innovative forms of film-making including tracking shots coupled with the delicate use of sound and precise cross-cutting editing. He is helped by a wonderful script, co-written with Mario Puza, a lush score by Nino Rota and a masterclass in acting from everyone involved, particularly Brando and Pacino. A brilliant, visceral riveting, flawless masterpiece, quite possibly the greatest film ever made.

10/10

title: 100% Story
description:
This movie comes from the golden age of Hollywood. No CGI, no fancy video editing, no second hand stories. This is what a pure movie story means.

I mean there are other great stories, but this was certainly genuine, unique in its own way. I have seen some gangster/mobster/mafia movies and none of them could offer the profound ambient of this movie. I like the way they capture every detail, and how the plot is twisted in every way.

The costumes are fabulous. Whoever made them, I want him to make one for me. The cars I believe are authentic and derive from that era. Also, the buildings and the scenery... ooh the details.

Oohh Francis Ford Coppola I wish you could make more movies like this, and I don't mean the sequels to this movie

title: An amazing movie that i couldn't refuse to watch
description:
Loved the the movie,the direction and the cast where amazing.

"Wow, what a phenomenal cast and an equally outstanding movie! From the moment the opening credits rolled, I was mesmerized by the talent on screen. Each actor brought their A-game, immersing me completely in the characters' world. The chemistry between the cast members was palpable, adding layers of depth to every scene. It's rare to see such seamless collaboration among performers, and it truly elevated the entire viewing experience."

"Not only was the cast exceptional, but the movie itself was a triumph. The storytelling was compelling, weaving together intricate plotlines with finesse. I found myself emotionally invested from start to finish, laughing, crying, and holding my breath in suspense. The director's vision was executed flawlessly, capturing the essence of the narrative with breathtaking visuals and impeccable pacing. It's a testament to the filmmakers' talent and dedication that they delivered such an unforgettable cinematic journey."

"In summary, this movie is a tour de force in every aspect. From its powerhouse performances to its gripping storyline, it's a cinematic masterpiece that leaves a lasting impact. I walked out of the theater feeling exhilarated, eager to discuss every twist and turn with fellow moviegoers. It's not often that a film resonates with me on such a profound level, but this one will stay with me for a long time. A must-see for anyone who appreciates the magic of cinema."

title: it's not historically accurate to the genre or dark and gritty like i expected. slow paced over-hyped family film
description:
I do not understand the hype, i have tried earlier today on my second attempt to viewing this movie, i made it about 45 minutes until Don Corleone's first assassination attempt until I coulnd't sit through it anymore.

I want to say again I don't understand the hype and high 9.2 IMDb score for this movie. I will try to explain for the following reasons: #1) There is a lot of hype involved because it is considered a true crime epic, well it's not even a true story or based upon one has anyone realized that? Yes , there is some elements which are relative to the crime world at the time, but no this does not do justice to the real crime families. It's not based on a true story in any way other than something like Inglorious Bastards would be, it only uses some real names and real ideas in our history.

#2) The action and build up is very slow paced and makes it difficult to sit through without getting bored. The action crawls at a snails pace, it does not bother to cover the history behind how Brando's character came to be in the position of power he is in. For something with such a slow build up i am surprised they did not incorporate anything about the don and how he came to be. I am disappointed to be unable to connect with the don on any level, it is only assumed that he worked hard and is a respectable individual.

#3) It does not fully capture the real danger and constant rush involved with living a dangerous life every day. It does not feel real. The first shooting scene looked bundled and strange, even unorganized. It did not look professional or scary. And second, they didn't bother to finish him off or plan this effectively it looked like an assassination attempt doomed to fail. Not to mention his bodyguard, might i add this is the DON the GODFATHER his bodyguard looked like a quivering mass of coward. For someone in such an esteemed and established position he should be able to pick more skilled bodyguards. His crony immediately broke down and cried, any true criminal knows that business comes first, avenge your boss, don't sit and cry. If i was his boss and still alive i would get up and shoot my henchmen in the face for being a chicken. Also the scene where Robert Duvall sneaks a horse head into the director's bed? Am i the only that fully can see how ridiculous that is, and the fact that it is also quite impossible? For you that don't know the movie, he gets welcomed into the directors house to discuss business, and like a sneaky petty con artist insults him behind his back and mutilates his prize horse and sticks it on top of his bed while he's sleeping. The reality of that is just crazy. First of all, a person does not become a godfather by employing low integrity sleaze balls into his direct office, that is not how the world works. Criminal organizations have a code of conduct as well, and need skilled and practical criminals to do their work, criminals who often maintain their own standard of rules and principles. If a criminal did that kind of bull he is gonna being embarrassment to his organization.

#4)This film does not appeal to me as dark and epic, but family fun inaccurate to the brutality and hustle real gangsters encounter. It is a strange concept it is too long and way too inaccurate to reality.

In conclusion, I Want to say as a hardcore fan of crime, and someone who has broken a few rules personally in my time I can say this does not accurately portray the genre. It is far too long and slow paced for me to sit through, i cant say that i have ever finished this from start to finish i tried twice now and don't see my self as being able to.

title: An Offer You Can't Refuse: A Perfect American Epic
description:
A towering achievement that redefined cinema.

Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather isn't just the greatest gangster movie ever made-it's an epic about family, power, and America itself. Marlon Brando's performance as Don Vito Corleone is magnetic, blending menace with unexpected tenderness. Al Pacino's transformation from reluctant son to ruthless boss is one of the greatest character arcs in film history. Gordon Willis's dusky cinematography bathes the film in a haunting, amber-toned shadow that lingers in the mind long after the credits roll.

Every scene feels monumental. Every performance feels alive. Every line of dialogue feels legendary. The Godfather is Shakespearean in its tragedy, timeless in its themes, and utterly masterful in its execution.

Essential cinema.

title: A masterpiece of cinema
description: The film boasts an excellent script, superb direction, stunning cinematography, and a brilliant cast of actors who deliver unforgettable performances. The film explores the themes of loyalty, family, power, and morality in a realistic and nuanced way, showing the complex and often tragic consequences of the choices made by the characters. The film also features some of the most iconic scenes and dialogue in film history, such as the opening scene with Don Vito Corleone, the horse head in the bed, the restaurant assassination, and the final montage. The film is a must-watch for any film lover and a timeless classic that will never lose its appeal.

Kudos to all the actors, but especially my favorites: Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan D,iane Keaton, Morgana King, Richard Conte, in amazing performances and moments of living what they play!!!!

title: Great movie
description: In 1972, one based on a bestselling film written by Mario Puzo emerged. The saga of the Corleone family is like a tragic opera, soaked in blood and deafened by the noise of the guns. The shooting marked by disagreements between the director and producers. A film that addresses violence, mafia, family and love. Yes, the love a father has for his family. Cynical characters under a humanized view maintains the essence of the work, no one is who is by chance, are the circumstances that define their choices, all for a greater good: the good of the family. A metaphor for America in the history of The Godfather is clear from the first moment, Francis Ford Coppola holds a dramatic power of passages of the book by Mario Puzo turning a great book into a powerful film, both in its aesthetics and in its essence. The Godfather is my favorite movie, and undoubtedly one of the most important films in history. The most talked about, imitated and revered film.

title: The Best Movie so far in its Class .....

The roles of Tom Hagen, Sonny and of course Michael (Al Pachino) are epic and very heart touching. The sound & music gives us a feel like Italian environment in USA. At the start you may feel a slow moving film, but as the time elapses the best of the acting, directing and dialogues comes on the surface. At the last its a must watch movie at least twice in your lifetime.

Original Title: Unwatchable

I spent twenty some years of life before I watched this movie.

I was always told that it is the greatest movie ever. I sat down one day and got around to watching it. It is really long. It isn't really interesting, and I could not finish it.

This reminds me of Citizen Kane, another movie that gets a lot of praise.

I am not sure why this is a 'timeless classic', but it is a fifty year old movie and it doesn't seem timeless to me. If you must watch it, be prepared to watch a lot of stuff that doesn't seem to have anything to do with the story.

The problem with anything really revolutionary is that it only looks that way once. Once they change how movies are made, other people follow suit. Then it is no longer revolutionary for those that grew up after the change.

I also hold that anything that deviates from a 1.5 hour length is not usually improved upon, and I would happily take a pair of editing shears to this movie.

title: The Saga of a Powerful Family
description:
Godfather, the saga of a family, who preferred to kill to prove power and occupy territories from powerless people.

When I was watching The Godfather, I was very young. I couldn't believe, how innocent people were killed because of the Mafia (in general). I was nailed in front of the TV together with my father, brother, and mother, watching each scene with curiosity what happens next.

I had a great time viewing these movies, and I wish I had seen them sooner. It's remarkable to see how Part III was created 18 years after Part I, yet everything appears to be continuous when you watch them together.

Director, actors, and the whole production crew worked very hard to make this saga to a memorable film for the audience.

Hollywood could bring more such stories on the big screen.

title: Le Godfather
description: The Godfather is definitely an impactful film that helped shape the gangster genre. I feel like it does a lot for Italian American and Mafia culture as its length. For me, I feel l went and did some other stuff while watching due to its length. I still find it is an impactful film regardless. It helped shape the gangster genre. It has two sequels (currently no remakes). It is often used as a blueprint for film making. I feel like it is good that it doesn't lighten up content to get a lighter rating in order to open it up to more audiences (I feel like that is a complaint of some stuff today in my opinion, I feel like the Venom movies should have been rated R). It does have a bit that takes place during Christmastime, so it is technically a Christmas movie, so that is the reason why I watched it and reviewing it today.

title: One of the Greatest Movies of all Time
description:
The Godfather is a film that is critically acclaimed to the point of reverence, and rightfully so. The writing of the movie is absolutely brilliant, it takes its time setting things up and developing its characters so that events that occur later on have an amplified impact. The outstanding score by Nino Rota is incredible, it is no surprise how popular the soundtrack of this movie is. Marlon Brando gives one of the most impressive performances I have ever seen. His portrayal of Don Vito Corleone was genuinely awe-inspiring. This is thanks in no small part to the dialogue of the movie which is simply stellar. The movie is absolutely brimming with nuanced and poignant lines.

The cinematography and camera-work is excellent too, each scene feels intricately filmed with characters and extras being placed in the perfect orientation.

This movie undoubtedly deserves its showers of praise and will forever be paraded as one of the greatest movies of all time. 10/10.

title: The Godfather (1972)
description: The Godfather is a great movie that innovated the crime genre. It has a great story which (for a nearly 3 hour movie) moves quickly. We are brought close to the professional and personal lives of these mafia men, and when we see some of them gunned down, it's relatively hard-hitting. This was an innovation at the time: for a mafia film to bring us emotionally close to the characters. Perhaps the most shocking scene in the film (not to spoil anything) ends with a car riddled in machine gun bullets. Marlon Brando's performance as Don Vito Corleone can be seen as one of the most iconic performances/roles in film history: it is Brando transformed, and he's fun to quote back to. Like any movie that is labeled with such a "legendary" status, The Godfather is a tad overrated; but still very good nonetheless thanks to it's great story, performances, and iconic scenes.

title: The perfect opening made a legendary movie.
description: I heard about "The Godfather" a long time ago. But the reason I watched it for the first time is because of my English conversation class. My teacher is crazy about it. He asked us to write a movie thesis. The story itself is very exciting. But as a movie, to turn this story into a legend, you need a team of extraordinary play. Marlon Brando, as a veteran actor, blended the two roles of father and godfather very well, and very natural. His first appearance in the movie has completely conquered the audience. He is a unique godfather. Director: Francis Ford Coppola also arranged the story very well. Although this is a very long movie, I have no fatigue at all. The climax and calm of the story have very good rhythm and regularity. Music is also iconic. You may forget it briefly, but when you hear it again, you will immediately know it is "The Godfather".

title: Masterpiece
description: Masterpiece Brilliant acting Great storytelling Inspiration to all generations

title: The Godfather
description: When you get a story written quite this magnificently it would take an extreme amateur to screw it up - and Francis Ford Coppola is no amateur. Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan and Robert Duvall represent the epitome of guile, sophistication, loyalty, honour and brutality in this self-adapted Mario Puzo story of the unambiguously ambitious "Corleone" family - they start with nothing and so the only way is up; however and whatever they need to do to get there. The characterisations are layered and colourful; Diane Keaton has no idea what she's getting herself into! John Cazale is great as the spineless brother "Fredo" too. Once again, Nino Rota pulls out all the stops to give this a score that helps cement this film's place as amongst the best ever made. My only criticism, and it is slight at that, is that the audio mix could have done with a bit of a boost. Much of the dialogue - especially from Brando - verges on the inaudible at times.

title: It was... OK
description:
look i understand how many people love this film; good acting, pretty solid storyline, etc... but one thing that is also a factor is what generation of movie audiences it is geared toward. i am a teenager, and while i do love guns, killing, and all that good "teenage stuff" that is in this movie, many people of my generation do not take such interest in mafia thrillers. i feel that they are a thing of the past, and therefor i do not identify with this movie in the slightest, and basically, don't love it as much as many people seem to. Having said this, i actually liked goodfellas more then the godfather, not because of the mafia ties, but the struggles that the man character underwent; struggles that i can identify with. this was something "The Godfather" lacked.

again, its not bad... its just... OK
