title: No Words To Describe
description:
THE GODFATHER ****

Here we have such a masterpiece of a film, that it has become a big part of the American Culture. Marlon Brando's speech is imitated, the horse head scene has been poked to death, and the musical score is used in spoofs. Yes, here we have the quissential mafia film. One of the first, and still the best.

It started off as a novel written by Mario Puzo, until Francis Ford Coppola came in and expressed his interests of turning it into a film. He took it to Paramount Pictures, and they originally slated it to be a modernized version. They figured it would be much cheaper to make it in the present day (1971) and would hit audiences harder. However, Coppola, along with Puzo, fought them day on end for the rights to leave it as it was. Eventually, they gave in, but gave Coppola even more troubles when they disagreed on practically half of Coppola's cast. Paramount eventually gave into Coppola again, and let him make the film.

This film is magnificent in so many ways. Performances by Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton, John Cazale, James Caan, and Marlon Brando make the film shine, and also make it some of the best acting ever caught on film. Most people will tell you that The Godfather is every guy's favorite film. I guess you could say that's true for the most part, although I know many women who love this film as well. It speaks a universal language to film buffs and non- film buffs alike.

The film is a wonderful example of perfection. A true American masterpiece.

I watched this film last night because I heard Kanye West once said that it was an all time classic. Now I do respect the rapper and producer's opinion but I beg to differ.

Firstly I found it quite boring, it just doesn't have the action packed pace of some of my personal favourite movies such as Weekend at Bernie's 2, Teen Wolf, or Kickboxer 3 : The Art of War.

The acting wasn't great either. I know Pacino and Brando are decent actors but compared to performances such as Judd Nelson in The Breakfast Club or Rodney Dangerfield in Caddyshack, it's seriously under par. It's easy to play a moody gangster but could you imagine Al Pacino playing Ross Geller in Friends? Me neither. The guy has no versatility.

One more thing is the music wasn't too hot either. Just classical nonsense all the way through. By my calculations, The Godfather would be 37% better if there was a tad more Genesis, maybe "Invisible Touch" playing over the restaurant shooting scene.

3/10.

Cheers.

title: Timeless cinematic excellence
description:
As long as movies exist, The Godfather will always be relevant and stand out as one of the all time best. When most people think of a perfect movie, this one comes to mind, and for good reason. Every single aspect of filmmaking is executed down to the finest detail with flawless results, most notably the violence, which is graphic but never gratuitous. The ensemble acting is arguably the best ever, with every performance being beliveable and memorable. The story of a mafia family trying to survive amidst a crumbling empire is very compelling, but it's much more than a mafia movie. It's a story about family and the importance of staying together.

Over the years, The Godfather has become nothing less than an American institution, inspiring several imitations as well as parodies and creating many phrases and expressions that have made their way into pop culture. There is something in The Godfather that appeals to everyone and every generation. For this, it will always find favor with the masses and truly remain a timeless classic of cinema.

But you will only express it as YOU see it... I think this is one of those artistic accomplishments that came very very close to what everybody sees. that's art. And thanks to Al Pacino & Marlon Brando ! anybody who even questions these actors... should think twice before. I'm proud to be a contemporary with Al Pacino ! thank you

title: What happens if you step into Chaos?
description:
When you finally decide to watch this movie, since it came out in the 70s, and you were born about twenty years later, you sit down in front of your TV with some degree of expectation. Expectation the movie sees in your eyes, then laughs at you for some minutes. And then a man wakes up with blood all over his pajamas and a horse head in his bed. So you realise that something you were simply fearing is actually true. That is the complex life of the Corleone family.

But please, try ignoring your expectations. Forget about the hype, as many describe this as one of the "greatest movies of all time", if not THE one. You won't be disappointed, that is, but there is nothing like a "greatest" movie. This is "only" a masterpiece in cinematographic production, acting, writing and score, much akin to an opera piece.

"The Godfather" does not care about classical Aristotelian unity, and it can do that thanks to an incredibly coherent screenplay thanks to the combined effort of writer Mario Puzo and director F.F. Coppola. Years pass by, oceans are crossed and decisions are taken without the viewers noticing, as they can't ignore every character's intriguing motivations and cold-hearted yet realistic resolution. This is one of the greatest strenghts of the movie, as its surrealisticly realistic tone constantly entangles your brain in its world: you always know that all you are watching is just fiction, only a story, yet it impossible for the viewer to unsee the cruel nature of a world that did exist. Its a "historical character saga" about nonexistent characers.

Marlon Brando's and Al Pacino's performances have no particular traints of features. Because they are flawless. The supporting cast did a great job too, so good in fact that most of the time you can't tell who is the supporting and who's the main cast.

Gordon Willis' fotography is gorgeous from the first moments of the movie. Slowly moving scenes, beautifully lit like Caravaggio's portraits, bring a whole new life to the words "noir" and "chiaroscuro". We are talking about Italians, after all, and making Marlon Brando mumble some "italian" words sure does not mean a lot. Still, it was nice to hear Italian words pronounced correctly almost all the time.

Nino Rota did not write music. The sophisticated sounds you hear while your eyes are accompanied by the splendidly crafted frames are powerful overflows of emotions. Nino Rota was truly a prodigy and a master of his art.

But how are all these different features kept toghether in this masterpiece of a movie? It's a slow and steady descent into darkness, just look at Al Pacino's character, Michele Corleone. So, what happens if you finally step into chaos? Well, you won't like it. Your life won't like it. Your loved ones won't like it. But you won't even notice.

title: The Greatest. Truly.
description:
Now, let's take a look at what anyone who is serious about film says is the greatest of all time. They're right. Both Godfathers stand alone as the two of the best scripted, acted, and directed films of all time. In all, they come out to the two best films. If you read some of my other reviews, you'll find that I consider a saga one film. A saga is best watched simultaneously. The Godfathers are a perfect example of how a series can get it right. Except the third. The third was just plain bad. Did Coppola really need to do this? Throw in another addition to the greatest saga in history? Sure, Andy Garcia was pretty spot-on as Sonny's illegitimate child. But they might as well have had someone like Dustin Hoffman play Michael, because he would've looked and sounded more like him than Pacino did at the time. And Sofia sucked. Good director, bad actress. It was not needed, because the first two were flawless. The ways of how this crime family rose, fell, rose, fell, etc., was perfect. I distinctly remember saying in one of my film classes (in front of a bunch of total film snobs) that Coppola is one of the greatest filmmakers of all time. The other students stared at me with blank looks on their faces, as if I had told some horribly offensive jokes. Screw them. Why shouldn't he be considered? He deserves it, with The Godfather, Part II, Apocalypse Now, and The Conversation. Four classics. Did the other students not like it because he made a couple of flops (Jack, The Rainmaker)? All the best did (Kubrick-Eyes Wide Shut, Nolan-Insomnia), and they continue to be praised. I did enjoy The Outsiders, even if it doesn't come close to touching The Godfathers. Apart, they are masterpieces. Together, they are the definition of flawless filmmaking.

The genius behind the storyline is that we never see the Don at his peak. We see him just before his peak, and just after as well. Everything, from the script to the directing, makes this storyline perfect. But it is the acting that has the biggest aspect on the story. Two actors (De Niro and Branda, both two-time winners) won for the role of Don Vito. Also, the surrounding cast of Pacino, Duvall, Caan, and Keaton, make the film what it is, attached to a pitch-perfect script by Mario Puzo and Coppola. to quote Richard Roeper, saying you like film but have never seen The Godfather is like "saying you love to drink but you've never had water." Too true.

title: The Godfather
description:
A defining film in the history of cinema, The Godfather introduced a legendary filmmaker and several acting greats in the telling of an Italian American dynasty undone by the tragic circumstances of their criminal exploits.

Of the many themes which The Godfather touches upon, it is that of "family" which resonates the most. The film is based upon the novel by Mario Puzo (who co-wrote the screenplay) and many sub-plots were minimized or thrown away by director/co-writer Francis Ford Coppola, himself an Italian American and family man. He knew that the only way to make Puzo's sprawling novel work on screen was to focus on the familial relationships within this crime story, whether it be father to son, brother to brother, or husband to wife. In this world blood is not only thicker than water, it is holy.

Coppola opens the films with an interesting shot of a pitch black screen giving way to a desperate figure, an undertaker pleading to Mafioso patriarch Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) to revenge the savage beating of his daughter. It is the wedding day of the lone Corleone daughter Connie (Talia Shire), and no Sicilian can refuse a request, which Don Vito takes on with reason, while also subtlety enforcing his position as a man to be respected and feared.

Brando's casting was a coup for Coppola, for three reasons. First, it exhibited the brilliance and innovation of Brando's thespian prowess, creating a wholly new mafia figure within a world of stereotype. Second, it re-established Brando's standing as a major player after years of being labeled "box-office poison". And third, it points to Brando's influence as "godfather" to a generation of actors, many which play his children in this film.

Plot wise, The Godfather begins with the attempted assassination of Don Vito from a rival crime family unhappy with his refusal to enter the narcotics trade. With the Don temporarily out of the picture, it is up to his sons to run the Corleone clan. There is hot tempered Sonny (James Caan), meek mild Fredo (John Cazale), adopted son of Irish ancestry Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall), and the fiercely independent Michael (Al Pacino).

It would be Michael who comes through as successor, and as a result The Godfather is as much Pacino's film as it is Brando's, introducing himself with a revelation of a performance.

title: A Masterpiece
description:
There is very little that I can add to the reviews on here, that have explained what is so wonderful about The Godfather so well. I have seen many amazing movies, as well as some clunkers, but The Godfather was beyond amazing. There are so many images, details and scenes that I seriously cannot get out of my head since watching it for the first time just nine hours ago. The Godfather is so incredibly well-made and acted that it stands out among the rest of those other amazing films I've seen, so much so I couldn't think of a single flaw, and I am struggling to think of a good enough reason to why I didn't see this film before now.

True, The Godfather is a little slow-moving and the plot takes a while to unfold, but neither of these are flaws as such. The slow pacing added to the elegiac quality The Godfather has, and as for the plot what is special about this plot is that it is very unpredictable because you have next to no idea where it is next going to take you. Being 18, I was worried whether I was old enough to appreciate this film or even understand it, but luckily I understood it perfectly, and I can well and truly appreciate it for the masterpiece it is considered to be.

The Godfather for one thing looks stunning. I strongly disagree with the previous reviewer who said the cinematography was horrid, for me the cinematography was one of the best assets of the film. In some scenes you have cinematography and lighting that is quite dark and mysterious, and then in scenes such as the wedding it is evergreen, autumnal and very picturesque. It is not just the cinematography that makes The Godfather look stunning, the costumes are beautifully tailored, the houses are gorgeous and majestic to look at and even the cars were immaculate.

title: the best movie in the world

title: A Flower of Sin
description:
As someone who didn't see this film until today, I hesitated for a long time before deciding to write this review. In fact, I've heard about The Godfather for a long time, it's said to be a film that 'a man must see once in his life', and people around me have mentioned it to me in one way or another. There are two reasons why I haven't watched it. The first is that the film was shot too long ago, and I felt that some of the ideas and filming techniques didn't resonate with me. The second reason is that it is a 3-hour drama that I don't have the courage to sit in front of my computer screen and finish it in one sitting. But today I did, haha. In fact, to be honest, maybe my expectations were too high, after seeing the shock to me is not so big, maybe this is a film that needs to be repeated to savour it. So today I'm going to talk to you about some of the little details of the film that I like.

The first scene in the film is so poignant that the lines between the funeral parlour owner and the godfather let the audience know that this is a gangster-themed film. The Godfather is also portrayed very impressively in this scene, most notably in the way he speaks, with his raspy voice and bulging cheeks, which the actor is said to have actually stuffed in his mouth at the time. In the dialogue between the two men, we learn that the funeral parlour boss didn't get what he called justice, so he came to the Godfather for help. His anxiety can be representative of the anxiety of the general public, especially the lower and middle social constituent groups. They want fair, direct, and effective punishment, so they turn to social groups with a gangster twist, which is often more effective in particular times. The Godfather agrees to help him with his problem, and the boss kisses the back of the Godfather's hand, a classic gesture that echoes the end of the film. I must mention the cat in the Godfather's hand, which perfectly portrays the Godfather's gentle and kind image. The second scene of the film comes to the wedding, and the cheerful and crowded scene is a strong contrast to the first scene. The characters of the film also appear one by one, and the film is officially opened.

In the wedding sequence, there are three dramatic events that the Godfather has to deal with: dealing with the unfair treatment of the undertaker, helping the woman to emigrate, and helping a celebrity to get a role in the film. The film shows one of the most difficult things to do - take care of the Hollywood mogul. This segment gives Tom's character a rather colourful logo.

Next comes the reversal of the story, when the Godfather is assassinated, but the situation is not fatal. Mike is calm and collected in the face of danger, while on the contrary, the other two brothers are at a loss for words. Next, Mike protects his father in the hospital again, and it is the rival assassination plan that fails again. This episode once again shows Mike's carefulness, alertness, resourcefulness and daring beyond the ordinary. The next assassination is in an Italian restaurant, a few bullets decided Mike's fate.

Mike returned to the U. S., replacing his father as the new generation of Godfather, the Godfather and Mike in the garden scene is also very exciting. It's not long, but it's very informative, but it actually explains one thing: whoever steps in and arranges a negotiation with the enemy is a traitor. But the scene is very informative: 1. The Godfather's poor state of health, suggesting that he will soon pass away. 2. the final succession of the old and new Godfathers. 3. the old Godfather's deep regret that Mike has taken over the family's business, and he hopes that his son will be the one who will control others, rather than being played by them. 4. the ambiguity for the Godfather's death in the next scene, when he is enjoying the heavenly pleasures of the world with his grandson. 5. how to deal with enemies, and to identify traitors . In fact, this scene is the Godfather's last words. At the end of this scene, which is also the climax of the film, Mike completes the baptism of the Godfather in the religious sense, and also completes the baptism as a mob godfather. And truly becomes a godfather like his father.

The film portrays the deceitfulness, intrigue and sinfulness of the noir characters very well, and at the same time shows the emotions and character of the mission in a delicate and precious way. It combines the beauty and darkness of human nature into one, making the fate of the characters more tragic. The Godfather is a landmark in both content and form, and no movies from that time can compete with it.

title: A great "family" movie
description: This movie gives the audience a look at what family really means. "The Godfather" has the cast, writing, score, directing, and cinematography that makes great movies. The story of the Corleone family is one that endures. It is less about crime and more about the trials of any normal family. It casts light on the hypocrisy of the establishment through showing society its own dark underbelly. The thought that a mafia don is no different than a Senator or President (Kay and Michael's discussion after Michael returns from Sicily and tells Kay he is running the family business), shows how naive society can be and how quick it is to offer blame on people who believe in something as opposed to nothing. All in all one of the Ten Best movies of all time.

title: The son of a Mafia
description: The son of a Mafia boss returns from the war and following an attempt on his father's life becomes more and more embroiled in the shadowy world of organized crime. Francis Ford Coppola's classic gangster saga is the story of a criminal dynasty headed by Marlon Brando in one of his most iconic roles. Coppola's direction is deceptively simple in that he uses no gimmicks or stylistic tricks; he merely allows the story to unfold and lets the superb cast do their thing. Brando's mumbling family and loyalty obsessed don has since become part of popular culture folklore (along with the classic score) and all other accompanying performances are top notch, from James Caan's hot headed Santino to Robert Duval's purely business orientated adviser. But this film is really the story of Michael's transition from honest war hero to shadowy underworld figure, played by Al Pacino in his finest role. The pivotal scene in which his newborn godson is baptized while Michael himself, the newborn "Godfather", is baptized in blood is an all time great. This is the birth of the modern gangster film and with the possible exception of Goodfellas, it is still to be surpassed. Source: http://www.huludb.com/movies/19122-the-godfather

title: Shallow characters, unrelated sketches.
description: There's no transition between Michael I (american hero, away of family business) and Michael II (Sicilian mobster). The shooting of Vito and the assassination of Sonny maybe explains a psychological turn to revenge (a little material showing the attachment between Michael and each of them would have been nice), but it's not enough for this transformation into a full-fledged mafia manager, interested in brothels and casinos. The character of Kay is pathetic, living among criminals and believing Michael's promises about changing his way of life. The whole movie is a collection of excuses to present sketches of violence.

title: How every movie should be made
description:
I can't say enough great things about "The Godfather." It is, without a doubt, the greatest film ever made. The plot is gripping, an amazing interpretation of the American Mafia, and the film's acting is superb. The characters make the film seem like we are watching a documentary moreso than a movie. You can see the transformation of Michael from the reluctant son, to the man who inherits an empire. Al Pacino's performance is outstanding. Marlon Brando is such a believable godfather that I think mafiosos throughout history would feel intimidated if they ever had to go to a "meeting" with Don Corleone.

James Caan also provides a smashing performance as the hot-headed Sonny. His ferocity and high spirited attitude adds so much to the film. I've always wondered if Robert Duvall's natural speaking voice is that of Tom Hagan or of another one of his characters like the preacher or Gus.

This is one of the few films that I will never, ever grow tired of watching. Dramatically and cinematically speaking, it is one of the few films that I admire and wish that other Hollywood directors and producers would try to emulate as far as style, story development and acting goes, especially in Hollywood's dark time of remakes and lackluster script writing.

title: Mafia King
description: Probably the best Mafia ever! So many scenes that depict the life of living with the gangsters. A great cast of family in crime, and the trials of families involved.

title: GOOD

Malone's performance was truly disheartening, the inarticulate godfather, but no one dared ignore his every word. His face was always impassive, but behind it lurked something that could not be ignored -- a kind of elegant rage, calm cruelty!

title: A Timeless Masterpiece of Cinema
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is a film that has transcended generations and become a landmark in the history of cinema. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the movie presents an epic narrative that immerses viewers in the ruthless and intriguing world of the Italian mafia in mid-20th century America.

One of the main reasons why "The Godfather" continues to be revered is Coppola's exceptional skill as a director. His masterful direction creates a dense and immersive atmosphere, conveying both the grandeur and intimacy of the story. Meticulously chosen camera angles and stunning cinematography capture the essence of the characters and the environment they inhabit.

Furthermore, the brilliant ensemble cast contributes to the film's exceptional quality. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, the powerful leader of the mafia family. His magnetic presence and distinctive voice bring to life a complex character who has become a cinematic icon. Al Pacino also deserves praise for his portrayal of Michael Corleone, the reluctant son who is drawn into the world of crime. His transformation throughout the film is fascinating to watch, showcasing Pacino's talent and versatility as an actor.

The plot of "The Godfather" is a true tour de force, filled with intrigue, betrayal, and loyalty. The screenplay, co-written by Coppola and Puzo, is a brilliant adaptation of the original novel. The story unfolds in a captivating manner, with thrilling twists that keep viewers glued to the screen. Moreover, the film offers profound reflections on themes such as family, power, and morality, delving into the dilemmas faced by the characters.

Nino Rota's soundtrack also plays a crucial role in "The Godfather," contributing to the dark and tense atmosphere of the film. The instantly recognizable music has become one of the most iconic themes in the history of cinema.

"The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that remains one of the greatest films ever made. Its perfect combination of masterful direction, incredible performances, intelligent screenplay, and memorable soundtrack makes it an undeniable classic. Even decades after its release, the film retains its relevance and impact, and its influence can be felt in numerous productions that followed.

In summary, "The Godfather" is a film that deserves to be appreciated and celebrated. It is a timeless masterpiece that sets the standard for the mafia film genre and continues to inspire filmmakers and captivate audiences to this day.

title: It is just an incredible movie then, now, and for eternity.
description: For a film that is almost 50 years old now, the story is brilliant, the acting, sensational especially from Al Pacino and Marlon Brando. There are very few films that I would give a 10/10 to but the godfather takes the cake with the cherry on top, for those who like a good story, brilliant acting, a bit of the mafia, guns blazing, this is your cuppa, it certainly is mine. Utterly incredible, now I just need to watch part 2 and 3!

The best parts were a couple of LOL moments during the shooting scenes, otherwise this has got to be one of the most boring movies ever and I fell asleep at least 5 times.

title: this is brilliant and takes its place as one of the best films of all time
description:
The Godfather is a 1972 American gangster-drama film based on the novel of the same name by Mario Puzo and directed by Francis Ford Coppola from a screenplay by Puzo, Coppola, and Robert Towne (uncredited).[3] It stars Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Richard S. Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte and Diane Keaton, and features John Cazale, Talia Shire, Al Martino, and Abe Vigoda. The story spans ten years from 1945 to 1955 and chronicles the fictional Italian American Corleone crime family. Two sequels followed: The Godfather Part II in 1974, and The Godfather Part III in 1990.

The Godfather received Academy Awards for Best Picture, Best Actor, and Best Adapted Screenplay, and has been selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry. In addition, it is ranked third, behind Citizen Kane, and Casablanca on the AFI's 100 Years100 Movies list by the American Film Institute. It was moved up to second when the list was published again, in 2008.[4]

title: unscrupulous killer
description:
What is The Godfather for us today? We know that this is one of the most famous films in the history of cinema, for most people it is, in principle, the very embodiment of the word "cinema". This is the ideal of authorial dramatic cinema, which is close and understandable to a wide range of viewers. It is an integral part of popular culture, broken into quotes, images and memes.

Although this film has a three-act structure, all the acts are well packed with content. And so the film is watched in one breath. And most importantly, what message ... Each person has the right to decide for himself what meaning was laid down by the author. For me, the central theme of the story is the theme of the family and its importance. In three hours of screen time, the two protagonists undergo a gigantic evolution, turning into their opposites in interaction with each other. The all-powerful mafia becomes a feeble old man, and an idealistic young man becomes an unscrupulous killer.

title: The Godfather of Mafia Film
description: As the name of this masterpiece implies, Godfather is truly the Godfather of Mafia Film. Every cliche and idea that has been introduced into movies and TV shows based around the Mafia have elements that were first introduced in the Godfather and its sequels. And the Godfather's influence does not only lay in English speaking countries. For example, as someone of Turkish descent, I have noticed that many of Turkey's mafia-based TV shows are influenced by this masterpiece.

title: Best movie ever!!
description: From the initial scene that represents joy (marriage of Vito's daughter) to Michael's death due to the death of his only daughter (innocent, unrelated to the world of the Mafia), the godfather represents cinema at its maximum splendor, he here my arguments. In this first film a series of events occur that make this film the best in history. At first Coppola chooses his cast perfectly, especially Michel (Al Pacino), a character with little experience and innocence in the world of the Mafia, Sonny, an impulsive man lacking reason, and Tom, a great lawyer and thinker, but always (redundancy ). ) focused on advocacy. This is where Michael stands out, as his cunning focuses on the street, on everyday life, on quickly reading his surroundings and in particular the sign that there is a conspiracy to murder his father, Vito. First talk of the first film, Santino thinks, Vito realizes that his son opened an important door for the enemy (Sollozzo) to take advantage of his weakness or perhaps enthusiasm, trying to overthrow Vito, through the natural and economic seduction of his son . Older, who at the time falters and interprets that he must take the reins. Later, Michael, in a flash of personality, performs one of the best sequences in cinema (spoiler); suggest the death of the police commander and Sollozzo himself. The only son who was never involved with the mafia suggests getting involved, the beginning of the best progress of the character, and likewise of one of the best actors in the history of cinema. With these short scenes that exemplify the magnificence of Godfather 1 (without even representing 30% of the saga), I take the argument as sufficient to explain what, for me, is the best movie and cinema saga that has existed, exists, and Maybe, in life, it will exist. I prefer not to dwell on these amazing details that explain life itself, and I give a rating of 10/10 for this film, which is the only one that in my life I have taken the time to, in my opinion, evaluate.

title: Very nice
description:
Widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time, this mob drama, based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, focuses on the powerful Italian-American crime family of Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). When the don's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino), reluctantly joins the Mafia, he becomes involved in the inevitable cycle of violence and betrayal. Although Michael tries to maintain a normal relationship with his wife, Kay (Diane Keaton), he is drawn deeper into the family business.

Rating: R Genre: Crime, Drama Original Language: English Director: Francis Ford Coppola Producer: Albert S. title: A masterpiece!

One of the best gangster movies that have been released.Some people say this it the only good one in the trilogy but I disagree with that statement, although it is the best one. It really feels as Coppola had some inside informant give him insight on how things work in a mafia family. They are many other crime movies but in my opinions none of those is on the same level as "The Godfather"(that's not saying they are bad or of inferior quality of course).

I recommend seeing this movie to anyone, enjoys not only crime flicks but good cinema in general.

title: The Greatest movie I have EVER seen!
description: I have seen movies from all genres, but NOTHING and no other movie has surprised me more than The Godfather! This movie has EVERYTHING, a great script, unforgettable performances and characters, great acting and a MIND-BLOWING story line! I was really surprised on how serious this movie was made and the effort it took to make this into a successful masterpiece! Marlon Brando's performance in this movie is EXCELLENT! I was really enjoying every minute of his screen time and because of his Italian accent and also because he was a very interesting and likable character. The amount of drama that occurs in the film between the five families is absolutely heartbreaking and mind-blowing due to FANTASTIC performances brought to the film! I also really enjoyed Al Pacino's character known as Michael Corleone! I felt that he had a lot of charisma in almost every scene he was in and he tries to avoid being an idiot character and ends up being another likable character throughout the film! I think this is DEFINITELY a film that everybody should see at least once because it is definitely worth a watch for anyone who LOVES watching movies from any genre including myself. The Godfather is a film that HIGHLY surprised me and it's a classic and a masterpiece in movie history and it will stay as one of the GREATEST movie of all time and it has to be the greatest movie I have ever seen and i'm gonna give The Godfather a 10/10.

title: Simply put, this is the greatest film ever made.
description: As close to a perfect film as you're going to get. The young, fairly new director(in 1972)Francis Ford Coppola did an outstanding job of getting A+ performances out of his 'entire' cast. When watching this masterpiece of American film, one does not even take notice that they are watching actors perform. Instead, it's as if a hidden camera has captured the real lives of a post war New York mafia family. This is by far my favorite film of all time and recomend it as a must see. I envy the person who will have the thrill of seeing it for the first time. It's quite awsome.

title: Enjoyable but disappointing
description:
The Godfather seems to be one of the most critically successful films of all time with many people claiming it to be 'the greatest movie of all time'. This makes it impossible to watch this film with a truly open mind. Anyone wait bing this film will most likely have very high expectations for this alleged masterpiece.

The film wasn't bad. The narrative was interesting, the dialogue was clever and it was executed perfectly with some of the greatest acting talent ever seen on screen. It was a good film, a great film in fact but the greatest film of all time? Not quite.

The film felt too long and was at some points hard to watch, almost even boring and although there are few things wrong with the film it just feels as though it is missing something special that would be expected from 'the greatest movie of all time'.

That said the film was somewhat enjoyable however it's reputation left me wanting something more and sadly the prequel films weren't quite that something.

title: Indescribably Special
description: Somehow 3 hours seem to flow on by faster than you can imagine. By far, the best directing in any movie I have ever seen. It is unbelievable how separate plotlines weave into one-another so perfectly. Despite being killers every character is so real and understandable. I can imagine living as each character and following the same paths they had as fate dictated. I don't believe that any movie will or has captured the pure magic of this movie. I am fully engage and in awe every time I watch this movie. I follow the stereotype of short attention spans among young people, but I cannot say that I was ever taken out of the movie or bored for even a second from the first line to the last, a feat only achieved by this and The Shawshank Redemption. The only criticism I have ever heard about this movie is that it is too slow, but I don't see it. There are no moments that left me bored, each moment is packed with pure entertainment, and every moment without dialogue or action is filled with incredible music that lets you ponder and digest the events that just transpired. That raises another point in how incredible the music is. The main theme is captivating like I have never seen before. It is so recognizable and unique. It has become a joke among my friends who I initially watched this movie with to play the main theme whenever there is any violence or talk about money. I even hum it without even realizing. I bring this movie up every time I need to make conversation with someone who was old enough to remember the release of this movie. There is something about it that separates it from all other movies. It perfectly entails everything great about movies and is the peak of entertainment.

title: Go on
description:
John Cazale brings the troubled Fredo to life, and you can see the weak Fredo desperately trying to live up to the family reputation but knowing that he can never be what his father wants.

The story of one man's reluctance to be drawn into the murky family business,and his gradual change through circumstance, paints a vivid picture of this violent period of US history.

title: Awful
description: People do not understand cinema. I see the movie The Fighter with top stars and sure it gets Oscars or The Godfather oh ya great movie. I just watched a movie called Rockaway (2007). A movie where the main actor is just a normal man. And, yes, he acts normal and looks normal. But the power that can come from a normal man explodes in this movie (Rockaway). The people who rate The Fighter or the Godfather with high ratings or liked it any are people with a low IQ. They probably like these types of movies because cuz they like crime, like the Godfather. The godfather is trash. This little dude in (Rockaway 2007) this movie mostly uses intelligence to take down the mob and its godfather. I cannot stand the movie the godfather because America is praising crime and gangsters. This movie shows how one mans determination to stop a gang of thugs is expelled mostly with intelligence training determination and more. I cannot stand the Oscar and academy award panel- they do not know how to judge films. I will sing to everything good when the day comes and people stop admiring trash like The Fighter and The Godfather. I get a kick out of the movie Rockaway because the character can be a good role model. He is not a criminal, drug addict, and he isn't stupid. When we watch The Fighter, or The Godfather, you see top American actors committing crime, drugs, and utter stupidity. But in Rockaway, a regular American, or hispanic, not sure, man comes back to town to take down the entire Russian mob. He even takes down the Godfather of the mob while he is blind, after his eyes were taken out. I am thankful that I am not stupid enough to be excited when the bad guys (mobsters) win. I am the type of guy that likes to go to work without the mafia trying to get in my way. Mobs and gangsters and their movies just don't excite me, but seeing this high rating, helps me to understand why there is so much crime in America and why most people are too scared to go outside haha.

title: An Offer You Can't Refuse
description:
A timeless masterpiece. A truly awe inspiring piece of cinema. One of the greatest movies I have ever seen. Very well directed with dazzling cinematography. Acting was superb and the script was flawless.

I'd recommend this film to anyone, especially those who enjoy Scorsese's work with mobs like Goodfellas and Casino. The film is so enthralling you can not believe it came out in 1972. The camera work and direction of Capolla was truly amazing.

It has such memorable and quotable lines. And another mention of the acting, because Pacino was unbelievable and so convincing as Michael. A defiant masterpiece, everyone should see this movie, at least once.

title: waste of 3 hours
description: While The Godfather is often hailed as a masterpiece, I find it to be highly overrated. There's no denying that the actors are professional and the direction is solid, but to label it as the best movie of all time feels excessive. The film is good, but it lacks the elements that would make it truly exceptional in my eyes. The storyline, while iconic, doesn't stand out to me compared to other crime movies that offer more engaging plot twists and intricate narratives. There are countless other films in the crime genre that I believe are superior in terms of storytelling, character development, and overall execution. I think the film's reputation is more about its cultural impact and historical significance rather than its actual quality as a movie. While it may have set a standard during its time, I don't see how it surpasses many other films that have come since. For me, it's a decent movie, but far from deserving of the overwhelming praise it receives. I give it a low rating because I find the hype around it to be disproportionate to its actual merits.

title: Subtle
description:
The Godfather (including Part 2 for purpose of this review) is probably the most analysed film of all time, so really I don't see the point in repeating any of the rhetorics. Rather, what I intend to provide here is my honest two cents of this film.

The Godfather is not an easy film to watch, so it baffled me at that time of watching for the first time (and still baffles me to this day) how it is so universally loved by almost anyone who has watched it. Firstly, there are so many characters that I gave up remembering anyone other than the Corleone family. Secondly, the script is so subtle and tight that the moment I missed a single sentence, I did not get the next scene. It was no easy feat to follow every sentence given the frequent mutterings, so subtitles are almost indispensable. In the end, I pretty much referred to the plot synopsis every 5 minutes.

Make no mistake, the reasons above are also what probably makes the Godfather regarded as one of the greatest films of all time. It just surprises me how a film as subtle as the Godfather has received just as much attention as 'lighter' classics such as Star Wars, Pulp Fiction, Taxi Driver, Goodfellas, etc.

Ultimately, my verdict is that the Godfather is a great, iconic film from the 70s era, but my honest take is that the Godfather is perhaps a little over-hyped (not overrated, but over-hyped) to the extent that it gets more exposure than some of the other equally great films from the olden era. For that, the Godfather is a great film, but is not in my consideration for the greatest film of all time.

title: The Greatest
description: One of the greatest movies of all time. The cast & characters were perfect.

A defining film in the history of cinema, The Godfather introduced a legendary filmmaker and several acting greats in the telling of an Italian American dynasty undone by the tragic circumstances of their criminal exploits.Brando's casting was a coup for Coppola, for three reasons. First, it exhibited the brilliance and innovation of Brando's thespian prowess, creating a wholly new mafia figure within a world of stereotype. Second, it re-established Brando's standing as a major player after years of being labeled "box-office poison". And third, it points to Brando's influence as "godfather" to a generation of actors, many which play his children in this film.

title: Vastly Over-rated
description: The Godfather is an engaging and compelling story to say the least, but as a movie- so what? Just because something makes for a great story or play doesn't mean it can automatically translate onto the big screen. There has to be some point of making it into a movie, and quite frankly, The Godfather works just as effectively as a book. The characters, the dialogue, the plot twists- yeah, they're all okay, but where are the shots, the angles, the editing techniques, the sound effects that make this into a number one film??? The conventions of film are all used pretty simply according to the Hollywood format- ie, make the camera invisible. There are few scenes anywhere in The Godfather Trilogy that stand out in the history of cinema. If you want an entertaining movie, you will certainly like the Godfather. But you may just as well read the book (unless, like so many today, you haven't the time). But if you want a film that stretches the genre or that will blow you away with an element OTHER than storyline and dialogue, you can do a lot better.

title: The Godfather supremacy has been broken by the Ring.
description:
The Godfather supremacy has been broken by the Ring.

The Godfather is a wonderful film, but it is not the best trilogy ever, at least not anymore. Let me give you a hint why the trilogy of Lord of the Rings is better than the Godfather trilogy. Godfather part III a big time loser!!!

You don't even have to be a fanatic filmgoer to see and realize that. The movie was clumsy and boring to a point that it was almost clear to me that Coppola wanted desperately to make his trilogy without having a clue of what he was doing. That reminds me of another 80'ties character called George Lucas (see Star Wars-saga). Maybe Coppola was trying to take the quote from Alfred Hitchcock a bit too literally, when he said that style in film is to plagiarise yourself. Godfather III is a recollection of scenes we saw before in a different outfit, adding some cheap cosa nostra crap that did not work, like the fake set-up scene with the helicopter. This is the moment where by unbelievable coincidence the Godfather and Sonny's son came out without a scratch. This is not the same kind of realism I saw in I and II. While Return of the King is the climatic moment of the trilogy, Godfather III was its lowpoint.

This is Hollywood wanting to sell tickets the cheap way, betting on a sure thing. And what about the story? What is it? Financial corruption at the Vatican? It is nothing more than an expensive soap-opera. So what if he did it the traditional way. He should of realized that he had no good story.

It is not because the actors from the Godfather trilogy received Oscars for their performances and probably LOTR not is because the actors from the first trilogy did a better job than the others. It has nothing to do with it. The whole show is not about rewarding talent, but to uphold a tradition of celebrating those who are loyal to the spirit of Hollywood. LOTR has but conformed to one tradition, the one from Middle-Earth, in a galaxy far far from Hollywood.

Let's not forget however to point out that Coppola is responsible for putting his daughter in the film who given us a stunning insight in how bad acting can be. Fortunately for her she has proven, she is much better off directing films. Even Pacino doesn't bring a good performance. While in Godfather II he brought us a believable and likeable anti-hero, while in part III he doesn't do anything else than shouting.

There are unforgettable scenes in the Godfather trilogy. But so there are far better scenes in LOTR, and probably in a way future generations will get inspired in how to make a sensible symbiosis between technique and story, in the same spirit of Hitchcock and Welles, who both were neglected by The Academy of Motion Pictures. If you talk about memorable scenes, look at how Peter Jackson brought us Gollem. It brakes again new boundaries for visual effects and surpasses even the matrix by far. Phantasy has never been that real since ever. And the examples could go on and on.

Part III doesn't bring anything new, while LOTR innovate at every turn. LOTR is not the typical Hollywood film. In fact, it is not a Hollywood film at all. But It is a pure refreshing experience and a great motivation for a lot of young filmmakers.

title: The Cream Of All Mobster Movies
description: "The Godfather" is, in my opinion, the best gangster movie ever created. I like this movie for its superior directing and excellent storytelling. This movie shows us that even gangsters are born human beings. They face victory and defeat about as much as any other group of people. Despite its graphic intensity, I found myself paying very close attention to the emotions of the main family. I'd say that it is a step above "The Untouchables". Anyone interested in major film classics should see the original "Godfather" at least one time.

title: The classic tale of a Mafia family. Not for kids.
description: Francis Ford Coppola & Mario Puzo bring the famed-mafia novel to life. The Godfather is an excellent portrayal of power, betrayal and family. Beautifully written and stunningly executed, the film is a landmark motion picture with stunning performances (Brando, Pacino, Caan) that is still held up to this day as a timeless classic. Spectacular. Every time I see it, it gets better. From its flawless direction, to its exceptional score, to its (near-)flawless script, I have no doubt "The Godfather" is one of the best movies ever made.

title: No movie can get any better than "The Godfather"
description: A Masterpiece of its time and all time, this movie defined the term - "blockbuster movie" and set the ultimate limit for a cinematic masterpiece. No one would have ever believed that this movie would have such an impact on popular, mainstream American cinema. The executives of the studio that funded this movie's production just seemed to keep their fingers crossed and hoped that the movie wouldn't bomb really bad in the box office. Their fears were not unreal. They were taking a mammoth risk by funding a movie to be directed by a 'risk taking, not so popular' director starring many unknown actors in major roles and to top it all, the story was to be adapted from a decently popular fictional novel. All these factors could have kept this movie down. If it weren't for the amazing talent exploited really very well in every department, aspect of the movie, their worst fears would have been realized. "The Godfather" established many careers and gave life to many interesting personalities to have ever graced the screen. A "Definite Watch" for anyone who wants to know what a 'perfect, no non-sense movie' is all about and also in general, an engrossing movie that grows on you over time.

title: i love it
description: This is like heaven for someone who is a fan of movies. With this movie Brando was able to bring himself back into the limelight. His performance as the godfather alone is iconic. His character has been recreated so much in films that it has almost if it has not already become a cliché. His performance though was not a cliché. His performance was subtle and breathtaking. It was so genuine and realistic that it was not just probably but definitely more genuine than Marlon Brando himself. Al Pacino was perfect for this film as well. What a way to start up your career. His character was all about depth and he displayed it perfectly. He was able to display his own inner-battles in his mind as well as the battles he had with his family, friends and enemies. His character was more of a psychological character study than anything else to me. Robert Duvall to me was the glue to the movie. He added a different perspective to everything in just that he was not Italian yet having the respect of the mafia. His character is a man of high authority within the Corleone family who was listened to and insightful;. This was simply perfect giving the film great balance throughout. The rest of the cast was just icing on the cake.

title: Great movie
description:
"The first time I watched The Godfather, I was a teenager, and honestly, I didn't appreciate it as much as I should have. At the time, I found the pacing too slow and didn't fully grasp the depth of the story or its significance. I dismissed it as something that wasn't for me and moved on.

However, after revisiting the film 20 years later, I decided to give it another chance, and I have to admit, I was completely wrong in my initial judgment. Watching it now with more life experience, I can truly appreciate the brilliance of the storytelling, the deliberate pacing, and the intricate character development. Every scene serves a purpose, and what once seemed slow to me now feels like a masterpiece of tension, emotion, and complexity.

The Godfather is not just a movie, but a profound exploration of power, loyalty, and family. I'm glad I gave it a second chance because it has become one of my favorite films, and I finally understand why it's considered one of the greatest of all time."

title: The Greatest Of All Time - Classic
description:
The Godfather" is not just a crime drama; it's a profound exploration of morality and the consequences of one's choices. It's a film that continues to influence and inspire generations of filmmakers and remains a must-see for anyone who appreciates the art of cinema. In summary, "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that has rightfully earned its place as one of the greatest films ever made.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of iconic, and his performance sets the tone for the entire film

The film's storytelling is masterful, with a gripping narrative that spans generations of the Corleone family. The intricate web of relationships, loyalty, and betrayal is portrayed with such depth that it keeps you engaged from start to finish.

title: Great movie
description:
I learned a lot of thing from this movie.

I love the Godfather movies. They are some of the best films ever made. The story, the acting, the music, the cinematography, everything is just perfect. The Godfather movies show us the complex and fascinating world of the mafia, and how it affects the lives of the Corleone family. The Godfather movies are not just about crime and violence, they are also about loyalty, honor, family, and power. The Godfather movies are great because they make us feel a range of emotions, from fear to admiration, from sadness to joy, from anger to sympathy. The Godfather movies are great because they are timeless classics that will never get old.

title: A masterpiece that presents a dark mafia movie with a meaningful family drama at its core.
description: This film is utterly brilliant in every possible way, from the character arcs to the dramatic and emotional moments. I won't say much about the plot; only that you need to watch this movie immediately if you haven't already so that you can experience its greatness firsthand. The brilliance of this movie lies in the fact that there are no "heroes" or "villains." Only people who do what they believe is right for themselves and their families, even if it means going against the rest of the world. I'm honestly not exaggerating when saying that this movie is quite possibly the best film I have ever watched.

title: Very good movie for long afternoons
description: When you want to see a good movie, you have to see this one. The script, the actors, just whole the film is incredible. It takes about three hours but it's done before you know. Everyone I know loved it, and I know many people.

title: A conflicting masterpiece
description:
Yes. I gave the movie a 7 out of 10.

I do acknowledge that the movie is a masterpiece that defined future mafia/gangster movies and even cinema as a whole, and I do very much enjoy the well-played characters in the movie where Brando and Pacino were the stars of the show.

However I couldn't help but feel like the movie stretched on for too long. It's not because I have anything against longer movies, hell, I loved Oppenheimer when I watched it in 2023. Maybe it was the fact that it was an older movie that often used a slower pace to build up tension. Maybe I have become numb to quality movies because of the Marvel and action movies that come out today? Who knows.

Nevertheless I still very much enjoyed this movie. I can see why it is seen as a masterpiece, most definitely.

title: Nearly flawless
description: This movie is truly a masterpiece. It is nearly flawless, and was remarkably realistic. No need for mob stereotypes ..... Just a conservative portrayal of a family with deep roots. Remarkable, and a treat to watch over again. It's too bad Brando was a bit of a flake, because he is probably the best actor that ever lived. Every character is complex, but I think my favourite must be Sonny. A hot headed son who is expected to take the reigns of the family one day, in spite of older brother Fredo. I was a kid when it came out but I would love to see it on the big screen. I also find the ages of the actors interesting... Pacino and Caan were very close in age despite Caan as being portrayed as years older. Duvall is actually considerably older than those two. And Abe Vagota is the oldest living cast member.

title: Brilliant!
description: What more could you ever want from a film?! The Godfather, created by Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola, is an absolutely mind boggling film. The acting is brilliant! Brando, Pacino, Caan, and Duvall are masterful actors. The topic, the mafia, fascinating. The motif and symbolism (shaded eyes, oranges for death), stunning and so well presented. The transitions (edition), genius. Most of all, watch for the wonderful cinematography...Coppola knows how to shoot a hell of a film! I personally don't believe any other film can compare to this movie. Truly a masterpiece and revolutionary in setting higher standards in filmmaking.

title: An aspiring classic and one of the most memorable in cinema
description:
From a stand point, The Godfather is one of the most epic and flawless Movies to be ever made. Everything from the direction to the fantastic art style and tone, this film is amazing. Here's why this is one of the most influential Movies today.

The story is great, in the 1940s, an aging patriarch is getting tired of his job and constantly struggles through Family life until he gets shot by a criminal, due to his damage on his chest, his son Michael Corloene takes over as patriarch and must infiltrate a series of criminals and live a New life in Sicily but the criminals Michael is looking for is after him and his Associates, With that in mind, he must protect everyone from this nasty spree from happening and have both New York and Sicily back in business.

The film's direction is a miracle, the film really is a serious gangster drama than most drama's With a touch of humor, this film has none of that, each character has the own respective emotion which makes the character more like a Virtual reality game than a fictional character in a Movie since the characters are portrayed realistically and that makes the film bring more attention to the Viewer than it's general audience.

The performances are fantastic especially Al Pacino, they really act like real life People which makes their acting skills nearly improvised, i must confess that Marlon Brando can sounds kinda wheezy and talks to quiet, but he is good but Al Pacino is the star of this Movie.

The art style is great, the film has a Perfect use of film grain and color which makes the film looks more realistic and appealing than usual.

The film is without it's problems, but pretty minor, the film's story can get to complex sometimes but that's a nitpick, other than that, the film is flawless.

The Music is great, sounds just like what a gangster soundtrack should be.

The Godfather is one of the best films of all time, the direction, soundtrack, performances, art style, story and it's emotions to it's characters make's this film appealing, the film's too complex but still don't overlook this Movie.

10/10

title: Perfection.
description:
"The Godfather" is a pinnacle of cinematographic excellence, evident in its meticulous attention to detail and masterful execution. Three specific examples highlight the film's brilliance:

The Opening Scene: The film's iconic opening sequence sets the tone for the entire narrative. As Amerigo Bonasera pleads for justice for his daughter, the camera slowly zooms in on his face, capturing every flicker of emotion in Marlon Brando's performance. The use of close-up shots emphasizes the intensity of Bonasera's desperation, while the stark lighting creates a sense of foreboding. This scene establishes the film's themes of power, loyalty, and justice, laying the foundation for the story that unfolds.

The Wedding Sequence: The wedding scene is a masterclass in visual storytelling, showcasing Francis Ford Coppola's ability to orchestrate complex ensemble shots. The sprawling mise-en-scène captures the opulence of the Corleone family's world, with the camera weaving through the crowd, introducing key characters and relationships. The use of long takes and fluid camera movements creates a sense of intimacy and immersion, drawing viewers into the festivities. Meanwhile, subtle details in the background, such as the whispered conversations and exchanged glances, hint at the underlying tensions simmering beneath the surface.

The Restaurant Murder: One of the most iconic scenes in cinematic history, the restaurant murder is a tour de force of suspense and tension. Shot from Michael Corleone's perspective, the scene unfolds in real-time, intensifying the sense of immediacy and danger. The use of low-key lighting and deep shadows heightens the atmosphere of dread, while the absence of music accentuates the sound of the train rumbling overhead. As Michael calmly executes his plan, the camera remains steady, capturing every calculated movement and expression. The scene's shocking climax, punctuated by the sudden eruption of violence, leaves an indelible impression on viewers, solidifying "The Godfather" as a cinematic masterpiece.

title: Good but not great
description: Good movie but Petro Balbao better movie. thanks -kristot

title: Masterpiece
description:
Direction and Production As a passionate film enthusiast, I can't help but marvel at the direction of Francis Ford Coppola. His ability to craft an immersive narrative that captivates the audience from the very first scene is truly exceptional. Coppola's talent for developing complex, multifaceted characters is evident in every frame, using cinematography that shifts between light and shadow to symbolize the moral duality of the characters. His choice to shoot many scenes in dimly lit interiors adds a tone of mystery and danger, underscoring the clandestine nature of the Corleone family's activities.

The production of "The Godfather" also stands out for its meticulous attention to detail and authenticity. The recreation of mid-20th century New York is flawless, from the costumes and sets to the music selection, which includes traditional Italian pieces that add an extra layer of realism and emotion to the narrative.

Performances The performances in "The Godfather" are nothing short of legendary. Marlon Brando, as Vito Corleone, delivers an iconic performance that defines the mafia patriarch with a blend of toughness and humanity. His portrayal earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor, cementing his place in cinematic history. Brando manages to convey an imposing authority while showing a touching vulnerability, especially in scenes with his family.

Al Pacino, as Michael Corleone, undergoes a masterful transformation from a reluctant, innocent young man to a calculating mafia boss. The evolution of his character is handled with impressive subtlety, and his ability to convey deep internal changes with minimal facial expressions showcases his immense talent. Michael's relationship with his family, especially his father Vito, is the emotional core of the film and is executed with an authenticity that deeply resonates with the audience.

Script and Themes The script, co-written by Coppola and Puzo, is a work of art in itself. It balances the complexity of organized crime with family dynamics, presenting a story that is both intimate and epic. The dialogues are sharp and memorable, filled with lines that have become part of cultural lexicon, like "I'll make him an offer he can't refuse."

The themes of "The Godfather" are universal and timeless. The film explores power and corruption, the cost of leadership and loyalty, and the struggle between family duty and personal ambition. These themes, presented with emotional depth and rich narrative, make the film transcend its genre to become a meditation on human nature and society.

Legacy As a lifelong fan of cinema, I can't overstate the impact "The Godfather" has had on popular culture and the film industry. It has influenced countless movies and TV series, setting a standard for crime and family stories. Its critical and commercial success, with multiple Academy Awards, is a testament to its enduring quality.

In summary, "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that combines visionary direction, exceptional performances, and an impeccable script to create a powerful and emotionally resonant narrative. It is a film that remains relevant and cherished, a true gem of the seventh art that continues to inspire generations of filmmakers and viewers. For anyone who loves cinema as much as I do, "The Godfather" is not just a movie-it's an experience, a benchmark, and a timeless classic.

title: Good ideas from the novel presented in an average way
description:
Another oddity in my collection, it is an overrated piece similar to 'Citizen Kane' and 'Schindler's List' although much more watchable I have to say. In the end there are too many ridiculous scenes and poor acting that undersells the overall arching plot.

Some strange things I have to ask within the first hour. Why does Don Corleone buy fruit in some craphole edge of the road stall? Why two oranges and a pepper? When the hitmen run towards him he does nothing to defend himself, yet he knows they are gunning for him. They shoot over 6 rounds into him and he, as an old man, survives and is placed into intrusive care?

What the hell writing is this? Or perhaps this is more a failing in direction from Francis Ford Coppola. Michael Corleone finds out his father was shot by walking around the street and finding a newspaper with something on it? What? Not a phone call or something that makes sense?

This is then followed by Sonny Corleone getting a phone call of the shooting. Why not Michael? What is going on there? Then Sonny writes a note with a pen on the kitchen cabinet door? What the hell? Not a piece of paper or just remember the facts, but he writes on the cabinet door?

This is awful. The script is nonsensical and the attention to irrelevant details is what boggles my mind. I think simple minded people think that is fascinating or something but it doesn't hold up the suspension of disbelief for me.

What I like from this film is the slow pace and burn. The conflict from the family turf war is gritty and well done. I love that David Chase, like many, took some inspiration from this movie and put a lot of details into 'The Sopranos'. But this movie itself is above average, well made, but full of plot holes and useless tat that could have been cut down to a tight film. The movie 'Goodfellas' has served more inspiration to filmmakers and popular culture than this title did.

Scenes such as the "Leave the gun, take the cannoli" one aren't as great as people claim. In this film it is just an afterthought that was captured on film. Nothing special in the way scenes like that were shot or presented, just bog average really.

The best part of this film is the transformation of Michael Corleone, it is good writing. But of course that came from the book, didn't it. This starts to get interesting at just before the hour mark. The murder scene is good but something is off about it. The wine cork pop is a joke, surely? The hit itself was well done, and showed at least how a hit should be done. But the bit of fanfare music is over the top and then a strange piano solo music to accompany the scenes thereafter? They use the garbage spinning newspaper montage like 'Citizen Kane' did, and it is lazy in my opinion.

Then plot then send Micahel off to Italy, which is ridiculous. The about turn in tone is off putting and thereafter I always lose interest. Somehow he gets married to an Italian girl and then becomes boss so suddenly. This is bad writing and happens too fast. Don Corleone in Italy running around with a small child in the tomatoes was ridiculous and over the top; stomping through the tomatoes like Goddzilla, then dies.

The end 30 minutes with Michael running things is again, over the top and ridiculous. He spent his whole life in school and the military, he knows jack diddly about the family and now they show him running everything on his own.

Whatever people say is great about this film, I question with more thought. It is not awful but it is certainly not a masterpiece. For gangster movies I prefer 'Goodfellas' and 'Casino', and of course 'The Sopranos' is the best written title ever created.

7/10 a good movie though nonsensical at times with above average filming.

title: Another Don' Roaming.
description:
Incoming hot take: It's good.

I watched "The Offer" a few weeks back and since then decided that it's high time that I watched "The Godfather" again, for the first time in what must be a couple of decades. It's a really perfect balance of interesting performances and a gripping story.

Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) turns down the opportunity to move his crime family into the lucrative narcotics business post-WW2. An attempt on his life leads to his hot-headed son, Sonny (James Caan) taking temporary control of the organisation whilst consiglieri Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall) tries to stop the escalation to all out war. Vito's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino) a decorated war hero, commits a murder on behalf of his brother and then heads to Italy to avoid retaliation.

You almost don't need to watch "The Godfather" again, so many of its lines, moments and scenes are iconic to all of pop culture that they are embedded in the consciousness. Brando is never quite as broad as the impressions make out to be, and though some lines are difficult to hear, there's a subtly to it that can be overlooked. It's mostly Michael's story though, as he rises to become the new Don from not being in the family business at all at the opening wedding. For me, this is still Al Pacino's best performance. Visually it's excellent, the score is another iconic aspect of the enterprise. It's just a great film. A perfect blend of commercial and artistic endeavours.

Being slightly more critical, it does introduce us to lots of characters and later refer to them by name only, eventually though these problems ease out and you learn who to focus on. John Cazale is slightly underutilised, but he would return for a bigger role in the sequel.

Speaking of, looking forward to rewatching that second film at some point soon.

title: Best movie ever!
description:
What more is there to say that hasn't been said? This is hands down my favorite movie of all time? "The Godfather" stands as an enduring testament to the power of storytelling and filmmaking. Widely regarded as the greatest movie of all time, this cinematic gem has transcended its genre, leaving an indelible mark on both the film industry and popular culture. Several elements contribute to its status as the pinnacle of cinematic achievement.

At the heart of the movie is a compelling narrative that unfolds with meticulous precision. Mario Puzo's source material, combined with Coppola's adept screenplay, weaves a tale of power, family, and betrayal. The film effortlessly navigates the complex dynamics of the Corleone crime family, delving into the intricacies of their relationships, both familial and criminal. The narrative unfolds in a series of interconnected events, creating a rich tapestry that captivates the audience from start to finish. Central to the film's success are its iconic characters, brought to life by an ensemble cast delivering career-defining performances. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is nothing short of legendary, a nuanced and powerful performance that earned him an Academy Award. Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader as Michael Corleone is a masterclass in character development. The ensemble, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and John Cazale, complements the leads, creating a memorable cast of characters that have become archetypes in cinematic history. The women in the film are very under-appreciated and deserve more recognition, including Simonetta Stefani as Apollonia, Diane Keaton as Kay-Addams Corleone, and Talia Shire as Connie Corleone. Coppola's directorial brilliance is evident in every frame of the film. The film's cinematography, led by Gordon Willis, is a visual symphony, employing a rich color palette and innovative techniques to evoke the mood and tone of each scene. The iconic use of shadows and low-lighting techniques adds a layer of sophistication, heightening the film's sense of drama. The wedding scene, with its dynamic ensemble cast, is a testament to Coppola's ability to orchestrate complex sequences with finesse. The hauntingly beautiful score composed by Nino Rota is a character in itself, evoking a sense of melancholy and foreboding. The main theme, synonymous with the film, has become synonymous with organized crime in popular culture. The music serves as an emotional anchor, heightening the impact of key moments and leaving an indelible imprint on the viewer's psyche. Beyond its critical acclaim, this has left an enduring impact on global culture. Phrases like "I'll make him an offer he can't refuse" have permeated everyday conversation. Other iconic films that people quote on a daily basis include "Look how they massacred my boy" which has become memed. The film's influence extends beyond the screen, shaping perceptions of organized crime and influencing subsequent generations of filmmakers. Beyond this movie being art, it is also a crowd-pleaser all thanks to its fast-pace even for drama standards. The movie makes sure it can be accessible to everyone and not just cinephiles. It has the rewatchability factor as well.

So overall, this is not merely a film, it is a cinematic opus that has stood the test of time. Its masterful storytelling, iconic characters, cinematic prowess, evocative score, and cultural impact collectively make it the quintessential movie experience. As it continues to be celebrated and studied, The Godfather remains an immortal masterpiece, rightfully earning its place as the best movie of all time.

title: Unquestioned masterpiece of 70's cinema
description: I am not going to get into extensive detail on how great this film is, hundreds if not thousands before me have already done so and to good credit. As a Hollywood director has once previously stated on another non-Godfather film commentary track, watching the film is a cinema class in of its self... if you are going to watch only one film in your life, it is this one. I must agree, I watch this film repeatedly, not only to be entertained but also to study as a filmmaker myself. Obviously the many directors who turned down the assignment to direct this adapted script had a strong moral objection to glorify the mafia, and I agree, there is absolutely "nothing" glamorous about real life gangsters in organized crime. But this is a fictional tale and Coppola used his own strong Italian American heritage to infuse the film with far greater themes and family bonding than any of the other directors originally approached would have done. He raised this film from the exploitative gangster flick that it was slotted to be by the studio, even wanting to change the novel's 1940's setting to modern day to save money on the budget, to that of Shakespearian levels and the best example of film art in Hollywood films. Coppola well deserved the Oscar, fame and the money that followed the film's release, in my opinion anyway. Perhaps it is because I saw this film as a youngster and accepted the film as is, as many others I watched, good and cheesy, but watching it even now there doesn't seem to be a single bad shot or angle in the entire film, except one.... Diane Keaton's false "double-take" reaction to the exploded vehicle in the back ground when she is confronted by Tom as she returns to the Mall to see Michael. It always takes me out of the film.

title: Best Movie
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather (1972) is not just a film-it's a cinematic landmark that redefined the gangster genre. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the film masterfully weaves a compelling narrative of power, family, and loyalty, set against the backdrop of organized crime in post-war America.

Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Don Vito Corleone, portraying the aging yet formidable patriarch of the Corleone family with gravitas and depth. Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, the reluctant son who is slowly drawn into the ruthless world of the mafia, is one of the finest character arcs in film history. His transformation from an idealistic war hero to a cold, calculating leader is both haunting and mesmerizing.

Every aspect of The Godfather is meticulously crafted, from its brilliant screenplay and deeply layered characters to its breathtaking cinematography by Gordon Willis. Nino Rota's haunting score perfectly complements the film's atmosphere, making each scene even more powerful. Coppola's direction ensures that the film is more than just a crime story-it's a profound exploration of family, morality, and the cost of power.

With unforgettable dialogue, intense drama, and some of the most memorable scenes in cinema history, The Godfather stands as a timeless masterpiece. Whether you're a first-time viewer or revisiting it for the hundredth time, its storytelling and performances remain just as compelling. A must-watch for any film enthusiast and a true testament to the art of filmmaking.

title: God Father
description: The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is an absolute cinematic masterpiece. This timeless classic has left an indelible mark on the film industry, captivating audiences with its intricate storytelling, impeccable performances, and unforgettable characters. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of legendary, while Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant heir to a ruthless mafia leader is a mesmerizing journey. The film's exquisite cinematography and haunting score further enhance its brilliance. "The Godfather" is not just a movie; it's an immersive experience that delves deep into the complex world of organized crime, making it an enduring gem in cinematic history.

title: amazing
description:
It is now past 1 PM and I just finished watching Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather". I should probably go to bed. It's late and tomorrow I have to wake up a bit early. But not early enough to postpone writing these lines. Now that I have seen it three times, the opportunity of sharing my thoughts and refreshed insights are too much of a good offer to sit on. So, bear with me.

This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.
