title: Just WOW !
description:
**Review of The Godfather**

The Godfather is an absolute triumph in cinematic storytelling and remains a cornerstone of film history. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, this masterpiece weaves a rich tapestry of family loyalty, power, and the complexities of the American Dream, all anchored by unforgettable characters and performances.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic, capturing the nuances of a patriarch who balances ruthlessness with deep familial love. Al Pacino's transformation from the reluctant Michael to a formidable force in the crime world is nothing short of mesmerizing. Each character is meticulously crafted, making the Corleone family both relatable and deeply compelling.

The film's cinematography is stunning, with its atmospheric lighting and meticulous attention to detail immersing viewers in the world of organized crime. Nino Rota's haunting score perfectly complements the narrative, enhancing the emotional depth and tension throughout.

What makes The Godfather truly remarkable is its exploration of morality and the consequences of choice. It invites viewers to reflect on the nature of power, loyalty, and sacrifice, leaving a lasting impression that resonates well beyond its runtime.

This film is a masterclass in filmmaking, showcasing exceptional writing, direction, and acting. It's a cinematic experience that demands to be seen and appreciated-truly a work of art that stands the test of time. If you haven't watched it yet, you're in for a profound journey into one of the greatest films ever made!

title: A Timeless Masterpiece
description:
The Godfather, released in 1972, stands as an undisputed classic in the realm of cinema, a mesmerizing portrayal of power, family, and the dark underbelly of organized crime. Directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's acclaimed novel, this cinematic masterpiece continues to captivate audiences and remains a benchmark for storytelling excellence.

Set in the post-World War II era, The Godfather unfolds the story of the Corleone crime family, led by the enigmatic and iconic Vito Corleone, portrayed flawlessly by Marlon Brando. The film delicately balances the intricate dynamics of the Corleone family, interweaving themes of loyalty, honor, betrayal, and the price of power.

The Godfather showcases the masterful craftsmanship of Francis Ford Coppola, who skillfully crafts a narrative that pulls the audience into the gripping world of organized crime. The pacing is deliberate, allowing the characters to breathe and evolve, and the script, co-written by Coppola and Mario Puzo, is a work of art, filled with memorable lines that have become an indelible part of popular culture.

The film's cast is a tour de force of acting talent. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is nothing short of mesmerizing, showcasing his ability to exude power and vulnerability simultaneously. Al Pacino's performance as Michael Corleone is a revelation, as he transforms from an innocent outsider to a ruthless leader consumed by his family's legacy. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, deliver exceptional performances that add depth and authenticity to the story.

Beyond its captivating performances, The Godfather is a visual feast. The cinematography, courtesy of Gordon Willis, paints a dark and brooding picture of a world where shadows hide secrets and violence lurks in the darkest corners. The film's iconic score by Nino Rota has become synonymous with the movie itself, elevating every scene and evoking a sense of both grandeur and impending doom.

What sets The Godfather apart from other crime dramas is its exploration of the themes of family and loyalty. Amidst the violence and corruption, the film delves into the moral complexities faced by its characters, questioning the extent to which they are willing to sacrifice their personal values for the sake of the family's survival.

The Godfather's influence on popular culture cannot be overstated. Its quotable lines, unforgettable characters, and powerful storytelling have left an indelible mark on cinema. Countless movies and TV shows have drawn inspiration from its narrative structure and iconic moments, but none have managed to replicate its magic.

title: A Masterpiece of Cinema Fifty years young =)
description:
I won't go into an in depth review of all the characters and plot lines etc. I'll keep it simple with just my immediate thoughts.

Spanning ten years from '45 through to '55 in post war America/Italy, The Godfather is a stunning masterpiece crime drama film and it's easy to see why it has cemented itself in the hearts of film buffs both young and old.

The centralization of the film is the Corleone family members and Coppola's direction is razor sharp. The entire film is masterfully shot from start to finish, death scenes are hard hitting and very impactful but never overdone. Acting and dialogue is superb from everybody. Brando's lines are a little hard to understand at times but he perfectly captures the image of an ageing Mafia boss.

Clocking in at almost three hours, it's a slow paced film but very engaging throughout. I enjoyed it so much it didn't feel like it was that long of a film. It feels like two hours, not three.

The 4K restoration makes this movie look truly fantastic. It looks like it's a movie made in the early 90's not the early 70's. I picked up the 50th anniversary box set in 4K and can't wait to watch Part 2 and Coda (Part 3). So great to have the full set of these three legendary films on the best format available.

The work of production designer Dean Tavoularis and costume designer Anna Hill Johnstone were very meticulous and truthful and created that impact of truthfulness that served as an indispensable support in the unraveling of the intertwining of a terrible and shocking but tender at the same time story, always exciting. A film that gives you something more at every new vision.

title: After the success of a new Top Gun movie and a new American Gigolo show, Paramount should think of a new Godfather movie or show!
description:
Is it even possible to still contribute something to the many glorious reviews that are already available?! I just do not know... This movie is perfect in so many aspects that it is ridiculous to say anything other than what everyone is already saying.

But wait... Maybe I can still contribute something! I personally loved the amazing performance of Marlon Brando in the role of Vito Corleone, a godfather in his 70's or 80's. To even realize that Marlon Brando was as old as I currently am, just makes me appreciate what a difficult task he was faced with.

The cool thing that I learnt is that the dentist of Marlon Brando even had a special mouthpiece made that brought his chin forward. Together with the very recognizable voice of Vito Corleone, it is this combination that contributes to making this movie iconic. Who hasn't ever tried to mimic the voice of the godfather?!

This 50-year old movie still stands at the top of the list of "best movies ever made". And rightfully so! I have watched this movie already several times in my life, and each time I enjoyed watching it.

And of course it isn't too surprising that I give this movie a 10-star rating. Anything less than a perfect score would be an insult!

It is remarkable that after 50 years - I write this in 2022 - Paramount still hasn't decided to make other movies that fit the "Godfather"-franchise. I can think only of the 3 movies that were released. But who knows... Seeing that Paramount just released a show based on the 1980's movie "American Gigolo" and another movie based on "Top Gun" makes me think that we may possibly see another Godfather show or movie! The question will then be how close it can come to the quality of the original Godfather trilogy.

title: Good one
description: With several million hardcover and paperback books acting as trailers, Paramount's film version of Mario Puzo's sprawling gangland novel, "The Godfather," has a large pre-sold audience. This will bolster the potential for the film which has an outstanding performance by Al Pacino and a strong characterization by Marlon Brando in title role. It also has excellent production values, flashes of excitement, and a well-picked cast. But it is also overlong at about 175 minutes (played without intermission), and occasionally confusing. While never so placid as to be boring, it is never so gripping as to be superior screen drama. This should not mar Paramount's b.o. expectations in any measure, though some filmgoers may be disappointed.

title: Not a masterpiece
description: This movie is one of the most famous in the history of cinema, but I can't see the reasons. It's true that Marlon Brando plays like a god and that Al Pacino begins to show why he is one of the best living actors... but there are too many dialogues that choke the breath of the movie. There are also some "holes" in the screenplay: for instance, why do we see one of the Godfather's sons (Al Pacino) first like a shy guy and then like a determined and blood-thirsty beast? Only because they killed his sicilian wife that he forgets soon to marry another girl? The direction of Coppola is flat: I don't like the way he just throws away the "crescendo" of some thrilling scenes and the way he doesn't emphasized the story. Besides after some killings we get to know their ways, so the last killings are "phoned"... we exactly know what is going to happen and so the surprise goes wasted. Only in the final Coppola succeeds in finding a beautiful alternated editing where he shows the deep contradictions of the members of the Mafia: Michael Corleone is in a Church where he swears to renounce the Devil and in the meanwhile his men are making a massacre. So: a good film but not a masterpiece as many people think.

title: Greatest movie of all time
description: What more can be said that already has on this utter masterpiece of a movie. Along with part 2, these are my favourite films of all time and I personally don't think there will ever be a movie that will surpass these stunning pieces of work. Let's start with part 1, The Godfather. An outstanding achievement in American cinema following Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, Francis F Coppola directs and achieved such a stunning piece of work, it's pretty much as close to perfection as a movie can get. It follows the story of an Italian American crime family, and is based on the real life Five families of New York City during this era, but is superbly paced and developed in such stunning fashion, you literally feel you are there with them in the screen. The character development is outstanding and we grow to love these characters like they are own family. The cinematography world class and still hasn't been beaten to this day. Who can ever forget the beautiful brown contrast colours that dominate when you are engrossed in this piece of art. The music without saying is up there amongst the finest piece in movie history. It's a film that still holds up, despite it being made nearly 50 years ago. It put actors like Al Pacino on the map to true stardom. If you haven't seen the Godfather then you clearly don't appreciate good movies. The greatest film of all time.

Although this film has a three-act structure, all the acts are well packed with content. And so the film is watched in one breath. And most importantly, what message ... Each person has the right to decide for himself what meaning was laid down by the author.

title: incredile
description: I was roughly twenty years away from even being conceived when The Godfather came out. Growing up as a film nut, I often heard of The Godfather as possessing a sort of mythic status that few films made after 1955 possess. I first watched it back close to ten years ago as a 12-year-old, never fully getting the story with the film falling into the "great film that I didn't appreciate" category until a month or so back when I got the Coppola restoration Blu-Ray and realized as an adult how fantastic of a film it truly was. The Godfather works so well because it isn't a film that kisses its ass on a variety of sub-levels. Francis Ford Coppola went out of his way not to make the film one that glorifies the Mafia in any way but still realized what a magnificent project it was. It begins in celebration and ends as the first part of the trilogy in bitter-sweet victory and tragedy for the Corleones with Michael having slowly morphed into a different character by the end and the Corleone family itself has endured tragedy after tragedy. Depending on if you're selective to certain genres of movies -- particularly crime and heist thrillers -- the 1970s were either a fantastic time with the New Hollywood group of directors or a pitiful time where the Anti-Hero was all the rage. I've always tried to keep a foot in both camps for the most part, but if a film like this doesn't make you at least sit there as the credits roll, musing in thought like Indiana Jones after being given a clue by a recently-killed shaman or anti-Nazi spy the first time you watch it, then I'm not sure you know how to appreciate films and movies as art and not just entertainment. There are so many ways this film just works so well; the first is that Coppola always had a way of making the cinematography and direction style look both extravagant, but also bleak at the same time, partially through sun-faded cinematography (I'm just guessing) and also partially through the way the film itself was shot. As well fact that Coppola spared nothing when it came to deploying talented screen stars of the day to cast The Godfather, leading Marlon Brando to find international success once more with his portrayal of Vito Corleone, Al Pacino as the reluctant, but the eventual successor to his father Vito, Michael Corleone, Diane Keaton as Kay Adams, Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, and of course, a pre-Rocky Talia Shire as Connie Corleone. These cast members in particular stand out in their performances and convey a sort of detached emotion that makes the film so great (if you need clarification on this, the scene where Vito overlooks his own son's body in the morgue is a prime example). Although it is the best install installment Godfather trilogy, the film itself suffers from a few key points that I've never been able to reason out why were included. Specifically, the whole sequence involves Johnny Fontaine and the Woltz horse fiasco which has no real involvement in the over-arcing storyline. However, with how spectacular of a film it is, I'm not going to sit here and complain about it any further.

2. Clothes ditto.

title: **** (Out of four)
description:
"The Godfather" is one of the crossroads one must cross before proclaiming oneself a movie fan and a genuine movie buff. Francis Ford Coppola's film is probably his most flawless, although it is NOT my favorite Coppola film (that honor belongs to the unmistakably problematic but highly visionary "Apocalypse Now"). Still, in the midst of a 90s cinema which seems to re-evalutate itself every five years or so with new computer-generated images and thusly cannot enjoy the same degree of timelessness of several earlier, better movies, "The Godfather" will undoubtedly hold its own as one of the most artistic endeavors in the relatively new medium of cinema.

The story has been told many times before: based on Mario Puzo's bestseller, the film examines the aura of the Italian Mafiosi as exemplified through the Corleone family, led by patriarch Vito (Marlon Brando, an Oscar winner in a very professional bit of acting). WWII-hero Michael (Al Pacino--the real star of the film as well as the real Best Actor of that year) comes home and breaks family tradition at his sister Connie's wedding ceremony not only by wearing his military uniform, but introducing his family to his WASP-ish girlfriend Kay Adams (Diane Keaton), the epitome of modernistic feminine and Protestant intentions in the Corleone's traditional Catholic--and increasingly outdated--worldview. The wedding scene is one of the great expositions of cinema, and yet the film lives up to all expectations by dashing us headlong into the Corleone's violent world. Of course who can forget the severed horse head in the mansion of the luxurious Hollywood producer, the murder of Luca Brasi, "sleeping with the fishes", Santino's bloody murder at the toll booth, Brando's death scene, the intercutting between the baptism and the murders, and especially the final scene as the door closes and Kay realizes the deceit her entire life will become? To launch into a detailed discussion of Coppola's masterly filmmaking would take beyond 1000 words, so let me just echo the comments of many when saying "The Godfather" is that priceless canoli one should always cherish amidst the decaying corpses of escalating Hollywood trash.

title: Great Movie!

title: pure genius
description:
`The Godfather' is quite possibly one of the best movies made in history. This film has been quoted/mimicked time and time again, even in a Rugrats (the famous children's cartoon) episode. Why would this movie be quoted so much if it wasn't so amazing? It wouldn't be. All the hype made about this movie really isn't understood until you actually watch the film. It's a classic that can't be described.

I suppose it's illustriousness could be arguable either way, but most viewers find this movie riveting and engaging. One could understand how someone could find this movie dry, especially in the beginning. If you're not familiar with the plot at all, many things could be missed the first time around. It starts out at his daughters wedding, and from there, all the events can easily run together and cause a vast amount of confusion within the viewer. If you stick to it, promises are that the movie does get betterimmensely.

There isn't one single thing that makes this movie so remarkable. It could be that it had a spectacular cast, intriguing plot, and very realistic situations. Or, it could be that this movie has what any great story has, a huge change in the main character. Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) is by far one of the most interesting characters through the movie. You watch every step of his moves, thoughts, actions and you see him evolve into the person his father tried so hard to keep him away from. The actual scene where he makes his huge jump could be argued, but it is often believed that this change took place at the hospital. This was his first opportunity to take charge of the `family business.'

Many details, sentences, phrases could go into this review to describe the movie. But, words could never really fill all of the emotions that you experience during this film. Out of all the classic films I've seen, this is by far the most captivating I've experienced. This film isn't recommended for smaller children, one because they wouldn't be able to comprehend as well as early adults would, and two, because there are some things that may be found offensive to a younger crowd. All in all, this movie receives a 10/10 stars for pure genius.

title: The GodMovie
description:
The Godfather it is an adaptation of Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo, taking as its main theme the Mafia Italian. The story portrays the "family" of mobsters Italo-American in the city of New York, known for Corleone surname, being Vito Andolini Corleone (Marlon Brando) their patriarch and the head of the family.

In his excellent acting, Marlon Brando, in fact devoted his career as an actor and had the best actor Oscar. And it was not only him, Al Pacino really showed the brilliant actor he is, and showed his performance to the world. The film grossed an estimated US $245,066,411, winning 3 Oscars: Best Writing, Screenplay Based on Material from Another Medium, Best Actor in a Leading Role and the last Best Picture. And among many other awards.

The Godfather portrays the life of the Corleone family, who lived and ran New York, there are also other 4 families beyond this that commanded their respective areas, so one could not intervene on the other. Between business and crime, there the loyalty and mutual respect between family members and with the other, as these were the main slogans of the Mafia. Once they became members family, would be treated with respect and loyalty, if there were treachery or disrespect or conflict of ideals with another member or family, this or the whole family would pay with his own life, as happens in many cases portrayed in the film.

title: A must-see for any movie lover!
description: The Godfather (1972) is an intricate yet compelling story about the Corleone family who is involved with the Italian mafia in New York in the 1940's. This movie shows the revenge, greed, and betrayal, between the Corleones and the mafia. Marlon Brando does a superb job playing the godfather who is the leader of the mafia, or Vito as they call him. His character gives one insight to what the mafia really is about and the business deals among them. Other actors such as Al Pacino and James Caan also portray their characters Michael and Sonny as the sons of the godfather very well too. Michael at the beginning of the movie has no interest in being involved in the mafia and by the end he has taken over the family business. People get to see first hand the transformation of these characters from beginning to the end of the movie. The story line makes this movie much more fascinating yet harder to follow than your average movie. Each scene that takes place in the movie is essential to understanding and delving in even deeper into the history of the Corleones and their involvement with the mafia. The great acting, excellent dialogue, and an ever-changing plot is what sets this movie apart from the rest. I recommend this movie to any movie fanatic. The Godfather is more aimed towards older teens and adults because of the complicated storyline and the violence shown.

title: One of the all time greatest and a unforgettable masterpiece.
description:
The Godfather was in 1973 a masterpiece and it still is and always will be. This movie is rightly considered one of the greatest films ever made.

The Godfather continues to influence producers of films, television shows, and video games more than 45 years after its release. This movie has become a huge part of popular culture. Nino Rota's score, the sumptuous set design, and Brando's raspy pseudo-whisper have become part of our collective cultural memory. I can watch it over and over again with great pleasure....

title: The Godfather is a masterpiece that will hold up for many years, brilliant storytelling and a true classic
description:
The Godfather is directed by Francis Ford Coppola, who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo and it's based on Puzo's best-selling novel of the same name. Why is this film regarded as a classic and of course among of the best films in history? It's an three hour ride of cinema of some of the finest written, finest acted, finest cinematography, finest editing, the remarkable musical score by Nino Rota and of course the brilliance that is Francis Ford Coppola. He created a masterpiece but bear in mind, though it is a movie everyone should watch, the slow pace and long length might turn some people off but if you bear with the slow pace then you will absolutely love the film. For being released in 1972 it was a very violent film. It's also full of symbolism which makes a second or third viewing so much more fun as there's so many details the director placed into its many scenes.

The Godfather is the first installment in The Godfather trilogy. Spanning from 1945 to 1955, it chronicles the Corleone Crime Family under patriarch Vito Corleone, focusing on the transformation of his youngest son, Michael Corleone, from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss. There's a huge cast playing these well written characters, also some big names who're playing them. Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone, Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, James Caan as Sonny Corleone, Richard Castellano as Peter Clemenza: a caporegime in the Corleone crime family, Sonny's godfather, Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen: consigliere, lawyer and unofficial adopted member of the Corleone family, John Cazale as Fredo Corleone, Talia Shire as Connie Corleone, Diane Keaton as Kay Adams: Michael's girlfriend and, later, second wife, Richard Conte as Emilio "The Wolf" Barzini: a crime boss of a rival crime family, Al Lettieri as Virgil "The Turk" Sollozzo: an adversary who pressures Vito to get into the drug business, backed by the Tattaglia family. As you see, there are a lot of characters and everyone is extremely well written and some even based on real people. The whole portrayal of the mafia is extremely well done and I'm glad they did the research. Each character has a meaning to the story and there's some terrific performances in each scene you watch. Thanks to Coppola's request approximately 90 percent was shot in New York City and its surrounding suburbs, using over 120 distinct locations. The remaining portions were filmed in California, or on-site in Sicily. Shooting on authentic locations made everything so much more realistic and immersive, Francis Ford Coppola used that to tell the story he wanted to tell, and I think it helped a lot for the actors and look for the film.

Marlon Brando's performance as Vito Corleone is truly and I mean this, among the best performances I have ever seen in my life, I didn't really find it to be the best on my first viewing but now... Just wow. He deserved that Oscar, without a doubt. Al Pacino is also great, truly terrific but in comparison to his performance in The Godfather Part 2, it's not as great as it's literally hard to top that. Though Brando and Pacino deliver some of cinema's best performances, there are still a lot of others who does some impressive acting performances, one of them being Robert Duvall who are among my favorite actors. Along with Marlon Brando, he and Duvall wear some serious make-up and prosthetics that make them almost unrecognizable. Everyone in the cast does a great job with showing emotion through the use of the facial expressions and I love that, I can't name everyone but it's an incredible ensemble cast.

The film won the Oscars for Best Picture, Best Actor (Brando), and Best Adapted Screenplay (for Puzo and Coppola). In addition, the seven other Oscar nominations included Pacino, Caan, and Duvall for Best Supporting Actor, and Coppola for Best Director. Since its release, The Godfather has been widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential films ever made, especially in the gangster genre. I'll agree fully with that as after rewatching this film for the second time I can only say how beautifully and brilliantly told it is, highest quality of storytelling and visual storytelling. The first time I watched it was in 2015 I believe and I loved it then, and absolute liked it a lot more the second time, it's a mesmerizing and literally breathtaking 3 hours.

title: Under Duress
description: First saw this film back in Sydney in the early seventies. Had a certain kudos then as it was a groundbreaking film of its sort. Or so the story goes! Watched it on BBC i player as there was nothing else at all in the film catalogue. Main observations after all these decades. In the signature and most memorable moment in the whole 3 hours plus (snooze), I would love to know how the mafia goon managed to get the enormous horses head in the bed without the director in it waking up. Apologies if IMDb have already noted this ludicrous goof in the list of goofs. It was a completely lame scene if you will forgive the pun Marlon Brando seems to be having trouble with vocal clarity and was slurring his way throughout the film. Maybe hitting the Sicilian wine a little hard? All in all, including the mammoth length of the movie, no satisfactory end. Of course it was groundbreaking possibly for this reason and this reason alone. They were laying the foundation for a franchise of Godfathers. Something the film industry in the twentieth first century have taken to the max.

title: The film that made us all an offer we couldn't refuse
description:
If there's one film for which the phrase "best ever made" seems like a massive understatement, it's The Godfather. This film is pretty much as close to cinematic perfection as you can possibly get. From the very first moments, with its beautiful theme playing on trumpets, it hooks you and doesn't let go for the next three hours. The opening is possibly the best I've ever seen: the first thirty minutes does an incredible job of establishing the setting, characters, and plot points, major and minor, all through dialogue and interactions. From there, it's a roller coaster of exceptional storytelling and character development that's endlessly captivating. And at its heart is the story of one man's rise to power coupled with the start of his fall from grace. Michael starts out as an honest man who wants nothing to do with the family business. But, as their enemies move in on them, he gets roped into that world in the worst way. After seeing the ugliness therein, he makes plans to make the family legitimate, but starts to go too far in his methods of doing so, starting a downward spiral that only gets worse as the series progresses. It's a brilliant character arc that I could probably talk for hours about.

It's astonishing to think that Marlon Brando had to fight to be allowed to even be in this movie, because he was truly born for it. He doesn't just play Vito Corleone, he is Vito Corleone, giving him a humble, gentle, yet subtly threatening performance that's easily one of, if not the best, acting job I have ever seen. Al Pacino, a personal favorite, excels as Michael, perfectly showcasing his growth as a character. The later scenes in particular are where he truly shines; all he needs to do is flash that signature glare of his and you know there's trouble waiting. James Caan really should have won the Oscar for his incredible performance. And the rest of the cast is fantastic too. What really makes the performances work, at least in regards of the actors who play the Corleones, is that they truly feel like a genuine family, in more ways than one.

From the opening pan out of the old man telling the Don his story to the final shot of Diane Keaton's disturbed look at what her husband's become, Francis Ford Coppola's direction is absolutely incredible. Every scene, every shot, every edit instantly grabs your attention and leaves you wondering what will happen next. The film is chock full of memorable moments, catchy music, and endlessly quotable dialogue. And it all leads up to a scene that still gives me chills every time I watch this film: the baptism scene. The music, the editing, the buildup and payoff, and the juxtaposition of this sacred ritual against all the horrors being committed at the same time make for a scene that's absolutely flawless and easily a top ten favorite. For the record, I actually got to see this film in theaters a couple of years ago for its fiftieth anniversary, and it was beyond worth the price of admission.

Overall, I think I've more than said all I needed to say about The Godfather. It's without a doubt one of my all time favorite movies, well deserving of its legendary status and I truly can't recommend it enough.

title: Believe the hype.
description: I remember when I was about 13 when I first watched the Godfather. I turned it off after half an hour. Three years later one of my friends had it on video. At first I was reluctant to watch it, but I became entranced by what I saw. Not only did it contain probably the best ensemble cast I have ever seen(Brando, Pacino, Duvall, Caan, Keaton and Shire), but it is also one of the greatest stories in modern cinema. The predominant theme in this film is not violence or power as some might say it is, but family. Without giving the film away, the most moving and evocative parts of the film are when the members of the family are involved. I must admit I have not seen a great deal of Brando's work (Apart from 'Apocalypse Now'), but he deserved an Oscar here, for one of the greatest performances of our time. Caan, as the explosive 'Sonny' should have got 'Best Supporting Actor' too, as well as other magnificent performances by Pacino as Michael, and Duvall as Tom. Watch this film, you will NOT be disappointed. The greatest film ever? Probably-a definite 10.

title: An all-time classic!
description:
There are simply no words to express how great this film truly is! How can one still watch this film made in 1972 today?

Very few films are able to achieve what the Godfather did, most aspiring actors look up to this movie as an inspiration and attempt to do what each actor was able to do in this film.

The movie is simply timeless and a huge reason why Al Pacino became a huge star. It is almost impossible to find any shortcomings in the film as all the performances were extremely organic and rarely felt scripted.

Last but certainly not the least, thank you to Marlon Brando, who did not just give us one of the most iconic movie posters of all-time but also hooked you to the screen whenever he came on and embodied the role of an aged mafia don with the utmost conviction.

A masterpiece of cinema, this.

title: Excellence
description:
The Godfather—Masterpiece. Watched this movie the other day and was surprised how good it is. Quite possibly the best movie I've ever seen. This is what happens when you have excellent writing, superb directing, great acting, and the right sound track.

This is a story about family, set to the backdrop of the Mafia. More than anything else, it is about the ascension of Michael Corleone, from WWII hero into the ruthless world of organized crime. Brando was certainly deserving of his Oscar, but Al and Francis should have won one as well.

It's the only movie I've seen where every scene matters and every scene is memorable. Probably too violent for some, but is definitely on my list of 10 movies everyone should see.

Way to go Francis!

title: nice movie
description: The Godfather, the first film in the franchise, was released on March 15, 1972. The feature-length film was directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based upon Mario Puzo's novel of the same name. The plot begins with Don Vito Corleone declining an offer to join in the narcotics business with notorious drug lord Virgil Sollozzo, which leads to an assassination attempt. Meanwhile, Vito's oldest son Sonny takes over the family and Michael strikes back for the assassination attempt by killing Sollozzo and a corrupted police captain, forcing Michael to go to Sicily in hiding. While in Sicily, Michael travels around the country and meets a young woman whom he marries, but who is eventually killed in a car bombing. Michael returns to America after the news of his brother Sonny's murder. After returning, Vito turns over the reins of the family to Michael. Michael plans to move the family business to Las Vegas; but before the move, he plots the killing of the heads of the five families on the day of his nephew's baptism. Other subplots include Vito's daughter's abusive marriage, Johnny Fontaine's success in Hollywood, and Vito's second oldest son Fredo's role in the family business in Las Vegas.

title: Hey
description:
I try to find an old animation movie that I watched as a kid on TV in the 90s (it could be older) and made an enduring impression on me. I remember the ending most vividly: a bloody battle on the top of a hill where two armies clashed, apparently led by a man and a woman inside cyborgs or some kind of robotic vehicle. These two seemed to share a history (fling?? / siblings??) and confronted each other beside a nearby river. They both died. The movie ended tragically with a shot of the great tree on the top of the hill, surrounded by corpses of both armies..

The only other thing I recall is a young man and a woman that spent the night in a house and in the morning the woman transformed in a butterfly and flew away. The man tried to catch her but without success. The butterflies (souls??) seemed central to the movie.

It was all very depressing (as you can imagine :-P) but it was so powerful animation that stuck to my head for years! I tried to find it in IMDb, google and anime sites through keywords but to no avail. It seemed to be Japanese animation but I cannot be sure..

title: An offer you can't refuse

One of the jewels in the crown of the 70s cinema, The Godfather tells the story of the Corleone family. Itialian immigrants, caring people, and mafioso. From the first frame in which you see Marlon Brando's face lit from in front and above like a dark angel to the last frame of the last film in which Al Pacino's wineglass falls out of his hand as he slumps, the family gone and destroyed.

The Godfather is the holy trinity of mob films. Every film after it has its influences in it, and, much like some people look towards the Star Wars trilogy for an answer to every question, many people do so for The Godfather.

title: The Godfather is in no short supply of action and suspense.
description:
The Godfather

Smart. That's how I describe `The Godfather'. Every aspect of this film is dripping with intellect. The directing, the writing, the cinematography, and the acting. And all the elements of the film are woven tightly together to make a very entertaining package. The intricate plot follows the development of Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) and the enthralling drama that pursues his `family'. The script does the impossible task of capturing the complex politics of organized crime, and makes it interesting to boot. The plot leads the audience along its windy path where it comes across many peaks until it finally builds to the fantastic finale. To achieve this famous finish, the director employs the use of some pretty clever technical tricks. To achieve suspense, he cleverly places the camera at angles that leads the audience one way, until he surprises them with the real result later on. He also infuses the sound of the church organ music and the crying baby, and then gradually increases the decibels subtly and effectively. That technique pulled the viewers in and made their knuckles white during the climax of the film. The director was skillful in his mastery of all the film's techniques and in getting what he needed from the actors. This strong cast of cast of actors included Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, and James Conn. Each actor portrayed their characters profoundly. Marlon Brando executed method acting techniques in a way that only a veteran like Marlon could. Al Pacino clearly shows his character (Michael Corleone) grow and change. His acting is subtle, confident and quiet until it explodes in an awesome rage. Michael Corleone is much like the entire movie. `The Godfather' is subtle and complex, and it builds to the memorable finish. `The Godfather' stimulates the mind and starts the blood and adrenaline pumping in anyone who watches it. That is why I recommend this beautiful masterpiece to anyone and everyone with a thirst for quality film.

title: Pure brilliance, cinema at it's best.
description:
Have you ever wanted to watch a movie with decency and class, with elegance and stature. If so, then this is it. The Godfather provides the audience with stunning acting, dialogue and memorable scenes.

The acting is phenomenal, with Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan and John Cazale all putting forward Oscar worthy performances.

The story is brilliant, director Francis Ford Coppola really put a lot of thought into this and the way the story is shown, it never loses interest, even though the film is two and a half hours long. If you stay focused, you stay amazed.

If the acting and plot weren't good enough, be prepared to be blown away by the classic theme for this movie, the way it is put into the scenes really adds to he grand stature of the movie.

It's a 10/10 and a definite watch for movie lovers with a good taste.

title: GOAT!
description:
Perfect movie does not exist.

Godfather : Hold my wine!

title: GREATEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME
description: Impressive. The Godfather is a more important film, of course it is. But The Godfather Part II is a better film. It's more ambitious, it's more elegiac, it delves deeper into the soil of Italian-American myth, plus... what were they thinking of, trying to match the critical and commercial dynamite of the first film? The Godfather Part II was, from conception upwards, an insane project. But it worked. When I watched this movie I was amazed that how Robert de Niro nailed the role of Don Vito Corleone. It could be a pressure for any actor to play a role of it has been played by a famous and good actor before. And most problem to play younger Don was that it was played by the god of cinema: Marlon Brando.

title: Masterpiece
description:
Unbelievable as it may sound, the first time I watched The Godfather I got too tired and we stopped the tape. After that I didn't forgive myself until I finally decided to rent it again. The second time around I made it to the end and I loved it. Of all the movies I've watched, I feel that this one has had the biggest impact on me. To me, being allowed to watch The Godfather is a gift. It's more than just watching a great movie: It's like observing a timeless piece of art by Leonardo Da Vinci.

The Godfather is a movie that tells the touching and invincible tail of the Corleones, an Italian family living in New York that is involved in the mafia affairs in the city. A drug lord named Virgil Sollozzo wants to start shipping drugs all over New York and asks Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) to help him with his affairs. Corleone does not approve of the idea and would rather stick to his own business. Angry with the rejection, Sollozzo sends two of his thugs try to kill him, but he survives. Michael (Al Pacino), the youngest of all the sons, wants to be the man to protect his father, although the other members of the family don't want him caught up in the affair. The plot rises in levels of drama and thrills as the film goes on, and it just gets better and better. Most of the scenes easily stand out as some of the greatest moments in movie history, such as:

The beginning. What else? No one could ever forget the thought provoking scenes with Brando stroking his cat and negotiating with his close friends and relatives.

Michael's assassination of the cop and Sollozzo at a small diner.

Michael being named the new godfather.

The killings of family enemies during the baptism.

Of course, these are not the only fantastic scenes in the movie. The Godfather also has an A++ cast, like almost everyone who has watched it will tell you. It practically made the careers of Francis Ford Coppola, James Caan, Robert Duvall, and of course, Al Pacino. Best of all, it has Marlon Brando at what could be his finest (I still haven't seen Apocalypse Now). I know it's been said many times, but I'll add my two cents anyway by saying that The Godfather is a classic and is pretty much flawless.

***** out of *****

title: Absolutely magnificent
description:
The Godfather is one of the most important masterpieces in the history of cinema. The film takes the audience on a deep journey with a family drama story set in the mafia world, while also dealing with universal themes such as power, loyalty, betrayal and family ties.

Through the lives of Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) and his son Michael (Al Pacino), the moral contradictions experienced at the intersection of crime and family love are emphasized. Brando's performance perfectly reflects the depth and power of the character, making him one of the most iconic figures in the history of cinema. Al Pacino's transformation in the role of Michael Corleone deeply affects the audience. While dark shadows and slow motions create tension and dramatic intensity throughout the film, the music also strengthens the atmosphere.

The Godfather is not only a crime story, but also a narrative that questions the complexity of human nature, traces social and individual power and becomes universal over time.

In the world of cinema, this masterpiece continues to become more valuable with each passing year.

title: Greatest Mob oriented movie ever made

By the time the movie ends you are rooting for the "bad guys", the Corleone family. Other great movies such as Goodfellas, Casino, Bugsey etc. are good, fun and entertaining, these latter movies show the lower level mobster, whereas the Godfather shows what life is like if you are on the top of the syndicate ladder. Keep in mind that as great as this movie is in real life the mob's retirement plan isn't all that great!!

Al Pacino shines above all in this movie, as the smart boy of the family he returns after fighting a war for his country, at that time not involved in the family business, but it doesn't take long before the war breaks lose and he see no other ways than to step in and fight for his family. This is definitely a masterpiece.

title: The Goofather!! Classic movie
description:
The godfather trilogy is an exclusive set of movies that will continue to live with humanity, every generation will see them to say, "Oh that was 10 out of 10." If you watch them you will know that the world that lives inside the underworld is same as the one we live in except that people in underworld are so smart, in fact smartness is the only thing that can keep them there. Don Vito Caroleone's early life shown in part-II is very well done to show the Don in making, how a kid who couldn't even tell his name went on becoming a underworld don who keep most senators, judges and lawyers in his pocket. Meeting of don with the so call five families are among most impressive scenes.

A saga that goes on for 9 continuous hours takes you around various walks in life of Mike (Don's younger son who become Don later), his school days, love life, personal life, family life, business life, political life and religious life. How all of these different roles Mike plays in his life and how intertwined these are.

I enjoyed watching these movies so much, I wish I had seen them much before then I did. Its amazing to see how the Part-III was made 18 years later the part-I was made and everything looks so continuous if watch them together.

I need not say much! The Godfather father trilogy been around for a while and everyone knows that they are great set of movies, its just the matter of when you actually get to see them.

Watch them! Kudos to Francis Ford Coppola! -Nathan Rudd Actor

title: The Godfather: A Timeless Masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is more than a movie; it's a cultural touchstone. It has influenced countless filmmakers, spawning a legacy that extends far beyond its own runtime. As a 38-year-old movie lover, I can confidently say that "The Godfather" remains a timeless masterpiece that continues to inspire and resonate with each viewing. If you haven't experienced this cinematic gem yet, it's high time you did. It's not just a film; it's an unforgettable journey into the heart of darkness and the human soul.

What truly sets "The Godfather" apart is its ability to transcend its crime drama label. It's not merely a story about gangsters; it's a meditation on power, morality, and the American dream. It challenges our notions of right and wrong, blurring the lines between hero and antihero. The film's universal themes make it accessible and relatable to audiences of all backgrounds and generations.

title: Blockbuster
description:
A masterclass in film making, is The Godfather a contender for the best film of all time? I'd argue the case that it is, this is the ultimate gangster movie.

Before you panic at the thought of a film being almost three hours long, you needn't, you won't even notice the time, it flies by.

Production values are incredible, it looks sublime the whole way through, it's so well produced, at roughly fifty years old it puts many new films to shame.

Brandon, Pacino and Castellano, just a few of the Incredible performances, I could add a whole lot more.

If you're considering buying a hard copy, I would recommend it on blu ray, it is sharper than the dvd, there is a difference.

This film has had a huge influence down the years, it is still, and will forever be, one of the greatest, 10/10. A masterclass in film making, is The Godfather a contender for the best film of all time? I'd argue the case that it is, this is the ultimate gangster movie.

title: A superb, yet confusing movie
description:
"The Godfather" is an extremely well known movie and one that

this reviewer just recently saw for the first time. There is a lot of

talk about it being the best movie ever made but honestly, there

are other movies that could be better. The cast was made up of

some pretty famous actors and they all did marvelous acting jobs.

The movie definitely wasn't lacking in that area. It was a big

attention getter in the way that there could be a scene where the

actors would be talking and talking, which isn't too exciting, and

then soon after it would be like "BAM!" and there was action. It

would certainly wake up anyone in the audience who might have

been dozing off. All in all, the movie didn't have too much talk, or

too much action, it was just the right amount of both.

It did have a superflous amount of special effects though, most

being gun shots and explosions. Considering the fact that the

movie is about the life of a crime family, the enormous amount of

killing that there is throughout the film isn't too suprising. Maybe a

little disturbing, but not suprisng. This reviewer has never seen a

movie with as much killing as "The Godfather." It was like

someone was killed from this family, so they killed the person who

did the killing. Then that family killed the person who killed their

family member and it went on like that back and forth and back and

forth, if that even makes sense. It was like an argument. Person #

1 says something to person # 2, so person #2 says something

back to person #1 and so on and so on. There was just an

excessive amount of killing. In fact, all the killing is sort of the thing

that the viewer might remember the most about "The Godfather." This movie does something that a lot of movies dare not do. It lets

some main characters die. That is probably the most unpredictable aspect of the entire movie. When people watch

movies they don't expect any main characters to die and they rarely

ever do. The fact that "The Godfather" does this, although it is

sad, is stupendous. The plot of the movie revolves around the crime family, Corleone.

It basically follows their lives during a certain period of time. What

that period of time is, this reviewer does not exactly know. In most

movies, when there has been a big time difference they say at the

bottom of the screen, "one year later" or something like that. "The

Godfather" does not do that. Instead of putting the time change

into words at the bottom of the screen it's put into words that the

actors say. It makes it so the audience has to listen very closely to

the movie to hear how long its been since something happened.

This reveiwer thinks that this is done because when words are put

at the bottom of the screen, like subtitles, it distracts the viewer's

attention away from the movie and what is going on. In "The

Godfather" there is not this problem. The clothing worn in the movie wasn't anything like big, fancy

costumes, but there was something about them that was quite

interesting. If the viewer was really paying attention to the actors'

outfits they would notice that the men are always wearing some

type of suit. They're never caught walking around in casual wear,

just suits. And the women are always wearing dresses. They

don't wear pants with t-shirts, they wear dresses. Tha'ts pretty

grand if you ask me. "The Godfather" was a very superb movie, but there are others that

are better. It's worst feature is the enormous amount of killing. It

is entertaining to watch, but it's not one that this reviewer would

want to watch over and over again.

title: The Godfather is like a perfectly painted fruit bowl
description:
A painted fruit bowl will not make you cry. It won't make you terrified. It's not romantic either and it won't change your mind on what you already thought about fruits. Yet it can still be a masterfully painted fruit bowl where al the fruits are beautifully portrayed by the artist the way they are. The Godfather is such a movie.

Just like most fruit bowl paintings, you wouldn't know if you had to root for the apple or the grapes. And during the entire movie you already know the fruits only have 2 possible outcomes: getting eaten or getting rot. I could go on with my analogy but I think you get the point. (edit: I will go on anyway)

Will you like this film? Well, some people will stand in front of a perfectly painted fruit bowl for 5 minutes and become utterly bored because of the subject. Others can stand there for days being amazed by the details on the apple, and discovers new perfections every time they are watching the painting.

There is no good or wrong here. Everyone has their personal taste. After watching The Godfather you know what kind of person you are. I absolutely do recommend you watch it for yourself. At the end fruit bowl paintings (or other versions of still lives) have become very iconic and appreciated. Hopefully i made you hungry to see this masterfully crafted icon of a movie called The Godfather.

title: This movie is a masterpiece
description:
**The Godfather (1972) - A Cinematic Masterpiece**

**Rating: 10/10**

Francis Ford Coppola's *The Godfather* is not just a film; it's an epic saga of power, family, and morality that redefined cinema. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, this crime drama is a flawless blend of storytelling, acting, and direction, making it one of the greatest films ever made.

### **Performances** Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, the aging patriarch of the Corleone crime family. His quiet authority and subtle expressions make Don Vito both terrifying and sympathetic. Al Pacino, in a star-making role as Michael Corleone, undergoes a chilling transformation from reluctant outsider to ruthless mafia boss-his arc is nothing short of mesmerizing. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, adds depth and intensity to every scene.

### **Direction & Writing** Coppola's direction is masterful, balancing brutal violence with intimate family drama. The screenplay (co-written by Coppola and Puzo) is sharp, layered, and filled with unforgettable lines (*"I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse."*). The pacing is deliberate, drawing viewers into the Corleones' world with a hypnotic grip.

### **Cinematography & Score** Gordon Willis's shadowy cinematography creates a moody, almost operatic atmosphere, while Nino Rota's haunting score lingers long after the film ends. The wedding sequence, the restaurant assassination, and the climactic baptism montage are visual storytelling at its finest.

### **Legacy** *The Godfather* set the standard for crime dramas, influencing countless films and TV shows. It's a tragic, gripping tale of loyalty and corruption, where family is both a blessing and a curse. More than 50 years later, it remains timeless.

**Verdict:** A perfect film in every aspect. If you haven't seen it, you're missing out on cinema history. **10/10.**

title: Excellent Classic
description:
Watching this for the first time I was aware of it's reputation as one of the greatest films of all time. Although it didn't quite hit that height for me, I can well understand the dedicated following it has.

Charting the story of a mafia family in America, the family's shift of power from father to son, and the family's turbulant relationship with similar power-hungry mafia families, The Godfather is long and at times violent film.

The violence though never seems out of place or thrown in for cinematic kicks - it is justifiably there and actually takes second place overall to excellent character development and dialogue. Equally the film seems to go by much faster than it's 3 hour run time.

A thoroughly enjoyable watch, and one experienced with the feeling of watching a classic piece of cinema.

title: The Best Trilogy Ever! May contain spoilers
description:
The year is 1945. The Sicilian-American family, the Corleones, is celebrating the wedding of a daughter, Connie, in New York. Everything is going fine...except for the secret meeting held inside the house, a secret meeting on revenge. Don Vito Corleone (Brando) is discussing a problem with a close associate, while his mentor, Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall) stands on. The Don's three sons are outside celebrating the wedding: Sonny, the hot-tempered oldest brother; Fredo, the shy and quiet middle son; and Michael, the youngest son who has returned from fighting in World War II. Sonny and Fredo are in with the Don's council of 'whacking' people, but Michael refuses to be any part of it, due to total commitment to his girlfriend, Kay Adams (Diane Keaton). However, one day while shopping for food with Fredo, Don Corleone is shot by a betrayal, and is rushed to the hospital. The verdict: An assassination attempt. After hearing this, from Long Beach, California, Michael rushes back home to his father. After hearing about the ones who almost killed the Don, he plots revenge with Sonny and close associates. But a twist of fate happens to the family, and in the end, the once-reluctant Michael is made Don over the Corleones.

Francis Ford Coppola beautifully shows a portrait of what seemed to be a harmless family into such malice. The story was adapted from the number one hit by Mario Puzo, who also collaborated with Coppola in this project. The cinematography is excellent, the screenplay gripping and intelligent, and the haunting but enchanting score is memorable. Marlon Brando is absolutely divine as the ruthless, merciful Don Corleone, which earned him the Oscar for Best Actor. New-comer Al Pacino is extremely excellent as Michael, showing both the innocence and fierceness of the son, and his performance received many praises. James Caan is great as scary Sonny, and Robert Duvall could not be a better Tom.

Some notable scenes are the monologue, the Baptism, and the ever-famous horse-head-in-the-bed scene. This demonstrates how scary and malicious the Mob can be. With twists and turns, it shows that even the Mob can lead everyday lives, but one could have a particularly hard time dealing with carrying out a deadly job twenty-four seven.

I personally love this movie, because of the intrigue I felt as I read some of the novel. I definitely recommend this film to people, but I hope that you would not show this to young children. Some things could scar them for life, much like myself...If you like this movie, I also recommend you watch the other two films with the trilogy. In my opinion, this is the greatest trilogy ever made.

title: An ultimate classic!!!

title: Best movie ever made!
description:
Epic in scope while maintaining a patience and intimacy characteristic of European art cinema, THE GODFATHER is rightly considered one of the greatest films ever made. The Godfather continues to influence producers of films, television shows, and video games more than 30 years after its release. Nino Rota's score, the sumptuous set design, and Brando's raspy pseudo-whisper have become part of our collective cultural memory.

The film possesses an operatic quality, yet it's more understated than it is flamboyant. It takes its subjects seriously, bestowing legitimacy upon the internecine power struggles of the Mafia normally reserved for classical themes in high art. The film's release initiated a period when American filmmakers dared to take themselves and their artistic ambitions seriously (perhaps too seriously). There is something deeply resonant in the film's treatment of filial piety, the need for respect, and our culture's abiding interest in the parallel moral universe of the Mafia.

title: Very Little To Offer
description:
Here's how the arguments go for liking this movie go: The Godfather is a great movie because it's a hallmark of the genre. While gangster movies before this had been wall-to-wall violence and only loosely strung together by a plot, The Godfather was able to move away from that tradition by having a plot-heavy mobster movie. The performances were all superb and the characters all felt real.

However, what this argument fails to recognize is that the plot moves at such a slow pace that it's difficult to give a damn about it. This is quite honestly the slowest paced movie I've ever seen, and it would have been improved a thousand-fold if an hour or so had been cut. It's not that I hate slow movies--a slow pacing can work brilliantly--but The Godfather? No, it doesn't do it.

As for the cast and performances, they're really not all they're cracked up to be. If indecipherable mumbling is your thing, so be it, and in that case, this movie is the best thing ever. In reality, though, half-mumbled lines don't really do anything for me, and because of that; all the characters seemed to be fairly one-dimensional as a result.

I can see how you could like this movie. On a technical level, it did move away from the traditional three-point lighting which was common in earlier films, and the plot was definitely something other than what had been dealt with in mobster movies before then. But the content of the plot was somewhat devoid of any real interest--or at least it was for me--and the characters came off as being one-dimensional as a result.

title: Greatest crime film ever made
description:
Man I just don't know where to start. This is hands down the best gangster movie ever made! The most powerful, the most violent, and even the most traumatizing. Al Pacino stars as Michael Corleone, the son of mob boss Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). Vito is a very powerful crime boss with a hoarse voice and he decides to one day let his son take control of the family business.

Michael Corleone was in the Marine Corps but he was discharged at some point later in his life. So the first movie of the franchise shows us how innocent Michael appears to be despite his surroundings. Over the course of the movie, we will be introduced to all the members of the Corleone crime family as well as the lawyer who is played by Robert Duvall.

The acting is top notch, it's so great it feels like you're actually right there in the movie experiencing what's right in front of your eyes. Michael's innocence is destroyed as the movie progresses, and he turns insane and becomes vindictive for reasons I won't explain because I don't want to spoil the movie for people who haven't seen it yet.

But be warned, The Godfather has lots of very jaw dropping but also shocking moments that can leave you traumatized. You could have some of these scenes stuck in your head for weeks, the movie teaches you a valuable lesson about living a life of crime, especially if you're in a gang or you show interest in the mafia.

There are some memorable quotes in the movie as well like "Leave the gun, take the cannoli".

title: An epic masterpiece
description:
After having watched the Godfather countless times, I have to say that it is (along with the rest of the trilogy) the best film/series of films I've ever seen. My comments are on the series of films as a whole.

Here are my main reasons for this assertion:

1-The complexity of the plot which draws one in to an involvement with the film without the complexity being just for its own sake.

2-The depth of characterisation of Michael. The way he seems to inevitably to get sucked into something deep and serious when he initially seems ashamed of the family 'business'.

3-The interlinking of scenes from present and past which adds something emotionally at certain points in the film. (eg. the flashback of Michael telling his family about him joining the army)

4-the music which creates an amazing and authentic atmosphere.

parts 1 and 2 merit a 10 and part 3 a 9. (part three is better than some have suggested I think)

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is a timeless classic that has left an indelible mark on the landscape of American cinema. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, this film is an epic tale of power, loyalty, and family, woven with intricate storytelling and unforgettable performances.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic, bringing a quiet, commanding presence to the screen that has become synonymous with the character. His performance is complemented by a stellar cast, including Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, whose transformation from reluctant outsider to ruthless leader is both compelling and tragic.

The film's narrative is rich and layered, exploring the complexities of the Corleone family and their dealings within the criminal underworld. Coppola's direction is masterful, balancing moments of intense drama with quieter, more introspective scenes that delve into the characters' inner lives. The screenplay, co-written by Coppola and Puzo, is sharp and engaging, with dialogue that has become etched in cinematic history.

Visually, "The Godfather" is a feast for the eyes. Gordon Willis's cinematography captures the era with a dark, moody palette that enhances the film's somber tone. The use of light and shadow is particularly striking, adding depth and nuance to the storytelling. Nino Rota's haunting score further elevates the film, providing an evocative backdrop to the unfolding drama.

While "The Godfather" is nearly flawless, it occasionally meanders with its pacing, and some scenes feel drawn out, which might test the patience of modern audiences used to faster-paced narratives. However, these moments are few and far between, and they do little to detract from the film's overall impact.

"The Godfather" deserves a solid 9 out of 10. It's a film that masterfully combines exceptional performances, a gripping story, and brilliant direction to create a cinematic experience that remains powerful and relevant decades after its release. This is a must-watch for any film enthusiast, a true testament to the art of filmmaking.

title: The Godfather: A Timeless Masterpiece of Cinema
description:
The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that continues to stand the test of time. The film's plot follows the Corleone crime family, with particular focus on the patriarch of the family, Vito Corleone, and his son Michael as they navigate their way through the world of organized crime in New York City.

One of the most striking aspects of the film is its ability to blend themes of family, loyalty, power, and corruption in a way that feels both authentic and emotionally resonant. The performances from the cast, particularly Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone and Al Pacino as Michael Corleone, are nothing short of phenomenal and have become iconic in the annals of film history.

Francis Ford Coppola's direction is masterful and the film's score, composed by Nino Rota, perfectly complements the film's mood and atmosphere. The cinematography by Gordon Willis is also noteworthy, capturing the gritty and realistic feel of New York City and the Corleone family's world.

The film's pacing is also well-done, with each scene building on the previous one to create a sense of tension and uncertainty. The editing is seamless and the dialogue is sharp and memorable.

In short, The Godfather is a film that should not be missed. It is a true classic that has left a lasting impact on cinema and popular culture. The film's themes and performances continue to resonate with audiences today and it's no wonder it is considered one of the greatest films ever made.

title: A Masterpiece of Storytelling, One of the Best Ever Made, Brando Remarkable
description:
The Godfather follows the Corleone family, a powerful Italian-American Mafia dynasty, as they navigate the dangerous and complex world of organized crime in New York City. This film has a legendary cast, including Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, and James Caan, and is one of the reasons I consider it to be one of the greatest films of all time.

I've rated the Godfather a 10 out of 10 as it is a masterpiece of storytelling, with a complex and multi-layered narrative that expertly explores themes of power, loyalty, family, and morality. The performances are all exceptional, with Marlon Brando in particular delivering a remarkable performance as the family patriarch, Don Corleone. It's not just the cast its the stylish direction, the memorable score, and the iconic cinematography that also make this film a masterpiece and have all stood the test of time and make the Godfather a must-see film for anyone who loves cinema like I do. Whether you're a fan of crime dramas, historical films, or simply great filmmaking, The Godfather is an undeniable classic that is sure to captivate you.

title: Well the best way to watch the Godfather is...
description:
The Best way to watch this movie is to watch it on DVD.

Actually your own DVD.

Not a second hand one if possible...

The reason?

Well... in that way, at least you try to watch it with patience.

I mean after all, you must have spent more than $60, well that's what the boxset costs.

In my case, that helped me enormously.

When I first ordered the boxset on the internet, i was so excited that i am finally going to watch the greatest movie of all time.

Then about 2 weeks later, the DVD arrived.

I waited until the weekend (I am a highschool student ~!) and watched the first Godfather.

My first experience of it was well... disappointing.

It was boring and the story went too slow.

I wasn't just disappointed, I was furious.

Furious about all the good reviews about this movies...

But then with my incredible patience, i watched it again, I mean after all i spent a huge amount of money on this, i had to understand what it was about.

Second time was also bad.

Then i watched it for the thrid time...

And it was....

Incredible....

It was fantasitc.

Suddenly i could see all the meanings of the movies and from then one, i watched it again and again.

I must have watched it more than 10 times now, but I will never get bored...

So Please... if you are watching the Godfather trilogy for the first time and you are young, buy the boxset.

It'll help. Trust me...

title: godfather
description: Widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time, this mob drama, based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, focuses on the powerful Italian-American crime family of Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). title: Best movie experience I ever had
description:
This movie isn't just about mafia or crime or just killing people. Some people thing that this movie is only about violence (mostly female people ;) ). The movie is more about family, how the people in a family are connected together, how a complete innocent son, can become a very violent guy.

It changes the way you look at mafia. Some think that mafia is just a group of gangsters that kill for money. Well, the movie tells you that it's not just that, there is honor. Of course, I'm not saying that they are right, but they aren't just a group of violent assassins. The music on the movie is very well made, the acting is fabulous, and Al Pacino is great. So is Marlon Brando. The movie starts at a good point and ends at a good point too. Some might think that it's not a good ending, doesn't explain enough. But I just love the way in which the movie ends, great music, great scene and great look on Kay's face. I know that there are people who will call this movie a boring one. I accept that it's long...very long, but it's necessary and it explains the entire story very good. Overall, it's a fabulous movie, the best movie experience I ever had. 10/10

title: Under World Movie
description:
This Movie nice. its open under world man life. "The Godfather" is told entirely within a closed world. That's why we sympathize with characters who are essentially evil. The story by Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola is a brilliant conjuring act, inviting us to consider the Mafia entirely on its own terms. Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) emerges as a sympathetic and even admirable character; during the entire film, this lifelong professional criminal does nothing of which we can really disapprove.

During the movie we see not a single actual civilian victim of organized crime. No women trapped into prostitution. No lives wrecked by gambling. No victims of theft, fraud or protection rackets. The only police officer with a significant speaking role is corrupt.

title: Amazing
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is nothing short of a cinematic triumph. Released in 1972, this film has stood the test of time and remains a benchmark for excellence in filmmaking. Adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, it tells the engrossing tale of the powerful Corleone crime family, blending intricate storytelling with top-tier performances.

Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, the patriarchal head of the family. His portrayal is both subdued and commanding, exuding a quiet power that leaves an indelible mark on the audience. Al Pacino, as Michael Corleone, showcases a masterful transformation from a war-hero outsider to a ruthless mafia leader. The cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, all contribute to the film's undeniable gravitas.

The screenplay is nothing short of genius. It intricately weaves themes of loyalty, power, betrayal, and family into a narrative that is as compelling as it is complex. Coppola's direction is meticulous and layered, allowing the story to unfold at a deliberate yet engaging pace. The cinematography by Gordon Willis adds a rich, almost operatic quality to the film, with its use of shadows and light contributing to a sense of impending doom.

Nino Rota's haunting score complements the film perfectly, enhancing the emotional weight of key scenes and contributing to its timeless quality.

What sets "The Godfather" apart is its ability to humanize its characters, even as it portrays a world steeped in crime and violence. It tells a universally resonant story about power and its influence on the human condition. The film is also a brilliant exploration of the immigrant experience, showing the lengths to which individuals will go to protect their family and secure their legacy.

"The Godfather" is more than just a movie; it is an experience, a study in cinematic excellence that has influenced countless films and storytellers. Its meticulous craftsmanship, stellar performances, and profound narrative make it a must-watch for any film enthusiast. Over four decades later, it continues to reign supreme as one of the greatest films ever made.

In closing, "The Godfather" is an essential piece of cinema that captures the essence of storytelling at its finest, and its impact will undoubtedly resonate for generations to come.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is a film that stands the test of time, epitomizing the pinnacle of cinematic storytelling. Released in 1972, this epic tale of the Corleone family delves deep into the intricacies of power, loyalty, and betrayal within the American Mafia.

The brilliance of "The Godfather" lies in its impeccable direction, superb screenplay, and an ensemble cast that delivers unforgettable performances. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic, bringing a blend of ruthless authority and tender family loyalty to the character. Al Pacino's transformation from the innocent Michael Corleone to a hardened mafia boss is both compelling and tragic, showcasing his incredible range as an actor.

The cinematography by Gordon Willis, often referred to as "The Prince of Darkness," is masterful, using light and shadow to create a haunting and atmospheric visual experience. Nino Rota's haunting score perfectly complements the film, enhancing the emotional weight of each scene.

The narrative is rich and multi-layered, exploring themes of power, family, and the moral complexities of the criminal underworld. Each character is intricately developed, making their journeys and fates deeply impactful.

"The Godfather" is more than just a film; it's a cultural landmark that has influenced countless movies and remains a benchmark for storytelling excellence. Whether you're watching it for the first time or revisiting it, "The Godfather" offers a profound and captivating experience that leaves an indelible mark.

title: A True Pioneer
description:
This movie is a pioneer to so many that have come after it. It paved the way like few have done before.

Definitely a slow burn, but that's partly what makes it so good. The build up, several scenes are thrilling, leaving your heart pounding, needing to know what's going to happen and how it's going to play out. It doesn't rely on constant, needless, high-speed action. Something almost impossible to do for a 3 hour runtime. Instead, the slow progression of a character's transformation. It's a beautiful thing that few get right, but The Godfather absolutely nails it.

Everything simply just "works", from the story, casting, themes, cinematography, music, etc. So many aspects come together to make one extraordinary, poetic film. That's how and why this film still holds up after nearly 50 years.

title: Great movie
description:
It is now past 1 PM and I just finished watching Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather". I should probably go to bed. It's late and tomorrow I have to wake up a bit early. But not early enough to postpone writing these lines. Now that I have seen it three times, the opportunity of sharing my thoughts and refreshed insights are too much of a good offer to sit on. So, bear with me.

This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.

But it goes even deeper than that. It all revolves around the Corleone family led by Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He is the most honest of these men, sitting right on the edge. But for people like him, who do not fully embrace this world, it's not easy. He avoids conflict until it is absolutely necessary. He is a man defined by moral principles. There is a scene at the beginning, in which, during his daughter's wedding day, one of his associates, Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana) practices his speech that he is going to give to the Don when he meets him. The scene with these two is funny and almost adorable. I could not help but sympathize both of them only to realize that I am feeling warmth for two mobsters. Not to even mention that Lenny Montana was an actual mob hit-man and that he was actually nervous as he said that line.
