title: Redefining Cinema with Unparalleled Greatness
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" stands as a timeless masterpiece that continues to shape the landscape of cinema. Released in 1972, the film's influence and historical importance are undeniable, thanks to its exceptional performances, masterful direction, and its profound exploration of power dynamics within the mafia underworld. Marlon Brando and Al Pacino deliver career-defining performances, while Coppola's virtuoso directing, alongside stunning cinematography, creates an immersive and unforgettable cinematic experience.

"The Godfather" boasts some of the greatest acting performances in the history of cinema. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is a masterclass in nuanced performance, with Brando breathing life into the iconic character. Meanwhile, Al Pacino's transformative performance as Michael Corleone captures the character's complex journey from reluctant involvement to ruthless power. Brando and Pacino's on-screen chemistry and their ability to convey subtle emotions with remarkable depth elevate the film to new heights.

"The Godfather" masterfully depicts the intricate power dynamics that govern the mafia world. Francis Ford Coppola's direction skillfully navigates the complexities of family loyalty, honor, and betrayal. He expertly balances the grandeur and intimacy of the narrative, immersing the audience in a world where every decision carries immense weight. Through meticulous pacing and deft storytelling, Coppola crafts a compelling narrative that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats while peering into the intricate web of power struggles and shifting alliances.

The visual aesthetics of "The Godfather" contribute significantly to its impact. The film's cinematography, captured by Gordon Willis, evokes a sense of both elegance and menace. The use of shadows, low lighting, and warm hues adds depth to the characters and heightens the atmosphere of the mafia underworld. Coppola's deliberate attention to detail in capturing the opulent settings and the subtle nuances of character expressions further immerses viewers in the dark and morally ambiguous world of the Corleone family.

One of the film's standout elements is the beautifully written and executed corruption arc of Michael Corleone. From his initial reluctance to get involved in the family business to his transformation into a calculated and ruthless figure, Michael's journey serves as the emotional core of the film. The gradual erosion of his morality and the conflicts he faces between loyalty, power, and personal identity are portrayed with remarkable depth and complexity. This narrative thread adds layers of intrigue and depth to the overall story, making it an enduring part of cinematic history.

"The Godfather" has left an indelible mark on cinema, becoming a touchstone for storytelling, character development, and technical excellence. Its influence can be seen in subsequent gangster films, and its themes of family, power, and the consequences of violence continue to resonate with audiences. The film's cultural impact, critical acclaim, and enduring popularity have solidified its place in history as a groundbreaking work of art.

"The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that effortlessly weaves together powerful performances, masterful direction, and a captivating exploration of power dynamics within the mafia underworld. Brando and Pacino deliver unforgettable performances, bringing depth and complexity to their iconic characters. Coppola's directorial prowess, coupled with stunning cinematography, creates a visually arresting experience that immerses viewers in the morally ambiguous world of the Corleone family. As a film that remains influential and historically significant, "The Godfather" stands as a testament to the lasting impact of exceptional storytelling and unforgettable characters.

title: Visually stunning and thematically rich
description:
"The Godfather" stands as an immortal masterpiece in the realm of cinema, a timeless epic that continues to captivate audiences with its riveting storytelling, unforgettable characters, and unparalleled craftsmanship. Directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, the film transcends its genre to become a profound exploration of power, loyalty, and the American dream.

Set in the dark underworld of organized crime, "The Godfather" chronicles the saga of the Corleone family, led by the enigmatic patriarch, Don Vito Corleone, portrayed with mesmerizing depth by Marlon Brando. Brando's iconic performance as the titular Godfather remains one of the most indelible in cinematic history, imbuing the character with a sense of gravitas and complexity that lingers long after the credits roll.

Al Pacino delivers a career-defining performance as Michael Corleone, the reluctant heir to the family empire, whose transformation from an idealistic outsider to a ruthless mafia boss is nothing short of mesmerizing. Pacino's portrayal is a masterclass in subtlety and nuance, capturing the character's inner turmoil and moral descent with haunting precision.

The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, delivers uniformly outstanding performances, breathing life into a rich tapestry of characters that are both larger than life and achingly human.

Coppola's direction is nothing short of genius, as he orchestrates each scene with meticulous attention to detail, balancing moments of intense drama with quieter, more introspective moments. The film's pacing is flawless, building tension gradually until it reaches a crescendo in the unforgettable climax.

"The Godfather" is not merely a crime drama; it's a meditation on the nature of power and the consequences of wielding it. Through its intricate plot and multi-layered characters, the film explores themes of family, honor, and the corrupting influence of ambition, leaving viewers spellbound from start to finish.

Visually stunning and thematically rich, "The Godfather" is a cinematic tour de force that continues to inspire and influence filmmakers to this day. Its legacy is etched in the annals of cinema history, and its impact on popular culture is immeasurable.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a masterpiece in every sense of the word, a timeless classic that remains as relevant and captivating today as it was upon its release. With its unforgettable performances, masterful direction, and profound themes, it stands as a towering achievement in the pantheon of great cinema.

title: Coppola's Way
description:
The story views the Mafia from the inside. That is its secret, its charm, its spell; in a way, it has shaped the public perception of the Mafia ever since. It is significant that the first shot is inside a dark, shuttered room. It is the wedding day of Vito Corleone's daughter, and on such a day a Sicilian must grant any reasonable request. title: Here's a review of The Godfather
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is widely considered one of the greatest films ever made. Released in 1972, the movie is a sprawling saga of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia clan in New York City.

The story centers around Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), the aging patriarch of the family, and his youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino). Michael, a decorated war hero, initially tries to distance himself from the family business. However, he's drawn into the world of organized crime after an attempt is made on his father's life.

The Godfather is a complex and morally ambiguous film. It doesn't shy away from the violence and brutality of the Mafia, but it also portrays the Corleones with a sense of loyalty and tradition. The film's central theme is the corruption of power, and how even good people can be drawn into darkness.

Here are some of the film's strengths:

Superb acting: Brando and Pacino deliver iconic performances, with Brando's raspy-voiced Don Corleone and Pacino's transformation from reluctant outsider to ruthless killer.

Gripping story: The Godfather is a masterfully crafted narrative that keeps you hooked from beginning to end.

Cinematography: The film's visuals are stunning, with memorable shots like the baptism scene intercut with violence.

Score: Nino Rota's haunting score is an essential part of the film's atmosphere.

The Godfather is a must-watch for any film fan. It's a complex and thought-provoking film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. However, it's important to note that it does contain violence and profanity.

Here are some additional points to consider depending on your audience:

The film has been praised for its realistic portrayal of the Mafia, but it has also been criticized for glamorizing organized crime.

The film is quite long, at over two and a half hours.

The violence in the film can be graphic and disturbing.

Overall, The Godfather is a landmark film that deserves its classic status. It's a powerful and thought-provoking exploration of family, loyalty, and the corrupting influence of power.

title: The Godfather is Flawless!
description:
Rather than concentrating on everything that is great about The Godfather, a much easier way for me to judge its quality is on what is bad about it. Almost every film has something that I don't like about it, but I can honestly say that I wouldn't change anything about The Godfather. There is nothing weak about it and nothing that stands out as bad. That's why it gets ten out of ten.

This is one of those films that made me wonder why I hadn't seen it earlier. The acting from everyone involved is great, Marlon Brando comes across perfectly as the head of the family, and James Caan and AI Pacino are excellent as his sons. The soundtrack by Nino Rota is also very memorable, bringing back memories of the film every time I hear it. The plot has to be excellent for it to get ten out of ten, and it is, it's far from predictable and the film is the definition of a great epic.

The film is pretty shocking in the way every death occurs almost instantaneously, and as it spans ten years so many different things happen and every minute of it is great entertainment. It's a well-made and entertaining film that is only the first part of a trilogy, but it stands on its own as a wonderful film in its own right. If you haven't seen it, what are you waiting for? This was one acclaimed film that didn't disappoit.

title: best movie
description:
Tell me a movie that is more famous than this. Tell me a movie that has had more parodies spinned off its storyline than this. Tell me one movie that has been as quoted as a much as this. The answer is you can't. No movie has had as much of an impact as The Godfather has had ever since it was released.

The acting was simply amazing, what else could you say. What could be more appealing to people(even today) than watching actors like Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire and Robert Duvall. This is like heaven for someone who is a fan of movies. With this movie Brando was able to bring himself back into the limelight. His performance as the godfather alone is iconic. His character has been recreated so much in films that it has almost if it has not already become a cliché. His performance though was not a cliché. His performance was subtle and breathtaking. It was so genuine and realistic that it was not just probably but definitely more genuine than Marlon Brando himself. Al Pacino was perfect for this film as well. What a way to start up your career. His character was all about depth and he displayed it perfectly. He was able to display his own inner-battles in his mind as well as the battles he had with his family, friends and enemies. His character was more of a psychological character study than anything else to me. Robert Duvall to me was the glue to the movie. He added a different perspective to everything in just that he was not Italian yet having the respect of the mafia. His character is a man of high authority within the Corleone family who was listened to and insightful;. This was simply perfect giving the film great balance throughout. The rest of the cast was just icing on the cake.

The writing was phenomenal and breathtaking. As mentioned before there has been no movie quoted more than this. It is not even the quotes though that makes the writing in here so perfect. It is the symbolism and meaning that went into every scene. There are countless symbols, messages and lines in here that are so memorable yet it is as realistic as a movie could get.

The directing by Coppola was perfect as well. Not many movies can be 3 hours and yet maintain a good level of interest from the audience like The Godfather. Coppola deserves credit for this. The symbolism and messages that went into every scene also has to do with the directing not just the writing. The movie is so well edited and strung together that the only word that could come to my mind is perfection.

The cinematography and music were perfect. The score of this movie is one of the most memorable ever. If you were to hear it you could identify it right away. The cinematography was what actually really drove this movie. The Godfather seems to have this mystique to it, it gives you the feeling you are watching something truly remarkable.

The horse's head, the scene of Brando running with his groceries, the coffee shop scene, "I'll give him an offer he can't refuse" and countless other scenes and quotes from this movie have become a part of our culture. These scenes and lines have been recycled over and over again in comedies, commercials, etc. that it is impossible to avoid the greatness of The Godfather. The Godfather is like a disease once you see it you fall in love with it. I don't know if it is the greatest movie ever but it is definitely the most iconic film ever made.

title: The Don of all movies
description:
It is widely known that 'The Godfather' is one of the five or ten greatest movies ever conceived. About three months ago, it celebrated its 50th anniversary, and was beautifully restored by a group of immensely talented people. I saw the film at a special screening at the Paramount lot theater, and it was one of the best experiences I've ever had watching a movie. Not only was I illuminated and electrified by the masterpiece up there on the screen, but I was also admiring how great the movie both looked and felt. I had always known that the film had become grainy, and even the first time I saw it I could tell. The restoration makes it look just about flawless.

It's a flawless movie, a life changing movie, a film changing movie... it's a movie with composure that Coppola hasn't lived up to since, or for that matter, I don't think any director has since. Coppola's direction is so precise, concise, efficient, lean and organized, and has beautifully intertwined pacing. If it's not the best movie I've ever seen, then it's certainly the most beautifully choreographed, wonderfully paced I've ever seen.

The beautifully constructed and rich plot follows Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), the Don of a postwar organized crime family, who's getting older and older. After a series of complicated events, his leadership shifts to the youngest of the family, Michael (Al Pacino). At first, Michael is hesitant to break into such brooding and dark territory, but slowly transforms into somebody that he thought he'd never be. The cast also includes James Caan, Diane Keaton, Richard S. Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte, Abe Vigoda, Talia Shire, John Cazale, and Lenny Montana.

Every sequence is designed with such passion and craft that it is hard to not be completely sucked in. My favorite scenes are the wedding sequence at the beginning, which Coppola intertwines with meetings with the Don, and the scenes with Capt. McCluskey, a corrupt police captain, eating dinner with Michael. I will not spoil anything. I think this is a film that everybody must see. It is an element of modern art; little has achieved such a high status. It's unquestionably a masterpiece, and a movie that brought American popular entertainment to the ranks of the foreign masters. It was a joy to see it again and absorb so much.

It's probably the best movie I've ever seen.

The Godfather (1972)

4 STARS (OUT OF 4)

Directed by Francis Ford Coppola

Written by Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola

Starring Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall and Diane Keaton

Rated R

175 minutes.

title: An absolute masterpiece. Epic

title: Cinematic Beauty
description:
How is it possible for a gangster film to bring a tear to one's eye?

I've lost count of the number of times I've watched this film, although every time it leaves me overwhelmed. The first thing which makes this film, for me, is the music; its genuine authenticity, being scored by a genuine Italian maestro, is unmistakable which, together with its stunning cinematography, gives the film its true and honest character. Beyond this, the storyline is excellent, although it does help to watch the film more than once given the extensive character list. On top of this, the cast is simply outstanding, each perfectly suited and giving clear distinction and definition to their character and each delivering a performance which they have surely not surpassed in their respective careers. It is easy to single out Pacino, Brando and Caan as the standout performances, each of which are excellent, however the supporting roles are equally impressive and go beyond support, sharing the intricacies of each character, their inter- relationships and their moral struggles in the face of organised crime and family values.

Without wanting to give anything away, the closing scene is, in my opinion, one of the best moments in cinema.

Quite simply, this is not a "gangster film". It is a masterpiece which needs no categorisation, it needs just to be enjoyed.

title: Visually Imppecable and fundementally one of the best films!
description: I actually have never seen the classic movie and was really impressed and understand why it holds the status that it does in American Cinema. The locations and set were beautiful and spot on with the theme. I thought everybody looked like they belonged perfectly. The legendary scene with Don Corleone where he is in his office on the day of his daughter's wedding. The lighting and shadows in that is really impressive. Another one of my favorites that show how a movie can take you on a journey. Forget about what's going on for a couple of hours. When Michael was in the bathroom of the restaurant and the train was passing by and you see him searching for his pistol. I think this is a great example of great cinematography, acting and writing all coming together to create a larger than life scene. Being in a theatre it emphasized everything by a ton. You could hear the train as if you are sitting in that restaurant. Notice all the lighting and shadows I was really impressed!

title: The pinnacle of American film. Undoubtedly a masterpiece.
description:

It takes a rich, deep, and intimate narrative; mixes it with stunning performances from a brilliant cast; adds the startling and intense direction of Francis Ford Coppola, and finishes it all off with an array of imagery and dialogue that is imbued in every film lovers' mind.

It is immaculately paced, rewarding, and allows you to take something new from it every time you see it. This is everything a film should be. Go watch it.

This is just a great movie. There is not one bad thing I could say about it. It's because of movies like this that I'm so passionate about movies. If you haven't seen The Godfather as well as Parts II & III you're missing out on something special.

title: a legendary masterpiece
description: Unquestionably the greatest masterpiece in the history of cinema! An saga about power, family, love, hate, business, in other words, about life itself. A rare example of a book adaptation. The movie, which inspired many projects, was able to stand upright despite the difficulties it went through during its production and brought endless fame to its creators. Especially the legendary acting of Marlon Brando as the Godfather and the choices he made for the role gave the movie a completely different dimension. Al Pacino's calm but stormy gaze, Sonny's brutality, the trust of his beloved Consiglieri and, above all, the ruthlessness of life and the mafia are beautifully portrayed.

title: Masterpiece of A Family Life
description: The film, despite being a masterpiece that has persisted throughout history, has managed to maintain its position at the summit for me, both up to now and in the future. Reflecting a family life in a dramatic way that anyone, regardless of age, can easily empathize with, this work achieves a unique success without compromising on realism. With its deeply poignant meanings that send shivers down the spine, it not only pulls the audience into a captivating story but also succeeds in touching universal emotions. The film stands out not only as a tribute to the past but also as an inspiration for the future. While each scene harbors a separate story, it invites the audience on an emotional adventure. This unparalleled work goes beyond art, offering an experience that delves into profound thoughts, leaving an unforgettable impact on its viewers.

title: Best Movie
description:
The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy, based on Mario Puzo's best- selling novel of the same name. It stars Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story, spanning 1945 to 1955, chronicles the family under the patriarch Vito Corleone, focusing on the transformation of Michael Corleone (Pacino) from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece: The Godfather
description:
This is one of my My favourate movies. I have watched for many times. I still remember the fist time.

Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that has captivated audiences for decades. This epic crime drama delves into the intricate world of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia clan led by the enigmatic Don Vito Corleone.

The film masterfully portrays the rise and fall of the Corleone family through the eyes of its youngest son, Michael Corleone. As Michael reluctantly becomes embroiled in the family business, he undergoes a transformation from a war hero to a ruthless crime lord.

One of the film's greatest strengths lies in its complex characters. Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal of Vito Corleone is a tour de force, showcasing the character's wisdom, power, and unwavering loyalty. Al Pacino's performance as Michael Corleone is equally compelling, capturing the character's gradual descent into darkness.

The Godfather is not just a gangster film; it's a profound exploration of family, power, and the corrupting influence of organized crime. The film's meticulous attention to detail, stunning cinematography, and unforgettable score create a truly immersive cinematic experience.

Whether you're a seasoned film buff or a newcomer to the world of cinema, The Godfather is a must-watch. Its enduring legacy is a testament to its timeless storytelling and powerful performances.

title: A classic, and one of the best movies ever made.
description:
The Godfather is a movie that will stand the test of time as one of the best movies ever made. It had one of the best group of actors ever assembled, and the performances they gave were top notch.

The pacing was very good; slow where it needed to be, and fast when appropriate. Nothing was out of place, and no line ever felt out of place.

The story was a brilliant one, and not once, despite all the characters involved, did it ever become confusing or boring. The story sped through the years and kept you in suspense as to what would happen the whole time.

All in all, this a movie that anyone should see who is over the age of 15. It has stood the test of time, and is still considered by many to be the greatest movie of all time. And this is for a very good reason.

title: Cinematic Storytelling at Its Best
description:
It's among the most famous, celebrated, parodied and influential films ever made. Adapted from the book by Mario Puzo, this is a clear demonstration of the fact that film adaptations do not have to be the poor relation of the original novel. For the few who may not have seen it, the film is centred around two characters: firstly, there's Don Corleone, a man of power and influence who exists in the penumbra of crime and respectability. He is ruthless but also humane, powerful yet vulnerable, wise and simultaneously stubborn. He is charged with taking care of his "family", including blood relations and his wider organisation, which is built on the Sicilian model of organised crime. In order to maintain his position of influence in a shifting and complicated political landscape, he must be judicious in his decision-making, picking his battles as appropriate and channelling his resources as prudent. Then there is his youngest son: Michael Corleone. Initially he wishes to have no involvement in the family business; he wants to be a fully-fledged American and to let go of the murky ties to his Sicilian heritage and its connection with clandestine murder and violence. He serves in the army during WW2 and is decorated for his service. But, as his father starts to lose his grip on power and the Corleone family find themselves thrust into severe peril, the duty falls to him to step into the centre of events. He demonstrated his heroism for his country, now he must do the same for his family. The question is, at what cost to himself and the wholesome American life that he had been on the verge of building?

This film is an absolute marvel in story-telling. In Michael Corleone, it essentially takes the mold of the hero's journey with a character beginning in inauspicious circumstances, from the perspective of the mafia world in which he finds himself embroiled, to facing test after test which will prove his valour, strength, will and determination. His fate is partially foreshadowed by his father, however. Uneasy is the head that wears a crown, there is great responsibility and sacrifice which comes with power and influence and the trajectory of both central characters' journeys are demonstrations of this. The soundtrack by Nino Rota is gloriously atmospheric, the supporting cast are all exceptional and make the film a rich, profoundly engaging spectacle. The acting by two of the greatest film actors there ever were: Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, is sheer magic to behold and Coppola pulls the strings of Puzo's narrative beautifully, creating an epic that is one of the films which defines cinema to this day.

title: The GodFather Review
description:
"The Godfather" is a classic movie that will have you in stitches... from laughter! This film is a true testament to the comedic talents of Marlon Brando, who absolutely steals the show as the lovable gangster, Vito Corleone. From his over-the-top facial expressions to his hilarious one-liners, you won't be able to stop giggling.

But it's not just Brando who will have you in stitches. The supporting cast is full of hilarious characters, including the bumbling and often confused Tom Hagen, the unpredictable and hot-headed Sonny, and the comically evil Sollozzo.

The film's script is also full of comedic gold, with lines like "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse... to join the clown college" and "Leave the gun. Take the cannolis."

Overall, "The Godfather" is a film that will have you laughing out loud and rethinking your stance on organized crime. Don't miss it!

title: Masterpiece!
description: Excellent story, a perfect scenario. Great actors and director has made the movie a masterpiece. This is a film that does not leave you indifferent after watching. For a long time I had to force myself to watch this movie. I now regret that I did not saw it before because I didn't started in time to appreciate the Al Pacino acting and Francis Copolla work. And of course, it is needless to mention the excellent work of Marlon Brando. This movie makes you to fall in love with New York in the 1920s, and to wish that you were born in that time. This is one of those rare movies whose II and III part are not ruininig the whole story and the overall impression of the film. The second and third sequel even more complete story. In addition to the excellent story and acting, and you will enjoy the artistic dimension of this masterpiece.

title: A brilliant begin of beautiful saga.
description:
The reason why I value this movie so high, is because of the brilliant casting of its players. Especially the young and not yet well-known Al Pacino. The director Coppola insisted that Al Pacino would play Micheal while the production company wanted someone else. The great pressure on Al Pacino to proof himself as a worthy actor is perfectly seen during the entire movie. Its seems that Pacino has a lack of self confidence which fits the exactly the type of character he has to play. In The Godfather 3 you see an entire different Al Pacino. His qualities are already well known and thus there's no need to proof himself anymore.

Also the role played by Duvall as Hagen is beautiful and is really missed in the third part.

title: A fully-fledged work
description: The Godfather (1978) is a remarkable film for its time and even now, and while it can be a bit boring, if you have a mature mind and patience, you can witness a masterpiece, to the point that I watched the second part immediately after finishing the first part. This masterpiece starring Mr. Brando and Al Pacino is one of those films that can give you a deep and unique experience of a mafia movie. Most of the negative comments are about the boringness of the full version of the film, but you just have to be a little patient or not force yourself to watch the boring part of the film. In my opinion, for a deeper experience, it is better to be patient and watch the film in its entirety if you can.

title: After Thoughts
description: What can I say that hasn't already been said about the Godfather. It's a masterpiece that is perfect in every way. The casting is perfect, the score is perfect, the story is perfect! It's a perfect movie! This was the first mafia/organized crime film I ever saw. I was 10 and was completely stary eyed when I finished it for the first time. Being from a long line of Italians, the personal mannerism they use in thier day to day life is perfect and authentic. And every actor in this movie acted so so good. If I could I would give an Oscar to every person in this film. If you are not convinced to watch and love the Godfather by all the other reviews I don't know what else I can say to change your mind.

title: The GODFATHER of film
description:
It isn't often that a Hollywood film masterpiece is achieved.

This is one of those very rare occasions.

For those who want a short and to-the-point review: This is an excellent story telling event about an Italian Mafia family from the mid 1940s to the mid 1950s centring on the (fictional) Corleone Family headed by Vitto and eventually super-ceded by his youngest son Michael.

For those who care to read on: this is a film based very firmly around Mario Puzio's book of the same name. To put it simply: the story is well crafted, the characters are given definition, the actors have given themselves to the roles they have been so fortunate to play and the direction is so pure that it seems effortless and almost transcends time - which is incredibly improbable to achieve when filming a period piece.

This film will outlive any of the garbage we seem to accept on daily/weekly/monthly and annual basis.

It may not be your go-to whenever you need to watch something but it will expand your understanding on what serious film making is about. Take your time in experiencing this journey.

title: Hmm... nevermind the headline
description: I love The Godfather. Sitting here with my overexpensive, 4K box, which tells me in big letters that this is the 50th anniversary for the greatest movie ever made, make me feel old. It was made the year before I was born, and I first saw it in... 1982, 9 years old, with my dad. I didn't get much of the story, but got hypnotized by the awesome beginning with Brando's speech and the wedding. My lifelong obsession as a film geek was truly lit. There's something really special about it, that other movies lacks. Some critics says it glamorishes the mafia. Don't agree at all. It's a movie about family, and in glimpses we see the power and violence Vito Corleone possesses. And if anyone thinks it glamorises the mob, they are beyond stupid. It anything, the trilogy tells about the corruption of the human soul, when Michael Corleone goes full in to be the next Don, with some incredible violent scenes edited into the bapthism of Michael's own godson. He sold his soul, but he doesnt care. It's beautiful told, because Coppolla happens to be a great director, with incredible actors around. Seems I'm in minority thinking the 1st is the best. Mostly because it's "my precious favorite", but Part II has a bit to much politics that doesnt involve The Corleone's directly, so I will always find it "inferiour". It's a great, great movie, none the less. Now I'm looking forward to finally see the revised The Godfather Part III in full 4K. Maybe I will finally embrace it as a part of a great trilogy?

title: Oh Those Corleones
description:
No American filmmaker has had a more disappointing trajectory to his film career than Francis Ford Coppola. To have directed four of the most influential films of the 70's (the first two "Godfather" films, "The Conversation," and "Apocalypse Now") and then to spend the last two decades churning out one stinky product after another ("Peggy Sue Got Married," "Bram Stoker's Dracula", the third "Godfather") earns Coppola my award for Most Promising Director Who Most Miserably Failed at Establishing Himself as an Important Figure of American Cinema. But before "Jack" there was "The Godfather." While I feel the whole "Godfather" trilogy has been lauded into oblivion and is somewhat overrated, who am I to argue with the majority? People think these are great movies, and they've certainly implanted themselves permanently in our cultural consciousness.

And don't get me wrong: these films have moments of greatness (at least the first two installments do). But I think "The Conversation" and "Apocalypse Now" are ultimately more interesting films, and I think Coppola stretched himself more artistically in those two films than he did in the entire "Godfather" trilogy combined.

Of the trilogy, the first film is by far the best. It shows Coppola's flair for being able to craft a story with extreme mainstream appeal while staying faithful to his artistic vision. "The Godfather" doesn't look or sound quite like any gangster film before it, with it's muddy lighting and sound. It's also much more ambiguous morally than the usual Hollywood gangster film, at least any produced up to that point. The line between crime and justice is blurred sometimes beyond distinction, and the Corleone family at times acts with more honor (in its own way) than the institutions charged with upholding freedom, justice and morality. In this way, "The Godfather" offered a scathing critique of the foundations on which America as a country was built.

Coppola, however, drives this point into the ground over the course of three films. There's really not much more to say after the first film (it's already apparent that Michael Corleone's style of rule is different from his father's, his coldness and ruthlessness necessitated by a changing time), but we have to sit through a nearly 3 1/2 hour second installment that does nothing but reiterate this point again and again. Part II at least is saved by the back story of Vito Corleone (played by Marlon Brando in Part I and Robert De Niro in Part II), and that story alone keeps Part II afloat. But Part III is wholly unnecessary and mars the whole enterprise, turning the franchise into the stuff of parody and camp.

Al Pacino is the glue that holds the trilogy together, though his character really isn't as complex as a first viewing would have you believe. The major conflict facing him is resolved in the first film, and the second and third films give him nothing to do but replay what are essentially the same scenes over and over again.

Other standouts in the cast include Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton and Talia Shire (who alone makes the third chapter worth watching).

Obviously a must see for cinema buffs, or even casual fans, but don't feel you have to label this trilogy as great just because of the reputation that precedes it.

My Grade--- Part I: A Part II: B Part III: C-

Is The Godfather a candidate for the best movie of all time and a masterclass in filmmaking?

I'd make the argument that this is the gangster movie par excellence.

You don't need to worry; the time will fly by and you won't even realise the movie is almost three hours long.

With such high production values and stunning visuals throughout, the film, which is over fifty years old, puts many contemporary movies to shame.

This movie is still and always will be one of the best; it has had a significant impact throughout the years.

I could list many more Incredible performances-Brandon, Pacino, and Castellano are just a few.

title: Best Gangster Movie
description: This is the best gangster movie I have ever seen. Acting, Story, Action all things are amazing.

title: A masterpiece
description: There is little to add to the comments on this message board and numerous other sources- The Godfather is simply the best movie released. Not "Best Gangster Movie", not "Best Mafia Movie"- there are no qualifiers needed. The movie captures so many elements of great cinema- story, casting, writing, direction, production qualities, that it rises above every other movie released. See this movie and marvel at the transformation of Michael Corleone, the intensity of Sonny, the ineptness of Fredo, the emptiness of Connie and how Tom Hagen calculates every move, always looking for the acceptance from the rest of the family. Vito Corleone is a study of cunning abilities. The family looks to him for guidance and advice, even while the world is moving so quickly to overtake them.

title: Classic!
description:
I just watched The Godfather and I'm absolutely blown away. It's a classic that I think everyone should watch at least once in their life. The story follows the Corleone family, a powerful Italian-American mafia family, and the struggles of its patriarch, Don Vito Corleone.

Marlon Brando gives an incredible performance as Don Vito Corleone. His portrayal is powerful, charismatic, and captivating. Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, James Caan, and Diane Keaton all deliver outstanding performances. The direction is masterful, with Francis Ford Coppola bringing the story to life.

The Godfather is an iconic movie that is a must-watch for any movie fan. The story is captivating, the characters are compelling, and the performances are all excellent. It's a timeless classic that will remain a favorite of movie fans for years to come. Highly recommended.

title: Close, but not the greatest
description: "The Godfather" is a visceral achievement in moviemaking and has a rightful place near the top of any list of the greatest films ever made. It seizes your attention, doesn't let go and takes you down the road promised to immigrants to America -- before taking a turn in which we confront the prejudices, mistrust and other roadblocks to the realization of their dreams, and how they went on to create success on their terms. But I have to put it near the top, not AT the top. That honor, on my list, belongs to "The Godfather Part II," for a reason that it's hard to fault Coppola for. In "The Godfather," I found Michael to be too far outside the family at the beginning of the movie. While not renouncing his father, Sonny or their enterprise, Michael seems to be more of an observer in an Army uniform with his white-bread girlfriend nearby than a family member PLANNING to immerse himself in the life his father and brother have chosen. Obviously Michael is drawn closer to his family as it becomes threatened with, then targeted by, violence. This is understandable but, to me, not foreshadowed by the life outside the family that he had chosen a few years earlier and seemed to be comfortable with. Of course, "Part II" gives a much fuller picture of how Michael got to where he was in running the enterprise, and heading the family. But we already know all we need to know about his motives and choices -- courtesy of "The Godfather." This deeper, more realized character of Michael in "Part II" is the reason I rate it ahead of "The Godfather" -- but not by much.

title: Greatest movie

Do not miss this film!

title: The Godfather (1972) - A Cinematic Masterpiece of Crime and Family Drama
description:
"The Godfather" stands as a cinematic masterpiece and a monumental achievement in the crime drama genre. Adapted from Mario Puzo's best-selling novel of the same name, the film delves into the world of the Corleone crime family, their struggles for power, and the complexities of loyalty and family ties.

At its core, "The Godfather" is a tale of power, ambition, and the consequences that come with living a life within the underworld. The narrative revolves around Don Vito Corleone, portrayed with haunting intensity by Marlon Brando. Brando's performance is nothing short of mesmerizing, with his iconic raspy voice and commanding presence, making him one of the most memorable characters in cinematic history. He portrays Vito as a man of principles, who operates by his own moral code in the world of crime.

The film's central focus is on Vito's son, Michael Corleone, played brilliantly by Al Pacino. Michael starts as an outsider, choosing to distance himself from the family business and opting for a more legitimate path. However, as circumstances force him to take on a more active role, we witness his gradual transformation into a ruthless and calculating leader. Pacino's portrayal of Michael's character arc is nothing short of astonishing, showcasing his talent and range as an actor.

The supporting cast also delivers outstanding performances, contributing to the film's overall brilliance. James Caan as hotheaded Sonny Corleone, Robert Duvall as the loyal family consigliere Tom Hagen, and Diane Keaton as Michael's love interest Kay Adams, all provide memorable and compelling performances that add depth to the narrative.

One of the film's greatest strengths lies in Coppola's masterful direction and attention to detail. The pacing is deliberate, allowing the story to unfold naturally while building suspense and tension. Coppola's use of shadow and light in cinematography gives the film an atmospheric and visually striking quality. The iconic score composed by Nino Rota further elevates the emotional impact of pivotal scenes, leaving an indelible mark on the viewer's memory.

Moreover, "The Godfather" boasts a rich and well-developed script that seamlessly blends powerful dialogues with intense and emotionally charged moments. The film skillfully explores themes of loyalty, tradition, family dynamics, and the price of power. It humanizes the characters, making them relatable despite their morally questionable actions.

In addition to its compelling storytelling, "The Godfather" is a testament to meticulous set design and authentic period detail. The movie effortlessly transports viewers back to the 1940s and immerses them in the world of the mafia, thanks to the attention given to costumes, props, and locations.

"The Godfather" had an immense impact on the film industry, shaping the crime drama genre and inspiring numerous subsequent films. It earned eleven Academy Award nominations, with Brando winning the Best Actor award for his iconic performance. The film also secured Oscars for Best Picture and Best Adapted Screenplay, highlighting its enduring legacy and influence.

Even after five decades, "The Godfather" continues to be revered and celebrated by critics and audiences alike. It remains a benchmark of cinematic excellence, and its cultural impact is still felt today. From its unforgettable dialogues to its profound exploration of human nature, the film stands as a timeless work of art.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" (1972) is a cinematic triumph that remains unrivaled in its genre. Francis Ford Coppola's direction, the outstanding performances of its cast, and the engrossing storytelling combine to create a captivating and unforgettable cinematic experience. This timeless classic will continue to captivate generations to come, solidifying its place as one of the greatest films in cinema history.

title: Very Good!!
description:
This movie is the best I've seen. Very Good!!!Perfect!!!I also saw the God father II&III, but I think I is the best , the I story also the best!

Throughout his long, wandering, often distinguished career Francis Ford Coppola has made many films that are good and fine, many more that are flawed but undeniably interesting, and a handful of duds that are worth viewing if only because his personality is so flagrantly absent. Yet he is and always shall be known as the man who directed the Godfather films, a series that has dominated and defined their creator in a way perhaps no other director can understand. Coppola has never been able to leave them alone, whether returning after 15 years to make a trilogy of the diptych, or re-editing the first two films into chronological order for a separate video release as The Godfather Saga. The films are our very own Shakespearean cycle: they tell a tale of a vicious mobster and his extended personal and professional families (once the stuff of righteous moral comeuppance), and they dared to present themselves with an epic sweep and an unapologetically tragic tone. Murder, it turned out, was a serious business. The first film remains a towering achievement, brilliantly cast and conceived. The entry of Michael Corleone into the family business, the transition of power from his father, the ruthless dispatch of his enemies--all this is told with an assurance that is breathtaking to behold. And it turned out to be merely prologue; two years later The Godfather, Part II balanced Michael's ever-greater acquisition of power and influence during the fall of Cuba with the story of his father's own youthful rise from immigrant slums. The stakes were higher, the story's construction more elaborate, and the isolated despair at the end wholly earned. (Has there ever been a cinematic performance greater than Al Pacino's Michael, so smart and ambitious, marching through the years into what he knows is his own doom with eyes open and hungry?) The Godfather, Part III was mostly written off as an attempted cash-in, but it is a wholly worthy conclusion, less slow than autumnally patient and almost merciless in the way it brings Michael's past sins crashing down around him even as he tries to redeem himself.--Bruce Reid

title: Masterful filmmaking!
description:
The deed is done, and I have finally watched one of, if not the most celebrated, works of art in the history of cinema, i.e. Ford Coppola's "The Godfather."

Although I have plenty to talk about, I will keep things short and only speak of a few pointers and aspects that made notable impressions.

First and foremost, the screenplay is astonishing-one of the finest pieces of literature I have ever encountered.

Despite being three hours long in length, I never felt the pace weighing down the script; there was this natural flow to it that kept things interesting as well as moving. Except for this one particular occasion, where Michael goes into hiding after assassinating the police chief (in Sicily) and ends up marrying a Sicilian girl, that part felt a bit inconsequential and honestly the only segment for which I hold reservations, for the rest? I have no complaints whatsoever.

And now the second thing that made the biggest impression was the character development of both Corleone, the father, and the son. Not to mention, Marlon Brando and Al Pacino had given their all and made their parts even more alive and believable.

title: It is a fairly good Mafia Movie !!!
description:
Marlon Brando was a great actor, who could amply improve a given role by his own imagination and Method based on his raw, visceral and natural acting style. He could add many dimensions to a given character /role by his own charismatic personality, demeanor and voice. People will never forget Stanley Kowalski of "A street Car Named Desire", Napoleon Bonaparte of "Desiree" and Christian Fletcher of "The Mutiny on the Bounty". He was definitely a living legend of his time, a towering personality over other contemporary actors.

Mario Puso's Godfather owes a lot to Marlon Brando, who was shown as an aging patriarch (Don Vito Corleone) teaching tricks of the underworld ominous trade to his young cub,(Michael Corleone) portrayed by Al-Pacino. As the young role demanded, Al-Pacino's innocent face and if not simple, straight acting style was appropriate while the old man's (Brando's ) visage bore the complexities of life's bitter machinations that were required of him to get to the top rung of the clandestine Mafia Empire.

It is beautifully directed while punctuating the cinematic sequence with retrospective details of the elder Corleone's youth. It takes the audience to the old times with a pensive setting that approaches the status quo/wealth and waste of American Underworld.

Howsoever great the title and story of this movie as well the acting skills of Marlon Brando, but it cannot be regarded as the all time great movie EVER MADE. There is more to the Mafia and Underworld than meets the eye after watching this movie. The human intellect is endowed with exploring and implementing even more innovative ways of the negative side as one can imagine.

Nevertheless, it is a good effort at revealing the gory and ruthless side of the criminal dark world.

title: One of the Worst American Films Ever Made
description:
After experiencing the Godfather many years ago, I finally made my mind up that this might be one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Taking a humanistic viewpoint on an unbelievable and fictitious Italian family mob, The Corleone's, communicates to me how truly "unAmerican" this movie is. Seeing how Michael Corleone (aka Al Pacino's worst role) is experiencing inner dualism between morales and his family showed me how boring this movie really is. When I'm watching a good "American" film I want action, not character development! This movie was one big slumber-fest and there wasn't enough boobs!

But what truly made me come to this decision was discovering the pile of popcorn and butter vomit that came from my mouth onto my smart phone's IMDb application, after revisiting this so called winner of "Best Picture," "Best Actor," and "Best Adapted Screenplay." Critics of Coppola's uncreative, cookie-cutter, three hour long cheep film cheated and lied to the American population. Make no mistake, this "Italian" cultured film is worse than a serving of stuffed calamari in tomato sauce with no garlic, rotten eggs, and a pregnant squid pulled out of the Sarno River.

For the those of you spent time to even explore the other two parts of the story, I apologize. When I eventually got up from my imitation leather lazy-boy for a bathroom break all that came out was Marlon Brando's crappy performance. Not to mention Diane Keaton "expanding" her acting career... should of stayed with Woody. I feel this movie was pretentious and belittled the American audience. Even Italian film theorist Jean Epstein would probably say, this movie was about as sincere as using Ragu in spaghetti. For my own taste, I'm going to stick with the true mob classics like Corky Romano and Mobsters (with the truly talented Christian Slater). Thanks for the waste of time Francis Ford Coppola!

title: one of the best
description: I wish to do the same Directing , its amazing in all way

title: a great movie
description:
The Godfather is the classic mob movie. The film is totally different from all the others in its genre. The way Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo wrote this film so that the viewer actually sympathizes with the characters of the Italian mafia. Within the first scene the writers introduced all the main characters and all that's left to the film are twists, suspense, surprises and thrills.

The film also has many romantic scenes. Michael Corleone (Pacino) is in Sicily and walking through the open country when he and his two bodyguards stumble upon a beautiful young woman leading a school of children. Their eyes meet and it's love at first sight. Michael being brought up with the utmost respect went to the girls father and asked to meet her in the presence of their family. The viewer can't help but think `How sweet.' Fortunately the father approves and love blossoms into marriage.

The acting in the film is like no other and with so many big stars the viewer can't help but be excited to see so many great names in one film. Marlon Brando plays the role of the Godfather AKA Don Corleone, the leader of one out of five Italian mafias in the New York area. The way Brando developed his character was amazing and his famous voice in the film that has been mimicked for 30 years now sounds untouchable in it's originality. Al Pacino plays Brando's son Michael Corleone, who actually wasn't wanted for the part at the time but the studio cast him with the recommendation from the Director (Francis Coppola). Pacino actually sets the bar for himself when he took this role, and for all the future roles he would play in Mafia movies. His acting is compelling, and his looks are almost unrecognizable.

There are actually no innocent by-standers that get hurt or victimized in the film that you might see in other mafia movies. Infact everyone that ends up dead were people that were a part of one of the mafia families. The whole film is about respect and the closeness of family if you can see behind all the violence.

The film is quite long to sit through in one sitting but is totally worth it by the end. The film will grab you in an instant with curiosity to the underground world of the mob.

This is undoubtedly the best mob movie ever. This film is recommended for people that love mafia films. And for the people who don't really care for these types of movies this film will change your mind on organized crime movies.

title: A masterpiece
description: "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that holds a special place in my heart, earning a solid 8/10 rating. The acting is nothing short of phenomenal, with Marlon Brando's iconic performance as Vito Corleone leaving an indelible mark. The film editing is expertly crafted, seamlessly weaving a sprawling narrative filled with power struggles and family dynamics. Its strength lies in its exploration of the blurred lines between morality and loyalty, making it a timeless classic. While some might find its runtime a weakness, I believe it only adds to the epic scale of the story. The music, particularly the haunting theme by Nino Rota, is both evocative and unforgettable. The cinematography captures the dark elegance of the mafia world with every frame. "The Godfather" is more than a film; it's a cinematic opera that has left an enduring legacy, and my love for it knows no bounds.

title: undoubtedly the best mob movie ever!
description:
The Godfather is the classic mob movie. The film is totally different from all the others in its genre. The way Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo wrote this film so that the viewer actually sympathizes with the characters of the Italian mafia. Within the first scene the writers introduced all the main characters and all that's left to the film are twists, suspense, surprises and thrills.

The film also has many romantic scenes. Michael Corleone (Pacino) is in Sicily and walking through the open country when he and his two bodyguards stumble upon a beautiful young woman leading a school of children. Their eyes meet and it's love at first sight. Michael being brought up with the utmost respect went to the girls father and asked to meet her in the presence of their family. The viewer can't help but think `How sweet.' Fortunately the father approves and love blossoms into marriage.

The acting in the film is like no other and with so many big stars the viewer can't help but be excited to see so many great names in one film. Marlon Brando plays the role of the Godfather AKA Don Corleone, the leader of one out of five Italian mafias in the New York area. The way Brando developed his character was amazing and his famous voice in the film that has been mimicked for 30 years now sounds untouchable in it's originality. Al Pacino plays Brando's son Michael Corleone, who actually wasn't wanted for the part at the time but the studio cast him with the recommendation from the Director (Francis Coppola). Pacino actually sets the bar for himself when he took this role, and for all the future roles he would play in Mafia movies. His acting is compelling, and his looks are almost unrecognizable.

There are actually no innocent by-standers that get hurt or victimized in the film that you might see in other mafia movies. Infact everyone that ends up dead were people that were a part of one of the mafia families. The whole film is about respect and the closeness of family if you can see behind all the violence.

The film is quite long to sit through in one sitting but is totally worth it by the end. The film will grab you in an instant with curiosity to the underground world of the mob.

This is undoubtedly the best mob movie ever. This film is recommended for people that love mafia films. And for the people who don't really care for these types of movies this film will change your mind on organized crime movies.

title: Beautiful
description: Watch it and you'll know it. Great casting, great direction, great storytelling.

title: A Masterpiece
description:
The Godfather is arguably THE defining drama motion picture of the 20th century. The character presentation was magnificent. Though Al Pacino had other great movies prior to this, Brando obviously took a shine to him and really mentored this actor in ways I believe no one can imagine. Pacino evolved and solidified the role of the head of the family that I believe is still being used in references today. A strong but loving Father figure, ruthless and forceful at times, Pacino drew on his personal background greatly during this role.

James Caan was spot on as Sonny. The typical view of Italian temper as well as showing the eagerness to make a dollar. This role was the glue in the first half of the film.

Talia Shire, just too good. What can one write about a flawless performance. The quintessential bad Italian daughter, awful wife and terrible sister. Scorned by her brother, bitter in the end of this movie, Mrs. Shire is wonderful in portraying the suppressed spirit of the true Italian mob family member.

John Cazale is a piece of work. As Fredo, he embodies the mob family's image of the family member "you should have just given money to instead of letting him in the business". What a smart role for a great actor. Through it all Fredo was the one family member that was actually true to himself the whole time. He loved his family dearly, wanted to earn money, and absolutely craved respect. I love how he was always like the lamb in the lions den no one worried too much about. The movie was tailored such that if one thinks about it, the family is the one that let Fredo down by not recognizing his inherent shortcomings.

Robert Duvall is a Master Counselor in the movie, but most the important contribution Duvall made was as an outsider. Not an Italian. His portrayal as someone who could be loyal and not blood Italian was huge in the USA at this time. I believe Duvall's role made it almost OK for races to interact with each other better without using side glances. This is a great testament to Duvall and one I don't believe was intended by the director or screenplay.

Finally there is Mr. Marlo Brando. There's nothing to say but marvelous, magnificent, platinum performance.

title: Godfather errors.
description:
Actually Sonny's car is a 1940 or 1941 Lincoln Continental.

When Michael rides in the 1941 Buick with McClusky and Sollozo, notice that the steering wheel shows a lot of wear on the rim, and the rear window panes are starting to delaminate- this is indicated by the odd shapes on lower inner corners of the glass. This would not occur on a car less than 10 years old (at the time of the scene), but certainly would on a car that was over thirty years old.

Sonny's shooting was actually filmed on an airport runway, but the toll booths are exactly as I remember as I grew up on Long Island. I first saw The Godfather in a theatre in Roslyn, Long Island and got pulled over by a cop on the way there so I missed the first 20 minutes! It's still my favourite film.

title: The best movie that i watched
description: "The Godfather", directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is one of the greatest films in the history of cinema. Based on the novel by Mario Puzo, the film explores the complexity of the Italian Mafia in the United States and the impact of power on the Corleone family. Marlon Brando's performance as Vito Corleone is monumental, bringing emotional depth to the character. Al Pacino, as Michael, shows a subtle and powerful transformation, reflecting the loss of his innocence. Coppola's direction and Nino Rota's score elevate the narrative, making it a fascinating study of morality and corruption. It is a work that continues to be relevant, offering an intense reflection on the dynamics of power and human nature.

title: gooood
description:
The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy from a screenplay by Mario Puzo and Coppola. Based on Puzo's 1969 novel of the same name, the film stars Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story, spanning the years 1945 to 1955, centers on the transformation of Michael Corleone (Pacino) from reluctant family outsider to ruthless Mafia boss while also chronicling the family under the patriarch Vito Corleone (Brando).

The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in world cinema[3]—and as one of the most influential, especially in the gangster genre.[4] Now ranked as the second greatest film in American cinema (behind Citizen Kane) by the American Film Institute,[5] it was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 1990.[6] The film was for a time the highest grossing picture ever made, and remains the box office leader for 1972. It won three Oscars that year: for Best Picture, for Best Actor (Brando) and in the category Best Adapted Screenplay for Puzo and Coppola. Its nominations in seven other categories included Pacino, James Caan and Robert Duvall for Best Supporting Actor and Coppola for Best Director. The success spawned two sequels: The Godfather Part II in 1974, and The Godfather Part III in 1990.

title: Great Movie
description:
I actually sat down today and watched The Godfather. I had held off from watching it until now, afraid that it wouldn't live up to it's 'greatest movie ever' title that almost everyone seems to place on it. It's a great movie all the way around.....the cast, the dialogue, the sound track is all top-notch. Everyone involved gave great performances from top to bottom. Watching how Al Pacino's character changes through the movie is amazing.

I noticed a few people made comments saying how long the movie was. To be honest I was so into the movie that it seemed to go by pretty quickly. Someone also said that you'll find better made-for-tv movies than this. Believe, I highly doubt that you ever will.

All in all, I can say that this is one movie that definitely lives up to the hype that is surrounding it. I would highly recommend that everyone go out and watch this movie at least once. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

title: The Definitive Crime-Drama Movie
description:
The epic of epics, in my wholehearted view, remains to this day one of America's most accomplished feature films. This movie is so good that it's not just a movie, it's a movie that has dominated and defined their creator in a way perhaps no other director can understand. Even without understanding the dialogue's nuances or the elaborate twists, one is still inexorably drawn to the movie, as I found myself to be since the earliest time.

One thing that makes this movie a classic is that it defined how bad violence in a movie can be. When you see movie character Luca Brasi stabbed in the hand while he's being strangled to death, you realize that the director likes to take this movie seriously and make an example of how far a movie can go when it comes to violence. I'll admit that when I saw this movie for the first time in my life it wasn't very good in my opinion. When I saw this movie being #3 on AFI's {American Film Institute} Top 100 American Movies Of All Time, I thought it really didn't deserved that spot. But when I gave it another chance, my opinion changed. I said to myself, "This movie represents the best of movies like what the Statue of Liberty represnts to America".

In short, this movie is fantastic. What Star Wars is to Sci-fi is what Godfather is to Crime-Drama, meaning it's a perfect example of the genre. There will probably never be another movie like this in many decades to come.

title: A Symphony of Power and Loyalty: The Godfather
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola, stands as a monumental pillar in the realm of cinematic storytelling. At its inception, the narrative unfurls with a meticulous structure, drawing viewers into a world where family ties and criminal enterprises are indistinguishably intertwined. The Corleone family, led by the patriarch Vito Corleone, portrayed with a blend of ferocity and tenderness by Marlon Brando, encapsulates the dichotomy of brutal authority and deep familial love.

The film's thematic depth is as rich and complex as its narrative. It delves into the nuances of power, loyalty, and the American Dream, all set against a backdrop of organized crime. The transformation of Michael Corleone, played with a chilling subtlety by Al Pacino, from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss, is a study in character development. His journey reflects the film's exploration of the corrupting influence of power and the moral compromises required in the pursuit of dominance.

Technically, "The Godfather" is a marvel. Gordon Willis' cinematography paints each scene with a palette that is both opulent and ominous, echoing the film's mood. Nino Rota's score, with its hauntingly beautiful theme, further elevates the emotional impact of the narrative. The editing, particularly in the iconic baptism sequence, is a masterclass in building tension and drawing parallels between disparate actions.

As the film progresses, one cannot help but become emotionally invested in the characters' fates. Their complexities and the film's refusal to paint them as merely heroes or villains create a narrative that is as morally grey as it is captivating. The film's ability to make the audience empathize with, and even root for, characters who operate in the moral shadows is a testament to its narrative prowess.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is more than just a film; it is a cinematic experience that resonates long after the credits roll. Its exploration of family, power, and morality is as relevant today as it was at its release. On a scale of 10, I would rate it a well-deserved 9.5. It is a film that not only defined a genre but also elevated the art of cinema itself. For those who have yet to witness its magnificence, prepare for a journey into the heart of darkness, illuminated by flashes of loyalty, love, and the unquenchable thirst for power.

title: Deserving its regard as one of the best films of all time
description:
There are so many reasons why this is a great film: unforgettable music (especially that theme that adapts itself to so many different moods), striking cinematography, strong pacing, but first and foremost are the performances. The entire cast shines; no wonder so many of them--mostly unknowns at the time, like Pacino, Duvall, Keaton, and Caan--went on to stellar careers. But two performances stand out: Brando's and Pacino's.

Don Corleone is, in reality, little more than a well-dressed thug. But Brando infuses the Don with a regal manner: he carries himself like a king and speaks in dignified cadences. He dispenses vengeance and vice, but calls them justice and business. Even that infamous mumbling adds to the effect--it makes everyone (including the audience) lean forward, in respectful silence, to hear this powerful man speak. We should despise Corleone, but Brando's charisma in the role--arguably his best in a remarkable career--wins us over.

It's Pacino, however, who carries the bulk of the film, along with our sympathy. He is, we are led to believe, the hero of the story: when Michael first appears, he's outside in the light, whereas the Don first appeared in a dark, shaded lair. He's in love with a woman from a brighter world (it's no coincidence Diane Keaton's hair was coloured blonde for this movie), and assures her that he's not like the rest of his family. We want the best for him: we hope he'll escape his family's unsavory business.

But gradually, Michael gets drawn into those dark rooms his father inhabits. Pacino masterfully portrays a character who tries to be a hero, who tries to defend or avenge those he loves, but loses himself in the process. By the end of the film, Michael Corleone is positively reptillian--cold-blooded, predatory, calculating, a creature without remorse or morality. He has gained the world but lost his soul.

Normally, we would regard a man like Michael Corleone from afar with a mixture of revulsion and fear. We would think him inhuman, refusing to recognize anything of ourselves in him. But Coppola makes us identify with Michael, sympathize with him. If he's become a monster by the end of the film, we've been forced to recognize that we, too, could become monsters in the right (or wrong) circumstances. We have stared into the abyss, and found that it contains a dark, distorted reflection.

With The Godfather, Coppola et al took rather base source material--a pulp crime novel--and elevated it to the realm of Shakespearean tragedy. This is great story-telling, great movie-making, and great art. 10/10.

title: Love it !
description:
I recently watched "The Godfather" for the first time and I was thoroughly impressed. This classic American film, directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on the novel by Mario Puzo, tells the story of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia family in New York City.

What struck me most about the film was the depth of the characters and the intricate plot. Each character is well-developed and multi-dimensional, making them feel like real people instead of just caricatures. The story of the family's struggles and triumphs, both in their personal and criminal lives, kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film.

The acting was also top-notch, with Marlon Brando delivering a standout performance as the head of the family, Vito Corleone. The attention to detail in the sets, costumes, and cinematography all added to the film's authenticity and overall impact.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a must-watch for any fan of classic cinema. Its themes of family, power, and loyalty are timeless and still relevant today. I highly recommend it!

title: A Story of Loyalty and Family
description:
The Godfather explores criminality, the temptations of wealth, loyalty, and what one is willing to do to protect those they love. There is a theme in the story of life and death, a duality of one thing ending and another beginning. While Michael Corleone, played by Al Pacino, is a successful and capable character within a crime family, he only fills this role to protect those he loves. This film explores the ideas of the complicated villain. Justice, loyalty, and family are of ultimate importance, but there is a criminal twist to these ideals.

The Godfather asks us all: how far will you go to protect your family? And does the ends justify the means? The Corleone's enemies operate the same way as they do, eliminating any notion of good and evil. It's simply "them vs us". In such a vile environment, the only virtue one can have is loyalty.

In the opening of the film, Vito Corleone, played by Marlon Brando, is throwing a wedding for his daughter. During this peaceful and happy family event, dozens of loyal followers come to Vito to pay their respects, and in some cases, request unhappy favors. The first guest shown with Vito elaborates an important point of the film: an Italian immigrant has been wronged and refused justice by a corrupt system. Therefore, the father goes down a dark path and comes to the Godfather for justice. This is an example of the ends justifying the means, the duality of using evil for good. In a way, the father received justice for his daughter, but he's also a murderer for taking the law into his own hands and punishing another beyond what the law would have called for. The opening scene also highlights the contrast of having a happy wedding while at the same time, making arrangements to have people murdered. This theme is reflected throughout the film, with a powerful ending.

title: "A man who doesn't spend time with his family can never be a real man"
description: When I first watched the Godfather, I thought it was long, and overrated. I really didn't understand what the hype was for, and why this film is so critically acclaimed, being #2 on IMDB's top 250 movies. It was only over time when I was reminded by it, such as the visual look of Don Vito Corleone, or the iconic quotes such as "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse", that I began to realise that I had witnessed a masterpiece. The Godfather is one of the most iconic films in history, that has truly influenced our society. There's good story telling, distinct memorable characters, and a very good ending. I don't believe that it's the 2nd greatest film of all time, I think films such as Fight Club, A Clockwork Orange and American Beauty are better, but it's certainly deserved a top 10 spot. Believe the hype.

title: An Iconic Film
description:
The acting was simply amazing, what else could you say. What could be more appealing to people(even today) than watching actors like Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire and Robert Duvall. This is like heaven for someone who is a fan of movies. With this movie Brando was able to bring himself back into the limelight. His performance as the godfather alone is iconic. His character has been recreated so much in films that it has almost if it has not already become a cliché. His performance though was not a cliché. His performance was subtle and breathtaking. It was so genuine and realistic that it was not just probably but definitely more genuine than Marlon Brando himself. Al Pacino was perfect for this film as well. What a way to start up your career. His character was all about depth and he displayed it perfectly. He was able to display his own inner-battles in his mind as well as the battles he had with his family, friends and enemies. His character was more of a psychological character study than anything else to me. Robert Duvall to me was the glue to the movie. He added a different perspective to everything in just that he was not Italian yet having the respect of the mafia. His character is a man of high authority within the Corleone family who was listened to and insightful;. This was simply perfect giving the film great balance throughout. The rest of the cast was just icing on the cake.

The writing was phenomenal and breathtaking. As mentioned before there has been no movie quoted more than this. It is not even the quotes though that makes the writing in here so perfect. It is the symbolism and meaning that went into every scene. There are countless symbols, messages and lines in here that are so memorable yet it is as realistic as a movie could get.

The directing by Coppola was perfect as well. Not many movies can be 3 hours and yet maintain a good level of interest from the audience like The Godfather. Coppola deserves credit for this. The symbolism and messages that went into every scene also has to do with the directing not just the writing. The movie is so well edited and strung together that the only word that could come to my mind is perfection.

The cinematography and music were perfect. The score of this movie is one of the most memorable ever. If you were to hear it you could identify it right away. The cinematography was what actually really drove this movie. The Godfather seems to have this mystique to it, it gives you the feeling you are watching something truly remarkable.

HE's got to be one of the worst actors that ever set foot on a set. Al Pacino acts like he is running on a 2 volt battery in this movie, and they're supposed to be Italians right? Mafia or otherwise Italians do not behave as they do in this movie, and this causes the film to lose credibility. Al Pacino is an amazing actor, my favorite, but in this movie he is mediocre. title: Truly, one of the greatest films ever made.
description: Francis Ford Coppola is certainly a respected name amongst the film industry, certainly due in part to Apocalypse now and The conversation (Maybe not dementia 13) but almost certainly for the Godfather trilogy. The first two films are peak cinema (The third isn't bad, but fails to reach the same heights.) with Coppola not being afraid to show the dark,gritty, ugly world of the Mafia. The Corelones are terrifying because they are such well-versed, attractive people. However, this is merely a front for their ruthless, uncompromising nature, turning on their so-called allies in a blink of an eye. There are many lessons in the film that are directly taken from Nicolas Machiaveli's The prince, regarding power, as well as a hint of Shakespeare's Macbeth. All these combine for a violent, dark, but artistic film, the likes of which may never be rivaled. Except maybe, by it's direct successor.

The other thing I really like about the film is how before he goes to get the gun from the bathroom to shoot the men in the restaurant. When he gets to the bathroom he takes the gun and has to calm himself down, then he goes to shoot the guys and hears the sound of a train right before he does it. I feel that the intensity of the train noise rising as he is about to shoot them was a brilliant choice of thing to do because it shows how he is thinking about it. I do not like how they used low lighting all the time. I get it is a dark type of movie but it does not need that type of lighting like all the time. They could have used neutral lighting because that is not light but not dark at the same time.
