The Godfather was a very good movie and overall it was a very nice movie with an amazing story-line. title: THE GODFATHER is perfect. Unbelievable performances. Outstanding direction. Strong dialog. Beautiful music.
description:
The Godfather is the greatest film of all time. It's perfect, or at least close to perfection. It is obviously overrated, but there's a reason it's like that.

The Godfather is perfect in many ways. First of, the acting. This is one of a few films in which brings amazing performances from the entire cast. Marlon Brando as the Godfather is obviously solid gold. The then 47-year-old nails it as the title character and offers an iconic, unforgettable performance that will always remain one of the strongest performances in movie history. Al Pacino succeeds as the "nice college boy" that changes strongly throughout the film. James Caan and Robert Duvall come strong as supporting characters, as well as Richard Castellano, Al Lettieri and Diane Keaton.

Francis Ford Coppola is one of the last great directors. His directing in The Godfather is brilliant and spectacular. The screenplay for the film is terrific. Many good and iconic lines, and great dialog. The music is beautiful. The main theme is bone chilling and the Love Theme is unique and a masterpiece. The cinematography is visually stunning, from the wedding party to Sicily, Italy, it's just breathtaking.

No matter how many years pass, I know for sure that The Godfather will always remain a strong and powerful film, and one of the most important films in motion picture history. Impossible to defeat, The Godfather really is the greatest film of all time.

title: A great movie
description:
This is a masterpiece. A timeless masterpiece. Initially, I didn't like this film all that much - I found it rather over-hyped and boring. This was until the advent of DVD, which gave me the feature I needed for this sort of film: subtitles. Once I switched them on and heard (read) every last word of Brando's ramblings and other characters ramblings, I grew a true appreciation for this epic.

To make a true epic, you need all of three following ingredients working in near perfect harmony. For screenwriters who come across this, take the following pointers on board: 1) Contrasting Characters: Good films have some character distinction, but most fall rather flat because the core of each character is the same.

Of course, there are exceptions to rule (ie... where you want mono-tonal characters... aka matrix; or where you want outlandish contrasts... aka The Fifth Element), but ultimately, this is what makes films deep, meaningful and grand. Consider the contrasts between the Don's children. Michael is rather cool, rational and collected, whereas Sonny is more hot-headed, spontaneous and simple minded. But simply having these contrasts is not nearly enough. What you really need to do is to develop these characters - place them in situations - and then dwell on how their character impacts on the situation they're put in. The Godfather is a terrific example of how to pull this off. While many try to do this in screenplays, most lose the plot and create character obscurities that stretch credibility.

title: One of the greats
description:
The Godfather is an incredible experience.

I can surely understand why critics put this movie at the top.

All of the performances done by the cast are incredible, they truly bring this movie to life. It's clear that the director and writer did their jobs brilliantly.

At the very start of the movie Marlon Brando gives out a powerful and emotional performance, making you wish that he was your Godfather.

Al Pacino is passed the torch at the middle of the movie, gaining more and more screen time, slowly becoming the star of the show.

This movie is an absolute pop culture hit. It has been referenced and continues to be referenced non stop throughout different types of media (movies,cartoons,tv series, etc...).

At it's time and for the next 30 years after it was released, it was probably THE best movie ever created.

It's certainly a classic and with a unbiased review I could easily give it a 10/10 if I was 20 years older and I grew up with this film.

If you live in the 21st century and for some reason you had not watched The Godfather like me, you will certainly have already seen most of the famous scenes and lines from the movie in one way or another.

Sadly watching this 50 years later has kind of ruined the delivery of those scenes for me.

In addition to that, this is a trilogy story, so the end does not really give it a satisfying conclusion. It does however give an amazing setup that makes you want more. My biased review is a harsh 8/10.

Summary: this movie is a must watch if you enjoy incredible quality cinema and very rich stories.

Al Pacino shines above all in this movie, as the smart boy of the family he returns after fighting a war for his country, at that time not involved in the family business, but it doesn't take long before the war breaks lose and he see no other ways than to step in and fight for his family.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece of Cinema
description: The Godfather is not just a crime film-it's a cinematic masterpiece that redefined storytelling. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, it offers a deep, emotional look into family, power, and loyalty. Marlon Brando delivers an unforgettable performance as Don Vito Corleone, while Al Pacino's transformation as Michael is one of the most powerful character arcs in film history. Every scene is crafted with precision, from the dialogue to the haunting soundtrack by Nino Rota. The film's atmosphere, pacing, and symbolism elevate it to legendary status. Even decades later, The Godfather remains one of the greatest films ever made.

title: Times have indeed changed
description: What helped Vito was loyalty, humanity, and a sense of honor. Times have changed, more things need to be balanced, and the direction of business is also adjusting, but in the gang, these things will not change. At the beginning of the second part, Frank came to Mike's son's birthday party and lamented, "There are so many musicians, but none of them are Italian." Mike became stubborn in the end and didn't trust anyone. This may have something to do with his brother. Fredo betrays himself. But Mike's incomplete trust in Tom was obvious from the beginning, even if he explained that it was because he didn't want Tom to be hurt, but trust or not, someone with a special status like Tom would be more sensitive. There is a section in the book that talks about how the old godfather used some methods to make Tom feel that he was fully trusted, but Mike obviously did not do this.

title: The best ever
description: Between the incredible story, superb acting and a musical score 2nd to none this is the one all others should be measured by. No one has done it better before or since. Coppola mastered, under incredible pressure, not only the interpretation of a best selling novel, but he was brave enough to fight for his casting choices. Brando, Pacino, Duvall, Caan and Cazale were never better or even equal to their performances in "the Godfather". Pacino fans may say "Scarface" was more of a tour de force, but to see the subtle change in Michael Corleone from pacifist war hero to cold-hearted killer is acting at it's finest. I have recommended "The Godfather" to a number of 20-something friends trying to imagine what their reactions would be. To a person, all have sung it's praises, proving the everlasting quality of "The Godfather".

title: Viewing is definitely recommended.
description:
Classics can be seen as old, intimidating, mostly black and white movies... The Godfather doesn't even glimpse at those characteristics, in contrast, it not only enthralls the audience, but also inspires other films relating to its topic. The 1940s revolved around a tone that was dark, and uninviting to sympathy, while The Godfather actually triggers extreme emotion towards the, otherwise seen as, "bad guys."

Characters that are seriously stereotyped take a new spin and actually make the viewer feel involved in the events of the movie. Michael, an army man in search of pure separation from his family and the family business, is in love with Kay, a young girl full of life and enthusiasm for Michael. While his older brother struggles to keep the family name intact.

The characters themselves shine in the light of a great story, full of excitement and suspense. Talks of war between families and the spread of drugs and gambling keep the viewer interested throughout the long film. The viewer is hopelessly involved with the family, having had no interaction with any real people or in conversations.

The Godfather is timeless with awesome actors and angles, the subject matter is rather heavy and it should be seen by parents before viewing by children. It is definitely a ten on a scale where that rates the highest.

If you are just starting into mob movies this movie is definitely the mob movie you must start with!

title: The quintessential film
description:
"The Godfather" is not only the greatest crime drama ever made, it is true perfection in every cinematic aspect. Coppola's directing is flawless, the performances and casting could not have been better, and the story based on Mario Puzo's novel is incredible in its intricate portrayal of a number of years during the twilight reign of an aging mafia Don, as he begins to disassemble his leadership over the family's business affairs and hand them over to his sons in the midst of an all-out war between New York City's Mafia families.

The editing is superb as there is not one scene in the film that is over or under done in any way. Indeed, every minute of the film is perfect, and I do not say that lightly. It is an extraordinary achievement and the confidence that Coppola demonstrates here cannot be understated. He masterfully moves the story from America to Sicily, and through the years without any blatant indication. Unlike what was to come in its wake, "The Godfather" manages to be violent but never gratuitous, which adds to its beauty and reinforces the point that what we are watching is splendid and perfect film-making. There is so much going on in the story, and plenty to watch out for, that it is a film you can watch and enjoy time and time again. The cinematography is breath-taking, the music strong and poignant, and when the going gets tough, it is very suspenseful and your heart will be beating rapidly. It is not only the quintessential crime film, but it is, as many polls and lists will tell you time and time again, the quintessential film. A riveting crime saga, a powerful family drama, and a nerve-shattering character study as we watch the fall of one Don, and the rise of another.

title: G. O. A. T Godfather!
description:
I wish to give 1000 stars. Epic movie! I have always loved movies on mafia and underworld. This movie is the rarest diamond amongst all. Extremely interesting, enticing, thought provoking. What else can be the benchmark for a cinema industry. This movie cams you, makes you feel joy, makes you think of sensible uber class dealing with organized crime, way of handling situation like a game play, astounding personality representation, makes your heart pound faster, your pulse rate, sweat and relief. The way this movie presents the reason for existence of mafia world, the beginning of it, the balance, the fall everything just is so heart touching. Unbelievable. Thank you for giving us such wonderful movie experience.

MASTERPIECE!

title: Perfect balance
description: Considered by many as "the best film in history", 'The Godfather' has earned a prestige and respect over the years, something fully deserved. To speak of 'The Godfather' is to speak of a perfect balance, a masterful balance between an epic Gangsters story, a powerful family drama and a man's personal conflict. All these themes are carried by Coppola in such a fluid way that nothing ends up feeling forced within the story. And although it is true, there are a large number of plots, characters and relationships, the aforementioned fluidity of the narrative, added to a technical perfection to tell the story, causes all these elements to have an impact on the narrative, which is pretty intuitive. Each factor is decisive and influences history, something that every filmmaker aspires to achieve, but that no one can say has achieved as Coppola. It is difficult to define cinematographic perfection, but if this were a conflict that encompasses all its characters and that all the factors play in order to tell the story in the best possible way, then we can consider that 'The Godfather' is a perfect work.

title: A piece of anthology !!!

title: Best film? Not likely... But it is filmmaking at its definite peek!
description: I have seen many films far more ambitious in their scope and execution, I have seen more than a dozen films that made far more important statements about the world, and I have seen films that moved me far beyond anywhere The Godfather could have moved me. But can the greatness of this film really be denied by anyone with even a vague knowledge about the filmmaking process? To call this film garbage is idiocy, there is no excuse, anyone who might make such a statement obviously has no clue about movies, even if they try to state otherwise. Despite the fact that in many ways it glamorizes the criminal life, The Godfather is the peek of excellence in film. It's a shame that people buy into the gangster formula created by Hollywood, it's a worse shame that people expect it, and when they do not see it they demand it! This film breaks out of the formula, and it does so shamelessly, but it doesn't do it thoughtlessly. There are truly excellent ironic statements all throughout the film, it surprises me that some people who claim to have some knowledge about film miss them. The baptism that Michael Corleone attends is just one example, the shots of the baptism are juxtaposed with intercut shots of brutal killings taking place at approximately the same time, killings that were ordered by Michael as he took over the "family business". It's a very powerful scene, almost revolting, it creates a very definite question mark as to the glamorous nature of the first part of the film. Once again, this is far from the greatest film, but it's a definite 10 - there is no question about it.

title: True to life
description: There's nothing more to say than that the acting was outstanding. Seeing stars like Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire, and Robert Duvall might still captivate audiences today. For a movie enthusiast, this is like paradise. Brando managed to re-establish his prominence with this film. His portrayal of the godfather on his own is legendary. His persona has been imitated in movies so frequently that it has practically become a cliché. However, his performance was not cliched. His performance was amazing and understated. It was arguably even more real and authentic than Marlon Brando himself because of how true to life it was.

title: Master
description:
To make a true epic, you need all of three following ingredients working in near perfect harmony. For screenwriters who come across this, take the following pointers on board: 1) Contrasting Characters: Good films have some character distinction, but most fall rather flat because the core of each character is the same.

Of course, there are exceptions to rule (ie... where you want mono-tonal characters... aka matrix; or where you want outlandish contrasts... aka The Fifth Element), but ultimately, this is what makes films deep, meaningful and grand. Consider the contrasts between the Don's children. Michael is rather cool, rational and collected, whereas Sonny is more hot-headed, spontaneous and simple minded. But simply having these contrasts is not nearly enough. What you really need to do is to develop these characters - place them in situations - and then dwell on how their character impacts on the situation they're put in. The Godfather is a terrific example of how to pull this off. While many try to do this in screenplays, most lose the plot and create character obscurities that stretch credibility.

title: an offer you can't refuse
description: This is, undoubtedly, THE classic movie of all time, and seems to set a standard for lines, effects, acting, action, and all other basic elements connected with any movie. With all due respects to the outstanding and late actor Marlon Brando, it was more than just he who made the movie an outstanding success, though he was convincing as the usually-calm yet almost-always cold, controlling don Vito Corleone The nostalgia effects were superb: it was not the least bit difficult to imagine what NYC was like between 1945 and 1955. (1971 NYC was "turned into" the NYC of the time setting of the story.) James Caan was as mean as mean could be in his role as the godfather Vito Corleone's son Santino, (Sonny) and Al Pacino, as the don's youngest and favorite son Michael Corleone, had his career launched in just this movie. Of course, Diane Keaton proved to be a promising future star in her role as Kay Adams at her young age of about twenty-five. The story came across as a story of, in my personal opinion, how NOT to live. (Of course, some would disagree with me one hundred per cent on that.) This in-depth study of the Mafia (though the word "mafia", as the case was supposed to be, was never used) was definitely a convincing view of the underworld with, among other things, the "eye-for-eye" mindset. To recapitulate, the nostalgia, the action, the acting, and the story itself made it THE great feat for Hollywood for all time. Paramount Studios, the director Francis Ford Coppola, and the producer Albert S. Ruddy should be proud.

title: Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece. Released in 1972
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is nothing short of a cinematic masterpiece. Released in 1972, this epic crime drama continues to captivate audiences with its compelling storytelling, impeccable performances, and iconic moments.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of the enigmatic Don Vito Corleone is a tour de force, earning him an Oscar for Best Actor. The film's narrative weaves a complex web of family loyalty, power struggles, and moral dilemmas within the Corleone mafia dynasty.

The cinematography, particularly Gordon Willis's moody and atmospheric lighting, sets the tone for the film's dark and brooding ambiance. Nino Rota's haunting score adds depth to the storytelling.

"The Godfather" is a profound exploration of the human condition, ethics, and the corrupting influence of power. It's a film that continues to be celebrated and studied, reminding us of the enduring impact of cinema as an art form. A true classic that stands the test of time.

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece and Epic tale of Power, Loyalty, and Betrayal
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is an enduring cultural landmark that reshaped the gangster genre and set a new standard for storytelling. It changed the image of the Italian American immigrant Story. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the film dives deep into the lives of the Corleone family. It offers a powerful narrative about power, loyalty, and family in the American Mafia.

At the heart of this epic is Marlon Brando's legendary portrayal of Don Vito Corleone, a role that has become iconic in film history. Brando's quiet, restrained power is mesmerizing, commanding every scene he's in with that Iconic Chin. Al Pacino, as Michael Corleone, delivers a transformative performance, evolving from a reluctant outsider to the ruthless leader of the family..

The film's pacing is deliberate, taking time to immerse viewers in its richly textured world of Italian/Sicilian American Culture of the 50's. Coppola masterfully balances grand, operatic set-pieces with intimate, character-driven moments, creating a perfect blend of tension and drama. The cinematography, with its rich shadows and iconic lighting, adds a sense of realism to every frame, giving the film a timeless quality.

Nino Rota's haunting score elevates the film, underscoring the tragic beauty and brutality of the Corleone family's rise to power.

The film doesn't just glorify crime; it examines the personal and moral costs of the characters' actions, making the audience question the true price of ambition and power.

The Godfather isn't just a movie; it's an epic. From its unforgettable dialogue to its twist in plot, it is a masterclass in filmmaking that remains just as captivating today as it was over five decades ago.

A timeless classic that continues to influence cinema and stands as the greatest film of all time for me.

title: Best ever
description:
Francis Ford Coppola brings to life one of the greatest crime novels ever, portraying Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone, one of the best performances ever.

The Godfather is head of organized crime, run by his family, and is a very 'reasonable' man. He offers help to anyone who comes to him, expecting in return, only friendship. His denial to accept a narcotics deal gets him shot and although he survives, things are never the same again, with constant attempts to murder the bedridden Godfather. It is at this time when the family is losing power, that Michael Corleone, another brilliant performance by Al Pacino, slowly rises to power within the family. The rest is history.

title: The greatest movie ever made
description:
The Godfather is the greatest movie ever made. The acting by the legendary Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone is the greatest male performance in movie history. The supporting cast of Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall and Diane Keaton started their legendary careers with this film, their first important work in a major epic film.

The Godfather is not a simple gangster movie. It is a movie about family. The family just happens to be made up of gangsters. But even in the terrible underworld there is morality amongst this group. they do not kill arbitrarily. The Godfather himself is reluctant to get into the world of narcotics and it almost cost him his life.

The script by Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola is extraordinary, as is Coppola's direction. The attention to detail of Italian culture is superb. From beginning to end you will be riveted by the interaction of the Corleone family, as well as the Corleone "family".

Don't miss the greatest movie ever made

title: An Icon
description: At once an observant homage to crime films of the Thirties and Forties and a loving portrait of an Italian-American family, Francis Ford Coppola's adaptation of Mario Puzo's superlative novel (Puzo also co-write the script) is an achievement few films can hope to approximate. Coppola, along with his cinematographer, Gordon Willis, and his production designer, Dear Tavoularis, have created a history wholly realized, burnished brown as if a memory that will never completely fade. The world of the Cosa Nostra they present is closed and stuffy which provides an intimacy that generates an extraordinary amount of warmth and a feeling of lives being affected. The cast is flawless: the actors, to a person, inhabit the characters with such understanding and affection that they will be forever associated with them. (Al Pacino as Michael in the trilogy will never be able to match this work elsewhere.) But it is Marlon Brando in the title role that delivers such devastating work that you can only sit and stare in wonderment. Brando has a presence wise beyond his years and his gentle, thoughtful manner is never once betrayed his calculating, violent acts. Every movement, every vocal inflection is detailed and planned but he offers a spontaneity that never reveals technique. Guided by Coppola's abiding dedication to realism, Brando pushes this film to icon status. Not to be missed.

title: Coppola's Masterpiece
description: Wow! When I came out the Godfather for the first time that was first thing I said, wow. I guess that one word can mean a lot of things but to me it was just short for 'this movie is amazing and I've never seen anything like it ever and I'm glad I can say that i've watched it'. The problem was, the first time I watched it, I had to asked my dad half the time what the hec these guys were talking about or who was killing who'. But the second time I watched it, I understood every word and really got into it. Cause, it's a classic and I'm that kind of person who loves to watch some of those great old films like On the Waterfront or the French Connection. And the The Godfather wasn't like any of them. The story was amazing and god forbid the fantastic dialogue but I think that the film's strong point is the acting. Well, when you've got Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Diane Keaton and Robert Duvall attached to a movie then you kind of already know it's gonna be amazing. And it was. Marlon Brando really deserved his Oscar for playing the extremely iconic role of Vito Corleone and Al Pacino, Robert Duvall and James Caan all deserved there nominations as well. Personally, I don't think there's anything really wrong with this film. The cinematography is wonderful, I've mentioned the acting and the writing, the costumes are superb and the violence is as brutal as it is compelling. If you have the time, then watch this masterpiece.

The movie shows us how a man can change, no matter what point in life he's at, because of the environment he's thrown into. An absolute masterpiece that has inspired millions of works of fiction-both those already made and those still being created today. Without a doubt you can say that this film started the new era of cinema.

title: God Father Review
description:
I would like to start with a thank you,

Thank you, thank you, thank you for making this classic.

By far the best motion picture i've seen, Lighting, Actors, Mood, Locations, Writing, Cinematography, Direction, Edit & Execution. Hands down it is a prefect movie in every shape of the word. The moment i began watching this movie it took me in, i'm not Italian but felt proud to be a Latin American after watching this because of the amount of pride and value the writer gave to these characters, the love of family is one that i can relate to being from a Hispanic family. Many similarities in the way we conduct our lives.

Building up the Godfather, with the dramatic lighting, long cuts, the sense of realism as if you were there at the wedding says so much about the director. The roll of the god father must have been a hard roll to fill and execute, but Marlon Brando murdered it. He is nothing like any of his movies in the past. The embodiment of this character is one to remember. Hollywood needs more movies like this to be released in 2016 and 2017.

I'll be waiting...

title: Real power cannot be given, it can be taken...
description:
The Mafia and its real power... Respect and reputation for you as a person and the value of your word.

Good evening, dear ladies and gentlemen. Before that, I wrote a fascinating review about what is so necessary for every person in our time. Come in, I'm sure you'll like it here. I happened to watch the Godfather movie... Advantages: Great actors Al Pacino and Marlon Brandon, an excellent plot, a wonderful musical composition, an intrigue that captures and does not let go during the entire viewing.

Disadvantages: No. In my opinion, this film is not a propaganda of the cult of brave and strong guys who were allowed everything, without consequences and punishment. I saw in it an attempt by Francis Ford Coppola to show how one strong, determined and strong-willed person can make completely different people, honest and immoral, principled and indifferent, become one whole, harmoniously working organism, clearly pursuing a certain goal - absolute power. Not the one that sits in Congress, but the real one - on the streets, solving daily topical issues.

Perhaps this is one of the best roles not only of Marlon Brando, but also of the young Al Pacino. It is precisely such a hero, brave and determined, a man who broke the law, but at the same time remained a man, that he will be remembered by me for the rest of my life. All other roles in other films just fade away against the background of this game - a real game of life.

There are no homegrown special effects in the film, many scenes are played out in the old classic way, with the help of scenery and extras, and the picture only benefits from this, because we become witnesses to a real life story that we begin to believe. All the feelings are so sharp and real that if the main character loves, I also begin to love, hates, and this terrible feeling is transmitted to me.

The film exposed, in my opinion, the most terrible and obvious problems of modern society, which are relevant to this day. No matter how strong the vertical of power is, it will never be able to protect each of its citizens, ensure the rule of law and justice, and then a person begins to fill the vacuum of power on the ground with other laws - force and authority.

I would also like to mention the excellent musical accompaniment that keeps the viewer in suspense throughout the film. The main melody has become a real hit and is recognizable all over the world. I am not a fan of the idea that any problems need to be solved, and if it does not work out peacefully, then by force, but our society has not yet come up with anything better than a more effective way. For my part, I would like to recommend this film as a real established classic of cinematography.

title: An Epic Masterpiece That Defines Cinematic Greatness - 10/10
description:
"The Godfather" stands as an unparalleled cinematic achievement that transcends mere storytelling to become a cultural phenomenon and a benchmark for excellence in filmmaking. Directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, this 1972 classic has rightfully earned its place as one of the greatest films in history.

At the core of "The Godfather" is the gripping narrative of the Corleone family, a powerful Italian-American mafia clan led by the patriarch, Vito Corleone, portrayed flawlessly by Marlon Brando. The film weaves a complex and morally ambiguous tale of power, loyalty, and the consequences of choices made in the pursuit of the American Dream.

Until now (and it's been 36 years), in my opinion, nothing has been shot in the genre of "gangster thriller", not only superior, but even close in quality. It's not a movie -it's life. You can watch it endlessly, and with each viewing discover some new details, circumstances, thoughts. At one time I watched it endlessly, in Russian and in English, and read the book, and in general I was a real fan, which almost never happens to me. Now I prefer films that are less bloody, but I take my hat off to the creator.

In general, what to say. Everyone has probably already watched it. And who hasn't watched yet - throw everything - and to the screen!

title: A multi-Oscar-winner and over 1500 reviews...what more can I say about the movie?!
description:
Up until today, I haven't bothered to review "The Godfather". After all, everyone pretty much knows it's one of the greatest films ever made. It's #2 on IMDb's Top 100. It won the Best Picture Oscar. And, there are nearly 1600 reviews on IMDb. So what's one more review?! Well, after completing 14,000 reviews (because I am nuts), I guess it's time I got around to reviewing a film I should have reviewed a long time ago. So, here goes....the film is perfect and only a dope wouldn't watch it. Unfortunately, IMDb requires me to say more to meet it's 10 line minimum for reviews. So, I'll point out that you do NOT need to like gangster films to enjoy this film. Yes, it's violent and nasty in spots--but it's also brilliantly written and produced from start to finish and deserves the accolades it's received.

My advice is that instead of just watching "The Godfather" and "The Godfather: Part II", see the combined version they created for television--with additional scenes that made it a very rich experience.

Citizen Kane was also brilliant, but it had flaws. How often is there a Godfather reference on tv? in a conversation? I can talk to anyone for hours about this film. This is the standard, this is the benchmark.

title: Seminal Masterpiece
description:
Everyone knows that "The Godfather" is a classic. I'm not saying anything new or adding to the conversation by stating the obvious. Today marks the third time in my life that I've watched "The Godfather" and each time I glean more and more, and each time I appreciate it more and more. At just under three hours long it was a chore to watch when I was younger.

We used to have a smallish collection of movies on VHS when I was growing up. Of them, I distinctly remember "Gandhi," "Lion of the Desert," and "The Godfather" as being long movies. I loved "Lion of the Desert" as a kid simply because of the war aspect (I need to rewatch it), while "Gandhi" and "The Godfather" used to put me to sleep.

If you're wondering how I was even allowed to watch "The Godfather" as a kid, I wasn't, but I would sneak and watch whatever we had on VHS. Whenever I tired of the movies I'd seen a dozen times already I would pop in one of the adult titles (meaning "R" rating or any movie with a plot too boring for an elementary school child). So I tried my hand at "The Godfather," among other titles, and found myself struggling to follow all the dialogue and slow developing plot.

I watched "The Godfather" again as an early twenty-something and found a true appreciation of it, but I still didn't catch on to the depth of the story.

Watching it again at nearly fifty-years-old, I could truly appreciate the story as it chronicled the broad, as well as nuanced, operation of the Italian mafia with a focus on the Corleone family. The most standout characters and performances were that of Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone and Al Pacino as Michael Corleone.

Like I said, I'm sure every superlative has been used already to describe "The Godfather." I'll just add that Director Francis Ford Coppola outdid himself with this seminal masterpiece. It's a film that will live on in cinematic lore and deserves its place as one of the best movies of all time.

$3.99 on YouTube TV.

title: Rarely can it be said that a film has defined a genre, but never is that more true than in the case of The Godfather.
description:
Rarely does a film tell as many diverse-yet-interconnected stories. Strong performances, solid directing, and a tightly-plotted script all contribute to The Godfather's success. This motion picture was not slapped together to satiate the appetite of the masses; it was carefully and painstakingly crafted. Every major character - and more than a few minor ones - is molded into a distinct, complex individual. Stereotypes did not influence Coppola's film, although certain ones were formed as a result of it.

We come to The Godfather like Kay Adams - outsiders uncertain in our expectations - but it doesn't take long for us to be captivated by this intricate, violent world. The film can be viewed on many levels, with equal satisfaction awaiting those who just want a good story, and those who demand much more. The Godfather is long, yes - but it is one-hundred seventy minutes well-spent. When the closing credits roll, only a portion of the story has been told. Yet that last haunting image (Kay's shock of recognition), coupled with Nino Rota's mournful score, leaves a crater-like impression that The Godfather Part II only deepens.

title: Spectacular! For the older crowd
description:
`The Godfather' is a spectacular movie, for the older crowd. Between a quotable script, great theme music, and a fabulous main character, this film will keep the viewer wondering.

While watching `The Godfather', the viewer may recognize many lines. Some of examples of those could be, ` I'll give em an offer he can't refuse,' or `Take it to the mattresses.' Simply the fact that lines from the movie are well known, proves that this movie is worthy of watching.

Throughout the movie, the same music is played over and over, but in different styles. For example, if someone is about to get shot, the music speeds up, and almost gets scary. When a happy time comes, the music gets softer, and more legato.

Finally, one of the best things about this movie is the main character. Al Pacino plays Michael, the child of the original Godfather. After his father gets shot in a mob hit, Michael, takes over the family business, and completely changes who from the person he used to be. Al Pacino is very believable in this role.

Overall, this reviewer gives this movie a 9 out of 10. It is definitely a movie worth seeing, but leave the kids at their friends, there is more gore than many would like.

title: This is a cinematic masterpiece
description:
The Godfather (1972) is a masterpiece that I recently rewatched for the first time in a long time on Paramount+. The storyline follows an American mafia family with a Godfather who is a direct descendant from Italy. As the father gets older and close to dying and handing down his power within the family he fields a series of asks, favors and political placement requests for power within the underground world.

This movie is directed by Francis Ford Coppola (Apocalypse Now) and stars Marlon Brando (A Streetcar Named Desire), Al Pacino (Scarface), James Caan (Misery), Diane Keaton (Annie Hall), Robert Duvall (Slingblade), Talia Shire (Rocky) and Abe Vigoda (Joe versus the Volcano).

The performances by the entire cast in this movie is outstanding with especially powerful performances by Brando and Pacino and strong supporting performances by Duvall, Caan and Shire. The soundtrack and settings are legendary. This film makes you want to book a trip to Italy immediately. The mafia wedding to start the movie is so well executed and as is the evolution of Pacino's character. The dialogue is brilliantly written and the cast delivers every line with the right level of intensity. The ending a perfect way to end the movie and show the power and struggle of being The Godfather.

Overall this is a cinematic masterpiece that is an absolute must see. I would score this an easy 10/10.

title: the best movie

We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.

title: Review for The Godfather
description: An acclaimed film that deserves its acclaim, The Godfather validates the crime epic and explores the dark side of the American dream. The Godfather is simply a classy production; unlike the mass of movies, most of which can each be criticized on some level, The Godfather manages to engage its audience throughout, and the portrayals of Brando, Pacino and Duvall, to name a few, were instant classics. Moreover, the film is memorable, in particular for its performances, assured direction and insightful depiction of the corridors of power of the American Mafia (not to mention it's extremely quotable). I did not give it ten out of ten for this reason: it did not move me so much as some other films. The Godfather is not my favorite movie, but I can see how for many people it is.

title: A 10, one of the greatest of all time
description: Crime dramas are not my favorite, but any movie that starts with a great script, great cast and the exceptional talent of Francis Ford Coppola means a great movie is not dependent on the subject matter but the execution. Al Pacino and Marlon Brando were at their best and it's hard seeing actors performances stand up to their talent; and Robert DeNiro as the young Vito matches Brando so well. All three cemented their places in film history with The Godfather. If there is a drawback it's that both parts I & II are all one movie and at 6 hours would have made a great mini series. While part III doesn't have quite the punch, it is a necessary addition to this mini series. There are very few films that earn a 10 in my book, but The Godfather Parts I & II are in the elite club.

title: The Transformation
description:
The movie starts with a wedding ceremony where the father of the bride is the boss of an organized crime syndicate. His elder son takes the whole control of his place when he was attacked to near death. The situation forced the younger son to take the whole control while he was not interested in his family business. Thus, the movie deals with how the youngest son transforms from a good guy to a ruthless mafia kingpin.

Umm, I don't have to tell more about this movie, as thousands of people in the world who are great in movie reviewing, are already reviewed it. So, nothing new to tell more.

The thing is, this movie is considered an all-time masterpiece in history. I would like to focus which I liked in this movie.

Marlon Brando, is the aging father, The Godfather in this movie. Whose performance is one of the things which made this movie great.

Al Pacino, is the youngest son, also did great performance which nominates him the Best Supporting Actor Academic Award. But he refused to attend it as he thought he deserved a nomination for Best Actor category. Since this movie centered him. And also he had the most screen time. Whereas, Marlon Brando got the Best Actor award for his almost brief role. I think, it is justified, as the first impression is the last impression. Marlon Brando is the first impression of this movie. He is the life of this movie and Al Pacino is one of the parts of the body. But in fact, Al Pacino is the hero of this movie.

I liked the music, which was also nominated for the Best Score award but cancelled its nomination at the last moment when it was discovered that the score was originally used in another movie first, which is Charlie Chaplin's Limelight.

The director of this movie is Francis Ford Coppola. I wonder, how he directs the movie? He was just 32-33 year old when the movie was made. A 31-32 year old young man directs this masterpiece movie. And finished it in 62 days of shooting. This is amazing. Being a 33 year one now, I really wonder how he directs the movie in this small age? Such a matured movie. Though, it was first offered to director, one of my favorite directors, the director of The Good, The Bad and the Ugly, Sergio Leone. Later he regrets his decision.

This movie is the finest example of an ideal writing and editing. Without these, this movie is nothing, despite having good casts and direction.

I enjoyed the movie a lot. I believe almost everyone will enjoy it. Despite a long movie, long 3 hours.

Don't watch it with the family.

Recommended 95%.

title: Best

title: A magnificent film seen and revisited multiple times
description:
Le Parrain is simply one of my all-time favorite films. I was completely captivated by this epic saga from the very first time I watched it. Every time I revisit it, I am immersed in the dark and fascinating world of the Italian-American mafia.

What struck me the most were the incredible performances by the actors. Marlon Brando is absolutely extraordinary in the role of Don Vito Corleone. His presence on screen is magnetic, and his acting is captivatingly intense. I also admire Al Pacino in the role of Michael Corleone, delivering a stunning performance as he portrays the gradual transformation of his character.

The plot is meticulously crafted, with surprising twists and palpable tension throughout the film. Each scene is carefully executed, with meticulous attention to detail and striking visual aesthetics. The iconic music by Nino Rota adds an extra layer to the film's atmosphere, enhancing the emotional impact of various sequences.

What makes Le Parrain so special is its ability to delve into the complexities of family and power, exploring the moral dilemmas that the characters face. The film raises profound questions about human nature and the choices we make. It also offers an authentic portrayal of immigration and cultural identity.

title: A film about family, not gangsters
description:
It's 2022, is it even worth writing a review of a film 50 years old that's already acknowledged as one of, if not the greatest film ever made?

I'm here because although I've had the vhs, then the dvd and now the restored blu-ray I've just been lucky enough to watch this masterpiece at the cinema, it's currently being shown to mark the 50TH anniversary.

I'm 50 myself so I've grown up with the film, so it's slow pace seems normal to me. Whether younger generations will adjust to it who knows. The wedding at the beginning is probably too long but perseverance for the first 25 minutes pays off later.

The Godfather has many iconic scenes, so much so that a lot of them are known to people even if they've never seen this film and they've been parodied heavily over the decades.

Although this was originally made as a stand alone film the beauty of the trilogy is that they tie the films together so well, although the third film arrived many years later so feels weaker than the first two it's still essential. Part ll jumps back and forth between events set before and after The Godfather which makes the whole story enriched and for the better.

Set yourself a weekend aside, turn your phone off. Make yourself some pasta, pour yourself a glass of wine and sit back and enjoy.

title: The Coppola Restoration
description:
The name "The Coppola Restoration" says it all - because the complete "Godfather" trilogy for this Blu-ray edition has been extensively restored at the insistence of director Francis Ford Coppola. Since the original camera negative no longer existed, the best possible pieces were brought together from all parts of the world, subjected to film scanning on a 4k scanner and then polished on thousands of individual images using the latest digital technology: Contrast and colors were optimized and coordinated with one another , Dirt particles removed and much more.

All this and what Steven Spielberg has to do with the whole thing can be found in the article "Rescue through film emulsion", which is unfortunately a bit short at 19 minutes. "When the shooting was over" also focuses on technical processes such as editing and music. Indispensable for cineastes is "A masterpiece that was almost none", which addresses the difficult production conditions and the problematic situation of the filmmakers at the end of the sixties (with detailed input from George Lucas, among others). The pop-cultural meaning of "The Godfather" is made abundantly clear to the viewer in "The Godfather's World" (keyword "The Simpsons"). In addition, there are many other new bonuses and - kudos to Paramount - all the extras of the DVD edition from 2001 (including three frank director's comments, a 75-minute documentary, deleted scenes). Our conclusion: the Blu-ray box is an offer that cannot be refused.

title: You straightened my brother out?
description:
What an absolutely marvelous movie! Ford Coppola is truly an amazing director, and so are the entire cast of The Godfather. If it weren't for the second film of this franchise, and also Goodfellas, I would've undoubtedly dubbed this as the best crime drama of all time.

The movie starts out showing the full and yet uncorrupted Corleone family, with Don Vito Corleone as the head of the family, Sonny as the hot headed underboss, Tom Hagen as the Consigliere, Fredo as the weak brother who is something between a soldier and a capo and Michael, the youngest of them all who doesn't want to walk along the path of his father. Soon enough though, internal trust issues arise in the family as multiple assasination attempts are carried out on a few family members, of which, Michael takes revenge for.

In an attempt to hide Michael from the ensuing drama, he is sent back to Sicily, where he finds new life and tries to start from there. But his short yet dark history follows him and he is left with nothing after going through all the things he has gone through. The innocent, brave war hero Michael is now willing to take on his father's shoes and bring the Corleone family its lost muscle and respect.

In this movie, we see many things that current movie crews can learn from. From using lighting to cover heavy make-up, to an absolute masterful execution of a Juxtaposition right around the end, this movie has it all. All 3 hours of it is a beautiful learning and enjoyable experience.

Also just saying, if you're watching this with kids, there's just a few seconds of upper-body nudity here from Simonetta Stefanelli and that's about it. So if your kid is above 14-15 it should be fine.

title: Who's the real godfather in this film?
description:
Well what is there to say about this movie? Is it still the top movie on this site, or is it not? Personally, it is not one of the reviewer's all time favorites, but it is still a very good movie. One significant detail of this movie, is counter culture. The movie is filled with it.

As the movie starts Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), who is known as the Godfather, is in his office. It is his daughters wedding day, and according to Sicilian tradition, he cannot refuse any requests that are made to him that day. The room is filled with people wanting something. The whole family is there for the occasion. Michael (Al Pacino), the God father's youngest son , is back home from the war. He brings his new girl friend, (Diane Keaton) with him. Michael's brothers, Sonny (James Caan) and Fredo (John Cazale), are there too.

Family loyalty is an important message that is stressed in this movie. The Don, Vito Corleone heads the family . He is against dealing in drugs. According to him, society is not alarmed by liquor, gambling or prostitution, but he feels it is wrong to deal drugs. He refers to it as a dirty business. What appears to be a moral decision on the Don's part is really counter culture because his decision not to support dealing in drugs has nothing to do with the legality of it but because he feels society would not accept it.

A lot of emphasis is put on trusting a man's word, yet the central character do not always trust each other. Woman are not highly regarded by the family. The Don's wife is only shown in a few scenes. Sonny ignores his wife. and the Don's daughter Connie's husband is not allowed into the family business. Instead, he given a job so he can earn a living. The counter culture in this movie, represents the killings of innocent, and not so innocent people between families. Throughout most of the movie, the Corleone family is in somewhat of a battle between another Italian family. Because of this, Don Corleone who is the Godfather of many, (Marlon Brando) is shot by one of the other families. This heats up the subject for the Corleone family, because it puts two of his sons Michael (Al Pacino) and Santino `Sonny' (James Caan) in between a rock and a hard place. That is just one of the examples of counter culture in this movie. Here is another example. Sunny finds out two different times that his sister's husband is beating her. Outraged by all this happening, Sunny takes off to go find his brother in law. The first time, he finds him, he is successful in beating the wind out of him, however the second time he gets gunned down by his in-laws. Right about then, Don, is called to make a peace treaty with the other family, to stop all this violence between the families. But are all the violent scenes in the movie over with? Unfortunately not. There are so many more examples of counter culture than the ones listed in this review. In order to see all the examples of counter culture, you would have to view the movie a couple times to understand what is going on in it.

Over all, it was a very good movie in my opinion. I was Glued to the edge of my seat the whole time, just waiting to see what happens next. The reviewer gives The Godfather a five gold star rating.

title: Top movie
description: The best movie of all time, because it shows what true character development is in a movie. The character arch of Michael Corleone through the movies is one of the best ever written. It succeeds not only in pulling off the use of a classical/formal/mannered film language correctly and remarkably; that language is used to emotionally evoke a grand archetypal American narrative, Operatic and Tragic, built around an immigrant family, and charting its rise, corruption, and fall in ways that comment on a vast array of subjects that relate to the American condition: Marriage, Politics, Poverty, Crime, Innocence Lost, Violence, Loyalty, Betrayal, etc. etc. So: It's a classical tale told nearly perfectly; with rich, soulful acting, magnificent cinematography, and insinuating, meaningful dialogue.

title: best movie
description: Best movie which has good number of actors dedicated to their role."The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, stands as a monumental masterpiece in the landscape of American cinema. This epic crime film, released in 1972, weaves the tale of the powerful Corleone mafia family, with a focus on the transformation of Michael Corleone, played with unparalleled depth by Al Pacino, from reluctant outsider to ruthless mafia boss."The Godfather" is not just a film about the mafia; it is a story about America, about the immigrant experience, and about the dark underbelly of the American Dream. It challenges the viewer to contemplate the price of loyalty, the bonds of family, and the cyclical nature of power and violence.

title: "I Believe in America"
description:
The Godfather is a masterpiece. It is one of the few films without any significant weaknesses (any that I've found, at least) and it's been my favorite film since I first saw it at age 15. Each and every actor gives a stellar performance, especially Marlon Brando as Don Corleone and Al Pacino as his son Michael. Both men completely disappear into their roles, transforming Mario Puzo's characters into pop culture icons. The pacing of the movie is brilliantly done, keeping the audience wanting more through the whole three-hour runtime. The score by Nino Rota is amazing and has stuck with me long after my last viewing (I will occasionally find myself humming the Love Theme without meaning to), and the writing is brilliant. I could go on and on about everything that makes this movie a classic, but it really has all been said before. All I have left to say is that you need to see this movie if you haven't already. The Godfather more than lives up to the hype.

10/10

The acting is impressive, and the story is even better. This is 100% a must-watch if you are into mob movies or classic movies.

title: So inspiring
description:
This film will works so well it takes the place in underworld

The Godfather is a 1972 American epic gangster film directed by Francis Ford Coppola, who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo, based on Puzo's best-selling 1969 novel of the same title. The film stars an ensemble cast including Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Richard Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte, and Diane Keaton. It is the first installment in The Godfather trilogy, chronicling the Corleone family under patriarch Vito Corleone (Brando) from 1945 to 1955. It focuses on the transformation of his youngest son, Michael Corleone (Pacino), from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss.

title: Simply a masterpiece.
description:
The Godfather is written & directed by Francis Ford Coppola and stars Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Richard Castellano, Robert Duvall and Richard Conte.

The ageing patriarch of an organised crime dynasty transfers control of his clandestine empire to his reluctant son.

Whenever you get into a discussion with someone about filmmaking or ask about their favourite movies of all time, at some point they will mention The Godfather. There's a very simple explanation for this, and it's something to be discovered when experiencing the movie for yourself.

It's very clear how incredibly well written this movie is, from the first scene, to the last. Not only the writing, but the magnetic performances throughout are consistently showcased against a backdrop of New York from 1945-1955. One of the reasons this movie is so beautiful is because of how realistic it is. Although we can't say we've been a part of an empire like featured in the movie, we can all relate to the characters. It's a dark and tragic story.

The acting as aforementioned is phenomenal. Brando is vitally important in his convincing portrayal of Don Vito Corleone. As is Al Pacino as he gradually becomes the front-man during the movie's running-length. Caan has a heart-breaking turn in his character's arc, and he performs wonderfully. The same for Duvall, Conte and everyone else not mentioned. The list is too long to name each individual, but they don't go unnoticed.

Although this is a long movie, there's so much going on and in such intricate detail that the time effortlessly drifts by. Every character has a chance to transform within the time-frame. Don't be put off by the duration. Many filmmakers these days are afraid of making their work too long, but if done correctly, it can be a tremendous piece of art. This movie is a fine example of that fact.

The original score by Nino Rota is one of the most recognised soundtracks of all time, and respectfully so. There are moments where his music is used greatly, and moments where it isn't used at all. While this happens the music is changing also. It's the perfect sound for such a story, and pairs with the picture brilliantly.

Verdict; The Godfather is widely regarded as a masterpiece. One of the greatest movies of our time. I can fully agree with these statements and add that in its many years since release, it hasn't aged a bit. If you haven't yet experienced The Godfather, please do yourself a favour. With so much greatness in front of you, it's an offer you can't refuse.

The Godfather, 10/10.

title: good
description: The Godfather is a technically educational film with a dark and realistic atmosphere. The cinematographer of the film, Gordon Willis, used shadows and contrast in such a way that when you watch, you say this is the movie. On the one hand, you are watching the dark and beautiful atmosphere, and on the other hand, you are watching the plot. Some people may have been bored in the first scenes while watching the movie, but I wasn't bored because the mafia theme was a theme I liked before. The film tells about the dispute between the Carlone family and Comma Solozzo over his drugged job. Don Carleone politely refuses the offer, calling it a "druggy" dirty job, but Solozzo, who is not very pleased with this, personally arranges an assassination of Carleone, causing things to escalate. This is the crucial point of the film. We are watching the characteristic change of Michael, who normally has little to do with family affairs. Michel first kills Solozzo to avenge his father, and then takes over the family business. It's as if that innocent child who was watching family affairs from a distance is gone, instead of a calm but cold killer has arrived. Michael is actually the opposite of his brother Sonny. Sonny is a person who can't control his anger, acts irrationally, while Michael is logical and so calm. No matter how much "The Godfather" is a crime movie, it's actually a movie that moves from a father and son relationship. The best example that can be given to this is the scene where Don Vito and Michael are alone. In this scene, Carleone says that he has always worked for his family all his life, and he will not be ashamed to work, but he has not thought about Michael to take over the family until today. It was a pretty good movie for me, but it may not appeal to everyone, I can understand that. The main point that you should focus on in this film is not the mafia life, but that you can't trust anyone but your family and that you have no one but them. Otherwise, why would Kim turn his family into a criminal organization? We also see in the film that almost everyone betrayed the father except his sons.(Comma Solozzo, Tattaglia family, Carlo, Tessio) That's what I meant when I said you can't trust anyone but your family. Finally, I have a cutting message for those who don't like the Godfather and have hated him all their lives: Watch the Godfather not as a mafia movie, but as a father and son movie, because only then can you love this movie. Enjoy the mafia theme if you want, hate it if you want Junkie theme. Thanks for Reading.

title: ADVENTURE
description:
The Godfather is a landmark film that redefined the gangster genre and elevated it to an art form. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's best-selling novel, the movie takes viewers into the complex world of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia dynasty in 1940s New York. From the beginning, Coppola immerses the audience in a world of loyalty, betrayal, power, and family, making every frame feel as though it's charged with tension and emotion.

The movie's storyline centers around the transformation of Michael Corleone, brilliantly portrayed by Al Pacino. At the beginning of the film, Michael is an outsider to his family's criminal empire, a decorated war hero with no intentions of entering the "family business." However, as events unfold, Michael is gradually drawn into the world of organized crime, ultimately becoming his father's successor. This transformation is a journey of inner conflict, one that pulls him away from his morals, family, and the hope of a different life. Pacino's nuanced performance is essential to the film's power, portraying Michael's descent into ruthlessness while maintaining a sense of humanity.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone, the patriarch of the family, is equally unforgettable. With his distinctive voice and measured movements, Brando gives the character an aura of authority and respectability, humanizing a role that could easily have felt one-dimensional. The character of Vito Corleone is a study in contrasts: he is ruthless when protecting his family's interests, yet shows warmth and wisdom in personal interactions. The audience can't help but be drawn to his sense of loyalty and his belief in the values that define the Corleone family.

Cinematography in The Godfather is masterful, establishing mood and atmosphere through the interplay of light and shadow. Cinematographer Gordon Willis, also known as the "Prince of Darkness" for his skillful use of low lighting, uses these shadows to add depth to scenes and reflect the moral ambiguity of the characters. From the intimate dimness of the Corleone family home to the stark contrasts of daylight scenes, Willis creates a world that feels both menacing and realistic.

The storytelling is paced deliberately, allowing viewers to become absorbed in the details of each character and their motivations. Unlike traditional crime dramas that focus on action and spectacle, The Godfather relies on dialogue, expressions, and moments of silence to convey tension and build suspense. The scene of Vito's son Sonny Corleone (James Caan) unleashing fury on a rival gang member, or Michael's first act of violence in the restaurant, are so intense and meticulously crafted that they stay with the viewer long after the credits roll.

Adding to the movie's impact is Nino Rota's haunting score, which brings an emotional depth to the film and becomes a character in itself. The Godfather theme is iconic, evoking both melancholy and foreboding, perfectly underscoring the tragedy that the story reveals. The music sets the tone for the film and subtly reflects Michael's internal journey and the inevitable fate of the Corleone family.

The Godfather isn't just a crime drama; it's a meditation on power, loyalty, and the American Dream. It explores how these values clash with morality, personal ambition, and family ties. Coppola's adaptation of Puzo's novel is meticulous, and each scene feels essential to the story, adding layers of depth to characters who are both flawed and admirable.

This movie remains timeless because it goes beyond the conventions of a gangster film, making it accessible to audiences of all backgrounds and eras. Its influence is evident in countless films and television shows that followed. If you're looking for an epic that combines masterful storytelling, exceptional performances, and thought-provoking themes, The Godfather is an essential watch. It's more than a film-it's an experience that continues to resonate, offering something new with every viewing.

title: A movie critic's dream.
description:
"The Godfather" is one of the most praised movies in cinema history. It gives everything that critics and audiences alike ask for in movies. In my opinion it gets all the attention it gets for being one of, or the best movies ever. One of the best things "The Godfather" does is its incredible casting and its iconic performances from each and every one of its characters. The actors are so convincing that it won the movie several academy awards. It also jumpstarted several actors, acting careers, and gave an incredible ending to others. The Characters in the movie are outstandingly well handled. Each Character has somewhat of an arc within themselves, it shows each of their worldview and opinion of the situation that they face. It shows how their opinions, worldview, and personalities conflict with each other, and the consequences for reckless, illogical, and sudden decisions made by various characters. The film also gives the greatest character arc literally ever, through Michael Coralone, played by the incredible Al Pacino. The Godfather takes the viewer behind the closed doors of the Coralone crime family, a powerful Italian mafia group, and explores the pros and Cons of the organized crime lifestyle. Somehow through the immoral lifestyle that this movie bases itself upon, through things like narcotics, prostitution, alcohol, and violence it deals with very evident moral issues that we still face today, and does it in a somewhat redeemable way. The movie is also able to maintain a complex story with several moving parts, while also developing a very slow paced story. Therefore it spends time to dissect and flesh out its Characters and plot. It gives you a lot of time to interact and emotionally connect with its Characters, so that when they are lost it leaves a lasting impact on the viewer, and changes your view on the movie, and shows how it affects each of the characters involved differently. Another one of my favorite components of the Godfather is the cinematography and atmosphere. Its usage of crucial elements such as casting shadows and lighting communicates the dark essence that the film is going for, culture, and immorality, but always is able to communicate a sense of hope throughout. "The Godfather" has a very accurate portrayal of Italian culture and ways that culture is established within Immigrant America. I really enjoyed the cinematic representation visualization of organized crime and the abundance of style throughout. Speaking of style, another way the film communicates style and Italian culture is through the score. Just like the cinematography, the score communicates style and Italian culture, and accurately represents the way we visualize culture, crime, and atmosphere. "The Godfather" holds the best and most detailed character arc I have ever seen. You experience progressive stages of complete transformation through the changes of worldview and personality over the long period of time that this film takes place in.

"The Godfather" though a very great movie, is very slow moving, so those who prefer their movies to be modern and fast paced fast paced may take a disliking to this movie. The Godfather has stood the test of time and leaves a lasting impact on cinema still today. It wows critics and audiences alike, and will for years to come. It truly is one of the greatest films ever produced.

title: "Experiencing The Godfather in the Heart of Italy: A Personal Journey Through Iconic Scenes and Locations"
description: *The Godfather* is a cinematic masterpiece that blends extraordinary performances, brilliant direction, and memorable dialogue. During my trip through Italy, I read Mario Puzo's novel and visited the locations featured in the film, deepening my connection to its iconic scenes. Al Pacino and Marlon Brando deliver unforgettable performances, and Coppola's direction brings a tale of family, loyalty, and power to life. The film resonates deeply, especially when you experience it in the places where it all unfolds, making it even more powerful and personal. The raw emotion and complexity of the characters truly come to life in these settings.

In fact my 15-year old brother loved it so much, he wants to see it again. 10/10, though this film is too good for that rating. Bethany Cox.

title: A truly incredible masterpiece
description:
The Godfather is a movie that will never be forgotten. I watched it when I was 11, and I fell in love with it then.

This is a movie about an Italian mafia family living in New York. Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) is the head of the family, and he's always been taking care of everything. The movie first shows how the whole business works, with making sacrifices, keeping promises, and getting revenge. Sonny and Michael are Don Vito's sons. Everyone knew that Michael was the smart, elite "college boy" of the family, and Sonny was the completely opposite, and someday he'd be the head, the new Don Corleone. Michael doesn't want to be involved in the family business, until Don Vito gets shot by some of his enemies because of the whole deal about whether drugs should be sold or not, and troubles start to happen. Michael knows he's the only one who he can save his father. When he agreed to take revenge to the enemies who shot his father, he had gotten himself into a completely new life filled with violence, hatred, and betrayal, a world he had never experienced before, and there's no turning back.

I'm not gonna say what's going to happen next, for the people who haven't seen this yet. But if you're one of them, make sure you see this. This movie is absolutely perfect and flawless.

title: The Greatest American Myth
description: Godfather sets a new golden standard in American cinema thanks to superb storytelling and bigger-than-life characters, creating a near mythological tale about family, power and corruption.

title: The temperament of outstanding men in the film
description: Author Mario Puzo made The Godfather a classic, when he wrote about the mafia but didn't talk much about drugs, blood and gambling, but focused on describing the plots, events of the family, how each member of the family improvising with difficulties. The temperament of the "small tycoons" is thereby also clearly depicted. In the midst of the storm, there are cowards who run away, there are people who turn their backs on betrayal, there are brute force who use violence to suppress and then die in an instant. After all, the people who seem weak at first end up doing great karma, and the smartest person to plan everything, is none other than the Godfather!

title: Winner of three Oscar
description: The film was nominated by the Academy in eleven categories, and won three Oscars, for Best Film, Best Actor for Marlon Brando and Best Screenplay Adapted for Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola. In addition, she was awarded five Golden Globes for Best Drama, Best Director, Screenplay, Soundtrack and Actor for Marlon Brando.

title: A Classic, but for My ADHD Brain is a Slog
description: It's a classic, right? But as someone with ADHD, I have to say, watching it can feel like a bit of a slog. First off, this movie is nearly three hours long. That's a lot of sitting still! The pacing is super slow, and while I get that it builds tension and lets you really dive into the characters, there were moments when I found myself zoning out way too often. Those long conversations? They can feel endless. If you're someone who thrives on quick cuts and fast action, you might find your mind wandering. And then there are the characters. Don't get me wrong; they're fascinating! But there are so many of them, and keeping track of who's who can be a real challenge. With all the shifting loyalties and family drama, it's like trying to follow a soap opera without any background knowledge. I often felt lost in the details, which made it hard to stay engaged. The emotional depth is impressive-there's a lot to unpack about family loyalty and the consequences of choices. But honestly? Those slower emotional beats sometimes made me zone out. Instead of feeling connected to the story, I found myself getting restless during some of the quieter moments. I appreciate what they're going for; it's just that I need a little more action to keep my brain engaged. So yeah, while The Godfather is undeniably a masterpiece that deserves its status in film history, it can be a bit of a struggle for someone like me. If you love films that keep you on your toes and move at a quicker pace, this one might require some serious patience-or maybe just a good snack to help you power through!

title: Best movie ever
description:
At its core, "The Godfather" is a story about power, family, and the price one pays for control. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is nothing short of mesmerizing, earning him an Academy Award for Best Actor. Brando brings a nuanced complexity to the character, presenting Vito as a man both feared and respected, with a deep sense of honor and loyalty.

The film's cinematography, led by Gordon Willis, is a visual feast. The use of dark and shadowy imagery adds an atmospheric depth to the narrative, reflecting the moral ambiguity of the characters. The iconic opening scene, set in Vito's office during his daughter's wedding, sets the tone for the entire film, capturing the duality of celebration and sinister undertones.

One cannot discuss "The Godfather" without acknowledging the brilliant ensemble cast. Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader as Michael Corleone is a cinematic journey that leaves an indelible mark. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, deliver performances that elevate the film to unparalleled heights.

Nino Rota's haunting score adds another layer of emotion to the film, with its memorable theme becoming synonymous with the legacy of "The Godfather." The music becomes a character in itself, underscoring the pivotal moments and resonating long after the credits roll.

Paired with his incredible storytelling are the performances of everyone in the cast; so strong and believable. (Marlon Brando being my favorite) This film should be a part of everyone's repertoire. What more could I say about a film that has been glorified since its creation?

title: Truly One of the Best Movies Ever Made
description:
About the only thing I remember when it comes to being introduced to this movie was with my oldest brother bringing in a box of movies that he didn't watch anymore. It turns out that one of them was this flawless work of art that we know as "The Godfather." Often imitated, never duplicated, you cannot go wrong with this. After watching it once, you just have to watch it again. The writing is crisp, the acting is excellent, and the music will hook you in without fail.

"The Godfather" is pretty much a staple with my family, particularly with me and my middle brother. My mom loves it just the same and would recommend it to anyone. As my title states (and as anyone else may say as well), this is truly one of the best movies ever made. Period. You cannot put any other movie against it whatsoever. It won't work. Watch "The Godfather" once and then watch it again. It will give just about every other mafia movie a run for its money...and then some.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is a cinematic treasure that transcends generations, standing as a true masterpiece of storytelling and filmmaking. Directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, this 1972 classic has left an indelible mark on the world of cinema.

At its heart, "The Godfather" is a tale of power, family, and the consequences of choices made in the ruthless world of organized crime. Marlon Brando delivers a career-defining performance as Vito Corleone, the patriarch of the Corleone crime family. His portrayal is nothing short of iconic, and it earned him a well-deserved Academy Award.

The film is a rich tapestry of complex characters, each brought to life by an exceptional cast. Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless heir is a masterclass in character development. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, is equally remarkable, adding depth and authenticity to this gripping saga.

Cinematographer Gordon Willis' work behind the camera is visually stunning, capturing the dark and moody atmosphere of 1940s New York with precision. Nino Rota's haunting score further enhances the film's emotional depth.

What truly sets "The Godfather" apart is its ability to evoke empathy for morally flawed characters. It explores themes of loyalty, betrayal, and the blurred lines between good and evil. The film's dialogue is sharp, its pacing flawless, and its storytelling, nothing short of Shakespearean in its complexity.

"The Godfather" is a testament to the enduring power of storytelling in cinema. It has left an indelible mark on popular culture and continues to influence filmmakers to this day. If you haven't experienced this cinematic gem, do yourself a favor and watch it. It's not just a movie; it's a cinematic journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

title: Epic
description: A blueprint for tenacity in the making of the film. Love the story line. They say that Marlon Brando never memorizes his lines. He doesn't have a long drawn out monologue but wow he is the best. And Al Pacino killed it. I think the writer of The Godfather deserves so much credit for writing such an epic story but also a family story. Can we all relate to these characters? It some ways yes. We all have a Sal the screamer brutal one. The Michael that at first seems all pure and acts better than others in some ways becomes the head of the worst crime family.
