title: The Godfather
description:
Watching The Godfather is an event. Clocking in at five minutes shy of three hours and having some of the most epochal dialogue in the history of film, watching The Godfather is taking part in something that has forever changed the landscape of cinema. Mario Puzo's novel that he himself helped adapt into the 1972 film by Francis Ford Coppola offered a groundbreaking insight into the world of an organized crime dynasty. Highlighting the human beings associated with such death and destruction certainly took audiences by storm in the early 70's, and continues to do so today. Seeing the origin of where a number of cinema's most iconic lines came from is a truly magnificent journey, and one certainly worth the three-hour investment.

Opening with a lavish and joyful wedding scene, a certain ominousness lurks beneath the smiles. The Godfather sets its tone exquisitely in its opening moments with the introduction of "Don" Vito Corleone, played excellently by Marlon Brando in arguably his most celebrated role. We learn in just a few minutes from both the body language of those around him and their willingness to please that Don Corleone is an important man with immeasurable influence. His influence is so great that, on this, the day of (his) daughter's wedding, there is a list of those approved to see him. In perhaps one of the most talked about film openings, we see Brando with his oft-imitated manner of speaking and his accidental side-kick of a small cat (a stray that had wondered on the set), delivering a speech that has left an indelible imprint on pop culture since its utterance.

The Godfather came out nearly 20 years before I was even born so I have heard lines from the film repeated for years. Somehow this film has avoided oversaturation and seeing the lines delivered from the characters onscreen was as fresh as hearing them for the first time. I was amazed to learn with this viewing that The Godfather is nearly a three-hour film. It is one of the films I watch with rapt attention every time I see it and is the perfect slow burn, that it has never felt like an overlong film. The coloration achieved is mesmerizing, as I almost feel like I'm watching the intimate home movies of the family onscreen.

A brilliant and elegant score by Nino Rota captivates the audience and informs us of the mood of each scene. In an interesting way, however, it also runs a contrast to the mood onscreen. In a move that has often been imitated, but never to achieve the effect of The Godfather, Francis Ford Coppola juxtaposed many happy and celebratory scenes with sinister ones. The most discussed example of such juxtaposition is the scene in which Michael Corleone, expertly played by Al Pacino, is becoming a Godfather to his sister Connie's (Talia Shire) baby at the same time that he is becoming the Godfather to the Corleone family. The baptism scene taking place in a brilliant church with beautiful stained glass and a menacing echo is shown between hitmen killing associates and members of the rival families. As Michael's Godfather vows are being read, the murders are taking place to bridge the two ways in which Michael is becoming Godfather. The splicing of that scene marked the phenomenal transition of Michael being the family outsider, to the don of the Corleone family. A number of other scenes use juxtaposition in such a powerful way, most notably the scene in which a man is killed with the Statue of Liberty towering in the background, representing the freedom that was sought, but never obtained. Another such commanding display of juxtaposition is the joy of Christmas filling the air when Vito Corleone was stopping for fruit, only to be paraded with bullets in an attempt on his life. Later, the glistening Christmas trees lining the front of the hospital when the second attempt on his life was made. In an astounding feat, Francis Ford Coppola flanked such opposite compositions together many times throughout The Godfather, with the method never coming off as a stale or forced representation designed to manipulate the audience.

In addition to the powerful scenes Francis Ford Coppola engineered using juxtaposition, he made many more standout scenes. Even though I'm vegan, THAT horse head scenes is among my favorite in cinema. That unassuming Nino Rota tone filling our ears as the camera pans the outside of the lavish home and into the bed where the horse head warning now sits is a truly brilliant example of powerful filmmaking. The tollbooth scene is another nod to the directorial aptitude of Francis Ford Coppola. Despite the fact that we have watched Sonny Corleone (James Caan) act with a quick temper and more than willing to kill any obstacle to his goals, we feel remorse for his massacre as we watch him being led to his death. There is such a bond between the Corleone's and the audience that we want to see them prevail over their troubles, despite the fact that they would be more than willing to consider us as acceptable collateral damage if we happened to walk on the wrong side of the street during one of their hits. That level of audience endearment to cold-blooded murderers proves Francis Ford Coppola's mastery at directing complex human relationships.

The Godfather is, for me, the film with the best opening and closing in the history of cinema. Losing none of its steam throughout its 3-hour runtime, the opening, and closing of the film show the lengths Francis Ford Coppola traveled through his incredible telling of Mario Puzo's story. The framing from the wedding to Michael becoming the Godfather of the family is magical. The framing and use of foreground, middleground, and background of that final scene are mesmerizing and perfectly sets the tone for the continuation of Michael's story for the two sequels that follow. Multiple actors play a role in The Godfather that also serves as my personal favorite roles of theirs including James Caan, Abe Vigoda, and Robert Duvall. In a film that is more tense and terrifying than my favorite horror films, The Godfather is a timeless classic that has more than earned its place on the list of best films ever made.

title: It's the restraint that makes the violence
description:
The Godfather is a masterclass in storytelling and direction. Coppola doesn't just tell a story about crime; he invites you into a world where every frame, every shadow, and every pause speaks volumes. The pacing is deliberate, almost methodical, letting each scene breathe and build tension. What stands out to me is how controlled everything feels. Coppola never rushes; he knows exactly when to hold back and when to strike. It's the restraint that makes the violence, when it happens, feel so much more powerful.

From a director's perspective, the transformation of Michael Corleone is what truly makes the film unforgettable. The way Coppola frames Michael's journey is almost like watching an evolution in slow motion. Al Pacino's subtle shifts in demeanor and Coppola's choice to keep the camera lingering on Michael as he descends into the family business is brilliant. It's not just the performances that make this happen; it's how Coppola uses silence, space, and light to emphasize his isolation and eventual dominance.

title: For me, This is The Best Movie of All Time
description: The Best Movie in History, its a beautifully crafted gangster film that highlights faith, family, and power. A lesson in filmmaking is sampled from many ivy league and big ten schools to highlight a new direction in storytelling in American cinema.

title: Best movie so far
description: For me everyone should watch this one time in your life and you never regret. This movie has everything in a good movie. I dont want to talk about information of this movie because i dont want to spoil. That all i want to say. Just watch this OKAY.

title: A masterful adaptation that turned into one of the best movies of all time
description:
This film, based on the legendary book by author Mario Puzo, is a prime example of movie making and the potential of Hollywood-flicks.

Helmed by the fantastic Francis Ford Coppola, who of course has an impressive legacy to account for in terms of all of his works - it followed the novel closely, but, like any good adaptation, made it into its own thing rather than an exact retreading. We are given an insight into the lives of the Siccilian mob in America during the post-ww2 area through the Corelone family, its most notable members being the leads played by Al Pacino and his father Marlon Brando. The Oscars received were of course completely justified, Brando, being at his peak during the 50s and 60s, sells it in this one and gives the performance of a life time. Don Vito Corleone stands as one of the most iconic movie characters of all time.

Pacino, though at his height in the sequel, is still fantastic in this one, playing a man who is tragically dragged into a life destined for him that he never wanted.

The cinematography is fantastic, and so is the writing - it is a sophisticated, yet very violent and melachonical story that does not shy away from ruthlesness, one of the best scenes being towards the end of the third act, which I will not spoil here.

It stands as one of the highest rated movies on IMDb's 250 list of best movies of all time, which is not an overstatement in any way. Coppola made movie history with this story, and the best (and worst) was yet to come with the movie's sequels, but more of that later...

title: this is the film that made me fall in love with movies
description: I am not going to tell you why I think this film is great. There are very few films that have been discussed so intently as this one (Citizen Kane and Casablanca are the only two that come to mind that might be more respected) and there is nothing I can say that hasn't been said. Also, I'm not going to try and change your mind, it's probably already set and if you are anything like me, it's not changing anytime soon. Besides, film is art not science and art is about emotion. No movie has meant as much to me as The Godfather, let me tell you why. I think I got hooked on movies because I am an obsessive person. If I read a good book I must read ALL of the authors work--two days into The Road, I had ordered McCarthy's other nine books. Everybody loves movies. I bet one in three adults hasn't touched a book in over a year but most of us make our pilgrimage to the local multiplex at least once every month or two and there are a handful of movies--whether they be Citizen Kane and 400 blows or Die Hard and The Rock--that we'll watch whenever they're on TV. At eleven or twelve, I certainly had my list of favorites but most of them were simply entertaining. I've since learned to appreciate Raiders of the Lost Ark as a piece of film making and ET as a genuinely brilliant work of art (its one of those movies you loved as a kid but love even more as an adult) but the Godfather was really the first movie that blew me a way. I may not have been able to tell you why but even back then i could tell, this was something special, this was a work of art. This film, along with its sequel (I like to think of them as one movie, mainly so I don't have to pick a favorite) Have topped my list of all time favorites for as long as I care to remember. Often I've wondered if its simply because of how strong my initial reaction was after that first viewing but every time I re watch it, from the beginning or starting in the middle, I'm reassured that it truly is the greatest film of all time. 'I believe in America,' still makes the hairs on my neck stand up, right down to the final scene when they close the door. The baptism is one of the greatest scenes in cinema, or is it the one at the toll booth, or at the wedding, or in the restaurant. There are too many. It is a film that doesn't just work at every level, it works perfectly at every level. If you have not seen this film you cannot say you love movies. American cinema may not have began here but every film since has been made in its shadow. It is the greatest film of all time and will never be topped, Period.

title: Outstanding. Masterpiece.
description: The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that effortlessly weaves a tale of power, family, and loyalty. Marlon Brando's portrayal is captivating, exuding authority and complexity. The film's slow-burning tension draws you into the morally intricate world of the Mafia. It's impeccable storytelling and iconic scenes, like the horse head in the bed, have left an indelible mark on pop culture. The direction by Francis Ford Coppola is flawless, and the ensemble cast delivers unforgettable performances. With its compelling characters and exploration of the consequences of one's choices, The Godfather remains a timeless classic that deserves every bit of its acclaim.

title: Spectacular
description: Such an iconic piece of art .It's like classic Italian mob documentary narrated by the people within the story. Totally understood the enormous pressure during the production of this film as it's realism nature eventually changed how movies are made.

title: The best story I heard
description: Now as I think, what to write about 'The Godfather' a thousand brilliant perspectives flash in my mind. Should I marvel at the mesmerizing story that surrounds you ever so sweetly or should I wonder about strong undertones which reveal themselves like shooting starts. Should I admire the vivid visualization of the dream or should I talk about the truth that emerges from it. Godfather might be a great movie to others but to me it is a journey through human mind, candid and knowing. The motives of a man and the eternal conflict with direction. All that is said about 'good', reveals itself in the story of this bad man. I am a fan of Vito Carlione, he is wise, he is respectful, he is a true capitalist. He is not bad himself but does not mind employing bad means. After all, some body has got to do the exploration. I can't say how thankful I am to people who made this movie for not spoiling my imagination. A truth well told is the biggest achievement.

title: Godfather
description: Godfather script portrays the duality of man: good vs evil, law abiding vs crime, loyalty vs betrayal, logic vs emotions, etc. It also warns of the long term consequences of our actions despite our short term intents and factors driving us to a certain path, which in the protagonist life, is crime.

title: Love this movie!

title: Absolute classic.
description: Absolute classic. To sum it up in a few words: it is simply the best film ever made. And my intention is not to repeat jargon: the film really is perfect in all aspects. Magnificent performances (seriously, absolutely EVERYONE acts with excellence, especially Marlon Brando and Al Pacino), impeccable script, wonderful direction, exquisite photography, unforgettable soundtrack, excellent production and costume design work, very well edited, and so on. Go. The film is approximately 3 hours long and is well used (in other words, there is no hassle as it is a long film: every minute is well used to tell the story). It is a must-see film for all those who like cinema. Despite being relatively old (1972), it is a film that has aged extremely well, including in terms of the actors' performance.

title: Simply the best...
description: I can't say enough about this film. It is simply the best example of what can be achieved through the art of cinema. It's visually stunning, literate and totally engrossing. It gave us the finest Pacino performance of his career, no small feat. And gave us Brando unlike I've ever seen him before. You can't take your eyes off him. His performance is stunning. Every other role is also perfectly cast. Look for James Caan to ignite the screen. I watch this film at least once a year so I can remember what a first rate film is supposed to be like.

title: Love this movie!
description: Love this movie! A true classic, never gets old. It was even better seeing it on the big Screen!

title: G.O.A.T. Movie
description:
The Godfather is often hailed as the greatest movie of all time, and for good reason. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, this 1972 classic is a masterclass in storytelling, character development, and cinematic technique.

The film follows the powerful Corleone family, led by the patriarch Vito Corleone, played by Marlon Brando in an iconic performance. The story delves into the intricacies of family loyalty, power struggles, and the moral complexities of the mafia world. Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, is a compelling transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader.

What sets The Godfather apart is its meticulous attention to detail and its ability to humanize its characters, making them relatable despite their criminal undertakings. The cinematography, with its use of shadows and light, creates an atmosphere that is both intimate and grand. The score by Nino Rota is hauntingly beautiful, perfectly complementing the film's tone.

The dialogue is sharp and memorable, with lines like "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse" becoming part of popular culture. The film's pacing is deliberate, allowing the story to unfold naturally and giving the audience time to connect with the characters.

In essence, The Godfather is not just a gangster film; it's a profound exploration of power, family, and the American Dream. Its influence on cinema is undeniable, and it continues to be a benchmark for filmmakers and a favorite among audiences..

title: the best movie

title: A terrifically entertaining movie, but deeply phony and morally dishonest.
description:
You get a lot to enjoy in The Godfather, although I suspect that anyone who has not read the book before seeing the movie might occasionally lose track of the plot.

But the movie is morally crooked, because the Corleone Family are never shown doing anything criminal, other than killing off rival criminals in justifiable self-defense. Don Vito Corleone is a wise, benevolent patriarch to the Italian American community of New York, and gets into trouble with rival gangsters only because he refuses to take part in selling heroin. Unless you have been told that he is a criminal, you'd never know. You certainly never see the Corleones cheating or hurting honest citizens. That's what I mean when I say that the movie is crooked.

Compare the Corleones to TV's Sopranos. Tony Soprano is overtly criminal-a brutal, thieving, murdering, adulterous extortionist who pretends to adhere to a Mafia code, which he breaks whenever it suits him to break it. This is why The Sopranos is artistically superior to The Godfather. The creators of the Sopranos have actually dared to make Tony Soprano and his fellow criminals hateful, which is just what you would expect real criminals to be. Don Corleone, on the other hand, resembles a real human being about as much as Tarzan of the Apes.

So, great as The Godfather is as an entertainment, it fails as art.

title: joining the underworld
description:
The Godfather is a great film made with gusto. Most of the participants are at their career best. Nina Rota's magnificent score and Francis Ford Coppola's direction tie things together very well.

Al Pacino is the greatest performer of a top-shelf cast. The decision to cast him as Michael is a stroke of cinematic genius. (Supposedly, Marlon Brando threatened to quit if Pacino wasn't cast, and this tipped the scales in Pacino's favor.)

Another diminutive actor playing Michael might have emulated James Cagney a bit, with bounce and swagger in his step. Pacino never seems worried about his physical stature; instead, his Michael is very articulate. Pacino and Brando are putting on a Method acting show; and their chemistry together is sublime.

The Godfather foreshadows Michael's destiny exquisitely. For example, consider the hospital sequence. Michael enters a room looking for the detectives protecting his father and we hear the musical soundtrack repeating the number "two." Michael opens the hospital door to his father's room--and it is clearly marked with the number two. The association of the number two with Vito when Michael is present foreshadows the rise of Michael in the family business. (That is, Michael is #1.) In addition, the actor playing Enzo the baker (Gabriele Torrei) has a strong resemblance to Pacino. When Michael throws Enzo's carnations away (on the steps outside the hospital) this is another clue that Michael is destined to chuck away the lover boy side of him and rise in the underworld.

Marlon Brando's performance is a lightning rod for criticism, praise and satire. It is difficult to imagine any other actor of his time portraying Don Vito with all the knowing looks and gestures that Brando makes. It is another brave portrayal from Brando.

The conflict between brothers Sonny (James Caan) and Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall) is well explored. Sonny is all testosterone and action while Tom Hagen is cautious and inexperienced in underworld affairs. Since Hagen is adopted, he is both an insider and an outsider. The audience needs him to help understand the Sicilian logic at play.

Having seen The Godfather dozens of times, it is fun pointing out the implausibility with the story. For example, it seems very hard to believe that a brother-in-law, already having been savagely smacked around in public for hitting his wife, would beat her again knowing that his wife's hot-headed brother would chase after him without his bodyguards. How much could Carlo have been paid to willingly absorb the risk that his brother-in-law exercises usual caution?

Another implausible is that Barzini is doing something in public the day of the Baptism. Forgetting that Baptisms usually occur on a Sunday, what happens to Michael if Barzini is staying at home that day?

The Godfather has us rooting for Michael even as he descends into evil. The transformation that Michael makes is shared by the viewer; we are also joining a criminal conspiracy. It is a uniquely memorable and pleasurable ride.

title: The best, unmatched realism and a wonderful work of art and entertainment
description:
this is probably the best film in the history of cinema, if not the best, then at least in the top 5. a film can be good for one of many reasons; good acting, good direction, writing, etc., good entertainment (simply fun to watch) or a brilliant artistic piece of work. the godfather contains all of these elements. the cast alone is a given that the acting will be brilliant, and as the cast suggests, it is. Brando reinvented himself, Pacino's screen legend was born and Duval and Caan are simply wonderful. the women are notable as well, Talia Shire and Diane Keaton. many others shine in smaller roles.

the writing is clever and authentic (having the original author, Mario Puzo co-write the script added the realism), while Coppola added what he needed for it to be a successful movie. the direction is crisp and faced paced when it needs to be, the film feels real, most viewers can sympathize with these criminals/murderers as well as easily being able to engulf themselves into their world.

the movie is entertaining and original. it is artistic, a great parable about family life and values, and containing an unexpected dose of morality, which serves as splendid irony. overall, this is probably the most well rounded movie of all time containing elements of everything one wishes a movie to contain. 10 out of 10, hands down.

title: Insane Performance

Marlon Brando has showed us that in order to be believable one has to search deep down his soul even look for a crazy version of himself in order to deliver a believable character. Directors should give the freedom to the actor to deliver a character that has to come somewhere from within the actor himself. Any judge of talent in an audition will tell you that a performer has to lay down his emotions on the floor and be true to himself so that the audience can feel his truth and relate to it. Marlon Brando has just showed us what acting is all about. The Godfather is now , thanks to Marlon, a man who knows that by lifting a finger his will shall be executed and the "scum who ruined your daughter would be suffering this very day"...Marlon Brando doesn't need to convince us how powerful the Godfather is, we are already convinced , he won us in just a few lines. Now we believe he is trying to bring Bonasera back to the "family" under his power and to the business of trading "services". The magic of the Godfather is right here and there.

title: Coppola's Masterpiece
description:
When a movie isn't called one of the greatest of all time, then high expectations are bound to come. Sadly, this means some people will be disappointed. I've felt the same way about Dr. Strangelove and Back to the Future. So every movie has naysayers, just how it is. But I am always astoundes when I hear someone does not like The Godfather. It really is the closet thing to a perfect film that I have ever seen. From the story, the production, direction, and of course, the acting. Brando puts on his greatest performance. Pachino, Duvall, Keaton and Caan also put on extraordinary performances. The movie is long but never boring. It always manages to keep you interested even in the more slow parts. That is good filmmaking.

The music is haunting and beautiful and fits the film like a glove. The story never glorifies the lifestyle. It takes great care to show the characters best and worst sides of themselves. They are all fully realized and incredibly well developed. It shows the saga of a crime families rise, fall and rise again, in the most epic fashion.

Im still pretty young, in my early 20s, and I'm hoping to be a movie critic someday. I don't think I could have picked a better movie to review.

Francis Ford Coppola has made at least three of the greatest movies ever made. This movie, it's sequel, and Apocolypse Now. Some say Seven Samurai, some might say Casablanca, others Citizen Kane, but in my mind, and many others minds, This is the greatest movie ever made.

title: Apart From Citizen Kane, This Is The Greatest Movie Of All Time.
description:
"Saying that you like film but you don't like The Godfather is like saying you like to drink but you don't like water! They are the be all, end all, best films of all time that will never be topped." - Film critic Richard Roeper.

Roeper, who worked with Roger Ebert on his show for 6 years, is absolutely right. You've probably heard again and again how either this is the greatest movie ever made, or that only Citizen Kane tops it. I'm in the latter category.

To be honest, I watched it for the 4th time recently, and that's when it made my Top 10. My first time was when I was 18- I'm 24 now. It was the first movie I saw as an adult.

I thought it was good, don't get me wrong, but I didn't fully understand why it was so highly regarded. A few months pass, and I watch it on TV. I liked it more. When I was 19, I saw it again on DVD, and I liked it even more.

5 years have now passed, and I finally appreciated it the way I, a film buff, should have. And there it went, in the Top 10 best movies I have ever seen.

The Godfather is set in Post-WWII New York, and focuses on the Corleone family. They're in The Mafia (a word never spoken in the film, the real Mafia requested this), and if someone betrays the family, they are hunted down and murdered.

The Don, Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), is getting old and his health is deteriorating, and he asks his godson Michael (Al Pacino) to take over the family business. Michael is reluctant, but he eventually agrees to uphold his family's honor.

The Godfather is so iconic that any praise I'd give it is nearly pointless. I can add very little to what others already have. Among the most iconic is the famous scenes and lines.

From the opening request of murder to avenge for the murder of a daughter, to the subsequent wedding scene, from the horse head in bed (which was real, by the way) to the baptism scene, so many segments have been ingrained into our modern culture.

The same goes for many lines. Even those who have never seen The Godfather are sure to be aware of lines like: "Luca Brasi sleeps with the fishes", "Leave the gun, take the cannoli", and of course: "I'm going to make him an offer he can't refuse."

The movie is filled with many well-known actors who have gone on to do great work. Apart from Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, other famous actors include James Caan (Misery, Elf), Diane Keaton (Father of the Bride-1991, Something's Gotta Give), Robert Duvall (The Apostle, Secondhand Lions), and Talia Shire (The Rocky films), to name a few. Even here, in their younger selfs, they display excellent talent.

The Godfather is flawlessly made, from beautiful camera work to the costumes, to the plot. There are also some visual things that stand out. For example, whenever oranges appear, that hints that someone is going, or about, to die.

I should note that Marlon Brando did insist on wearing a mouthpiece (this is why his jaw is bigger), and this mumbles his speech. That is the closest I can come to faulting The Godfather, an otherwise exquisite masterpiece. And that's extremely minor.

The Godfather is without a doubt one of the greatest contributions to cinema. Regardless of if you are a film buff or a casual viewer, it is a must see. You may be like me and need to grow and see it more than once but trust me when I say that it is the grand film that it is regarded as.

title: excellent
description: The aging patriarch of an organized crime dynasty transfers control of his clandestine empire to his reluctant son.The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy from a screenplay by Mario Puzo and Coppola. Based on Puzo's 1969 novel of the same name, the film stars Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story, spanning the years 1945 to 1955, centers on the transformation of Michael Corleone (Pacino) from reluctant family outsider to ruthless Mafia boss while also chronicling the family under the patriarch Vito Corleone (Brando). The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in world cinema[3]—and as one of the most influential, especially in the gangster genre.[4] Now ranked as the second greatest film in American cinema (behind Citizen Kane) by the American Film Institute,[5] it was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 1990.[6] The film was for a time the highest grossing picture ever made, and remains the box office leader for 1972. It won three Oscars that year: for Best Picture, for Best Actor (Brando) and in the category Best Adapted Screenplay for Puzo and Coppola. Its nominations in seven other categories included Pacino, James Caan and Robert Duvall for Best Supporting Actor and Coppola for Best Director. The success spawned two sequels: The Godfather Part II in 1974, and The Godfather Part III in 1990. On the day of his only daughter's wedding, Vito Corleone hears requests in his role as the Godfather, the Don of a New York crime family. Vito's youngest son, Michael, in a Marine Corps uniform, introduces his girlfriend, Kay Adams, to his family at the sprawling reception. Vito's godson Johnny Fontane, a popular singer, pleads for help in securing a coveted movie role, so Vito dispatches his fear, Tom Hagen, to the abrasive studio head, Jack Woltz, to secure the casting. Woltz is unmoved until the morning he wakes up in bed with the severed head of his prized stallion. Shortly before Christmas 1945, drug baron Virgil "The Turk" Sollozzo, backed by the Corleones' rivals, the Tattaglias, asks Vito for investment in the emerging drug trade and protection through his political connections. Vito disapproves of drug dealers, so he sends his enforcer, Luca Brasi, to spy on them. The family then receives two fish wrapped in Brasi's vest, imparting that he "sleeps with the fishes". An assassination attempt by Sollozzo's men lands Vito in the hospital, so his eldest son, Sonny, takes command. Sollozzo kidnaps Hagen to pressure Sonny to accept his deal. Michael thwarts a second assassination attempt on his father at the hospital, but is accosted by corrupt police captain McCluskey, who breaks his jaw; Sonny retaliates by having Tattaglia's son killed. Michael comes up with a plan to hit Sollozzo and McCluskey that his brother approves over Hagen's objections: on the pretext of settling the dispute, Michael lures the pair to a restaurant, retrieves a planted handgun and murders them. Despite a clampdown from the authorities, the Five Families erupt in open warfare and the brothers fear for their safety. Michael takes refuge in Sicily, and Fredo Corleone is sheltered by associate Moe Greene in Las Vegas. Sonny attacks his brother-in-law Carlo on the street for abusing his sister Connie. When it happens again, Sonny speeds for her home but assassins ambush him at a highway toll booth and riddle him with submachine gun fire. Michael's time abroad has led to marriage to Apollonia Vitelli. Their euphoria is shattered when a car bomb intended for him takes her life. Vito, saddened to learn that, despite his hopes, Michael has become involved in the family business, decides to end the feuds. Believing that the Tattaglias were under orders of the now dominant Don Emilio Barzini, he promises, before the heads of the Five Families, to withdraw his opposition to their heroin business and forgo revenge for Sonny's murder. His safety guaranteed, Michael returns home and over a year later marries Kay. With his father at the end of his career and his surviving brother too weak, Michael takes the reins of the family, promising his wife to make the business legitimate within five years. He allows rival families to pressure Corleone enterprises even as he plans to move family operations to Nevada and delegates New York business to members who stay behind. Hagen, upset when Michael replaces him with Vito, is mollified by the older man's reassurance about their long- range plans for him. When Michael travels to Las Vegas to buy out Greene's stake in the family's casinos, Greene derides the Corleones as a fading power. To add injury to insult, Michael sees Fredo falling under Greene's sway. Vito collapses and dies in his garden while playing with Michael's son, Anthony. At the funeral, Salvatore Tessio arranges a meeting between Michael and Don Barzini, signally his treachery as Vito had warned. The meeting is set for the same day as the christening of Connie's son, to whom Michael will stand as godfather. As the christening proceeds, Corleone assassins, acting on Michael's orders, murder the other New York dons and Moe Greene. Tessio is told that Michael is aware of his betrayal and taken off to his death. After Carlo is questioned by Michael on his involvement in setting up Sonny's murder and confesses he was contacted by Brazen, Peter Clemenza kills him with a wire garrote. Michael is confronted by Connie, who accuses him of having her husband killed. He denies killing Carlo when questioned by Kay, an answer she accepts. As Kay watches warily, Michael receives his capos, who address him as the new Don Corleone.

title: The Godfather
description:
The Godfather is the most cinematic Film in world. The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, stands as a cinematic masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of time. This iconic film, adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, unfolds the gripping tale of the Corleone crime family, weaving a narrative that is as intricate as it is compelling.

At its core, "The Godfather" is a story about power, family, and the price one pays for control. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is nothing short of mesmerizing, earning him an Academy Award for Best Actor. Brando brings a nuanced complexity to the character, presenting Vito as a man both feared and respected, with a deep sense of honor and loyalty.

The film's cinematography, led by Gordon Willis, is a visual feast. The use of dark and shadowy imagery adds an atmospheric depth to the narrative, reflecting the moral ambiguity of the characters. The iconic opening scene, set in Vito's office during his daughter's wedding, sets the tone for the entire film, capturing the duality of celebration and sinister undertones.

One cannot discuss "The Godfather" without acknowledging the brilliant ensemble cast. Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader as Michael Corleone is a cinematic journey that leaves an indelible mark. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, deliver performances that elevate the film to unparalleled heights.

Nino Rota's haunting score adds another layer of emotion to the film, with its memorable theme becoming synonymous with the legacy of "The Godfather." The music becomes a character in itself, underscoring the pivotal moments and resonating long after the credits roll.

What sets "The Godfather" apart is its ability to balance intense, dramatic sequences with quieter, character-driven moments. The intricate storytelling allows the audience to delve into the psyche of each character, blurring the lines between right and wrong. The film explores the themes of power and morality, questioning the cost of maintaining control in a world driven by crime.

Coppola's meticulous attention to detail is evident in every frame, creating a cinematic experience that remains unparalleled. The film's narrative unfolds like a Shakespearean tragedy, with themes of betrayal, loyalty, and the consequences of one's choices echoing through the generations.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a timeless classic that continues to resonate with audiences across the globe. Its influence on filmmaking is immeasurable, and its legacy is etched in the annals of cinema history. The combination of stellar performances, masterful direction, and a rich, layered narrative makes "The Godfather" a true masterpiece that transcends generations and genres. It is not merely a film; it is a cultural phenomenon that stands as a testament to the enduring power of storytelling.

title: "...wherever he goes, death follows..." F.F. Coppola on Michael Corleone
description:
The Great Contribution to Cinema and American History itself... because, let's face it: If you're not part of any religious or ethnic minority in the good-ol' US-of-A (and we all came from another country; American Indians being the only true Natives), then the Godfather franchise means nothing to you except slickly-packed violence.

A masterpiece of American filmmaking; less derivative and more seminal than other films previous and since.

Novelist-screenwriter Mario Puzo and screenwriter/director Francis Ford Coppola care for the characters they wrought here, and the two sequels. Maybe not all of their individual efforts work for us, but they are still products of meticulous filmmaking, and each Godfather film deserves a serious examination in this esthetic sense.

Godfather lays down the groundwork, introducing us to Don Corleone and his sons, each of which have their own tragic destinies. The Don's youngest son, Michael, prooves to be the wisest and most formidable, and takes over the Family Seat.

Godfather Part II gives us the Don's family history in Sicily, and Michael's transformation into a paranoid 'monster.'

Godfather Part III examines Michael's pain, panic and remorse, for having gone this far (1979) and not having become "legitimate."

Actors Al Pacino and Talia Shire each grew and became better, thespian-wise, through these three aforementioned Godfather installments, and deserve recognition for their efforts.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece!
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is not just a film; it is an experience. The moment the film begins, you're drawn into a world so rich, so complex, and so beautifully crafted that it's impossible to look away. The story of the Corleone family, their rise to power, and the loyalty, betrayal, and sacrifice that come with it, is told with such depth and precision that it feels as if you're witnessing history unfold. Every element of this film-its acting, direction, writing, and music-works in perfect harmony to create a cinematic masterpiece.

Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is legendary. He doesn't just play the character; he becomes him. With every deliberate movement, every whisper of dialogue, Brando paints a picture of a man who is both feared and respected, whose kindness and ruthlessness coexist in a delicate balance. The now-iconic "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse" line? It's a moment that will send chills down your spine every single time you hear it, because Brando delivers it with such authority and depth. His performance is a perfect blend of subtlety and power, elevating the film to new heights.

And then there's Al Pacino, who, in the role of Michael Corleone, goes through a transformation that is nothing short of extraordinary. When we first meet Michael, he is an outsider to the family business, a man of honor who wants to distance himself from the violence and corruption that surround him. But as the story unfolds, we watch Michael's descent into the dark world of organized crime, and Pacino's performance is nothing short of mesmerizing. His ability to convey Michael's internal conflict, his struggle between loyalty to his family and his desire for a different life, is haunting and unforgettable. By the film's conclusion, Pacino has crafted one of the most compelling character arcs in film history.

The screenplay, written by Mario Puzo and Coppola, is pure genius. It doesn't rush to tell its story; it allows the audience to immerse themselves in the lives of these complex characters. The power struggles, family dynamics, and personal tragedies unfold slowly and methodically, creating a tension that never lets up. The Godfather isn't just a story about crime; it's a poignant commentary on power, loyalty, and the human condition. The family's devotion to each other is both touching and tragic, and as the film progresses, we realize that the Corleones are a family bound by blood, but also by the choices they've made and the lives they've taken.

Coppola's direction is nothing short of masterful. He understands the nuances of the script and brings it to life with incredible attention to detail. Every frame feels purposeful, every scene meticulously composed. The lighting, especially, is a crucial part of the film's atmosphere. The use of shadows creates a sense of mystery, danger, and moral ambiguity. And the pacing? Perfect. The film is long, but it never drags. You're never bored because there's always something captivating happening on screen, whether it's a tense conversation, a violent confrontation, or a quiet moment of reflection.

The music by Nino Rota is the perfect complement to the film's tone. The hauntingly beautiful score sticks with you long after the film ends, evoking feelings of nostalgia, melancholy, and, at times, dread. The music doesn't just accompany the story-it becomes a part of it, deepening the emotional impact of every scene.

In the end, The Godfather is more than just a film. It's an exploration of family, power, loyalty, and the choices that define us. It is a story that resonates on a universal level, one that continues to be relevant and impactful even decades after its release. Every time I watch it, I discover something new, something I missed before, and that's what makes it so special. The Godfather is not just a classic; it's a timeless work of art that will remain at the top of the cinematic world for generations to come.

title: A timeless masterpiece based on the novel by Mario Puzo.
description:
The Godfather, directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on the novel of the same name by Mario Puzo, is considered one of the greatest masterpieces in cinematic history. Released in 1972, the film is a captivating portrayal of the Italian-American mafia, told through the story of the Corleone family.

Plot and Themes The story follows Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), the youngest son of the powerful mafia boss Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). Initially uninvolved in the family business, Michael gradually becomes entangled, eventually rising to lead the family. The film explores universal themes such as power, family, loyalty, and corruption, presenting a moral and human epic that transcends a mere tale of a criminal family.

Direction and Screenplay Coppola delivers masterful direction, characterized by a slow yet compelling narrative that builds tension and emotional depth. Every scene is meticulously crafted, from pacing to dialogue, turning even the most violent moments into artistic representations. The screenplay, written by Coppola and Puzo, strikes a perfect balance between narrative complexity and character development, creating a work that is both intimate and epic.

Performance of the Actors The performances are extraordinary. Marlon Brando delivers one of his most iconic roles as the patriarch Vito Corleone, infusing the character with a blend of authority and vulnerability. Al Pacino, as Michael, portrays a tragic and chilling transformation from an idealistic young man to a ruthless mafia leader. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, also significantly enhances the film's quality.

Score and Cinematography Nino Rota's score is an unforgettable element of the film, with its main theme evoking both melancholy and solemnity. Gordon Willis's cinematography, earning him the nickname "The Prince of Darkness," skillfully uses chiaroscuro to emphasize the story's dark and dramatic tone.

Cultural Impact The Godfather has had a lasting impact on popular culture, influencing generations of filmmakers and redefining the gangster genre. The film also serves as a critical portrait of America, reflecting on the American Dream and its contradictions.

Conclusion With its combination of compelling storytelling, memorable performances, and technical mastery, The Godfather is more than just a mafia film-it is a work that explores the complexities of the human soul. It remains a cinematic experience that continues to captivate and inspire, solidifying its status as a timeless classic.

title: Perfection.
description:
"The Godfather" exists within a vacuum: it is without precedent, and (not for the want of much effort), it is without imitation. To try and objectively review this Film, after its effect on my life, would be a poor joke. Frankly, I adore it. It is Romantic, absolutely. Beyond belief. Even Technically, it's a paradise. The colours drip, rich and heavy. The characters hold up a mirror to our psyche, and the dialogue has rightly cemented "The Godfather" as a movie which will always have a relevance. Ironically, this tale of counter-culture has become arguably the definitive Pop Culture statement. "The Godfather" IS the gap between Mainstream and Art. It is the scale to which every "classic" must compare itself, and inevitably fall short. Concise Coalescence: "The Godfather" is the greatest Movie ever made. But that's not why I LOVE it. Sure, I respect a whole bunch of Films. I can recognise a Film's influence, award it its dues, and move on. But I keep coming back to this, because I feel an affection for it. Every time I hear that sweeping Niño Rota score, I'm reminded: this changed my life! Days spent dreaming of my future as either a Mafioso or a Film-maker. To a degree, "The Godfather's" reputation does it a disservice; this isn't a Movie to admire, it's a Movie to FEEL. And I guarantee you, it's so powerful that only a truly emotionally dead person won't feel it.

And so I again ask myself: Why is it I love "The Godfather"? I love "The Godfather" because it never becomes cute or cuddly. I've just waxed lyrical about it, but as I sit to watch it, it's still dark, it's intimidating. It never gives itself up to soppy nostalgia, and that's why it remains as shocking a statement now as it did more than a quarter of a century ago. Perfection.

title: The one film I would bring to a desert island
description:
A unparalleled statement in cinema on almost all fronts.

"The Godfather" (1972) is directed by Francis Ford Coppola, and co-written with and based on the novel by Mario Puzo. It tells the tale of The Godfather, alias Don Corleone, and originally born Vito Andolini, he is the leader of the Corleone mafia family. As an ageing patriarch, Don Corleone wants his youngest son Michael to take over the family affairs, but he seems uninterested. From then on, the film centres on the increasing tensions between the Corleone and its rival mafia families in the search for power, integrity and honour.

I first saw "The Godfather" when I was around 14 or 15 years old, and that was truly when I fell in love with films. As a young boy, I could not attribute it to anything specific, but as I grew older, I realised that its grandeur was to be attributed to the numerous levels that Francis Ford Coppola excels at making the perfect film. From the formidable screenplay, to the precise direction, beautiful integration of the awesomely impressive cast (will there ever again be so much acting talent in one film), the perfect score by Nino Rota, the masterful cinematography by Gordon Willis, and the flawless editing by William Reynolds and Peter Zinner.

To focus on perhaps the film's most impressive element, Brando. His pure artful talent shines through in an ever-immersive performance, where he inspired all of his juniors, including Al Pacino and Robert Duvall. His performance in "The Godfather" perfectly exemplifies, why they and so many others of the greatest actors (Robert De Niro, Dustin Hoffman, Gene Hackman, Martin Sheen, the list goes on) hail Marlon Brando as the greatest in the history of the acting craft. He exemplifies how he was capable at portraying all human emotions with such depth and range, and he contributes to making this perfect film shining even more.

The very definition of a seminal work and a masterpiece in cinema!

title: Best movie
description: BestbBest film i have seen. Best actinacting best direction bestbbest story

title: A masterpiece in every sense of the word
description:
In my opinion this is undoubtably one of the best and one my favourite films ever made. What is surprising as anything is that two years it was followed by Part II which is just as good (and then 20 years later and money-grabbing, dull and unnecessary third film). The first time I watched this film, I thought it was very good but overly long. But the second time I watched it, it didn't seem overly long at all, but beautifully detailed and concise - despite being nearly three hours long. I didn't find myself become bored, because the remarkable thing about this film is that almost every line, ever scene adds to the story or unfolding the characters, and their interaction with each other. The acting is believable, the direction is superb, and cinematography excellent.

As well as all this, the film avoids cliches and over-dramatising deaths, but instead shows the Italian culture and strong importance of relations with your family. The differemt characters seem to perfectly gel. Micheal who changes from being relatively uninvolved ('a citizen') to heading the family, Sonny -overly volatile, Fredo - not clever enough (he's more involved in the 2nd film), and Tom - the level headed, sensible lawyer, who doesn't let his emotions run away with him like the others. My only (slight) criticism of the film, is that the Scilly scenes didn't run as smoothly as the rest of the film. Although it was interesting to see where family orginates from (again the 2nd film covers this more), Micheals falling in love and then his newly-weds' death seem a little unrealistic. Well in didn't make as well sense to me in a way.

In summary this is a brilliantly detailed and enjoyable film, if not as 'entertaining' as Armaggedon (supposedly) or other rubbish. I can see how this film wouldn't be for all tastes, but anyone interested in the more 'classic' style which people remember for years to come, as well as the storyline, this is a MUST see. Also note its a good idea to watch Godfather Part II shortly afterwards, while Part I is still fresh in the mind, as they link together brillantly. 10/10

title: best o the best
description: This movie is Epic. i never tired no matter howmany i see this.

title: Do you like the godfather? (Jesus ok you don't)
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is by far the most loved and cherished Movie in cinema history, You just can't escape it, but that might be the problem.

Since everybody that has access to the internet have read that sentence or one like it (The Godfather is the best movie ever), It feels like everybody loves it because they're told to, Everybody says they love the godfather and that it's the best movie ever made, but are they just following the crowd?

When's the last time you heard someone say the godfather is one of their favorite movies ever? Probably not long ago, when's the last time you heard somebody actually tell you what's so good about it without repeating those same words (Acting, Influential, Classic)?

Of course there ARE people who actually explain everything that is great about it and deep dive into analyzing the subtle things it inhabits, but would they have done it if they haven't constantly heard that it's the greatest movie ever?

Ok, you can stop screaming at your screen, "The Godfather Is Terrible! It's so overrated!" and so on, you don't like it, or are you just following a trend?

Look at the ratings of the godfather on any reviewing site (IMDB, Letterboxd etc.) and you'll see that 5/10 stars as the most popular rating and then the numbers of all the other ratings quickly go down, until a random spike at the bottom (1/2 star/1 star), that's because it's become a trend to hate the godfather.

People have 2 reactions to hearing that the godfather is the best movie ever made: 1, I know, It's a masterpiece, so amazing, it's a classic. (And they just didn't watch it or didn't pay attention) or: 2, No it's not! It sucks! It's overrated! Worst movie ever! (And they probably didn't watch it either)

My point is, you can't find a single review of "The Godfather" which hasn't been HEAVILY influenced by the general stigma of this movie, it's either they followed all the others like zombies, or they think they're revolutionaries by saying they don't. Nobody thinks the Godfather is a 1 star/ half a star movie, they just don't.

This movie IS amazing, but nobody seems to actually think so.

title: Best movie I've ever watched
description: Popularly viewed as one of the best American films ever made, the multi-generational crime saga The Godfather is a touchstone of cinema: one of the most widely imitated, quoted, and lampooned movies of all time. Marlon Brando and Al Pacino star as Vito Corleone and his youngest son, Michael, respectively. It is the late 1940s in New York and Corleone is, in the parlance of organized crime, a "godfather" or "don," the head of a Mafia family. Michael, a free thinker who defied his father by enlisting in the Marines to fight in World War II, has returned a captain and a war hero. Having long ago rejected the family business, Michael shows up at the wedding of his sister, Connie (Talia Shire), with his non-Italian girlfriend, Kay (Diane Keaton), who learns for the first time about the family "business." A few months later at Christmas time, the don barely survives being shot by gunmen in the employ of a drug-trafficking rival whose request for aid from the Corleones' political connections was rejected. After saving his father from a second assassination attempt, Michael persuades his hotheaded eldest brother, Sonny (James Caan), and family advisors Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall) and Sal Tessio (Abe Vigoda) that he should be the one to exact revenge on the men responsible. After murdering a corrupt police captain and the drug trafficker, Michael hides out in Sicily while a gang war erupts at home. Falling in love with a local girl, Michael marries her, but she is later slain by Corleone enemies in an attempt on Michael's life. Sonny is also butchered, having been betrayed by Connie's husband. As Michael returns home and convinces Kay to marry him, his father recovers and makes peace with his rivals, realizing that another powerful don was pulling the strings behind the narcotics endeavor that began the gang warfare. Once Michael has been groomed as the new don, he leads the family to a new era of prosperity, then launches a campaign of murderous revenge against those who once tried to wipe out the Corleones, consolidating his family's power and completing his own moral downfall. Nominated for 11 Academy Awards and winning for Best Picture, Best Actor (Marlon Brando), and Best Adapted Screenplay, The Godfather was followed by a pair of sequels. ~ Karl Williams, Rovi

title: The Godfather: An Unparalleled Masterpiece in Cinema History
description:
Introduction:

Since its release in 1972, Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" has stood the test of time, cementing its position as one of the greatest films ever made. With its compelling storytelling, impeccable performances, and artistic brilliance, "The Godfather" continues to captivate audiences, solidifying its status as an unparalleled masterpiece in cinema history.

Plot and Storytelling:

"The Godfather" takes us deep into the intricate world of organized crime, exploring the Corleone family's rise and fall in the mafia hierarchy. Coppola expertly weaves a narrative that combines elements of family, loyalty, power, and betrayal. The film's plot unfolds with meticulous precision, presenting a gripping story that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats throughout its nearly three-hour runtime. The script, based on Mario Puzo's novel, is flawlessly executed, delving into the complex psychology of its characters and highlighting the moral ambiguities that lie within.

Iconic Performances:

One cannot discuss "The Godfather" without acknowledging the exceptional performances that bring its characters to life. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of legendary, as he effortlessly embodies the power, wisdom, and vulnerability of the character. Al Pacino's nuanced performance as Michael Corleone, the reluctant heir turned ruthless mob boss, showcases his remarkable range as an actor. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, deliver performances that are equally memorable and impactful, adding depth and authenticity to the film's ensemble.

Cinematic Brilliance:

Visually, "The Godfather" is a work of art. Coppola's direction, coupled with Gordon Willis's cinematography, creates a distinct atmosphere that immerses viewers in the world of the Corleone family. The use of shadows, lighting, and composition adds a layer of depth to the storytelling, emphasizing the film's underlying themes of darkness and secrecy. The iconic wedding scene, the horse's head in the bed, and the baptism sequence are just a few examples of the film's visually striking moments that have become ingrained in popular culture.

Memorable Dialogue:

"The Godfather" is renowned for its memorable dialogue, which has become ingrained in the lexicon of cinema. From Don Vito's iconic line, "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse," to Michael's chilling declaration, "It's not personal, Sonny. It's strictly business," the script is filled with powerful and quotable lines. These lines not only contribute to the film's narrative impact but have also transcended the screen to become a part of our collective consciousness.

Influence on Cinema:

"The Godfather" has left an indelible mark on the world of cinema, influencing generations of filmmakers and shaping the crime genre. Its influence can be seen in subsequent films that explore similar themes and narrative structures. The film's success paved the way for a new era of character-driven storytelling, elevating the expectations of audiences and filmmakers alike.

Cultural Impact:

Beyond its cinematic achievements, "The Godfather" has become a cultural phenomenon. It has spawned countless references in popular culture, from parodies to homages, further solidifying its status as a touchstone in the collective imagination. Its portrayal of the mafia and its exploration of themes such as loyalty, power, and family have resonated with audiences around the world, transcending language and cultural barriers.

Conclusion:

In the pantheon of cinema, "The Godfather" stands as an unrivaled masterpiece. Its compelling storytelling, iconic performances, visual artistry, and lasting cultural impact have secured its place as one of the greatest films of.

title: they don't make them like this anymore
description: Everything you want a film to be, this is it. Amazing character(s) development and story that keeps you interested. All the actors seemed to be born to play these characters, especially Brando and Pacino who are at their finest.

title: Cool
description: Rarely does a film tell as many diverse-yet-interconnected stories. Strong performances, solid directing, and a tightly-plotted script all contribute to The Godfather's success. This motion picture was not slapped together to satiate the appetite of the masses; it was carefully and painstakingly crafted. Every major character - and more than a few minor ones - is molded into a distinct, complex individual. Stereotypes did not influence Coppola's film, although certain ones were formed as a result of it. Although the issues presented in The Godfather are universal in scope, the characters and setting are decidedly ethnic. Even to this day, there is an odd romanticism associated with New York's Italian crime families.

title: Great Movie
description: Whenever i saw a list of the top 100 movies, "The Godfather" was always on top. I had no clue why. I heard it was really good so i felt i should see it. So one evening, after all my homework was done, i sat down on the couch in front of the TV and surfed through the channels and i land upon a memo saying, "The Godfather: Next at 8 pm" So i decide to just watch maybe an hour or so of it and then go to sleep. I stayed up the whole night watching it. The acting in the movie was excellent and the cinematography was great. The characters were so believable that whenever i see a picture/movie of any character in the movie, the first thing that pops into my brain is their character name. After watching the movie, i couldn't stop talking about it to all my friends. Now i understand why its always on top of top 100 lists.

title: The Godfather is without a doubt one of the greatest movies of all time.
description:
I have seen it four times and have enjoyed it every single time. In fact if I could only watch three movies for the rest of my life, this would be it along with to Kill A Mockingbird and American Beauty.

There are many things that make this movie enjoyable so many things that I have to break it down.

The plot. There are few American movies that have a plot as deep and complex as the Godfather. Usually when I don't want to spend 6 dollars to see a movie I'll just go to a website and read a recap, but with this it is impossible. There are more twists and turns then a hamster maze. In fact the first time I watched this I had to pause every 20 minutes just to take in what I was seeing.

It delivers what it promises. With 90 percent of today's movies they promise something big and epic, only to fail to deliver. The Godfather sets up high expectations and meets them all and then some. It is impossible to say this movie is over rated, because there isn't a scale in the world that can rate a movie such as this.

The characters. Just as a captain is nothing without his crew a movie is nothing without its characters and this movie has some of the most memorable. I cannot possibly have a favorite because they are all incredible. Clearly when casting they chose the best and not the ones that looked good and had six packs.

The dialogue. Very few movies have realistic dialogue. They sound rehearsed and forced, but this movie is the exception. The actors were speaking as if this was real life and they were having a realistic conversation. If I didn't know this was a movie I would think that someone had recorded an actual person's life.

The action. I won't deny it, I love action and this movie does not fail. The fight scenes were epic and unpredictable. One moment a family could be sitting down to a nice dinner and the next minute machine gun fire could be going everywhere. My personal favorite was when Emilio Barzini was shot and rolled down the stairs.

This is a movie that I would recommend to anyone. This is one of the few movies that can please everyone. It has action, romance, comedy, drama, suspense, a deep plot, and a feeling of satisfaction after you see it. If you haven't seen this movie do so as soon as possible this is one film that you can't refuse.

title: Tbe Godfather Movie

They did it to the fullest!

title: A Movie You Can't Refuse
description:
The world works differently in 1940's New York City, especially if you were a Sicilian. The Godfather, in all its twists and turns that coincide with the style of living in the mafia, sets itself aside from all other gangster/mob/mafia movies by providing a transformation unlike any other. This change, however, comes from an individual that you, as a watcher, wouldn't want it to come from, until you do. The hook is in the constant re-occurrence of the meaning of loyalty to an Italian.

Advice for first time viewers: watch with someone who has seen it before, because you will get lost at some points and will need the legal and mafia jargon explained.

title: Is The Godfather the greatest film of all time?
description: No! But it is in the top five. The Godfather is the king of mobster and mafia films. It goes where no family has ever gone before. Marlone Brando is The Godfather, the head master of the family. His raspy voice is copied by people all over the world, but is never mastered. The Godfather is such a great film. But, I do warn you though. It's a long,long film. I think it's about 3 hours long. If you don't like sitting there for 3 hours watching a movie, then watch it hour by hour. It's a hard decision to make..if The Godfather is the greatest film of all time. Some people say yes, others no. I say..and I stand by this..The Wizard of Oz is the greatest film of all time. Yeah, yeah, I'm picking Oz over The Godfather. The Godfather is #3 on my list, which is a pretty hard list to get on. You must watch this film. It's one of America's classics. This comments has taught me many this. It taught me..keep your friends close..and your enemies closer. That's in part 2..but, Hey! Who's keeping up?

title: Amazing film
description: This is one of a kind. The acting is perfect. Al Pacino's character goes from a kind hearted man to a man with hardly any heart at all and I love it. The music is amazing sounding like something you would hear at Epcot in the Italy section. The only reason I rated this a 9 and not a 10 is because the beginning is a little slow but it starts moving faster and faster to where it becomes an compelling crime drama.

title: Wow!
description: A very well known classic film. The story is what keeps me coming back to this. A mafia boss' son that has managed to stay separate from the family and their dealings, only to gradually be drawn back in as his father's life comes under threat. The transition of this early conflict of the main character is the main force behind this film. Pacino's performance is stand out as one of the best performances of all time. That would be good on its own but there's so much more to offer. All the characters are well fleshed out and Coppola's direction of slowly letting the story unravel whilst giving the actors time and space to portray their characters is genius. Highly recommended.

title: Sublime. Classic. Classy. Brutal. THE gangster movie
description:
The Godfather is a movie that I first saw on BBC 2 when I was 14 years old. That's 34 years ago.

Its impact on me was immediate and throughout the years whenever I have watched The Godfather it still leaves me with a feeling that I've just seen something great.

The direction from Francis Ford Coppola is pretty much flawless and each actor commits to their roles with skill and passion.

Al Pacino is perfect as Michael and James Caan convinces entirely as the hot headed Sonny.

Marlon Brando is at the height of his acting ability in what is his greatest role as Vito Corleone.

For me this is the greatest gangster film of all time.

description: No words can define this movie it's100/10 and i still think this rating is way less and who am I to rate this movie.

title: Not My Favourite, But Deserving
description:
For starters people will now no longer be able to say to me "I can't believe you haven't watched the Godfather". If you haven't seen it, I know you too have been told this.

As for the movie, with many often labeling it the greatest movie ever , it puts it under the highest tier of scrutiny for me. For starters, unlike some GOAT movie contenders, I can see how this movie would produce a cult like fan following. Despite there not being a real deep dive into any of the characters for the most part early on, all of them give off strong sentiments of having worked in the family business with the paradoxical idea that life is cheap and yet family is sacred. Trying to keep up with all the different characters for my first viewing was certainly a huge challenge.

The Godfather is very deliberate and is in no hurry. While some complain or joke about the 3 hour runtime I believe all of the time used is critical to building the aura that surrounds the Corleone family. In moving at this speed it allows us to see the fall from innocence of the movies true main character that is Michael Corleone. Unlike many fall from innocence type themes, the Godfathers greatest success is in its believability. While watching you are never made immediately aware of the snapping point within Michael, in fact he is strongly contrasted by his brother Sonny who knows only one way to react to events. However, this makes Michael feel even more dangerous as you can feel the impacts of what occurred to the family grate on him and shift his morals slowly but surely as the movie unwinds.

While , I certainly don't see this as in the greatest of all time debate for me, I appreciate it as extremely high quality cinema especially for an early 70s film. The acting is world class, the score perfectly fitting , and with sets way ahead of its time. For me it didn't have the highest entertainment factor but I certainly think the film deserves its place as a groundbreaking trailblazer that has provided a format for success for many future inspired films.

title: "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is a timeless classic that continues to captivate audiences more than 50 years after its release with stunning performances, iconic scenes, and unforgettable dialogue.

The story of the Corleone family, a powerful mafia dynasty in 1940s New York. At its core, the film is a tale of loyalty, betrayal, and the high price of power. The Godfather, Vito Corleone, played by Marlon Brando, is a man of immense influence and respect in the criminal underworld, but when he is targeted for assassination, his son Michael, played by Al Pacino, must step up to take his place and protect the family.

title: Simply, Greatest Movie of All Time
description: We are all humans and most of us have a family and those who don't are likely to create their own kind-of-family environment around them. Family means love, devotion, sacrifice, and many other greatest things. Humans surely can't survive on its own and without even a family has even less chance than to stand out. What's a film? For me it's like a book with graphics which makes one person re-live the story with the characters as if he/she was there too. Coming from these two aspects; family & film, I think what movie could be better than a one which shows what family is and makes the one re-live the story of the film. We see a person, a father who would do everything to protect his family. Needless to say, all the actors who played were also the best actors of all time.

title: Best movie of all time
description:
Best of best!!!

The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola, who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo, based on Puzo's best-selling 1969 novel of the same name.

The Godfather Part III was released on December 25, 1990. Francis Ford Coppola returned as director for the feature-length film, while also writing the screenplay with the help of the author Mario Puzo.

On December 4, 2020, a recut version of the film titled The Godfather Coda: The Death of Michael Corleone was released in a limited number of theatres as well as being released on Blu-ray and streaming platforms. Coppola said the film is the version he and Puzo had originally envisioned, and it "vindicates" its status among the trilogy and his daughter Sofia's performance. Sofia's performance was received negatively by critics. Leonard Maltin, said of the film that the casting of Sofia Coppola was an "almost-fatal flaw"

source wikipedia.

title: The Godfather Series
description: What makes this movie so good? Just about everything. Good acting, good direction, good story, good development...it's weird, but this is one of those cases where the sequel makes it better. Godfather II is the best sequel ever made, and I just don't think you can really say anything about this movie until you've seen that one. Really, you have to look at the first one as the rise of Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), and the second as his fall. Despite the fact that he doesn't lose power, he loses almost everything else. You don't really get much character development of Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) in this movie, because it's all being saved for the sequel (in the form of Robert De Niro). The way that the two are intertwined is just absolutely brilliant. As a movie by itself, The Godfather is still a masterpiece. One of the things that I think makes it so compelling is the blurring of the line between good and evil. Just about everyone in this movie is a bad guy. But there are good bad guys and bad bad guys, and we're on the outside trying to decide which ones we want to root for. We end up cheering on the Corleones, the focal point of the movie, but it's very reluctant as the climactic scene unfolds. I found myself right there with Kay (Diane Keaton) at the end, torn between what I know to be right and what has to be done for survival. I cannot imagine this movie being any better. It's fascinating, and the sequel does not do anything to diminish that sense of awe. It's a timeless classic about the battle between good and evil. But does evil really win out? It's impossible to tell.

title: The Best

The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola who co-wrote the screenplay with Mario Puzo, based on Puzo's best-selling 1969 novel of the same name. The film stars Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Richard Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte, and Diane Keaton. It is the first installment in The Godfather trilogy. The story, spanning from 1945 to 1955, chronicles the Corleone family under patriarch Vito Corleone (Brando), focusing on the transformation of one of his sons, Michael Corleone (Pacino), from reluctant family outsider to ruthless mafia boss.
