title: Powerful, Stunning, Astonishing, Outstanding, Brilliant, etc.
description:
This movie has some of Hollywood's top performancesand is a classic on every level on filmaking.

Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, James Cann, and Diane Keaton star in this brilliant mafia movie about Al Pacino taking over the business when Marlon Brando, playing his father brilliantly, is wounded. Diane Keaton plays his wife and James Cann plays his brother Sonny.

Classic Hollywood films can't and don't get much better than this movie. Deserved every oscar it won plus it's nominations. Oscar winners were Marlon Brando for Best Actor, Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo for Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Picture of '72. Nominations include Best Costume Design, Francis Ford Coppola for Best Director, Best Film Editing, Best Sound, and Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, and James Cann for Best Supporting Actor of '72. Followed by an equally brilliant sequel.

title: A Masterpiece of Cinematic Brilliance
description: "The Godfather" is an unparalleled classic that stands the test of time. Released in 1972, this epic crime drama, directed by Francis Ford Coppola, showcases exceptional storytelling and a compelling portrayal of power, family, and loyalty. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, creating a character whose presence is both formidable and deeply human. The film's meticulous attention to detail, combined with its haunting score and atmospheric cinematography, makes it a gripping experience from start to finish. "The Godfather" is a cinematic triumph that continues to captivate and influence audiences worldwide.

title: Most accomplished US film
description: This epic of epics, in my wholehearted view, remains to this day America's  most accomplished feature film. Even without understanding the dialogue's nuances or the storyline's elaborate twists, one is still inexorably drawn to the movie, as I found myself to be since the earliest time. What makes it so enormously appealing and deeply satisfying is Copolla's masterful direction. Every frame is constructed in such an ingenious manner, that if taken out of context and hung up on a wall as a painting, it would take up another value, becoming as work of art in and of itself. Indeed, it is tempting to compare the dark indoor compositions (the mise-en-scenes' arrangement especially) to Rembrandt and other Dutch masters, without exaggeration. The staging of each scene is handled with the kind of technical and spiritual balance advocated only in Eastern religions: no extreme close-ups, no jittery or stale camera movements. On a visual level, "The Godfather" possesses an ethereal beauty regardless of content. The picture's other aspects reveal an astounding proximity to irrefutable perfection: an immortal original score with at least three distinguished motifs; the superlative acting by all of the Corleone Mafia clan and their enemies; the compelling plot which swiftly unfolds before us through, among other things, the most riveting montage since "Battleship Potemkin", no less. Even its minute details are widely quoted today: what comes most easily to mind is the shot-by-shot parody of Brando's botched assassination in '99's "Analyze This", and the more obscure slang term : "to pull a Fredo", coined  in "Swingers" (one of the 90's hippest comedies). Just to decipher the later (decidedly dirty) reference should be a good excuse to watch "The Godfather" yet again.

title: I love it
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" stands as an enduring masterpiece in the annals of cinematic history. Adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, this epic crime drama paints a vivid portrait of the Corleone family, New York's most powerful Mafia dynasty.

At its heart, "The Godfather" is a tale of power, loyalty, and the inevitable cost of ambition. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of iconic, encapsulating the duality of a ruthless crime lord and a family man guided by an unwavering moral code. Al Pacino's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a calculating heir is a tour de force, mirroring the film's broader themes of legacy and destiny.

Coppola's meticulous direction, complemented by Gordon Willis's evocative cinematography, immerses viewers in a world where honor is as treacherous as betrayal. The film's narrative unfolds with the precision of a chess match, each move fraught with consequence and emotion. Memorable sequences, from the chilling horse-head scene to the haunting baptism juxtaposition, have seared themselves into the collective consciousness of audiences worldwide.

Furthermore, Nino Rota's haunting score lends an operatic grandeur to the film, amplifying its emotional resonance. The impeccable ensemble cast, including Robert Duvall, James Caan, and Diane Keaton, delivers performances that are both nuanced and unforgettable.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is more than a crime saga; it's a cinematic masterpiece that transcends genres. Its enduring appeal lies in its profound exploration of human nature, power dynamics, and the intricate tapestry of familial bonds. A timeless classic that continues to captivate and inspire, "The Godfather" remains an indispensable part of film history.

title: Superb
description:
There is very little that I can add to the reviews on here, that have explained what is so wonderful about The Godfather so well. I have seen many amazing movies, as well as some clunkers, but The Godfather was beyond amazing. There are so many images, details and scenes that I seriously cannot get out of my head since watching it for the first time just nine hours ago. The Godfather is so incredibly well-made and acted that it stands out among the rest of those other amazing films I've seen, so much so I couldn't think of a single flaw, and I am struggling to think of a good enough reason to why I didn't see this film before now.

True, The Godfather is a little slow-moving and the plot takes a while to unfold, but neither of these are flaws as such. The slow pacing added to the elegiac quality The Godfather has, and as for the plot what is special about this plot is that it is very unpredictable because you have next to no idea where it is next going to take you. Being 18, I was worried whether I was old enough to appreciate this film or even understand it, but luckily I understood it perfectly, and I can well and truly appreciate it for the masterpiece it is considered to be.

The Godfather for one thing looks stunning. I strongly disagree with the previous reviewer who said the cinematography was horrid, for me the cinematography was one of the best assets of the film. In some scenes you have cinematography and lighting that is quite dark and mysterious, and then in scenes such as the wedding it is evergreen, autumnal and very picturesque. It is not just the cinematography that makes The Godfather look stunning, the costumes are beautifully tailored, the houses are gorgeous and majestic to look at and even the cars were immaculate.

Then there is the score by Nina Rota. One word, outstanding! I have heard many wonderful scores in my lifetime, but after hearing this score few stick in the memory as much as the score for The Godfather. This score is both beautiful as seen with the main theme, and haunting in the way it sticks in your head after watching the film itself. Other outstanding assets are the masterly direction from Francis Ford Coppola, and the brilliantly written screenplay that is intelligent, thought-provoking and darkly humorous. As for the violence, some of it is shocking and intense especially in the climax which was enough to almost make your heart either beat twice as fast or stop, and I almost covered my eyes when the producer found the horse's head in his bed, but underneath that this family is somewhat loyal and honourable come to think of it.

title: Modern Day Cinema Vs. The Godfather
description: Wow! Ross And Ronnay in the Sunday papers will have their work cut out for them commenting on this film! It is the greatest film ever, just like Casablanca, Shawshank Redemption and Shindlers List, it has mastered its genre, except many people do not know of the film!!! Now days movies such as oceans 11, Layer cake and even police investigative stories try to have the original concept of them film, with the moral battling of crime. The beauty of the story is that it is original and none of the actors (in the first part) were well known, which gives them an better on-screen identity, compared to modern day Hollywood heroes such as brad Pitt, Collin pharrel and Tom Cruise. Even action packed scarface can take The Godfathers title as 'Best Crime/Gangster Film Ever' because that is exactly what godfather is. Its only downfall is the conclusion of the saga, in part number three which is kind off like The Matrix trilogy in a way, The First part had a cult following, number 2 was "good but will never beat the first" and the third one was awful! The Godfather = legendary film, which will live long in existence especially with the Italian population! The only deteriorating factor is its lenght not many people can watch a film for 2 hours and 10 minutes, but i could :). Also the plot is tricky to understand for first time viewers!

title: Simply the finest film ever made....
description:
The Godfather has got to be the finest film ever made. It has all the ingredients of a great film. Directing, being Coppola's first major film, he does an astounding job of recreating Mario Puzzo's novel. The acting is top notch, with Brando and Pacino really shining and supported by the likes of Robert Duvall and Diane Keaton. The script is breath taking and really pulls you in to the story.

From the opening scene to the final credits, you just know that the Godfather is special, and it refuses to let you go. The more you watch this film, the more you'll understand the plot and the characters, adding to a already great film. The Godfather has been copied many times, but never beaten. Soon, i'll get the Godfather: Part 2 and watch that, and see if its better, but until then, The Godfather remains No.1 on my top 10 list of all time.

title: The Godfather Review
description: "Godfather" is consider one of the greatest film of all time in my opinion because of the plot, the visuals, the characters and the overall theme of the film. I love the fact that paramount pretty much went against almost everything Francis hand in mind for his vision down the casting. They didn't even agreed with some of the shot and artistic vision he had for his film but and went on to do amazing things, breaking records ad setting new ones. It did great in the box office that year and it went on to become the greatest film of all time. Not only did the film inspired filmmakers like my self but it paved the way for Mafia films in general. Ironically Francis him self became in his own right a godfather in the world of Mafia film. I also enjoyed watching how the characters in the film changed towards the ending of the film. Each character had a transition moment and my favorite was when Michael agreed to join the family business. In doing so he became the don at the end.

title: no doubt
description: I was fortunate to see "The Godfather" back in 1972 upon its theatrical release. No matter how many "gangster" movies were made before this, here we had a different kind of movie. We had a movie foremost about "family" and dedication to one another. If you could manage to ignore the fact that this was one of the New York mafia families (set in the 1940s), it was as if we were watching a model family. At once honoring the family patriarch, Don Vito Corleone memorably played by Marlon Brando , and at the same time witnessing the rise of the new family leader, Michael Corleone played by Al Pacino. Equally memorable was the role of Santino 'Sonny' Corleone created by James Caan. And memorable for Robert Duvall who created the quiet role of Tom Hagen. Many list have "The Godfather" as number one of all time. To me that doesn't matter, films are meant to be enjoyed each for its own merit. Regardless, there probably will never be a "gang family" movie that approaches the overall impact of this one.

title: Good
description:
Any classic is approved over time, and the painting by Francis Ford Coppolys proves its inaccessibility in the genre every decade. Many years passed, and I postponed watching the film in order to "mature" for a certain objectivity.

The picture was shot very qualitatively, which gave her the key to success to be relevant in the visual range among other competitors from other directors. There are not so many paintings I have seen with the legend of the past Marlon Brando, however, I am very glad that he received the golden statuette for the best male role in Coppola's film. His role is not as big in screen time as Al Pacino's, for example, but his character's monologues and dialogues can be quoted and quoted.

"The Godfather" is not only the beginning of the famous criminal saga, it is also the beginning of a stellar time for Al Pacino, no matter how initially this actor did not fit his role, according to the producers, his fame could not pass unnoticed in modern cinema, and the actor cemented the image of a criminal figure forever.

Referring to objectivity, I would call the film "The Godfather" a high-quality, benchmark in the genre, and I can understand the surge of criticism and perception of the film several decades ago, which attributed the tape to the rank of cult. But many years later, Francis Ford Coppola's tape suffered a semantic and technical reassessment, at a time when the genre of crime cinema is saturated with high-quality pictures, with no less strong acting.

title: An Opera on Screen
description: Along with it's sequel, Godfather II, this movie is what American movies should aspire to. Great acting, great story line. The power of the family, the immigrants' rise to glory, the failures of society, the paradox of religion and violence woven together to form the perfect movie. The characters are composites of real men and women in history. The scenes fictionalize real historical events. The Don's granting wishes to his neighbors remind you of Marranzano's despotic rule in the early 30's. The shooting in the restaurant mirrors Luciano's assassination of Masseria. Moe Green's execution is really Bugsy Segal's. The climax is the night of the Sicilian Vespers. This film is a classic. Puzo's work is wonderful and Coppola's vision is perfect.

title: The Godfather
description:
The Godfather, directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is an undeniable masterpiece that has solidified its place as one of the greatest films in cinematic history. Adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, this iconic crime drama weaves a complex and compelling narrative of power, family, loyalty, and the corrupting influence of organized crime.

Set in the 1940s, The Godfather takes us into the world of the Corleone family, led by the enigmatic and powerful Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). The film follows the transition of power from Vito to his reluctant son, Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), as he becomes embroiled in the dark underbelly of the mafia.

The Godfather is a masterclass in storytelling, with a screenplay that flawlessly intertwines multiple storylines and characters. The narrative unfolds at a deliberate pace, allowing the audience to become fully immersed in the intricate web of alliances, betrayals, and moral dilemmas that shape the Corleone family's destiny. Every scene is meticulously crafted, drawing us deeper into this world of crime and power struggles.

The performances in The Godfather are nothing short of extraordinary. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic, exuding a captivating blend of charisma, vulnerability, and ruthlessness. Al Pacino delivers a career-defining performance as Michael Corleone, masterfully capturing the character's transformation from an innocent outsider to a formidable force within the mafia. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, deliver equally powerful performances, each bringing depth and nuance to their respective roles.

Coppola's direction is impeccable, showcasing his keen eye for detail and his ability to create an authentic and immersive atmosphere. From the dimly lit interiors of the Corleone family home to the grandeur of their compound, every visual element contributes to the film's rich and evocative ambiance. The cinematography, accompanied by a haunting score by Nino Rota, further enhances the film's dramatic impact, emphasizing the tension and emotional depth of each scene.

Beyond its technical brilliance, The Godfather delves into profound themes that resonate with audiences even decades after its release. It explores the complexities of family dynamics, the allure and consequences of power, and the moral compromises individuals make to protect what they hold dear. The film poses thought-provoking questions about the nature of morality and the blurred lines between good and evil.

The Godfather stands as a testament to the power of cinema to transport and engage its audience. Its influence on subsequent films and popular culture cannot be overstated. Coppola's masterpiece is a gripping, emotionally charged exploration of the human condition, propelled by stellar performances, impeccable direction, and a narrative that continues to captivate generations of viewers.

In conclusion, The Godfather remains an unparalleled achievement in filmmaking. It transcends the crime genre, offering a profound examination of power, family, and the human psyche. With its rich characters, intricate storytelling, and timeless themes, this cinematic magnum opus continues to leave an indelible mark on the landscape of cinema, making it an essential watch for all cinephiles.

title: hi
description: This is a great movie. You won't be disappointed if you watch this movie.

title: All you nutty fans.....take it easy on me!!
description:
OK, I am 32 and have seen the vast majority of this film several times, particularly when I was younger. I have just bought the DVD boxed set for £20 and watched the 1st film the WHOLE way through for the 1st time.

Oh my god. This film is absolutely brilliant. I always had Casino and Goodfellas as my top 2 gangster films. I am now re-writing my list!! Blown away by the acting, script, cinematography and sheer realism. There are so many scenes that will be used in film study courses for decades to come.

One of my favourites, which some might find surprising is when Vito has the heart attack whilst playing with his grandson. The young boy plays the scene to absolute perfection. Of course, Brando just keeps up what was an excellent performance throughout.

I had memories of this film being quite difficult to follow as a youngster. This may have been in part due to the sometimes muffled voice of Brando, but with the help of subtitles at my dumbest moments(!), the plot and characters are actually fairly easy to keep up with.

Cant really say much more. If you like your gangster style films and need advice on whether to watch....its a no brainer. Its quite a long film so keep the distractions to a minimum and be prepared to take a couple of toilet breaks! I just wish that I wasn't working tomorrow otherwise I'd watch the next one now instead of tomorrow evening!

title: A Timeless Masterpiece: "The Godfather"
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" stands as a monumental achievement in cinematic history, seamlessly blending intricate storytelling with profound character development. From the very first scene, the film immerses viewers into the complex world of the Corleone family, portraying the delicate balance between power, loyalty, and morality. Marlon Brando delivers an unforgettable performance as Vito Corleone, embodying the character's strength and vulnerability with unparalleled nuance. Al Pacino's transformation from the reluctant Michael to a formidable Don is equally compelling, showcasing his remarkable range as an actor.

The film's screenplay, co-written by Coppola and Mario Puzo, masterfully weaves themes of family, honor, and the corrupting influence of power, all set against the backdrop of post-war America. The meticulous attention to detail in the cinematography and score, composed by Nino Rota, enhances the narrative, creating an atmosphere that is both authentic and hauntingly beautiful. Each supporting character, from James Caan's hot-headed Sonny to Robert Duvall's calculating Tom Hagen, adds depth and richness to the story, making the Corleone saga both epic and intimate.

"The Godfather" is not merely a crime drama; it is a profound exploration of human nature and the complexities of leadership. Its influence extends beyond cinema, shaping the way stories of organized crime are told and appreciated. Decades after its release, the film remains relevant, resonating with audiences through its timeless portrayal of ambition, family ties, and the inevitable consequences of one's choices. Coppola's masterpiece is a testament to the power of exceptional filmmaking, earning its place as one of the greatest films ever made.

title: The Greatest Film Ever Made!
description: The Godfather is a true definition of great filmaking. Unbelieveable acting by Marlon Brando, James Caan, Sterling Hayden, and of course Al Pacino. The story itself is unlike any other I have ever seen. Landmark! Simply Landmark! It really invented a new genre of Mafia films. Often copyed never duplicated, except its sequel The Godfather Part II.

title: The Greatest Movie Ever Made... i love it
description:
This is a masterpiece. A timeless masterpiece. Initially, I didn't like this film before... but I realized one day when my one of my friend brought DVD's then i saw God father title. And well' we watch them together w/ some other friends and then..

This movie for me is an epitome of perfection, it scores a perfect score in almost all the departments, be it direction, acting, music, screenplay, character development, cinematography etc. I just couldn't find a fault with it (and mind you I tried really hard).

With a blazing canon of actors which include Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall this film pierces right through you and makes a place for itself. Even days after you watch this movie you will find yourself, in your own private moments, speaking out those wonderful lines, trying to copy Vito Corleone or shape your voice like Michael Corleone. In its own mysterious ways the movie will sure remain with you.

It leaves you wanting more, not because there are questions that remain unanswered, but because this film feels so good that you never want to leave it, leave the streets of New York or the Godfather's mansion.

title: Best ever
description: The Godfather is an American classic and an iconic film that has stood the test of time. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, the film is widely regarded as one of the greatest films ever made. The story focuses on a powerful mafia family in New York City and their struggles to maintain control over their business empire. The film features some of the best performances in cinema history from Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, as well as an excellent supporting cast. The direction is masterful and the film's score is legendary. The Godfather is an unforgettable movie that should be watched and enjoyed by all.

title: "A Personal Odyssey through 'The Godfather': An Offer I Couldn't Refuse"
description:
"The Godfather," directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola, is not just a film-it's an unparalleled cinematic journey that left an indelible mark on my movie-loving soul. Having finally experienced this epic mafia saga, I find myself compelled to share my personal odyssey through the Corleone family's dark and complex world.

From the moment the film begins, you are transported to a bygone era of power, loyalty, and family, as you're introduced to the enigmatic patriarch, Vito Corleone, played with commanding brilliance by Marlon Brando. His raspy voice, profound wisdom, and mesmerizing presence demand your attention and respect. Brando's performance alone is worth the price of admission.

As the film progresses, we witness the transformation of Michael Corleone, portrayed by Al Pacino in a career-defining role. His evolution from a reluctant outsider to the ruthless heir of the Corleone empire is a character study of Shakespearean proportions. Pacino's subtle yet powerful portrayal takes you on an emotional rollercoaster, and you can't help but empathize with this complex antihero.

The supporting cast is a who's who of talent, with James Caan, Robert Duvall, and John Cazale delivering standout performances that add depth to the family dynamics. Each character feels meticulously crafted, and their interwoven relationships create a rich tapestry of intrigue and tension.

The film's script, adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, is a masterclass in storytelling. The dialogue is sharp and memorable, peppered with iconic lines that have become part of the cinematic lexicon. Coppola's direction is flawless, and the pacing keeps you on the edge of your seat, even during moments of quiet tension.

Cinematographer Gordon Willis's use of shadow and light adds a layer of visual sophistication that enhances the film's mood and atmosphere. The haunting score by Nino Rota complements the narrative beautifully, evoking a sense of nostalgia and foreboding.

One of the film's most compelling aspects is its exploration of the blurred line between good and evil, as well as the idea that in a world filled with corruption, power, and betrayal, family remains the most important foundation of all. It's a theme that resonates deeply and invites introspection.

My personal journey through "The Godfather" was a captivating one, as I found myself engrossed in the power struggles, moral dilemmas, and intricate relationships of the Corleone clan. The film's iconic moments, such as the horse's head in the bed and the baptism scene, left an indelible imprint on my cinematic memory.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a timeless masterpiece that transcends the crime genre. It's a film that demands repeat viewings to fully appreciate its complexity and nuance. I am grateful for the opportunity to have embarked on this cinematic adventure, and I wholeheartedly agree with its status as one of the greatest films ever made. To those who have yet to experience it, I say: Make an offer to yourself that you can't refuse, and dive into the world of "The Godfather." It's a journey you won't soon forget.

title: Best movie ever!
description:
Now as this is my favourite movie ever made it is going to be hard for me not to be bias towards this movie and I will try and be as objective as I possibly can.

I'm a huge fan of the first Godfather film and it's story I've read the book, played the game and watched the movie countless times. The story is a great story of a family. That is what the story is basically about the family and how they cope in all these different situations. Now I'm a huge fan of gangster movies and this movie is the best of them.

The movie has some of the best cast of actors I have ever seen in a movie, with actors such as Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Cann, John Cazale and many other fantastic actors it would be hard not to make a masterpiece. Each character is exactly as you imagine them to look and act in the book and this movie is one of the few movies where it is actually as good or even better than the book.

The only negative I can find about this movie is that it is abit of an unrealistic take on the Mafia and glorifies them more than what they were. As the movie shows them being very close like a family even the ones that aren't related, but in actual fact it would be best friends killing each other in the mafia as seen in movies such as Goodfellas or Donnie Brasco. But those movies are supposed to be dark and gritty realistic movies. But this movie isn't; it's supposed to be a movie about a family which just so happens to be in the mafia.

I have never met anyone that has not liked this movie and most people put it up there with the best. Which it deserves it is a masterpiece. The acting is terrific, the costume and set design is amazing and the story keeps you interested even when it is just dialogue. These are all the reasons why this movie is my favourite movie ever and why it deserves 10 our of 10 stars!

title: The Marionette in Coppola's Hand
description: The first part of the unassailable trilogy by Francis Ford Coppola , The Godfather set in the early 1940s follows the life of Don Vito Corleone , the aging patriarch of a crime dynasty who transfers the control of his empire to his reluctant son Michael Corleone. Based on the Pulitzer Prize winning novel of the same name by Mario Puzo , The Godfather is one of the only two films based on a Pulitzer prize winning book which went on to win the prestigious Oscar , the other being " To Kill A Mockingbird" . When narcotics hits the streets of New York and tension between the five families (Strachi, Cuneo, Barzini, Tattaglia, Corleone) heat up , all of the families wind up supporting Virgil Solozzo to avoid a long destructive war. The film has every odd in its favor as Brando pulls off the performance of a lifetime portraying Vito Corleone, Pacino introduces his innate and instinctive whit and, Coppola's meticulous direction which shapes up into a genre defining timeless classic of the west. While Brando and Coppola walk home with an Academy win each, Pacino wins hearts all over. Released in 1972 and often crowned as the film of the decade, the film however does not appeal to people of all ages. Despite being a timeless classic, the film may at some points come across as very strong and too violent. A deep untwisting plot supported by iconic performances and impeccable direction, the film narrates a story about crime, drama, redemption and an offer you can't refuse. All in all, ' The Godfather' comes out as a benchmark in classic film making and speaks for itself. Even after all the years that have gone by and all the years to come the film continues to elate and appease the viewers, who return the love for the same. " Watch all the movies you want but remember it is a sin to skip The Godfather "

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is a timeless masterpiece that has stood the test of time. Based on Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, the film is widely regarded as one of the greatest movies ever made. With its unforgettable characters, compelling storytelling, and breathtaking performances, "The Godfather" has left an indelible mark on the history of cinema and continues to captivate audiences to this day.

A Tale of Power, Loyalty, and Betrayal:

Set in the tumultuous world of organized crime in New York City, "The Godfather" tells the epic story of the Corleone family and their rise to power. At the center of it all is Vito Corleone, brilliantly portrayed by Marlon Brando. Brando's performance as the aging patriarch is nothing short of mesmerizing, earning him an Academy Award for Best Actor. From his iconic raspy voice to his commanding presence, Brando brings depth and complexity to Vito Corleone, a character torn between his love for his family and the violent world he operates in.

Beyond Brando's remarkable portrayal, the film boasts an ensemble cast that delivers outstanding performances. Al Pacino shines as Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, who undergoes a transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader. Pacino's restrained intensity perfectly captures Michael's internal struggle and his descent into darkness. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, all deliver exceptional performances, adding layers of depth to their respective characters.

Impeccable Direction and Cinematography:

Francis Ford Coppola's direction in "The Godfather" is nothing short of brilliant. The film's pacing is meticulous, allowing the story to unfold gradually, drawing audiences deeper into the Corleone family's world. Coppola's attention to detail is evident in every scene, from the opulent wedding sequence to the tense moments of confrontation. The film's cinematography, beautifully captured by Gordon Willis, creates a dark and atmospheric visual palette that perfectly complements the story's themes of power, loyalty, and betrayal.

Unforgettable Dialogue and Memorable Scenes:

"The Godfather" is packed with unforgettable dialogue that has become deeply ingrained in popular culture. From Vito Corleone's iconic line, "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse," to Michael's chilling proclamation, "It's not personal, Sonny. It's strictly business," the film is filled with lines that have become synonymous with the gangster genre. These timeless quotes, combined with the film's memorable scenes, such as the horse's head in the bed and the baptism montage, have cemented "The Godfather" as a cultural phenomenon.

Impact and Legacy:

"The Godfather" not only revolutionized the gangster genre but also had a profound impact on filmmaking as a whole. Its influence can be seen in subsequent films and TV shows that explore themes of power, family, and moral ambiguity. The film's success spawned two equally acclaimed sequels, further cementing its status as a cinematic trilogy for the ages. "The Godfather" remains an essential viewing experience for cinephiles and a testament to the power of storytelling, leaving an indelible mark on the world of cinema.

title: Surrogate Father
description:
As someone who experienced the gritty reality of Brooklyn's ghetto in the 1970s without the guidance of positive male role models, "The Godfather" presents a complex and, at times, conflicting narrative.

Firstly, the film's portrayal of organized crime may resonate deeply with individuals from marginalized communities where systemic injustices and limited opportunities prevail. The allure of power, respect, and the ability to control one's circumstances, albeit through illegal means, can seem like a tantalizing escape from poverty and oppression. In this sense, the character of Don Vito Corleone embodies a figure of authority and influence that many may yearn for in the absence of positive role models within their own communities.

However, it is essential to recognize the consequences depicted in "The Godfather" are steeped in violence, betrayal, and moral ambiguity. While the Corleone family may command respect and fear, their wealth and power come at a profound cost, often resulting in the loss of loved ones and the perpetuation of a cycle of revenge and bloodshed. For individuals growing up without positive male role models, this portrayal may serve as a cautionary tale, highlighting the destructive nature of pursuing power at any cost.

Furthermore, the film's exploration of family dynamics and loyalty may strike a chord with those who have forged their own sense of kinship and belonging amidst adversity. The notion of "family" extends beyond biological ties in many marginalized communities, with individuals forming bonds of loyalty and support with peers and mentors who provide guidance in the absence of traditional familial structures.

Nevertheless, it is crucial to approach "The Godfather" with a critical lens, recognizing that its portrayal of organized crime romanticizes a lifestyle fraught with peril and moral compromise. While the film may offer a glimpse into a world of power and influence, it ultimately serves as a cautionary tale about the consequences of forsaking one's principles in pursuit of dominance.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" presents a compelling narrative that resonates with individuals who have experienced the challenges of growing up in marginalized communities without positive male role models. While the film may offer a sense of escapism and empowerment, it also serves as a stark reminder of the dangers inherent in pursuing power through illicit means. As such, it prompts reflection on the importance of integrity, compassion, and resilience in the face of adversity.

title: A Tale of Power and Betrayal
description:
What sets The Godfather apart is its ability to humanize its characters and delve into their complex motivations. The film presents a meticulous portrayal of the Corleone family, exploring their dynamics, conflicts, and the moral choices they make. The characters are multi-dimensional, each with their own flaws, desires, and vulnerabilities, making them relatable and intriguing.

Marlon Brando's performance as Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of legendary. With his gravitas and subtle nuances, Brando commands the screen, effortlessly embodying the power and authority of the character. Al Pacino, in his breakout role as Michael Corleone, delivers a mesmerizing performance, capturing the transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless and calculated leader.

Francis Ford Coppola's direction is masterful, creating a rich and immersive world that draws viewers into the story. The film's pacing is deliberate, allowing the narrative to unfold at a measured pace, building tension and suspense. The cinematography, coupled with a haunting score by Nino Rota, enhances the film's atmosphere and adds to its timeless appeal.

At its core, The Godfather is a profound exploration of the corrupting nature of power and the consequences of one's choices. It delves into themes of loyalty, honor, and the moral ambiguity that arises when individuals are faced with difficult decisions. The film raises thought-provoking questions about the nature of right and wrong, and the lengths people will go to protect their loved ones.

The Godfather's impact extends far beyond its technical brilliance. It has become synonymous with excellence in storytelling and filmmaking. Its richly developed characters, intricate plot, and compelling dialogue have inspired countless filmmakers and influenced the crime genre for decades to come.

title: An absolute masterpiece of the craft
description:
What can I say that hasn't already been mentioned from people countless times? This film is so beautifully woven and is a perfect example of a flawless film. You are doing yourself a disservice if you don't experience this holy grail. I watched it for the first time in cinema due to the 50th anniversary release and was completely subdued in the story the 3 hour runtime went by so fast. Some people say that slow pacing is a drawback but for this film it's the total opposite. The pacing just really lets the audience feel apart of this family and like you are actually there on the dark paths that ensue my favourite example being the end shot of the door closing shutting out Kay and us, leaving you with a feeling of awe, intrigue and frustration as you want to see more of this world Coppola throws you in.

The cinematography is so well done, especially the low key lighting and longer takes in important scenes. The performances are some of the best I've seen. Brando's, Pacinos, Keaton's all superb but Cann's is just so powerful and evocative you can't help but really feel all the emotions and depth he brings to Sonny. My favourite aspect to this film though has got to be Michael's turn from an average distant son to Vito's successor it's just wonderful to watch it happen. The best scene to exemplify this for me is the restaurant scene where a key turning point occurs which acts as a catalyst for the rest of his forceable actions.

To conclude I definitely recommend this film to everyone and is a must watch.

title: masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is told entirely within a closed world. That's why we sympathize with characters who are essentially evil. The story by Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola is a brilliant conjuring act, inviting us to consider the Mafia entirely on its own terms. Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) emerges as a sympathetic and even admirable character; during the entire film, this lifelong professional criminal does nothing of which we can really disapprove.

During the movie we see not a single actual civilian victim of organized crime. No women trapped into prostitution. No lives wrecked by gambling. No victims of theft, fraud or protection rackets. The only police officer with a significant speaking role is corrupt.

title: An offer so good,
description:
An offer so good, I couldn't refuse It is now past 1 PM and I just finished watching Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather". I should probably go to bed. It's late and tomorrow I have to wake up a bit early. But not early enough to postpone writing these lines. Now that I have seen it three times, the opportunity of sharing my thoughts and refreshed insights are too much of a good offer to sit on. So, bear with me.

This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.

But it goes even deeper than that. It all revolves around the Corleone family led by Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He is the most honest of these men, sitting right on the edge. But for people like him, who do not fully embrace this world, it's not easy. He avoids conflict until it is absolutely necessary. He is a man defined by moral principles. There is a scene at the beginning, in which, during his daughter's wedding day, one of his associates, Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana) practices his speech that he is going to give to the Don when he meets him. The scene with these two is funny and almost adorable. I could not help but sympathize both of them only to realize that I am feeling warmth for two mobsters. Not to even mention that Lenny Montana was an actual mob hit-man and that he was actually nervous as he said that line.

The more I watched the more I realized just how incredibly complex and ruthless this society is and how it has the power to corrupt anyone to come in contact with it. The best example is Corleone's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino). He returns home for his sister's wedding as a war hero dressed the part with his long-time girlfriend, Kay Adams (Diane Keaton). At first, he avoids this underworld, but necessity, first-hand exposure and just its sheer devilish appealing nature draws him in. As we get further in the film, the change is shocking and every outsider who ever got close to him is tainted in one way or another. If they survive it, they are drawn in as well as we are as viewers.

Inside, Coppola exposes the family to us fully, with a bold personal approach and we witness every discussion, every methodically calculated choice. Crime is done simply because it is the nature of their business, and we are put on a chair alongside them, so we easily relate. For us, they are the good guys, the rival families are the bad guys. This is the greatest feat this film managed to pull off--set apart good guys and bad guys in a world filled with bad guys.

This is a film of unmatched subtlety. No other movie sustains itself as good. No other film is done with such precision, attention and completeness. There are many layers which I probably missed and maybe will never notice. But I felt them. What director Francis Ford Coppola and his partner in crime (poor choice of words, sorry) Mario Puzo did is nothing short of a timeless piece of reference cinema whose influence is not based on reinventing the wheel, but rather perfecting it to the absolute maximum.

Most masterpieces are remembered for their historical contributions. "Citizen Kane" brought the biggest step-up to the art form, the same things did "Gone With the Wind" or "2001: A Space Odyssey". "The Godfather" is one of the few films that will be remembered simply because they are that good and I cannot possibly imagine a greater achievement.

title: Best movie ever made
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that has stood the test of time. This epic crime drama delves into the intricate world of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia clan led by the enigmatic Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando).

The film's narrative is both captivating and complex, exploring themes of family, loyalty, power, and corruption. Coppola masterfully balances moments of intense violence with quieter, more intimate scenes, creating a rich and immersive experience.

Brando's performance as Don Vito is a tour de force, delivering a nuanced and unforgettable portrayal of a man who is both feared and respected. Al Pacino's transformation from reluctant outsider to ruthless mobster is equally compelling, showcasing his exceptional talent.

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece: *The Godfather* (1972)
description:
**The Godfather** (1972), directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in cinema history. The story centers around the powerful Corleone crime family, led by Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), as they navigate loyalty, power, and betrayal in the dangerous world of organized crime. As Vito's youngest son, Michael Corleone (Al Pacino), is reluctantly drawn into the family business, the film examines his transformation from a war hero into a ruthless mafia boss.

The film is a perfect blend of compelling storytelling, complex characters, and iconic performances. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is legendary, bringing a quiet yet commanding presence to the role. Al Pacino's nuanced performance as Michael is equally powerful, as his character's journey from innocence to corruption drives much of the film's emotional weight. The supporting cast, including James Caan as Sonny and Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, adds further depth.

Coppola's direction is masterful, creating an immersive atmosphere with its deliberate pacing, stunning cinematography, and haunting score by Nino Rota. The film's themes of family, power, and morality resonate on a deeply human level, elevating it beyond a typical crime drama.

**Rating: 10/10** - *The Godfather* is an unparalleled masterpiece that transcends the crime genre, offering a richly layered exploration of power, loyalty, and the dark side of the American Dream. Its impact on cinema is profound, making it a timeless classic.

the second part 1. Bauna Sala's daughter was bullied by her American boyfriend. The law could not give them heavy penalties, so Bauna Sala asked the godfather for help. First of all, it presents the ideology of the entire American society represented by the American spirit, economy, freedom, and law. At the same time, it also mentions the family culture that Italian culture attaches importance to. The first line is "I believe in America." By Buna Sala. The picture is completely black at this time, suggesting the huge darkness under this line. Immediately after "America made my fortune", this line is a well-known American dream, and strives to succeed. Next is the American way of raising her daughter, giving her freedom, and also telling her never to be humiliated, of course, the latter is of great importance to Italian culture. The rape of her daughter by an American man reflects the conflict and inequality between Americans and Italian immigrants, and her daughter resisted and suffered violence. The punishment of rapists by US law was suspended for three years and the execution was suspended. The question of law and fairness and justice was thus raised. Is fairness or justice guaranteed by law or by individual violence? The godfather answered, "Why didn't you come to me first before you call the police?" The rest is the Godfather's conquest of Buna Sala. It shows the power of the godfather and the value of friendship and respect under the cover of money, which also reflects the ideological confrontation between the United States and Italy. Finally, the arrangement and arrangement of the Godfather on this matter reflected his careful thoughts, and he arranged it to Tom Haggin to explain his status as a military division. Kremensha is also mentioned. 3. Form A Image Styling Gordon Willis's low-key photography complements content narrative. The appearance of Baunasala, the background is almost completely black, and the characters are fully emphasized, and the low-key photography of the entire room shows that the work performed inside is out of sight. The outdoor light comes in through the blinds, and there are two light sources in the room, showing the texture of the objects in the picture, making the whole picture look like an oil painting. The red roses on the clothes of the godfather were as bright as blood. B In terms of scene angle, the long zoom lens at the beginning is perfect. The space in which the character is located and the godfather of the close-up scene gradually show up, but it is still the back and adds suspense. The performance of Baunasala was wonderful. The rest are mostly stable fixed lenses. In terms of character transfer, it is mainly the interaction between the godfather and Baunasala. The two were originally in the same sitting position from a distance. Later, he became a stance of Baunasala. Although the godfather was in a low position, he still controlled the position. The later godfather stood up and had more control. Taking a shoulder shot of Buna Sala was also at an angle of depression, which was completely at a disadvantage. There is a very interesting composition, with the godfather and Baunasala in the foreground, and Santino in the background, showing Santino's learning of the way the godfather deals and his inheritance. The use of the cat is said to be a temporary intention of the director, but it is here to show the grace and calmness of the godfather. Out of color.

description:
The movie teach us how to be a real man.

Cinematographer Gordon Willis earned himself the nickname "The Prince of Darkness," since his sets were so underlit. "Paramount Pictures" executives initially thought that the footage was too dark, until persuaded otherwise by Willis and Francis Ford Coppola that it was to emphasize the shadiness of the Corleone family's dealings.

The acting was simply amazing, what else could you say. What could be more appealing to people(even today) than watching actors like Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, James Caan, Diane Keaton, Talia Shire and Robert Duvall. This is like heaven for someone who is a fan of movies. With this movie Brando was able to bring himself back into the limelight. His performance as the godfather alone is iconic. His character has been recreated so much in films that it has almost if it has not already become a cliché. His performance though was not a cliché. His performance was subtle and breathtaking. It was so genuine and realistic that it was not just probably but definitely more genuine than Marlon Brando himself. Al Pacino was perfect for this film as well. What a way to start up your career. His character was all about depth and he displayed it perfectly.

title: Subtitles Necessary
description:
Does "The Godfather" live up to the hype? I think that it does. This was my first time watching the #2 rated movie on IMDb and it did not disappoint. The film transports you to the world of organized crime and does so in such an elegant way. I forgot that I was watching a movie and was enveloped in the terrifying underworld of the mafia.

The acting is superb, with one of the strongest casts of all time. Marlon Brando, James Caan, Robert Duvall, every single actor in this film made the characters feel real. These guys all do terrible things, yet you care deeply for them. While everyone else is phenomenal, the star of this film is Al Pacino. He made me so invested in the character of Michael and had a raw vulnerability to him. Starting as the boy who was estranged from the family business to then becoming the ruthless Don Corleone was remarkable to watch.

The movie is long and there are some dry spells. The names of all the different characters can get a bit jumbled, especially without subtitles on the first watch. Both of those are probably just my ignorance, but I am eager for a second watch and to dive into the sequel.

Best Character: Michael Corleone Best Quote: "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse." - Don Corleone Best Scene: Michael in the Restaurant (Honorable mention to "Settling All Family Business") Best Piece of Score: "The Godfather Finale.

title: This movie defined an era
description: The Godfather. You just say that name and most people get a picture of Vito or Michael in their head. They can literally see the shady suits and the corrupt deals. This movie defined a generation, people who were kids when it came out wear the badge with honor. I, for one, was not blessed with that gift, but I did grow up with this movie. I convinced my parents to get this movie for me when I was about 12-years old. I sat down and watched it so intently, that for years if someone talked about a scene and didn't say the words just right, I could correct them and tell them down to about the minute where to find that scene in the movie. I would go to Jr. High and talk like I was Vito Corleone, and I'd recruit friends to be in my family. We became a tight bunch because of that fact, so basically, what I'm saying is, The Godfather is responsible for a lot of joy in my life. One of the top 10 greatest movies of all time.

title: The Godfather: An operatic tapestry of power, family, and tragedy
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's 1972 masterpiece, The Godfather, isn't just a gangster film; it's an epic saga exploring the Corleone family, their rise and fall from grace within the American mafia. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Don Vito Corleone, the aging patriarch grappling with succession and a changing world.

Cinematography is masterful, with hauntingly beautiful shots that capture both the grandeur and intimacy of the Corleone world. Nino Rota's score is another standout, its melancholic themes underscoring the film's tragic inevitability.

The Godfather isn't afraid to confront the brutal realities of organized crime, but it also delves into complex themes of loyalty, honor, and family. Coppola masterfully blurs the lines between good and evil, forcing viewers to question their own moral compass.

The film's impact on cinema is undeniable. Its influence can be seen in countless subsequent gangster films and beyond. The Godfather is a timeless classic, a must-watch for anyone who appreciates exceptional filmmaking.

title: My Best all time movie
description:
"The Godfather" (1972) is a timeless classic that has left an indelible mark on the world of cinema. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, this film is a masterful epic that explores the inner workings of a powerful Mafia family in New York City. The story is based on the novel of the same name by Mario Puzo and follows the aging patriarch of the Corleone family, Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), as he tries to maintain his power and protect his family from the various threats that come their way.

What makes "The Godfather" so exceptional is its exceptional cast of characters. Each actor brings their own unique charm and charisma to the screen, creating a rich tapestry of personalities that are both fascinating and compelling. Marlon Brando delivers a standout performance as Vito Corleone, delivering one of the most iconic performances in film history. He brings a quiet strength and vulnerability to the role, making him one of the most memorable characters in cinema. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Richard S. Castellano, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Richard Conte, and Diane Keaton, are equally impressive, adding depth and nuance to the film.

One of the hallmarks of "The Godfather" is its memorable dialogue, which is rich with meaning and nuance. The film's dialogue is often quoted and has become part of popular culture, and it is a testament to the film's power and impact. The film's score, composed by Nino Rota, is also an integral part of the film's success. The music sets the mood and underscores the film's themes of family, loyalty, and power, making it an unforgettable experience.

The cinematography of "The Godfather" is also worthy of praise. The film's visual style is stunning, with richly saturated colors and sweeping vistas that capture the grandeur and majesty of the world of the Corleone family. The film's editing is seamless, moving from scene to scene with a fluid grace that keeps the viewer engaged and invested in the story.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a true masterpiece of filmmaking. It is a film that transcends time and remains as relevant and impactful today as it was over 50 years ago. It is a film that is both a cultural touchstone and a testament to the power of cinema to tell stories that resonate with audiences of all ages. If you haven't seen "The Godfather" yet, do yourself a favor and watch it. You won't regret it.

title: Godfather- Movie Great
description:
You can't comment that the Godfather is a bad movie if you haven't seen all three. The "first movie" is actually the first part of a three movie story. It isn't three separate movies; it's three parts of one story. The third movie sums it all up. If you say you don't like the Godfather, watch the second and third parts and then comment. You cannot intelligently comment on a story that you haven't heard all of.

And if you think the movie is boring, why did the book sell so well? Why has the movie endured for so long? The story must be a good one. If you don't like it, chances are you just don't get it. The movie isn't about a mafia family. It's about the life of one man (Michael Corleone) and his personal struggles with what he has done and what he believes he is forced to do to protect his family.

title: The Godfather(1972) IS THE BEST FATHER !!
description:
This is a masterpiece. A timeless masterpiece. Initially, I didn't like this film all that much - I found it rather over-hyped and boring. This was until the advent of DVD, which gave me the feature I needed for this sort of film: subtitles. Once I switched them on and heard (read) every last word of Brando's ramblings and other characters ramblings, I grew a true appreciation for this epic.

To make a true epic, you need all of three following ingredients working in near perfect harmony. For screenwriters who come across this, take the following pointers on board: 1) Contrasting Characters: Good films have some character distinction, but most fall rather flat because the core of each character is the same.

Of course, there are exceptions to rule (ie... where you want mono-tonal characters... aka matrix; or where you want outlandish contrasts... aka The Fifth Element), but ultimately, this is what makes films deep, meaningful and grand. Consider the contrasts between the Don's children. Michael is rather cool, rational and collected, whereas Sonny is more hot-headed, spontaneous and simple minded. But simply having these contrasts is not nearly enough. What you really need to do is to develop these characters - place them in situations - and then dwell on how their character impacts on the situation they're put in. The Godfather is a terrific example of how to pull this off. While many try to do this in screenplays, most lose the plot and create character obscurities that stretch credibility.

2) Transformation: The central character(s) must undergo a transformation, resulting in them being almost unrecognizable by the end of the film. By putting them into situations, the character's character must not only influence the outcome of the situation; it must also have a lasting impact on the character. Consider Michael at the wedding and compare that to the Michael we see at the end of the film. Again, many films try, but most fail because they come up with unreal (literally, not praisingly) or simply moronic transformations (eg, Wall Street).

3) Patience: Men in Black 2 was an astounding film for one simple reason - it was an entire film squashed into about 70 minutes. It was not much longer than an episode of ER or Buffy. I certainly hope the new goal of Hollywood isn't to make films as short as possible.

All the great ones spend time - time developing characters, family life, growth, patience with the story telling in general. This is the key (provided that the story isn't mind-numbingly boring). Dances with Wolves, Heat.. and so on are very patient but top-class films. While studios may be lukewarm on the idea of longer films, they are worth it if you have a ripper story to base it on.

title: Cinema Personified: Incredible Movie
description:
Rating: 9.6 Overall, and Incredible Movie that stands up to being 'One of the best movies ever made' as it is the definition of subtly and symbolism (helping drive the story forward and influencing the characters decisions/emotions) in a movie as Coppola delivers a magnum opus not only in his career but for the whole film industry (something that others have tried to learn from).

Incredible to Brilliant Direction, Great to Incredible Acting (Brilliant from Marlon Brando, Incredible from Al Pacino, Great to Incredible from James Caan, Great to Incredible from Robert Duvall, Great from Diane Keaton, Great from Talia Shire, Very Good to Great from the rest of the cast), Incredible to Brilliant Story (though its storytelling is a bit confusing), Brilliant Screenplay (Mixed with the nuances of subtly and symbolism), Great Score, Incredible Cinematography (uses Sound/Cinematography/Film Editing to really show the mood of the scenes and emotions of the characters), Incredible Sound (see Cinematography), Incredible Editing (See Cinematography), Plot Structure was good and unexpecting (considering I did not expect how the turns of the story went the way they did), Pacing was slow and steady; Runtime was log but it is hard to take out/cut any scenes because each scene feels like it is important to the story, The build to the climax was great with the final moments of the movie being amazing and full of symbolism, The Michael Corleone Story was incredible in showing how an outsider of the family could never escape the life made for him (even though he tried really hard to never be a part of it)

title: the best movie of all times.
description: I have watched it more than six times and every time I watch it I discover that it is more beautiful than before. Every aspect of this movie is really wonderful. I can say it is one of the masterpieces in the history of film making. To me it is the number one movie of all times. Marlon Brando was marvelous. Al Pacino was adorable. James Caan was great. Robert Duval was really great. It is really hard to tell what is missing in this movie. The whole package was really astonishing. I have never imagined a movie will have such an impact on me as well as on many others. I have watched it with my brothers a couple of years ago. You won't believe it if I tell you that every year I go to a movie store and rent it again. I will be doing this for the rest of my life because it is an artistic piece that is worth watching more and more. In conclusion, I would like to say that if Marlon Brando had not been there, this movie would have lost a lot of its glimmering and shimmering light. Al Pacino was also as outstanding as Marlon Brando. The movie is a way beyond criticism. It is a work of art for all generations and at all times. Also the story itself is well-knit that you feel it happened in reality. There are lots of movies out there, but they never measure up to the God Fahter.

title: Simply put: The greatest film ever made.
description:
I know the title "the greatest film ever made" is thrown around too loosely, but The Godfather is the one movie that deserves it. It deserves it's place at #1 in the IMDB's top 250.

The depth in The Godfather is phenomenal. Every character has their own problems, their own stories, their own lives. So many times in movies characters lives revolve around the plot, but in The Godfather the plot revolves around the characters.

The acting is perfect. There is so much subtlety in every performance. A single look from Al Pacino expresses so many different emotions. It is a shame he was never rewarded an Oscar for any of the Godfather's. The movies center on him and his flawless performance.

The atmosphere of the movie is also excellent. There is always an air of tension or foreboding. Practically every scene is a classic moment with a classic line.

It is the mafia movie to which all mafia movies are compared, and none of them hold a candle to it. The only mafia movie I would put close to it is Scorsese's Goodfellas.

If there were 11 stars this would be the only movie I would give it to.

Great cinematography, maybe one of the best i've ever seen. Francis Ford Coppola maybe isn't greatest director ever but he deserved so much respect for what he did in this movie.

How i can got over? The script. Easily one of the best scripts in the history. Storyline is very very good. Godfather is one of few movies when are 100 % focused on what happened next. Personally i feel very shocked when i watch this movie for the first time.

For me, there will be no movie like Godfather. Godfather is something you just can't hate. Godfather is the world 8th miracle. Godfather is life. Godfather tells you about life and how you should always love your family.

Maybe not a good review for this movie but i cannot find the right words to describe a perfect movie.

Thank you.

title: The Story of Michael Corleone
description: Al Pacino has played many great characters in motion pictures, including Serpico, Sonny in Dog Day Afternoon, Bobby Deerfield, Tony Montana, Frank Slade, Roy Cohn, Jack Kevorkian, Phil Spector, Joe Paterno, and Jimmy Hoffa. The role for which he will be remembered is Michael Corleone. Pacino carries the entire trilogy, surfacing as the main protagonist in the first film opposite Marlon Brando. Brando got people into the theaters, but Pacino was the reason they kept coming back. Regarded as one of the best films in cinematic history, The Godfather is a classic story about the struggle of immigrants to America and the means one family pursues in order to rise from poverty. In addition to Pacino and Brando, John Cazale delivers an outstanding performance.

title: Film Liquet on The Godfather
description:
This criminal drama focuses on a powerful Italian-American mafia family of Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). After his daughter's wedding he refuses to make a deal with a new drug lord in the area, which leads to him getting shot by a rival family, who is now in a deal with the said drug lord. Following these events, the youngest son of the family (Al Pacino), leaves his civilian status and joins the Mafia, becoming involved in the ever-going family business, made of violence and betrayal.

Widely regarded as one of the greatest films of all time, the lighting and cinematography are the first things that you notice throughout the film. The use of light and shadows, combined with precise framing makes this film unique, almost like Francis Coppola adopted a different style for this particular film. The menacing sound track makes sure to put the viewers on edge, seemingly making the protagonists even more menacing and scary in the eyes of the audience, as the mafia should be like. Being one of the best performances of Al Pacino, the aesthetic of the film only adds to the dark world of mafia orientated New York.

The film itself is a good illustration of the post-war America in 1945 to 1955, so if you like me, are a sucker for post war America, you'll be pleased by the film's look at the very least.

Follow us on instagram! @film_liquet

title: Will there ever be another movie like The Godfather ???
description: Oh my GOD. WOW. Amazing. These were the words that popped up into my mind just as the movie ended. Each word, each dialog, each expression on the faces of the characters, every single bit of the movie was PERFECTION. At one point, i was made to believe that I too was a part of the movie and a living-breathing character. I was so into it. Oh my god it was perfection. Marlon Brando's and Al Pacino's acting was nothing less than AWE-INSPIRING. The scene when Al Pacino shoots down 'Solozzo and McCluskey' was terrific. It just transformed Michael's character from a civilized American army-man into a civilized Sicilian-American don, and this journey of transformation was conducted so beautifully in the movie. Another great scene was when Vito Corleone(Marlon Brando) expresses his grief to Michael Corleone(Al Pacino) his son over Michael's current profession. He tells Michael as to how he once hoped that Michael would be the one to give the family a taste of Legality, but ended up being the Don who would head the Crime Family of the Corleone's. How he hoped that one day Michael would become a Senator or a Priest. Every actor's performance was supreme. What a fantastic movie. Can't wait for it to be Re-released.

title: "One of the Best Films of the Decade."
description:
The "Godfather" is Frances Ford Coppola's best film. Marlon Brando gives the most memorable performance in film history as Vito Corleone. The Movie is based on the gripping and compulsive book, The Godfather. Al Pacino gives a legendary performances as Michael Corleone.

The beginning is set late in the summer of 1945. The films roots, however, are set in the gangster films of the early thirties. The plot is about rival gangs murdering each other, and now we see the inbred corrupt system of loyalty and terror, in which killing is a preferred way of dealing with the competition. We see how the gangs encroach on each other and why this form of illegal business inevitably erupts in violence. We see their subculture, based on a split between the men's conception of their responsibilities, which they keep dark form there families, and the false world the create to shelter the women and children.

The visual scheme is based on the most obvious life and death contrasts, the men meet and conduct their business in deep toned, shuttered rooms, lighted by lamps even in the daytime, and the story moves back and forth between this hidden, world and the sunshine that they share with the woman and children. The tension is in the meetings held in the underworld darkness and one gets the feeling that this secret life has its own poetry of fear. The dark and light contrast is so operatic and so openly symbolic that it perfectly expresses the basic nature of the material. Noting the Catholic background of the characters and the eternal battle of good and evil, of innocence versus knowledge, knowledge in this instance equates with shame nd guilt.

BRANDO

The enormous cast is lead by Marlon Brando as Don Vito Corleone, the "Godfather" of a powerful Sicilian - American clan, with James Caan as his hothead son, sonny, and Al Pacino as the thoughtful, educated son, Micheal. Is Brando marvelous? Yes, he is, but then he often is, he was marvelous a few years ago in "On The Waterfront." He's shockingly effective in a current film, the "Score." The role of Don Corleone, a patriarch in his early sixties, allows him to release more of the gentleness that was so seductive and unsettling. Don Vito could be played as a magnificent old warrior, a noble killer, a handsome bull, but Brando manages to humanize him. Brando internalizes Don Vito's power, makes him less physically threatening and deeper, hidden within himself.

THE CAST

However, Brando isn't the whole show; James Caan is very fine actor , and so are Robert Duvall and many others in lesser roles. Don sons suggest different aspects of Brando, Caan's Sonny looks like the muscular young Brando, while his heir, Michael, and Al Pacino comes to resemble him in manner and voice. Like Brando in this film, Pacino is simple, you don't catch him acting, yet he manages to change from a small, fresh-faced, darkly handsome college boy into an underworld lord, becoming more intense, smaller, and more isolated at every step. Coppola doesn't stess the father and son links, they are simply there for us to notice when we will. In the end of the "Godfather" nothing is resolved, because the family business goes on. Terry Malloy didn't clean up the docks at the end of "On The Waterfront", that was a lie. The "Godfather" is popular melodrama, but it expresses a new tragic realism.

I don't have to recommend this film. I give it a 15 out of 10.

title: Pure Brilliance
description: A cinematic Masterpiece. Every character is incredible and diverse and other movies should strive to be this great.

title: Couldn't refuse this piece of cinema
description: Upon my decision to finally sit down and watch this film, I was well aware of some of the cultural influences made by this film. I was aware of, "Make him an offer he can't refuse" and, "I don't get no respect". I knew of these quotes and was pretty sure they were from this film. Solidified obviously when I watched, but I was also made aware of more quotes and clichés from this film. The horse head in bed, for instance. The voice and manner of Don Vito. So many iconic quotes and lines came from this film that it would be impossible to give it anything lower than a 10 just for that. And now, the film itself. The acting in this film was out of this world. Brando seems to become Don Vito as much as he is himself. Al Pacino is a new world of acting. His way of showing the inner battles Michael faces as he attempts to stay out and stay a good man is beautiful. The decisions he makes obviously affect him in many ways, and Pacino does this representation of conflict and struggles flawlessly. As entertaining and as high-octane as this film was, there was one piece of cinematography that I noticed throughout. This being the lighting of Marlon Brando. Throughout the film, Don Vito goes through a lot, from being the mob boss of New York to being bed-bound. The lighting of his eyes in his office, particularly, is absolutely breathtaking. His entire face is portrayed in this eerie yellow light which allows for some beautiful shots with cigarette smoke as well. But, this yellow light is positioned so perfectly that it darkens his eyes, so they are just black holes of emptiness. It gives the illusion of inhumanity, of heartlessness. Even outside at the wedding, his eyes are still sunken. However, when bed bound, the lighting is right in his eyes, and you can see right into him. This is merely one example of a probable infinite amount of examples of excellent cinematography that you could get from this film. One of my most entertaining watches ever, and somehow Coppola keeps me gripping the edge of my chair for 2 hours. An absolute must watch for any human being breathing air. A classic now, a classic then, and a classic for years and years to come.

title: One of the greatest of all time
description:
This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld in which we are so embedded that we do not even observe it. Coppola puts us straight in the smack-dab center of what is, admittedly, a society made by criminals for criminals. It is also the reason why it's so welcoming. We are surrounded by its inhabitants--cold-blooded murderers, men who see crime like a 9 to 5 job masquerading as honorable men. And I do mean men. From the outside, we would only witness the horrifying, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought out actions.

But it goes even deeper than that. It all revolves around the Corleone family led by Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He is the most honest of these men, sitting right on the edge. But for people like him, who do not fully embrace this world, it's not easy. He avoids conflict until it is absolutely necessary. He is a man defined by moral principles. There is a scene at the beginning, in which, during his daughter's wedding day, one of his associates, Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana) practices his speech that he is going to give to the Don when he meets him. The scene with these two is funny and almost adorable. I could not help but sympathize both of them only to realize that I am feeling warmth for two mobsters. Not to even mention that Lenny Montana was an actual mob hit-man and that he was actually nervous as he said that line.

title: Awesome Movie - The Godfather
description: "The Godfather" (1972), directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is an undeniable masterpiece that stands the test of time. Set in the world of organized crime, this iconic film paints a compelling portrait of the Corleone family's rise and fall. Marlon Brando's mesmerizing performance as the powerful and enigmatic Don Vito Corleone anchors the narrative, while Al Pacino shines as his conflicted son, Michael. With its richly textured storytelling, impeccable cinematography, and a script that delves deep into themes of loyalty, family, and the corrupting nature of power, "The Godfather" captivates audiences from start to finish. Coppola's masterful direction and the stellar ensemble cast bring the characters and their intricate relationships to life, leaving an indelible mark on cinema history. A timeless classic that combines gripping drama, intense performances, and unforgettable dialogue, "The Godfather" remains an essential viewing experience for all film enthusiasts.

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece That Stands the Test of Time
description: "The Godfather" is a towering achievement in the realm of cinema. This 1972 classic has garnered widespread acclaim for its exceptional storytelling, rich character development, and unforgettable performances. The film delves deep into the complex dynamics of power, loyalty, and family within the world of organized crime. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is nothing short of extraordinary, and the film's atmospheric cinematography and haunting score add another layer of brilliance. It's a true masterpiece that continues to captivate audiences and remains a timeless classic. Trust me, you won't want to miss out on experiencing this cinematic gem! 🎥🌟

title: I've watched the entire series on repeat.
description:
A great production takes every party on deck.

This was well written, well directed, and beautifully casted. Everything was polished and a little bow placed on top for the finished product. I want nothing more than to curl up on the couch with a glass of wine and bowl of buttery popcorn to watch the entire series all over again.

I am a black woman engaged to an Italian man --- this movie is chef's kiss. The Godfather did an amazing job of capturing the culture and using it to enhance the story. Many filmmakers get lost in trying to capture the culture that they lose the audience or even worse the story. It was easy to fall, easy to fall in love, and even more easy to be on the edge of your seat the entire time. As an actress, this was one of the movies from my childhood that inspired me.
