title: An Epic Saga of Power and Transformation
description:
The Godfather," directed by the visionary Francis Ford Coppola and based on the novel by Mario Puzo, is a cinematic triumph that continues to astonish and inspire viewers across the globe. Its narrative, grounded in the dark, complex world of the mafia, is a brilliant exploration of power, loyalty, and the inevitable transformation wrought by violence and ambition.

At the heart of this epic story is the Corleone family, led by the formidable Vito Corleone, a role immortalized by Marlon Brando's stellar performance. Brando, with his whispery voice and imposing presence, embodies the essence of the patriarch, earning him an Academy Award. Yet, it is Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, the youngest son who evolves from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader, that stands as the film's dramatic core. This transformation is depicted with such nuance and depth, showcasing Pacino's extraordinary talent.

The film's success is also attributed to its impeccable casting, where each actor, from James Caan's hot-headed Sonny to Robert Duvall's calm consigliere, Tom Hagen, contributes to the rich tapestry of Coppola's world. The cinematography by Gordon Willis, with its dark hues and inventive use of shadows, creates an atmosphere that is both timeless and evocative of the era it portrays.

What sets "The Godfather" apart is not just its narrative brilliance or technical mastery, but its profound insights into the human condition. It delves into the complexities of family bonds, the corrupting influence of power, and the tragic consequences of ambition, making it a narrative that resonates across ages and cultures. The film's legacy is further cemented by its significant impact on cinema, influencing countless filmmakers and being recognized as a cornerstone of the crime genre.

With a soundtrack that is hauntingly beautiful, a script that balances epic storytelling with intimate character studies, and a direction that combines boldness with sensitivity, "The Godfather" is more than a movie. It is a cultural artifact, a mirror to the paradoxes of the American Dream, and a testament to the power of cinema to explore the depths of our collective psyche.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is not just a film; it is an experience, a masterpiece that transcends the confines of its genre to touch the very essence of artistry and storytelling. To watch it is to be immersed in a world where every frame, every line, and every performance is a brushstroke on a canvas of unparalleled cinematic magnificence.

title: Fantastic and classic movie
description:
Why is "The Godfather" so highly rated? There are several reasons for this. For example, the great writing. The nearly 3-hour film has a great story: the twists and dialogues are nearly perfect.

What can be highlighted is the acting. Almost every actor - bringing out their best - gave an amazing performance. If I had to choose, maybe Marlon Brando and Al Pacino were the best.

Perhaps you won't be surprised if I say that the direction was also good... very good. Francis Ford Coppola is really a very very great director.

What is also very good is the cinematography. The entire film is beautifully shot - perhaps it couldn't be better.

In summary, a brilliant film that is absolutely worth watching!

title: The term "mafia" is never used
description: Possibly my favorite movie, this is an unsurpassed gangster film and well deserving of the universal praise it received. It scores a 10 in my book, not surprisingly, but I will include what I consider to be some minor flaws. First and foremost, the kindheartedness of Brando's Vito Corleone character is extremely misleading. I don't believe that any mob boss of that era, or even today, possesses anything but heartless greed for money and power. The viewer is left thinking that Vito is warm and gentle and had no choice but to enter the life of crime to support his family--bulls**t! The sequel (another gem) tries to explain this, but I still don't buy it. Also, I don't think James Caan was cast well as the hot-headed Sonny. He looks about as Italian as James Cagney. His acting is superb, but I think someone like Robert DeNiro (who also auditioned for the role!) would have delivered a far more accurate portrayal. On that note, it also struck me that Richard Castellano, who plays Clemenza, could have just as convincingly played the Don as Marlon Brando and, perhaps, saved the producers millions. Brando is, of course, phenomenal, but I think it's important to point out that the less recognized co-stars are comparably as talented. Aside from this, The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece not to be missed.

title: Underworld dark site movie
description:
This is a masterpiece of world cinema.. John Cazale ( Fredo) and Richard Castellano ( Clemenza) give wonderfully performances in that character. one of god father for world Don Films. i like very much.

At the wedding, Michael's centrality is signaled by the Don's frantic call, "Where's Michael? We are not taking the picture without Michael!" A World War II hero still in decorated uniform, Michael is meanwhile busy differentiating himself from his family to his girl friend and future second wife, Kay (Diane Keaton). "Luca Brasi held a gun to the band leader's head," he relates, "and my father assured him that either his signature or his brains would be on the release. That's my family Kay. It's not me." Michael's initial disinterest in Mafia activities is reinforced by his adoring father who envisions him as "Senator Corleone" or "Governor Corleone" not as his successor. That role is reserved for his hot- headed eldest son, Sonny (James Caan). But, of course, events conspire to suck Michael in - and to keep sucking him in right through Godfather III - the assassination attempt on his father, Michael's coolly murderous response, the car bomb meant for him that kills his first wife, the Sicilian beauty Apollonia (aptly named for the god of sun light), the riddled body of his brother Sonny. Inevitably, a morally darkened Michael emerges at the end of the film, one who outdoes his father in guile and ruthlessness and whose final brutal and deceitful acts in Godfather I seal his doom as a Macbeth-like villainous tragic hero its really good

title: Authenticity
description:
Title: The Godfather.

Director / Creator: Francis Ford Coppola.

Genres: Crime, Drama, Mafia, Thriller, Classic, Tragedy, Period Piece.

Release Date: 24/3/1972.

Duration: 2h 55min Main Cast: Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton Country of Origin: USA.

Language: English.

A crime/ drama movie, set in New York and Siciliy of 1940- 1950.

The movie is authentic, highlights the beauty in Italian-American culture, with the special accents and authentic dialects- Italian-American with Sicilian roots.

An amazing soundtrack, that empathies the environment and vibe of that time, comes and goes at the right moment, to elevate certain scenes and feelings.

Being true to culturist costumes and traditions.

Aside that, the movie explores family conflicts and hierarchic, Brother bonds, father- son bond and romantic bonds.

title: Uncomparable
description:
Rather than concentrating on everything that is great about The Godfather, a much easier way for me to judge its quality is on what is bad about it. Almost every film has something that I don't like about it, but I can honestly say that I wouldn't change anything about The Godfather. There is nothing weak about it and nothing that stands out as bad. That's why it gets ten out of ten.

This is one of those films that made me wonder why I hadn't seen it earlier. The acting from everyone involved is great, Marlon Brando comes across perfectly as the head of the family, and James Caan and Al Pacino are excellent as his sons. The soundtrack by Nino Rota is also very memorable, bringing back memories of the film every time I hear it. The plot has to be excellent for it to get ten out of ten, and it is, it's far from predictable and the film is the definition of a great epic.

The film is pretty shocking in the way every death occurs almost instantaneously, and as it spans ten years so many different things happen and every minute of it is great entertainment. It's a well-made and entertaining film that is only the first part of a trilogy, but it stands on its own as a wonderful film in its own right. If you haven't seen it, what are you waiting for? This was one acclaimed film that didn't disappoint.

title: An intense epic of loyalty and the cost of betrayal.
description: Based on the old style Sicilian mafia, Francis Ford Coppola directs Mario Puzo's novel "The Godfather" into the dramatic tale of Sicilian Godfather Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). Coppola and Puzo convey the importance of loyalty to the family, the cost of betrayal, and ever-present power of organized crime rings.

title: What else need to be said?
description: What can I possibly add to all the comments that have been given? I think the true greatness of this movie lies in the fact that Puzo and Coppola both worked on the script of these movies. Directors often get a book all wrong and screw up the translation from the book to the movie, and that's only logical, because a book is art and that's personal. THe movie would have been completely different if Coppola had written the screenplay on his own without Puzo telling him what the real essence of the story is. And that is what lifted this movie and the other godfathers beyond greatness... I give a 9 out of 10.

title: THE GOD FATHER REVIEWS
description: The Godfather is an excellent movie with an excellent story. It is a film depicting the Sicilian mafia in USA as well as Italy itself, and is written by a person with direct Italian ancestry. ... The film had legendary actors like Marlon Brando, Al Pacino and Robert Duvall to mention a few.

title: Al Pacino Godfather is a must watch!
description: Well written classic must watch movie!!! Go see it or buy it!

title: A Cinematic Masterpiece Perfection in Every Frame
description:
I don't just like The Godfather-I love it in every way imaginable. From the hauntingly beautiful score to the flawless performances (Marlon Brando, Al Pacino-unmatched!), every moment is etched into cinema history. The pacing is deliberate yet gripping, the dialogue is sharp and iconic, and the themes of family, loyalty, and power resonate across generations.

Coppola's vision is a masterclass in storytelling, and The Godfather isn't just a movie-it's an experience, an education, a feeling. It's a film that teaches you how art can transcend entertainment and become something timeless.

Every time I watch it, I discover something new: a subtle expression, a hidden meaning, a moment of brilliance that redefines what cinema can be.

To me, The Godfather is not just the best film ever made-it's the gold standard. A 10/10 masterpiece.

title: 2nd best of all time....

The wonderful director Cappola has created not just a movie but a work of art that will be indelible forever. title: A must watch

title: Do Good
description:
This film works so well because it takes place in an underworld where we are so embedded that we don't even notice it. Coppola places us smack-dab in the center of what is, admittedly, a society created by criminals for criminals. That's also why it's so welcoming. We're surrounded by its inhabitants - cold-blooded killers who see crime as a 9-to-5 job masquerading as respectable men. And I don't mean men. From the outside, we'll only witness the horrific, disturbing manifestations of their well-thought-out actions.

But it goes deeper than that. It all revolves around the Corleone family, led by Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He's the most honest of these men, sitting right on the edge. But for someone like him, who doesn't fully embrace this world, it's not easy. He avoids conflict unless it's absolutely necessary. He's a man defined by moral principles. There's a scene early on where, on the day of his daughter's wedding, one of his associates, Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana), practices the speech he's going to give to the Don when he meets him. The scene with these two is funny and almost adorable. I couldn't help but feel sympathy for both of them, not to mention that I was actually warming up to both of the mobsters. Not to mention that Lenny Montana was a real mob hit-man and was actually nervous as he said this line.

The more I watched, the more I realized how incredibly complex and ruthless this society is and how it has the power to corrupt anyone it comes into contact with. The best example is Corleone's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino). He returns home for his sister's wedding dressed as a war hero with his longtime girlfriend, Kay Adams (Diane Keaton). At first, he avoids this underworld, but necessity, first-hand exposure, and the sheer devilish allure of it draw him in. As we progress through the film, the transformation is dramatic, and every outsider who comes close to him is tainted. One way or another. If they survive, they are drawn in, as are we as viewers.

Inside, Coppola presents the family in its entirety to us with a boldly personal approach, and we witness every discussion, every methodically calculated choice. Crime is committed simply because it is the nature of their business, and we are put in a chair alongside them, so we relate easily. To us, they are the good guys, the rival family the bad guys. The greatest achievement this film has managed to pull off is separating the good guys and the bad guys in a world full of bad guys.

This is a film of unparalleled subtlety. No other film holds its own so well. No other film is done with such precision, attention, and completeness. There are so many layers that I probably missed and may never notice. But I felt them. What director Francis Ford Coppola and his partner in crime (poor choice of words, sorry) Mario Puzo did is nothing less than a timeless reference movie whose impact is based not on reinventing the wheel, but on making it perfectly optimal.

Most masterpieces are remembered for their historical contributions. "Citizen Kane" brought the biggest step forward in the art form, the same things "Gone with the Wind" or "2001: A Space Odyssey" did. "The Godfather" is one of the few films that will be remembered because they are so good, and I can't possibly imagine a greater achievement than that.

title: Fantastic

title: A Timeless Classic
description:
I read the book first and considered it a literary masterpiece of drama and intrigue.

A year later when I watched the film on a friend's recommendation I was completely mesmerized by the way the characters of book made their presence felt on screen.

It is one of the masterpieces of cinema world over. Many a director worldwide has paid tributes to this film in one way or the other. Twice in the recent history in India only (Sarkar and Raajneeti).

Marlon Brando is amazing as the Godfather. Al Pacino (who was still making a stronghold in Hollywood at that time) has done justice as the son who is in conflict with his family business. His transformation, both by action and his psyche, is a treat to watch.

The beauty of the film, and why it works at so many levels, lies in the fact that the characters' charisma is built not by their actions on screen but by a sense of intrigue that the writers and director have achieved by this flawless narrative.

Add to that the cinematography of Gordon Willis. The lighting in the frames (and lack of it) adds to the sense of intrigue.

The cutting is crisp and helps build the tension.

Undoubtedly a 10/10

description:
After been about five minutes searching the correct words to describe this movie, I only found that three: "more than perfect".

Thank you Coppola for being god!

title: Nothing Personal, Just Business
description:
The Godfather is a fantastic movie that shows struggles of the Corleone family, in the midst of a mafia War.

It's hard to write a review about this movie, because so much has been referenced through other media, so much that you would fear it have been watered down because of it, but surprisingly it still holds up 100% today.

The acting is spot on. It Can deliver this funny Italian dialogue in a way where it still believable and does not become distracting, It's a incredible.

The pacing and the story just flows, it does not feel prolonged, it Just shows all the interesting turns in the Corleone family in this horrible time. It is so well done.

If I were before you in person, I could gosh about the performances, about the turns in the story, about the amazing presentation, but I have to spoil to do that, so I will just say go and watch it.

Shows the ending of the old mafia ways, and the beginning of the new, It's a dark, bloody and interesting Family Story, would recommend.

title: An indelible mark on cinema history
description:
Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic. His powerful and nuanced performance brings depth and humanity to the character, making Vito a sympathetic and complex figure.

Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone is equally brilliant. His transformation from a war hero and innocent bystander to a calculating and cold-blooded leader is one of the film's most compelling aspects.

Coppola's direction is nothing short of masterful. He crafts a visually stunning and emotionally gripping narrative, perfectly capturing the atmosphere and setting of the 1940s and 1950s. Coppola's attention to detail and his ability to draw out powerful performances from his cast contribute to the film's success.

"The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that excels on every level. Its engrossing storytelling, exceptional performances, and impeccable direction make it a landmark film in the crime genre. The exploration of power, family, and morality, coupled with its stunning cinematography and memorable score, solidify its place as one of the greatest films ever made.

title: An iconic and great film that stands the test of time
description:
What do we think of when we think of "The Godfather"? Intense shoot-outs and violence, beautiful scenery, sets, costumes, and cinematography, Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal as the menacing Don Vito Corleone, maybe even the final shot of the film, which speaks volumes. No matter what you think of when you think of "The Godfather", you think of greatness.

It's the film that launched the careers of Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, and Francis Ford Coppola into the realm of the legendary. It's a film that oozes cinematic and artistic mastery. With its seemingly slow-pace and silent ferocity, the film catches you off guard with so many scenes that pack a powerful punch, both emotionally and visually. It's also a film with many personal and sincere moments, dwelling on themes of family, loyalty, and trust; and the consequences of betraying that trust.

It's certainly a film for the ages, and I find something new that I love about it every time I see it.

title: Great Movie, but highly overrated !
description: I know a lot of people don't want to hear this, but you've already knew it deep inside of you. IT ISN'T THE BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIMES !! Yeah, I agree, the story is complex, the acting is outstanding, but all in all it's a proper 8 out of 10.

title: As good as it gets...
description: The Godfather has been a tradition in my family forever. Even when I was young I wanted to see what this "wonderful" movie was like. Finally, when I was eight, my whole family got together on New Year's Eve to watch the trilogy and The Godfather became my all time favorite movie. There is nothing better. I've seen the movie a million times, and never get tired of it. I also enjoy watching the little documentary before the movie, but that totally spoils some of it if you haven't seen it before. My family says I like Part 1 more than Part 2 because Marlon Brando was in it (yes, partly, but he's my favorite actor), but the story was so much better. Many movies that are based on the book tend to add ridiculous scenes, but the Godfather kept true to the story. All of the actors were wonderful, and now, the Corleone family is like a part of my family.

title: A Timeless Classic of Family and Loyalty
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in cinematic history. This review will explore the movie's remarkable storytelling, compelling characters, and the powerful themes of family and loyalty that make it a timeless classic.

Plot and Storytelling

Set in the 1940s, "The Godfather" tells the story of the Corleone family, an influential and respected Italian-American family in New York. The head of the family, Vito Corleone (played by Marlon Brando), is a wise and revered figure who values family above all else. The narrative revolves around the family's efforts to maintain their legacy and protect their loved ones.

The movie's storytelling is masterful, weaving together intricate plotlines and character arcs. It captures the audience's attention from the very beginning, with each scene building upon the last to create a rich and immersive experience. The dialogue is sharp and memorable, contributing to the film's lasting impact.

Characters and Performances

One of the standout features of "The Godfather" is its unforgettable characters. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is iconic, and his performance earned him an Academy Award. Vito's sons, Michael (Al Pacino) and Sonny (James Caan), play pivotal roles in the story, each bringing depth and complexity to their characters. Michael's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a decisive leader is particularly compelling.

The supporting cast, including Robert Duvall as the loyal consigliere Tom Hagen and Diane Keaton as Michael's love interest Kay Adams, also deliver exceptional performances. Each character is meticulously developed, contributing to the film's rich tapestry.

Themes of Family and Loyalty

At its core, "The Godfather" is a story about family and loyalty. The Corleone family is bound by deep ties of love and duty, and these themes resonate throughout the film. The importance of family is evident in Vito's actions and decisions, as he strives to protect his children and secure their future. Loyalty is another central theme, as characters navigate complex relationships and alliances.

The film beautifully portrays the sacrifices made for family and the lengths to which individuals will go to support and protect their loved ones. These universal themes make "The Godfather" relatable and enduring, appealing to audiences of all ages.

Cinematography and Music

"The Godfather" is also renowned for its stunning cinematography and memorable musical score. The visual style, with its careful attention to detail and atmospheric lighting, enhances the storytelling and adds depth to the film. The music, composed by Nino Rota, is equally iconic, with the haunting theme becoming instantly recognizable.

Conclusion

In summary, "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that transcends its genre. Its powerful themes of family and loyalty, combined with exceptional performances and masterful storytelling, make it a timeless classic. Whether you're watching it for the first time or revisiting it years later, "The Godfather" continues to captivate and inspire audiences around the world.

title: I love it!
description:
The film's narrative is truly remarkable. It skillfully delves into the depths of each character, weaving a complex and captivating storyline. Initially, I had reservations, but as the plot unfolded, I realized the sheer brilliance of this cinematic masterpiece.

This film stands as a testament to cinematic excellence, ranking among the finest ever made. Its superb acting, intricate plot, and gripping dialogue are exemplary. The climax, particularly the last 20-30 minutes, leaves viewers eagerly anticipating the sequel, rumored to surpass its predecessor. I admire how older films take their time to unfold, allowing characters to develop fully and the story to shine. Rushing through a narrative often results in a shallow experience, a pitfall avoided by this film and many others like it.

In conclusion, this masterpiece deserves to be experienced on the big screen, ideally with friends, to fully appreciate its magnificence.

title: THE BEST MOVIE EVER!!!
description:
The Godfather has quickly become this reviewer's favorite dramatic movie. With a mixture of love, action and scandalous plot developments not once in the 175 minutes of watching it did looking at the clock to see how much longer it would be come to mind. There is such a sympathy created for the Corleone family that you end up rooting for them, even though they are a mafia related family. It's crazy to think about really, for instance, this reviewer can't remember the last time she felt sympathy for a murderer The Godfather is amazing, it's well written, and the cast just meshes well on screen. The names can be confusing because they are all Italian and people address each other by their last name most of the time, but after a while it starts to make a little sense. The lead character of the movie is, surprisingly, Michael Corleone (Al Pacino). This story follows his coming of age from a young man wishing to get as far away from the business to his deep involvement after some family catastrophes. Upon first introduction Michael is dressed in his service uniform and bringing a new love, Kay (Diane Keaton), to the wedding of his sister. When Kay asks about his family, and his father in particular, Michael explains to her that his father is a mafia leader and he wants nothing at all to be like him. So far, he had been doing very well at trying to keep himself separated, until one day when his father gets shot in the back several times and is put into the hospital. Well, of course, the henchmen aren't going to be satisfied with just putting him in the hospital, they want to finish the job. Luckily, Michael goes to visit his father and upon arrival realizes that there is no one there keeping guard over his father. He calls his brother to get backup and places his father in a different room in the hospital. The suspense in this scene is SO heavy it's almost suffocating, in a good way. There are distant footsteps heard coming toward Michael's father and this reviewer felt her hands clench and her heart beat racing; it was so well done. But this is the point when Michael really starts to enter the mafia; and he only gets deeper and deeper into it as the movie plays out. There is, however, one death scene that is a bit too played out. A character is in a car and suddenly there are a gazillion guys around the car and they all have rapid firing guns. Well, the character is shot while in the car and proceeds to crawl across the seat and exit out the passenger side of the car. At which point, the character puts themselves in full exposure to the henchmen. Why? No clue, but then another 70 or 80 shots are successfully taken AND THEN one of the henchmen proceeds to take a few shots at close range and throw in a few kicks. This is a bit excessive upon reflection but at the time, this reviewer almost cried. It was SO unfair! If it wasn't for the fact that it is completely impossible, jumping into the screen to save the victim was all this reviewer could think of. Once again, it's amazing because the victim wasn't exactly an angel to say the least.

The story is truly what manipulates the audience to feel sympathy for this family. They seem to be falling apart left and right, which is tough to see because they used to be such a strong unit. The values of family love seem to be falling apart with each new marriage, the men are trying to stay ahead in the game but they keep getting attacked from behind because there are traitors amongst the alliances. Personally, this reviewer can't wait to see the two following films in this trilogy and compare them to the first, because topping this one will be extremely difficult. If your looking for an awesome drama, watch The Godfather, it's got a little bit of everything in the story for everyone. It's a great movie to watch on an icky day when you're stuck at home, because it will make time fly so fast.

title: The Godfather: A Cinematic Masterpiece
description:
"The Godfather" is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, the movie was released in 1972 and has since become an iconic part of cinema history.

The movie follows the Corleone family, a powerful mafia dynasty led by the patriarch, Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). The story is set in the 1940s and centers around the Corleone family's struggle to maintain their power in the midst of a changing world.

Brando's performance as Vito Corleone is nothing short of legendary. He brings a sense of gravitas and authority to the character that is unmatched. Equally impressive is Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, who is forced to step up and take over the family business after his father is nearly assassinated.

The movie is a masterclass in storytelling, with a gripping plot that keeps the audience on the edge of their seats from start to finish. The themes of loyalty, betrayal, and family are explored in great depth, and the characters are all complex and multifaceted.

The movie is also visually stunning, with breathtaking cinematography that captures the essence of 1940s New York City. The iconic score by Nino Rota is equally impressive, and the use of music throughout the movie is masterful.

Overall, "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that has stood the test of time. It is a must-see for any movie lover, and its influence can still be seen in countless movies and TV shows today. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and watch it as soon as possible.

title: The Godfather: A Cinematic Masterpiece of Crime and Family
description:
"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's best-selling novel, is a landmark in cinema history. Released in 1972, this film is widely regarded as one of the greatest movies ever made. Its intricate plot, unforgettable characters, and thematic depth have captivated audiences for decades.

The story revolves around the powerful and influential Corleone crime family in post-World War II America. Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) is the patriarch, known as the Godfather, who presides over the family with a mixture of benevolence and ruthless efficiency. His three sons, Sonny (James Caan), Fredo (John Cazale), and Michael (Al Pacino), are positioned to inherit his legacy, though each has a different relationship with the family business.

The film opens with a lavish wedding scene for Vito's daughter, Connie (Talia Shire), establishing the complex web of familial and criminal alliances. This scene masterfully sets the stage for the film's exploration of loyalty, power, and betrayal. Coppola's direction captures the intricate dynamics of the Corleone family and the world they inhabit, weaving a tale that is as much about family bonds as it is about crime and violence.

Marlon Brando's performance as Vito Corleone is iconic, embodying the character's authority and charisma with subtlety and depth. His portrayal won him the Academy Award for Best Actor and remains one of cinema's most memorable roles. Brando's Vito is both a loving family man and a shrewd, calculating leader, exemplifying the dual nature of his character.

Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, is equally compelling. Michael starts as a reluctant outsider, a decorated war hero intent on living a life separate from the family business. However, as the story unfolds, Michael is drawn deeper into the criminal underworld, ultimately assuming the role of the family head. Pacino's transformation from the innocent and detached son to a powerful and ruthless leader is one of the film's most captivating arcs. His journey is both tragic and inevitable, showcasing the corrupting influence of power and the demands of loyalty.

The supporting cast, including James Caan as the hot-headed Sonny and Robert Duvall as the loyal consigliere Tom Hagen, delivers exceptional performances that add layers to the film's narrative. The ensemble cast brings to life the complex relationships within the Corleone family, making the audience care deeply about each character's fate.

Coppola's direction, combined with Gordon Willis's cinematography, creates a rich visual tapestry that captures the period and mood of the story. The film's dark, shadowy aesthetic reflects the moral ambiguity and danger inherent in the world of organized crime. Nino Rota's haunting score complements the visuals, enhancing the emotional impact of the story.

The film's exploration of themes such as loyalty, power, and the American Dream resonates with audiences on a universal level. "The Godfather" portrays the criminal underworld as a parallel society with its own rules and hierarchies, examining the fine line between legitimacy and illegality. The Corleone family's struggle for power and survival reflects the broader American experience, questioning the price of ambition and the nature of justice.

One of the film's most famous scenes is the baptism sequence, where Michael stands as godfather to his nephew while orchestrating the brutal elimination of his enemies. This masterful juxtaposition of religious ceremony and violence underscores the film's central themes of duality and moral complexity.

"The Godfather" has left an indelible mark on popular culture, influencing countless films and television shows. Its dialogue, such as Vito's iconic line, "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse," has become part of the cultural lexicon.

In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that transcends the crime genre to explore profound themes of family, power, and morality. Its compelling characters, masterful storytelling, and timeless themes ensure its place as one of the greatest films ever made. Whether viewed for the first time or revisited, "The Godfather" remains a powerful and unforgettable experience.

title: A perfect movie.
description:
"For justice, we must go to Don Corleone."

Out of the vast amount of movies, more than 50,000 total to date as of this review, only a few films are described by many a noted film critic as a "perfect movie". However, one of those movies, to me, deserves the title of being the most perfect movie out of 'em all. That movie is the 1972 crime drama by the name of "The Godfather".

Based on the novel by Italian-American author Mario Puzo, this was the movie that revolutionized the art of gangster pictures since its inception. This wasn't like films such as The Roaring Twenties (1939) or The Public Enemy (1931), which were about ordinary mobster life. Instead, we focus on an entire family of the mafia that runs a vast empire in New York City, lead by the aging, yet all powerful Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando). He's retiring from the business, and has to choose which one of his sons to take his place, either the hair-trigger tempered Sonny (James Caan), adopted son, consigliere, and lawyer Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall), or his youngest son and war hero Michael (Al Pacino). However, as this is happening, unexpected things are happening within the Corleone family itself including selling out and betrayal, and an all-out war between all of the five families (Corleone, Barzini, Tattaglia, Stracci, and Cuneo) is brewing that turns the entire city into a blood-drenched war zone where only one can remain supreme.

The film is directed by Francis Ford Coppola, whom prior to this was also responsible for movies like Finian's Rainbow (1968), You're A Big Boy Now (1966) and The Rain People (1969), none of which were very successful box office-wise. The Godfather was the turning point of Coppola's career, not just because most of his future pictures would be smash hits, but would also earn him his first Best Picture win. The film itself is poetic, thanks to the assistance from the book's author Mario Puzo, who also wrote the screenplay for the picture. Coppola illustrates both the positive and negative sides of mafia life, the fall and rise of an underground empire, and the meaning of loyalty all at once. All of the main characters in the film are also relatable and three-dimensional to a tee. You actually feel for them and understand their mindset, making it true to life, to where even actual mobsters commend the film for its realism.

Future gangster pictures like Brian De Palma's Scarface (1983), Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas (1990), and Mike Newell's Donnie Brasco (1997) owe something to this movie, aside from the fact that two of those films also star Pacino, making it about not just about the career of a mobster, but also about the mobster himself and the relationship between his colleagues. In other words, they're in-depth character studies, and that's what makes The Godfather a truly epic and moving film, let alone a film that, as I've mentioned in the beginning, is described as a "perfect movie". Even teachers in colleges and universities that teach film studies or any form of filmmaking would refer to showing this film as part of a curriculum. Overall, it's a film that is considered mandatory viewing for every moviegoer, even if you don't like sitting through films that are nearly or over 3 hours. If you haven't seen it, stop what you're doing right now and see it.

title: The Godfather
description:
The Godfather is a 2006 open world action-adventure video game developed by EA Redwood Shores and published by Electronic Arts. Originally released in March 2006 for the PlayStation 2, Xbox and Microsoft Windows, it was later released for the PlayStation Portable as The Godfather: Mob Wars, Xbox 360 as The Godfather: The Game, Wii as The Godfather: Blackhand Edition, and PlayStation 3 as The Godfather: The Don's Edition.

The game is based upon the 1972 film of the same name, and tells the story of an original character, Aldo Trapani, whose rise through the ranks of the Corleone family intersects with the plot of the film on numerous occasions. His actions in the game often take the form of events that happened off screen in the film; for example, he avenges Bonasera's daughter, he drives Vito Corleone to the hospital after he is shot, he plants the gun for Michael Corleone to kill Sollozzo and Captain McCluskey, he places the horse's head in Jack Woltz's bed. Although the game was condemned by Francis Ford Coppola, who claimed Paramount never told him about its development or asked for his input, it does feature voice acting from several stars of the film, including James Caan as Sonny Corleone, Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen and Abe Vigoda as Salvatore Tessio. Marlon Brando also recorded dialogue for Vito Corleone, in what would be his final acting job, but his ill health made most of his recordings unusable. Al Pacino, who played Michael Corleone in the film, is absent in both likeness and voice, choosing to lend his image instead to Scarface: The World Is Yours.

The Godfather received mixed to positive reviews across most systems, although the PSP version was generally seen as inferior to the others. The game was a commercial success, selling over two million units. In 2009, a sequel was released for PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and Windows. Based on the 1974 film, The Godfather Part II, the sequel did not sell as well nor do as well with critics as had the original, and EA scrapped plans for an adaptation of the third film.

Once you have seem this film you will understand why it won Best Picture at the oscars.

title: There Are So Many Reasons for the Movie's Greatness
description: In writing an apology for a film that really needs none, let me begin by noting how many careers were established with this movie, beginning with that of Al Pacino. Pacino had made movies before and was a respected New York stage actor, but this was his breakthrough movie. Brando was regarded as poison: he was impossible to work with, causing movies to lose money with his outrageous demands, so the studio execs despised and distrusted him. This movie, for which he had to suffer the humiliation of auditioning, resurrected him. It opened the door to the memorable "Last Tango in Paris." Of course we had all seen Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton, James Caan and John Cazale in other movies, but this one made them stars. (I don't recall seeing Talia Shire before this.) And it gave Coppola the kind of artistic freedom that would lead to "Godfather II"--another masterpiece. Puzo, who wrote the book and collaborated on the screenplay, would go on to do the scripts for "Superman" and other movies. It was magic for everyone who appeared in it. I am only sorry that the success it brought people like Marlon Brando and Richard Castellano led them to price themselves out of "Godfather II."

title: A masterpiece of crime cinema
description:
Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" is a timeless classic that stands as a pinnacle of crime cinema. Based on Mario Puzo's novel, the film delves deep into the intricate world of the Corleone family, offering a compelling portrayal of power, loyalty, and the American Dream. Marlon Brando delivers an iconic performance as Vito Corleone, the formidable patriarch whose influence extends far beyond his criminal empire.

Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, Vito's youngest son, is equally riveting. Michael's transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader is depicted with subtlety and intensity, showcasing Pacino's extraordinary range. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, contribute to the film's richly layered narrative, creating a vivid and immersive experience.

Coppola's direction is masterful, balancing moments of quiet introspection with bursts of shocking violence. The film's cinematography, with its chiaroscuro lighting and meticulous composition, enhances the story's mood and themes. Nino Rota's haunting score further accentuates the film's emotional depth and grandeur.

"The Godfather" is more than just a crime saga; it's a profound exploration of family, power, and destiny. Its complex characters and unforgettable scenes make it a cinematic masterpiece that continues to resonate with audiences, solidifying its legacy in film history.

title: The Godfather (1972): A Masterpiece of Cinematic Storytelling
description:
Here's a personalized review of The Godfather (1972), from your perspective:

The Godfather (1972): A Masterpiece of Cinematic Storytelling

The Godfather (1972) is a film that completely engrossed me from start to finish. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, it stands as a timeless work of art, blending crime, family, and power into a narrative that's both captivating and haunting.

What really struck me was the depth of the characters. Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone is unforgettable, embodying a quiet authority and wisdom that makes you sympathize with a character who is, at heart, a criminal. His portrayal of family loyalty and the fine line between love and control is magnetic. Al Pacino's transformation from Michael Corleone, the reluctant son, into a ruthless leader is nothing short of brilliant. Watching Michael evolve from someone distant from his family's mafia roots to becoming everything he once opposed feels tragic yet inevitable.

The storytelling is meticulously layered, with each scene unfolding with a sense of purpose. The film masterfully weaves themes of power, loyalty, betrayal, and morality in a way that makes you question the price of ambition. The family dynamics, especially between Michael, his father Vito, and his brother Sonny (played by James Caan), felt real and raw, pulling me deeper into the Corleone world.

Visually, The Godfather captures the gritty, dark underbelly of organized crime while balancing it with moments of lavish grandeur, like the wedding scenes or family dinners. The use of shadows and the moody lighting enhanced the sense of danger lurking behind every decision.

What left a lasting impression on me was how the film doesn't glorify the violence and crime; instead, it highlights the emotional cost. The slow-burning tension, the betrayals, and the gradual collapse of relationships felt like an inevitable consequence of the Corleones' world. The scene where Michael takes revenge in the restaurant-one of the most intense moments in cinema-left me holding my breath, a perfect balance of silence, tension, and explosive action.

In short, The Godfather isn't just a crime movie; it's a study of human nature, power, and the tragic consequences of one's choices. It's a film that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, and for me, it's one of those rare films where every element, from acting to direction, comes together flawlessly.

title: Amazing Movie
description:
The Godfather" (1972) is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in cinematic history and a classic in the crime genre. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on the novel by Mario Puzo, the film tells the story of the Corleone crime family and their patriarch, Vito Corleone, played by Marlon Brando.

Compelling Story and Screenplay: Mario Puzo, who co-wrote the screenplay with Coppola, crafted a compelling narrative that explores themes of power, family, and the consequences of a life immersed in organized crime. The story spans several decades, providing a comprehensive look at the characters' lives and the evolution of the Corleone family.

Outstanding Performances: The cast of "The Godfather" delivered remarkable performances that have become iconic in the history of cinema. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor, and Al Pacino, who played his son Michael Corleone, showcased an impressive transformation from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless leader.

Cinematography and Visuals: Cinematographer Gordon Willis's work on "The Godfather" is celebrated for its moody and atmospheric style. The use of low-key lighting, shadowy compositions, and the sepia-toned color palette contribute to the film's distinct visual identity, capturing the dark and complex nature of the Mafia world.

title: The Corleone Dynasty
description:
The Godfather is the most influential American film that has ever been released.

So there isn't much more that I can say to really emphasize how much you should watch this film.

An epic film telling the tragic story of the Corleone family who is one of the biggest mafia families set in the 1940s to the 1950s.

A film that really goes deep into the topic of family, power structure and being placed at the head of your family's empire without a choice.

Marlon Brando and Al Pacino are the two stand out characters.

Without even having any sort of back story you can see the type of power Vito Corleone holds among the family and to see the transition of Michael Corleone become a major head of his family despite originally wanting to have nothing to do with his family's business.

It's a tale that is engrossing from start to finish even being at almost 3 hours long.

title: A movie you can't refuse
description:
"I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse." That line alone is cinematic royalty-and The Godfather doesn't just deserve a 10 out of 10, it redefined what a 10 looks like.

Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, based on Mario Puzo's novel, and featuring a stacked, God-tier cast, this film is more than a movie-it's a cultural monument. A masterclass in storytelling, character, tension, and tragedy, The Godfather isn't just about the Mafia. It's about family, legacy, power, and the quiet, cold decay of a man's soul.

Let's talk cast: Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone - iconic doesn't even begin to cover it. The rasp. The power. The calm presence that chills and comforts all at once. Brando didn't act this role-he became the Don.

Al Pacino as Michael Corleone - this is one of the greatest character arcs in cinema history. From soft-spoken war hero to stone-cold Mafia boss, Pacino's performance is terrifying in its subtlety.

James Caan as Sonny - all fire and fury, perfectly counterbalancing Michael's coldness.

Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen - the Consigliere with steel nerves and quiet loyalty.

Diane Keaton, Talia Shire, John Cazale-every performance is pitch-perfect.

The pacing? It's patient. Deliberate. It simmers, never rushing, never dragging. Every scene is vital. Every silence is louder than most blockbusters' explosions. The horse head scene, the restaurant shooting, the baptism sequence-each one is legendary.

The cinematography by Gordon Willis, aka "The Prince of Darkness," gives the film its moody, shadow-heavy palette-like the soul of the Mafia itself is seeping into the frame. It's rich. It's textured. It's timeless.

Let's not forget Nino Rota's score. That haunting theme? That is the sound of family and death braided into one.

But what makes The Godfather so damn powerful isn't just the blood or the betrayal. It's the tragedy. Michael never wanted this. But the world, the violence, the need for control-it pulls him in, inch by inch. By the end, when that door closes on Kay's face and Michael fully becomes the new Don? That's not a triumph. That's a fall. A quiet, suffocating fall.

Bottom line: The Godfather isn't just one of the greatest films of all time-it is the gold standard. Every crime drama, every serious film about power or family or loyalty, wishes it could touch what this movie did. It's cinematic perfection-crafted with elegance, danger, and emotion.

10 out of 10. A masterpiece etched in stone.

The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that has cemented its place in film history. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola and based on Mario Puzo's novel, it tells the story of the Corleone family, a powerful Mafia clan in New York City.

The film's intricate plot, unforgettable characters, and iconic performances have made it a timeless classic. One of the best Mafia movies ever made; great actors and characters, costly production, awesome plot.

I agree that Brando's portrait of Don Corleone sometimes appears slightly comical but you also have to see that his character is getting old and weak, hence the raspingly low volume voice and he isn't a purely bad Don and very sincere with his family (especially own blood) members and I think Brando was the right man to portrait these kinds of character traits. Also, every time I saw myself thinking it's comical, I also got bad thoughts like 'You can't think like this of the Don', hence this shows, it is a good performance if he makes me scared as a viewer having these kind of thoughts.

There are quite a few people in this movie who only get introduced to the audience on the surface, but play a bigger role towards the end but me as a viewer, I don't feel any bonding to them since I only saw them for 5 minutes before. I think they should've gave them more screen time, so the viewer remembers them better.

Overall, this is a milestone in the history of movie, you have to watch it at one point. Some scenes - You won't forget. 9/10

title: Cinematic Masterpiece That Has Not Been Surpassed
description: A favorite by so many people in the world, Mario Puzo's The Godfather is considered by many, including myself, to be the greatest accomplishment in the history of cinema. Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall and the rest of the cast has brought to life one of the most acclaimed film of all time. The popularity of this film is not surprising because it contains memorable music, moving scenes, thought provoking dialogue/phrases and extraordinary acting by an extraordinary cast. At the risk of sounding redundant, which in the case of giving thoughts about this movie is a given, it is so much more than what it seems storywise. If I try to even explain this aspect of the movie, I'd lose myself. This film is important to so many people that I recommend it to anyone that haven't seen it (which are some very unlucky people I might add). Unfortunately, no simple explanation could ever compensate for the experience of watching Don Vito Corleone and His Family's Tale of Crime and Family. In conclusion, I wish to say that everybody should see it for themselves and be enlightened to what could be a wonderful journey and learning experience.

title: The Godfather
description:
**The Godfather: A Cinematic Masterpiece**

Francis Ford Coppola's *The Godfather* (1972) is often considered one of the greatest films ever made. Based on the novel by Mario Puzo, the film delves into the intricacies of family, power, and betrayal within the context of the American Mafia. With its meticulously crafted screenplay, complex characters, and unforgettable performances, *The Godfather* remains a quintessential example of cinema's power to evoke deep emotion and explore universal themes.

Set in the years following World War II, *The Godfather* revolves around the Corleone family, one of the most powerful Mafia dynasties in New York. At the center of the story is Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando), the aging patriarch of the family, who tries to balance his role as a loving father with the brutal demands of his criminal empire. The film chronicles the shifting dynamics within the Corleone family, especially as Vito's youngest son, Michael (Al Pacino), is slowly drawn into the Mafia world despite his initial desire to stay away. As Vito struggles to maintain control over his empire, Michael's journey from an innocent war hero to a ruthless Mafia boss becomes the film's central arc.

One of the most compelling aspects of *The Godfather* is its exploration of the notion of family. In the Mafia world, family ties are everything, and Coppola effectively uses these relationships to examine loyalty, honor, and the consequences of violence. The opening wedding scene sets the tone for the entire film, as Vito's godfather role highlights the intricacies of family loyalty. Throughout the film, we witness how loyalty to the family is both an anchor and a burden. The tension between family loyalty and personal morality plays out in Michael's character arc, as he is slowly pushed into a leadership role that he never wanted but ultimately embraces in order to protect the Corleone name.

The film's screenplay, co-written by Coppola and Puzo, is rich with intricate dialogue and subtext. The writing is sharp and often subtle, with key lines and moments that resonate long after the credits roll. Take, for instance, the famous line, "I'll make him an offer he can't refuse," which has become iconic in American cinema. It encapsulates the power dynamics at play in the world of the Mafia while also emphasizing the manipulative force that Vito Corleone wields. These carefully constructed moments not only advance the plot but also build tension, develop characters, and reveal the emotional depth of the story.

Visually, *The Godfather* is a masterpiece in its own right. Cinematographer Gordon Willis, often referred to as the "Prince of Darkness," employs low-key lighting throughout the film, creating a somber, almost noir-like atmosphere. The dimly lit scenes reflect the moral ambiguity of the characters and their actions, adding to the film's haunting tone. The use of shadows, particularly in scenes involving Vito and Michael, is masterfully done, heightening the sense of danger that lurks just beneath the surface of every interaction. The careful framing of shots and the film's pacing contribute to the immersive nature of the story, making the world of the Corleone family feel both intimate and expansive.

Of course, the performances in *The Godfather* are nothing short of legendary. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is one of the most iconic performances in cinema history. With his distinctive voice, mannerisms, and commanding presence, Brando creates a character who is both feared and revered. His portrayal of Vito is not just that of a ruthless crime boss, but also of a father, a husband, and a man burdened by the weight of his own power. The complexity of Vito's character is what makes him such a compelling figure. Brando's performance is full of nuance, evoking sympathy, admiration, and even fear, sometimes all in the same scene.

Al Pacino's transformation from the reluctant Michael to the cold-blooded Don is another standout aspect of the film. In his early scenes, Pacino plays Michael as an innocent, idealistic young man who refuses to partake in the family business. As the film progresses, Pacino subtly shifts Michael's character, capturing the inner conflict and moral decay that comes with power. His performance is restrained yet powerful, perfectly capturing Michael's internal struggle and eventual acceptance of his role as the new head of the Corleone family.

The supporting cast, including Marlon Brando's son, James Caan (Sonny Corleone), and Diane Keaton (Kay Adams), further enrich the film, adding layers of complexity to the story. Every character feels fully realized, with each actor bringing something special to their role.

The score by Nino Rota is also integral to the film's atmosphere. The haunting, iconic theme music, with its melancholic and nostalgic tone, enhances the film's emotional depth, perfectly complementing the film's themes of loss, power, and family.

In conclusion, *The Godfather* is a film that transcends its genre. It is a profound exploration of power, family, and identity, set against the backdrop of a violent and morally complex world. With its exceptional storytelling, direction, and performances, it continues to be a touchstone of cinematic achievement, influencing generations of filmmakers and audiences alike. It is a work of art that still resonates today, and its impact on cinema remains immeasurable. *The Godfather* is not just a movie; it is an experience.

title: Beautiful colors, script, character chemistry, and acting
description: "The Godfather" is one of those movies that everyone has heard of, everyone knows scenes of, and is quoted, parodied, and paralleled in everything from major movies to children's cartoons. There's the raspy voice of Don Corleone, the bloody horse's head in bed, and the actors for which the film defined their careers (Robert Duvall, Al Pacino that make this film). All of these things make this film a unique addition to American cinema and a classic to remember for years. The plot follows the trail of the Corleone family for several years after the assassination attempt of the family patriarch, Don Corleone (Marlon Brando). After the Don is unsuccessfully gunned down by five shots from rival's gang, his son Michael (Al Pacino) is forced to take over through a series of unfortunate events. One of the beautifully tragic events in this movie is Michael's transition from naive to a mob leader in his father's name. This movie has it all-action, drama, love, beauty, and politics. It is a must-see of American Film and a institution for mafia films and will be for years to come.

title: Good Film

title: Amazing
description:
The most outstanding of all time, a cult film about the Sicilian mafia and its head - Vito Carleone (played by Marlon Brando). A film based on Mario Puzo's book of the same name, directed by Francis Coppolo (who became a great Hollywood director thanks to the film).

Sometimes the ingenious play of the actors and the genius of the efforts of the director himself, even from a fairly primitive mafia film, can make a masterpiece for all time, which will disperse into winged expressions, memes... No more than a dozen such crime dramas as "The Godfather" have been filmed in the entire history of cinema, which once again confirms the luck of everyone who created this outstanding film.

title: The Greatest
description: This is simply one of the greatest movies of all time. With amazing performances by Al Pacino, Robert Duvall, Diane Keaton, James Caan, and Marlon Brando. I know it is one of my favorites and I would recommend this film to anyone who really likes and a appreciates movies.

title: This film was soooo good and amazing and brilliant, no wonder it is one of the greatest films of all time.
description: The Godfather is a brilliant and flawless film. From start to finish, with Coppola's incredible directing skills, a just downright brilliant a screenplay and incredible acting, it is no wonder many consider this is the greatest film of all time. Even as 12 year old watching this, I can still truly understand how amazing this film is. Every shot has significance and with instantly quotable and amazing lines. I can't even put into words how much I loved this film. And after watching it about five times now, I can't find any flaws in the narrative or directing. I can't even find the words to describe how amazing this is and how much I loved it, but that was my attempt. Thank you, Francis Ford Coppola and Mario Puzo for this masterpiece.

title: Epic Masterpiece
description: I had heard about this movie (who hasn't really?) and I had a desire to watch this film. Yet, I couldn't because no one I knew had it, and I couldn't buy it. So, I decided to get the next best thing, and I read the book. I read the book in about a week, and I was astonished that such a book had existed and I hadn't read it before. So, my desire to watch the film was greater than it had ever been before. Finally, I was able to watch it. And, my God in Heaven. If I could, I would name my first born child Don Corleone (that's a joke) and make him look exactly like Marlon Brando. The acting, the writing, the directing, the cinematography, everything is fantastic. The only thing I can critique on is the action, and the fact that it was semi-cheesy. But, this is too be expected, as it was made in the early 70's, before great special effects. Despite this, I'd give this film 11/10.

title: Fantastic, but not the best.
description:
The Godfather is possibly one of the best constructed films I have ever seen: the lighting and colouring are perfect, giving every frame an almost painting like quality; the camera work is brilliantly modest; and the film hosts some of the greatest acting ever committed to celluloid.

However, there is something about the film which stops me from becoming as emotionally involved as I feel I could have been. Maybe its just the story itself, which I personally cannot connect to. It feels cold, but I'm sure that's the intention.

So, definitely one of the greatest films ever made, however I cannot agree with other posts claiming it is a better film than Citizen Kane.

title: The high praise is well earned
description:
Based on the novel by Mario Puzo: in the post-war period of 1945 - 1955 in New York City, Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) leads a criminal family business and is often at war with other Mafia families as well as other enemies. Vito's son, Michael (Al Pacino), wades into the family business and is groomed to eventually lead it.

Director Francis Ford Coppola co-wrote the screenplay with Puzo. The creative team does an excellent job in deceiving the viewer: while we can see that the family does terrible things, we can't help but sympathize with them occasionally especially as they are vulnerable to the acts of other criminal families and betrayals from within the clan. This works mainly due to many scenes involving extended family - the highlight being the enjoyable wedding scene at the film's beginning. The folks we see in such scenes seem to be likeable people.

The acting is brilliant overall with Brando and Pacino standing out. Brando gives a wide-ranging performance especially in the second half where he shows a more mellowing attitude compared to his ways in the first half. And there are many things to praise about Pacino - one of them being his ability to incite terror just by giving a still, brief glare. Pacino also carries the film's mid-section with a series of scenes involving a hospital, a restaurant, and Sicily in that order (a succinct summary). These segments, like others in the film, are intense with perfect build-ups.

The film's most powerful scene involves one where Michael is literally being a godfather at his nephew's baptism. The holy atmosphere of the event is contrasted, back and forth, with other scenes (involving family business) that are anything but holy. The polar opposites play brilliantly against each other in an almost sarcastic way.

And the film ends with a poignant scene between Michael and his wife, Kay (Diane Keaton), and a powerful closing image. A perfect ending for a perfect film.

In addition to the great performances of Pacino, Brando, and Keaton, the excellent cast also includes James Caan, Robert Duvall, Richard Castellano, Sterling Hayden, John Marley, Abe Vigoda, John Cazale, Talia Shire, Gianni Russo, Morgana King, Richard Conte, Lenny Montana and Simonetta Stefanelli.

"The Godfather" is considered outstanding by film critics as well as movie fans. Both groups are right. - dbamateurcritic

RATING: 10 out of 10 (after six viewings)

OUTSTANDING ACHIEVEMENTS:

Directing by Francis Ford Coppola

Acting Ensemble

Cinematography, Musical Score, Set Design (including the use of vintage cars), Costumes, and Editing.

title: Innovative movie of Gangster Genre
description:
"Keep your friends close, but your enemies closer." "A man who doesn't spend time with his family can never be a good man." "Never let anyone know what you are thinking"

These overwhelming quotes are the most discussing insights of this popular gangster trilogy- The Godfather. The first installment released in 1972 and gained both commercial and critical acclaims.

The first part revolves around the godfather Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) and how he deals with his competitors at NY city. At the same time, he is too caring about his family. He wants to involve his younger son Micael Corleone (Al Pacino), who just returns from World War 2. He has a faith on his younger son than his two elder sons. He faces different troubles from his anti groups lead by Solozzo, to whom Vito refused to do narcotic business. Vito thinks that narcotics would harm the society a lot. And, he aspires to stop Solozzo by sending his men and later his elder son Sonny. But it was Michael, who successfully defeats in battles with the help of Clemenza (Richard Castellano), who is a caporegime and the godfather of Sonny. In a battle with the opponents, Vito losses his elder son Sonny. Also, in Sicily, Michael meets and marries Apollonia, but a car bomb intended for him takes her life. Devastated by Sonny's death and realizing that the Tattaglias are controlled by the now-dominant don, Barzini, Vito attempts to end the feud. He assures the Five Families that he will withdraw his opposition to their heroin business and forgo avenging Sonny's murder. His safety guaranteed, Michael returns home to enter the family business and marry Kay, promising her that the business will be legitimate within five years. Kay gives birth to two children by the early 1950s. With his father nearing the end of his life and Fredo too weak, Michael takes the family reins.

The performance of Marlon Brando and Al Pacino was quite remarkable and the accolades they received proved this.

In the 30th Golden Globe Award, the film had won the categories for: Best Screenplay, Best Director, Best Actor - Drama, Best Original Score, and Best Picture - Drama out of 7 nominations. In the 45th Academy Award (Oscar), the film had nominated in 11 categories,and out of them, it won three of the Academy Awards: Best Actor, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Picture. The interesting fact is that, Marlon Brando refused to take the Oscar for raising his voice against the poor treatment of American Indians by the film industry who have virtually no representation in the film industry and were primarily used as extras

title: The godfather

title: Awesome !
description:
The portrayal of mob life in the post-war era seemed realistic enough, and the appropriate atmosphere was set. The opening scenes (revolving around Don Corleone's daughter's wedding) gave me mixed feelings. I thought the whole thing went on too long, but it did demonstrate that Corleone's "business" never ended - he was constantly meeting with various people looking for favours rather than being front and centre at the wedding. Brando, of course, won (and refused to accept) the Oscar for Best Actor for his portrayal of Corleone, but I wasn't actually taken with his performance. First, I really didn't think of him as the Lead Actor. Al Pacino (as Corleone's son Mike) was, I thought, far more important to the story and far more interesting to watch. Brando had - to me - an almost cartoonish aura around him. Over-rated in my view. But Pacino was excellent, and the character of Mike the most interesting in the movie, as he evolves from the returned war hero who wants nothing to do with the family "business" to the eventual "Don."

It's not that I thought this was a bad movie. It was quite watchable and for the most part very interesting. I just think I've seen better.

6/10.

title: Classic
description: All time fav. Great cinematography, great acting, great all around.

title: Classic
description:
The Godfather is not just a movie it's a masterpiece. Francis Ford Coppola's 1972 film is a defining moment in cinema history, delivering a gripping, emotional, and intense story of power, family, and loyalty. From its unforgettable performances to its beautifully crafted storytelling, this film is the gold standard of filmmaking.

Marlon Brando as Vito Corleone delivers one of the most iconic performances of all time, embodying the role of the powerful yet complex Mafia patriarch. Al Pacino's transformation as Michael Corleone is nothing short of phenomenal, taking the audience on a journey from an innocent outsider to a ruthless leader. The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, all add depth to this unforgettable film.

The cinematography, music, and dialogue are near perfection. Every scene is meticulously crafted, with tension that slowly builds until it reaches its unforgettable climax. Nino Rota's haunting score adds to the film's atmosphere, making it even more immersive.

Whether you're a fan of crime dramas or not, The Godfather is essential viewing. It's a film that has stood the test of time, influencing countless movies and directors. A true classic that deserves every bit of its legendary status.

title: Almost 30 year later, and still the best film ever made
description:
I'm a member of Generation X and was born the year THE GODFATHER was released. I didn't see it until about 5 years ago and was mesmerised at the ability of film to translate a tale with such a respect for the characters it is portraying.

I believe Francis Ford Coppolla adapted the screenplay along with the author of the original Godfather. His young, fresh and hungry talent is the reason we have this film today.

Every element of the film adds to tell the tale of family and loyalty, memorable characters with settings, wardrobe and cultural experiences that I will enjoy forever. The rich sadness of "The Godfather" theme (composed by Coppolla's father) alone brings tears to my eyes. The Godfather is the result of a truly gifted filmmaker.

In "the Godfather" the infallible image of "Don Corleone" combined with the performance of a lifetime is horribly disrupted with the multiple attempts on his life. We see his humanity in the once believed unstoppable Santino Corleone when his own fall takes place. The growth of character of Michael Corleone is like none other I've ever seen, this innocent school boy, turned in to this cold-blooded killing machine, in the name of "business."

Only in film can we, the audience, sympathise with such heartless killers and admire the strength of Sonny, the honourability of the Godfather, and the resurgence of the new Godfather.

Who knew a bunch of Italians and non-Italians could come together a portray such a glorious image of an Italian family?

And thank God, Francis Ford Copolla stuck to his instincts and prevented Danny Thomas from playing Marlon Brando's part, Burt Reynolds from playing Sonny and Robert Redford(there are blond haired blue eyed italians) from playing Michael. There's a nobility in the final cast, including his own sister, who plays Connie. It's a film about loyalty, and family, "Do you spend time with your family? Good, because a man who doesn't spend time with his family, can never be a real man."

And for the length? A film is to transport you into another world, one that you may or may not be familiar with. For those of us who suffer from short attention fans, you should not see this film. Films today are about packing as many violent, sexually explicit images, and colourful special effects,as possible in order to entertain the Attention Deficit Generation. Thank goodness the Godfather was created before this time and thank god there is a segment of society that is able to enjoy the quality of this film.

I give this film a 10 out of 10, an honor that no film I have ever seen, besides, The Shawshank Redemption, has ever been bestowed by myself.

The violence is stylized like a 1950s movie. The dialogue moves every scene forward. It breaks every rule by starting with a wedding and it works. title: My Big Fat Sicilian Wedding
description:
Big shout out to Flashback Cinemas for helping me finally, FINALLY, get this off my list of shame.

Of course now I'm left in the precarious position of having seen it and NOT thinking it's the best thing ever. I really wonder how much of that is due to the films own legendary status because it's impossible to go into this for the first time and not know it's supposed to be one of the finest pieces of cinema ever crafted.

I mean don't get me wrong, it's good. The performances are... WHAT HAPPENED TO AL PACINO?! I didn't know he could even do this! I think my first exposure to Pacino was The Devil's Advocate and he's been pretty over the top in most things I've seen but in this he's so quiet and understated but you know there's alot beneath the surface. Brando is great. Would have liked subtitles though for him, honestly.

I think what I most appreciated though was the way it handles the audience. These days it seems like most movies can't do anything without trying to explain everything. We get inundated with exposition but not here. Things are laid out beautifully so that just by paying attention you pick up on what's going on and who people are.

There are a LOT of people though. With a lot of very Italian names. Had a bit of trouble keeping the rooster straight in my head. Fortunately this is one I'd definitely enjoy revisiting, which I can only imagine to be a deeply rewarding experience because it feels like there are a lot of layers here to explore and new things to hone in on.

It's a great movie. I just don't think any movie could really live up to the massive hype machine of The Godfather. I can only imagine my estimation of it increasing though with future viewing.

title: Finally the classic Mob Trilogy has arrived on DVD
description:
This is one of the most eagerly anticipated film series ever (along with Alien Saga, Die Hard etc) and marking Paramount´s greatest DVD effort yet. The First Godfather film involves the epic story of The Corleone Family, where each member is supurbly acted by a superb cast, top notch from the principle parts to the smaller ones. As head of the Corleone family Don Vito (outstanding Marlon Brando) is ambushed and shot and put to hospital, his sons, Michael youngest of them, unwilling heir of the family top spot (Al Pacino), hot head oldest brother Sonny (James Caan), and quiet middle brother Fredo (John Cazale) must take control over the family business while he is gone, and rely on Don Vito´s new consigliere Tom Hagen´s (the always great Robert Duvall) and end the conspiracy bestowed upon them. The story is perfectly vowen, marvelously executed violence scenes. It´s a movie that must be seen by any movie fan, this is as perfect as movies become. No different is The Godfather Part II, even possibly better than the first one, this movie however is longer and is split up as two stories intercutting in parts, one showing the life and rise of younger Vito Corleone (Robert DeNiro) and the other his son Michael tightening his grip on his family business, alienating his wife kay (Diane Keaton) in the 1950´s. The third and weaker of the Godfather movies but not all that bad, involves middle-aged Michael legititimizing his earlier crime business, while trying to win back his ex wife Kay. However new enemies within and outside the family ultimatelky corrupts the business and resulting in his retirement, as his son in law Vincent (Andy Garcia) ascend as the new Don, with the help of Michael´s hardened sister Connie (Talia Shire). The weakest performances come from George Hamilton as Michael´s new lawyer B.J. and Coppola´s own daughter Sofia as Vincent´s cousin and lover, which isn´t to say Sofia is all bad but doesn´t really have the experience for this pivotal role. The Video transfers aren´t all that top notch showing some grain but never-the-less show flawless detail and color resolution, the audio transfers are deliverd in powerful detail and gives the subwoofer a run for its money. The special features are all good and interests showing good value, Coppola´s commentaries on all three movies is as informative and interesting as they come, commenting on the cast behind the scenes facts, the how´s and why´s, his feeling about the third movie´s pointlessness. The facts are all here, the features as great as can be expected from a highclass trilogy such as this.

title: perfect
description:
"The Godfather" is a masterpiece. After a long time of waiting I was able to see this acclaimed film, and I must say that the high ratings I noticed are absolutely not wrong. In this film everything is perfect: the actors are the best point in favor of the film, Marlon Brando among all, incredible. Also Al Pacino, James Caan and everyone else have been excellent in their roles. The characters are iconic, everyone! Starting from Don Vito Corleone, one of the characters I love most in the history of cinema (all due especially from the huge performance of Brando), to Michael Corleone, also excellent. The direction of Coppola is incredible as well as the photography, the film also for this factor has always entertained me while lasting 3 hours, which are not heavy. This last factor, that of rhythm, is mainly due to the excellent plot and the excellent writing made and thought. For the '70s, the quality of the music, like photography, vocal audio and special effects are fantastic. During the movie there is a lot of suspense, especially in the movie end, which is excellent. I loved very much the fact that they wanted to insert strong and touching scenes not limited even to the level of cruelty and topics treated, that are very interesting. The setting is perfect for the genre and the costumes as well. I can't wait to complete the trilogy, I expect a lot after this movie.

. Rating: 9.9/10.
